Schools awarded specialist status receive extra government funding, and are allowed to select up to 10% of their intake by aptitude, which has promoted comprehensive campaigners to level charges that they are operating "selection by the back door". Although they offer the mainstream curriculum, they also provide specialist teaching in a range of subjects. Until now the specialisms have been confined to sport, arts and media, technology and music. But yesterday, following extensive lobbying by teacher unions, the government announced the addition of three new categories - engineering, science and business and enterprise. All maintained secondary schools are eligible to apply, except in some areas where there already are large numbers of specialist schools. They must raise £50,000 sponsorship from the private sector, prepare four-year development plans with measurable targets in teaching and learning in the specialist subject area, and make provision to involve other schools and the wider community. In return, successful applicants receive £100,000 capital grant and £123 per pupil per year (for the first 1,000 pupils), initially for four years. The Department for Education and Employment said yesterday that it expected the first engineering, science and business and enterprise colleges to start operating in September 2002. Specialist schools are popular and over-subscribed, not least because of mounting evidence that they out-perform their comprehensive rivals. Research by David Jesson of York University last year revealed that non-selective specialist schools had 52% of their pupils achieving five good GCSE passes at grades A to C, compared with 41% for all other state schools. Between 1994 and 1999, non-selective specialist schools improved their pass rate by 21% while other state schools went up by only 12%, although. some parents' organisations have expressed concerns about the pressure on youngsters to specialise too young. David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, warned: "This vision cannot be delivered if an overhaul of the comprehensive system leads to a widening gap between the advantaged and the disadvantaged. Expanding specialist schools to embrace engineering, science and business and enterprise can only be achieved if the government invests a great deal more money in recruiting the teachers crucial to the delivery of such a radical approach." Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers said: "The prime minister ignores reality. He continues to set targets without considering whether they are achievable in individual schools against a background of severe teacher shortages.'' The education secretary, David Blunkett, is expected to announce details of a co-ordinated package of measures to "recruit and retain" teachers this weekend. On Monday he and Mr Blair will launch a green paper fleshing out further details of a 10-year education plan.

webTitle: NHS apologises after selling skin for chemical weapons research

fields.headline: NHS apologises after selling skin for chemical weapons research
fields.trailText: An NHS trust has apologised after it admitted selling surplus skin for chemical weapons research without explaining to patients what it would be used for.
fields.body:
An NHS trust has apologised after it admitted selling surplus skin for chemical weapons research without explaining to patients what it would be used for.

Salisbury health care trust said that, until a fortnight ago, it sold surplus skin to the Defence Evaluation and Research Agency (DERA) at Porton Down for an annual fee of £17,000 a year.

The admission will refuel the ethical debate over the appropriate use of human tissues and the extent to which patients' informed consent should be required for medical research purposes. The trust only stopped the practice in the wake of last month's Alder Hey children's hospital organs storage scandal.

The skin, which was removed during breast and abdominal surgery at Salisbury district hospital, was used in "chemical absorption studies" as well as investigations of drug delivery and barrier cream formulation, the trust said.

Patients were required to sign a consent form but this did not fully explain the purpose of the research, the trust admitted.

A statement from the trust said: "The trust now recognises that this did not inform patients of the specific use of the skin and that some individuals may not have wished for the skin to be used by DERA and offers its sincere apologies for this."

The chemical and biological warfare research centre at Porton Down, Wiltshire, carried out the world's longest-running programme of chemical warfare experiments on humans between 1940 and 1989.

The consent form that patients were required to sign, which was updated in 1996, read: "I agree/ disagree to any tissue that is removed in the normal course of the operation being used for medical research."

The trust's statement said: "The trust thought it appropriate for patients' consent to be sought for the use of surplus skin in all forms of medical research through a consent form." It went on: "The trust made a decision to stop providing skin to DERA two weeks ago in the light of issues raised in the Alder Hey report.

"The Department of Health is currently considering the issue of guidance on the appropriate use of human tissue and on gaining informed consent from patients and relatives for its use for medical purposes."

A spokesman for the trust added: "We are stopping the process until we get further guidance from the Department of Health."

The trust said the money it received from DERA went back into patient care.

As well being sold to DERA, skin was also used within the trust to investigate wound healing and the preparation of artificial skin, as well as the treatment of burn wounds.

A Ministry of Defence spokeswoman, speaking on behalf of DERA, confirmed the skin was used in chemical warfare tests. She said the tests were to discover how the skin absorbs chemicals that might be used to attack British servicemen and women.

She added that chemical tests on the skin were also done for the benefit of civilians, for example, to see how the skin would be effected by a spillage of corrosive chemicals used in the home and at work.

webTitle: Hospitals redesign needed if climate crisis continues

fields.headline: Hospitals redesign needed if climate crisis continues
fields.trailText: NHS hospitals may need to be redesigned to cope with the health risks posed by major climate change, a leading environmental scientist has warned.
fields.body:
NHS hospitals may need to be redesigned to cope with the health risks posed by major climate change, a leading environmental scientist has warned.

Professor Graham Bentham of the centre for environmental risk at the University of East Anglia said hospitals and nursing homes would need cooling systems to protect elderly and vulnerable patients from the effects of heatwaves.

His comments came after the publication of a government report on the impact of climate change. The Health Effects of Climate Change warned thousands could die over the next 50 years as a result of frequent heatwaves and severe flooding. It also warned that cases of tropical diseases, such as malaria, could rise.

Prof Bentham predicted that climate change would lead to a rise in mental health problems. "If your home is devastated by flood water that is clearly going to seriously disrupt your life. Studies from overseas suggest it can cause psychological problems similar to post-traumatic stress disorder."

However, the professor said outbreaks of malaria were unlikely in the UK. "There was a type of malaria that affected this country in the 19th century but we managed to get on top of it even with a poor public health infrastructure. So it's unlikely to seriously affect us now," he said.

Dr Geof Rayner, chairman of the UK public health association, called for better education about the health risks of travelling abroad, particularly as more people were visiting to tropical countries.

"The globalisation of travel has led to the old barriers against disease breaking down. We've seen large rises in cases of tuberculosis in this country in recent years as a result of that.

"Three years ago, it was predicted that there would be a further 50 to 80 million cases of malaria worldwide. People need to realise that immunisation against malaria is not 100% effective.

"The cult of brown skin among white people also needs to end," he said.

Frances MacGuire, climate policy officer at the pressure group Friends of the Earth, said: "This report shows thousands of British people will die early from skin cancer, in heatwaves and during extreme weather events caused by man-made climate change.

"This will place an added burden on our already over-stretched health service.

"The government must deliver on its promise to cut carbon dioxide - the most important greenhouse gas - by 20% at home but it must also work internationally to salvage the climate talks that collapsed so dramatically last November."

webTitle: The Bay of Angels by Anita Brookner

fields.headline: The Bay of Angels by Anita Brookner
fields.standfirst:
(Viking £16.99
Condensed in the style of the original
Buy it at a discount from BOL
fields.trailText: More intense feelings valiantly repressed and cruel suffering nobly borne as another Brookner heroine lies back and thinks of Chelsea and Nice
fields.body:
As a child I was minded to think that, as in fairy tales, hardships brought their reward, so I was content to accept my lot with passivity. My mother and I lived in distressed gentility in Edith Grove; my father had died when I was small, a source of puzzlement to me and regret to my mother, and we coexisted in proximity, if not closeness, as neither presumed to burden the other with the intensity of our profound emotions.

I was relieved when my mother met Simon. He was much older and held the assumptions of his generation, but he was kind and we could not have asked for more. He bought me a small flat, which gave me a modicum of independence, and my mother and he moved to his home in Nice.

Away from the confinement of my mother, I entered a relationship with Adam, a far freer spirit than that to which I was accustomed. I might have been saddened, if not jealous, at his affairs with other women had I been otherwise minded, but I grew to value the times he chose to share with me.

Adam was not to SimonÍs tastes; our visit to Nice was far from a success. I used to hear Simon listening at our door to see if Adam had crept into my bed, which, being of a hotter temperament, he invariably had. It was with a sense of relief on all sides that we returned to London, and my relationship with my mother reverted to a formal normality.

It was with some shock that I heard Simon had fallen and died. My mother had been so overcome that she had been taken to hospital for a sleep cure. I moved to Nice, where it was with some annoyance that I found Simon had been financially incautious and I was forced into more straightened circumstances.

My conversations with Dr Balbi led me to believe my mother was unlikely to recover, but I was obliged to continue my visits. Dr Balbi encouraged me to think he desired me but, despite 10 pages of intense introspection and repressed sexual longing followed by a raised eyebrow, he failed to make an advance.

Some months later I observed the formalities of my motherÍs death and found myself financially comfortable once more. Dr Balbi - dear Antoine - now spent the occasional night with me. We were not more open about our relationship for fear of upsetting his sister. One day I might even contemplate a life without him. How bold I have become.

And if you really are pressed, the digested read, digested: More intense feelings valiantly repressed and cruel suffering nobly borne as another Brookner heroine lies back and thinks of Chelsea and Nice

fields.headline: Sky shares slip after downgrading by analysts
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: BSkyB's shares have slumped to their lowest point this year after analysts said its subscriber figures were not good enough. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Shares in BSkyB have slumped to their lowest point this year after the Merrill Lynch media team said its subscriber figures were not good enough.

Influential analyst Neil Blackley, whose warnings on ITV advertising revenues caused Granada's shares to crash last September, said the digital subscription total of 4.08m was slightly below estimates.

Merrill Lynch downgraded BSkyB's shares to "neutral" from "accumulate" and chopped £70m from the group's 2002 pre-tax profit estimate.

BSkyB fell 6.56%, or 68p, to 969p on the news.

BSkyB revealed a £45m increase in interactive TV costs and a loss of £46m from its stake in KirchPayTV when it announced its first-half results last Wednesday.

Despite posting a 50% rise in losses to £112m, many analysts gave the thumbs-up to the results.

West LB Panmure kept its "buy" recommendation, saying that the interactive Open and KirchPayTV provided long-term opportunities.

Mathew Horsman at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite was also supportive, maintaining his "buy" assessment and saying the results were "bang in line with expectations."

webTitle: Ali G leak sparks BBC witch hunt

fields.headline: Ali G leak sparks BBC witch hunt
fields.trailText: 4.45pm: BBC bosses are seeking the culprit behind the leaked transcript of an interview featuring Ali G and the Beckhams, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
BBC bosses have begun a witch hunt to find the culprit behind the leaked transcript of a Comic Relief interview featuring Ali G and Posh and the Beckhams.

A full transcript of the unedited interview found its way onto emails around the country, causing uproar at the BBC.

The transcript begun appearing on the internet today and the Daily Mail has also published extracts.

FHM was the first to obtain a leak and its website was among several to have posted the full script today.

MediaGuardian.co.uk also ran the transcript before being ordered to pull it down by BBC lawyers.

But the BBC does not believe an insider is to blame.

"Someone who watched the interview being filmed must have smuggled in a tape recorder," said the spokeswoman.

"We don't produce transcripts until after a show is edited."

The no-holds-barred interview has Ali G ask a shocked David Beckham if he would rather be married to Baby Spice.

But it's Sporty Spice who comes in for the most abuse.

At one point Ali G asks Beckham: "You is the best at football, ya know.

"So you get Posh. So does Sporty Spice go out with someone from Scunthorpe United?"

Later, he asks Posh whether she thought she ought to put on some weight, adding that of course she shouldn't go as far as Sporty Spice.

But many of the more offensive - and funny - sections will never reach our screens.

The BBC is planning to edit out references to Sporty Spice, among others.

And it has set its lawyers on to anyone who tries to publish the leaked transcript.

"We're incredibly unhappy about all this," said a BBC spokeswoman.

"Comic Relief was planning to publish bits of the show in the run-up to the broadcast to attract people to its website, which would have brought in extra income to the charity.

"People seeing it beforehand ruins that."

fields.headline: BSE report highlights food fears
fields.standfirst:
Special report: BSE crisis
Comment: beefing about freedom of information
fields.trailText: Public confidence in food safety has plummeted in the wake of the BSE scandal and only drastic steps can restore it, the government admitted today.
fields.body:
Public confidence in food safety has plummeted in the wake of the BSE scandal and only drastic steps can restore it, the government admitted today.

In its long-awaited interim response to Lord Phillip's critical BSE report published last year, it pledged ministers will be more open in handling health scares.

The agriculture minister, Nick Brown, outlined far-reaching measures to keep people better informed about future crises.

"There has been a significant loss of public confidence in the arrangements for handling food safety and standards, due in large part to the events surrounding BSE," said the response, which is due to be presented to parliament today.

"The government recognises that its efforts to build and sustain trust through openness cannot succeed unless it is fully prepared to acknowledge uncertainty in its assessments of risk."

Lord Phillip's 16-volume report highlighted a desire to avoid an unjustified health scare, poor departmental communication and bureaucratic delays in responding to scientific warnings about BSE risks.

Published last October, it criticised ministers and civil servants for failing to be open about the possibility of BSE spreading to humans.

Today's 102-page response sets out plans to ensure lessons are learnt from the scandals and to rebuild faith in food safety.

It said: "The whole approach and behaviour of departments and individuals will need to change to ensure that the lessons identified by the inquiry are properly absorbed and implemented."

It continued: "A balance needs to be struck between intervening too much, forgoing benefits and stifling people's freedom of action, and failing to help protect them sufficiently from actual or potential hazards."

But the government added that it had already taken steps to improve the situation, such as setting up the food standards agency in April 2000 and improving arrangements for other departments to communicate with the public.

More than 80 people have died from vCJD, the human form of mad cow disease, and the government has agreed interim compensation for families.

Today's response said BSE was "a national tragedy", adding that it has had "damaging and far reaching effects."

It focused on a number of key areas for improvement, including science and governments, and examines the way ministers obtain scientific advice and how it is used in taking policy decisions.

The report also looks at openness and what the government is doing "to generate greater public trust in its handling of food safety and related issues."

The report added: "The government does not believe there any serious gaps in its powers to take proportionate emergency action against hazards to human or animal health."

But it added that, in general, the response recognises "the need for government departments to change the way they operate, with the emphasis in securing positive changes in behaviour rather than policy, structure or machinery."

The Consumers' Association said the EU must also learn the lessons from the Phillips inquiry. The consumer watchdog said there were still loopholes in current EU control measures that needed to be addressed.

fields.headline: Mussorgsky: Pictures at an Exhibition
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Mussorgsky's Pictures at an Exhibition.
fields.body:
Mussorgsky's biggest, most radical piano work is so much better known in Ravel's bespangled orchestration that the raw, muscular intensity of the original is sometimes forgotten. It is a tribute to the composer's artist friend Hartmann, who died in 1873, and takes the form of a series of impressions of his paintings. These are interspersed with the ever-developing Promenade refrain. which represents Mussorgsky walking from one canvas to the next.

The colours that are implicit in the piano writing are made explicit in Ravel's 1922 scoring, full of the deftest instrumental touches. Anyone who wants both versions of Pictures side by side could opt for either for André Previn and the Vienna Philhamonic, coupled with Alfred Brendel in the piano work (Philips), or Vladimir Ashkenazy both as conductor with the Philharmonia, and as pianist (Decca). But there are more incisive accounts of the two to be found separately. In terms of sheer excitement and the brilliance of the piano playing, one performance stands head and shoulders above the others - Sviatoslav Richter's, from a recital in Sofia in 1958 (Philips). The sense of occasion and the virtuosity outstrip even Vladimir Horowitz's equally revered 1951 version (RCA), but the sound is thin, and the audience sound as if they were all in the terminal stages of pneumonia.

The best modern studio recording is Mikhail Pletnev's: it is full of magical colour and articulation, even if, like Horowitz, Pletnev occasionally adds his own embellishments to the score. Among the orchestral versions there is far more choice, from Arturo Toscanini's strait-laced performance with the NBC Symphony (RCA), right up to Giuseppe Sinopoli's with the New York Philharmonic (DG), which teases out every detail of Ravel's scoring.

Herbert von Karajan's 1960s recording (DG) has a dramatic tension that never slackens, while Claudio Abbado's (DG) is just as sumptuous, and perfectly refined. Abbado just gets the nod because of his enterprising couplings - all Mussorgsky, including Night on Bare Mountain, as well as some rare choral fragments.

Key Recordings: piano version, Pletnev (Virgin); Ravel orchestration, Abbado (DG)

Anyone who wants both versions of Pictures side by side could opt for either for André Previn and the Vienna Philhamonic, coupled with Alfred Brendel in the piano work (Philips), or Vladimir Ashkenazy both as conductor with the Philharmonia, and as pianist (Decca). But there are more incisive accounts of the two to be found separately. In terms of sheer excitement and the brilliance of the piano playing, one performance stands head and shoulders above the others - Sviatoslav Richter's, from a recital in Sofia in 1958 (Philips). The sense of occasion and the virtuosity outstrip even Vladimir Horowitz's equally revered 1951 version (RCA), but the sound is thin, and the audience sound as if they were all in the terminal stages of pneumonia. The best modern studio recording is Mikhail Pletnev's: it is full of magical colour and articulation, even if, like Horowitz, Pletnev occasionally adds his own embellishments to the score. Among the orchestral versions there is far more choice, from Arturo Toscanini's strait-laced performance with the NBC Symphony (RCA), right up to Giuseppe Sinopoli's with the New York Philharmonic (DG), which teases out every detail of Ravel's scoring. Herbert von Karajan's 1960s recording (DG) has a dramatic tension that never slackens, while Claudio Abbado's (DG) is just as sumptuous, and perfectly refined. Abbado just gets the nod because of his enterprising couplings - all Mussorgsky, including Night on Bare Mountain, as well as some rare choral fragments. Key Recordings: piano version, Pletnev (Virgin); Ravel orchestration, Abbado (DG)

webTitle: All 17 MoD quangos fail to find minority recruits

fields.headline: All 17 MoD quangos fail to find minority recruits
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence is the only major government department that has failed to recruit a single ethnic minority person to its 17 quangos.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence is the only major government department that has failed to recruit a single ethnic minority person to its 17 quangos.

The MoD's performance - published last month in the Cabinet Office's annual review of more than 1,000 quangos - is the second time in a year it has failed to meet ethnic appointment targets. Last year all three armed forces were unable to meet the 3% recruitment target set for 1999-2000.

A plan of action, drawn up by the MoD in 1999, promised to approach the commission for racial equality to raise the representation of ethnic minorities on the boards of its quangos to 1.5% by next year. Since the total of appointments stands at 123, this could almost be achieved with the addition of one person from an ethnic minority. It aims to reach 3% by 2004.

The quangos - or non-departmental public bodies - include the boards of six museums as well as a number of advisory committees with a total annual expenditure of £23.4m. Led by the Cabinet Office's central secretariat, the government has a long-term aim of having quango boards reflect the 5.7% from ethnic minorities in the economically active population.

Across the whole of government, the figure stands at 4.4% or 1,353 of the 29,000 board members. The other departments that have no members from ethnic minorities on their quangos are the central office of information and the royal mint.

Of big departments which are not even close to the target, the Ministry of Agricuture, Fisheries and Food has five out of 1,322 appointees from ethnic minorities, or 0.4%, and the lord chancellor's department has 101 out of 4,828 or 2.1%. The highest number is in the Department of Health with 397 out of 4,205 (9.4%).

webTitle: Panic, Ask, and What Difference Does It Make?

fields.headline: Panic, Ask, and What Difference Does It Make?
fields.trailText: DO NOT PASS PORT, DO NOT COLLECT £200 (PER MINUTE)
fields.body:
DO NOT PASS PORT, DO NOT COLLECT £200 (PER MINUTE)

You can never have too many passports. The Fiver, for example, would still be working in a Bolivian sweatshop were it not for the "existence" of our shadowy grandfather (and sometime launderette owner) Mr Papodopolous. But for some reason the police have got a bee in their bonnet about such useful and helpful documents, and are investigating the 80 players in Britain with dual nationality to see whether they are entitled to EU passports. Not only that, the National Criminal Intelligence Service is also to investigate whether any UK clubs have been involved in helping players obtain bogus papers. Haven't they got anything better to do?

The whole passports issue has been a biggie in Europe ever since Lazio's Argentinian midfielder (and passport owner) Juan Sebastian Veron was hauled before the beak on civil charges of fraud. Soon after, Inter's Uruguayan international midfielder Alvaro Recoba was found to be an illegal immigrant and got yanked out of Italy by his foreign ear. When the scandal spread to France and Spain, it was not going to be long before British folk started to get the fear. And sure enough, with the status of Premiership players such as Newcastle's Nobby Solano and Arsenal's Tomas Danilevicius being questioned, knees are beginning to publicly rattle.

"There is no room for complacency!" panicked Kate Hoey, sports minister and chum of Kuddly Ken Bates, today. "Clearly, there is a problem in other countries in Europe - and we need to be vigilant!" Almost before she had finished, players' chief Gordon Taylor could be heard wailing like a small child having its head kicked in by a banshee. Calling on the FA to clobber clubs knowingly fielding illegible players, he yaroo-ed: "The FA's disciplinary sanctions are there, and if someone has knowingly broken their rules they can be docked points or fined! If there is a breach of a rule there is going to be consideration for penalties to make sure it does not happen again!!!"

Luckily, the chief executive of Uefa, Gerhard "Corporal Jones" Aigner was soon on hand to calm everyone down. "Serious problem! Serious problem!" he screamed over and over again, until someone slapped him round the face with a wet visa.

RAVE ON

Rant! Rave! Rant! Rant! Rave! Hello, Anne Widdefiver here. And seeing as I'm not sending bogus asylum seekers back to Italy where they belong, I can concentrate my ire on the indiscipline in the FA ranks. Exterminate! Exterminate! Yesterday the FA imposed only a one-match ban on Patrick Vieira - even though their rules clearly state violent conduct should carry a three-game suspension. So what have these soaking-wet liberals got to say for themselves? I'm outside the new FA building in Soho Square to find out.

Here comes Barry Bright, chairman of the FA's disciplinary committee, and he's spouting some flab about how the FA is determined to enforce its disciplinary code. "We recognise our responsibilities and are fully supportive of the system and the guideline punishments as laid down," he insisted. "We will enforce them fully." Another example of all talk and no delivery! What about Mr Vieira yesterday, I ask you? Bray!

Let's see if FA chief Adam Crozier is any more convincing. "From the outset consistency has been our aim when administering disciplinary penalties. That remains the objective. Everyone in the game has agreed to this." Ah, discipline, that's more like it! Now, come on Mr Crozier, let's hear some talk about locking everybody up! "Clubs and players need to understand what actions they will face if serious offences are committed," he continues. "We must now ensure that the process is enforced rigidly." Exactly! And the more we put away the better!

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"It was Terry Venables who inspired me to go into coaching and management. It's all his fault! He was the one who planted the seeds in my mind about going down that route" - Fed up of blaming his players, John Gregory turns his fire on other managers instead.

TIC-TAC D'OH

Why is the Fiver dressed in a ridiculous tartan cape and a deerstalker? Why have we grown a pair of huge sideburns? And why are we waving our hands in the air like a lunatic, pausing only to puncture the air with tedious rants? Because, like TV's John McCririck, we're betting mad! For example, we've just placed our month's wages on Middlesbrough being relegated this season. The reason? Because Terry Venables has just won the manager-of-the-month award for January, that's the reason.

As we all know, once this prestigious award has been bestowed on the recipient, their fortunes take a comical turn for the worse. (This is known as "doing a Burley" in some parts of East Anglia.) It's scant reward for Venables, who presided over an 11-game unbeaten run that had the dual purpose of (a) spiriting the Teesside club away from the relegation zone and (b) making official boss Bryan Robson look totally hopeless indeed. The spell, which included wins against Chelsea and Liverpool, has been attributed to hard work, defensive resilience and finally getting Alen Boksic out of bed.

Ever the professional, Tel is well aware that they're not out of the woods yet. "I've said right the way along that it will go right to the end," he gravely intoned after last Saturday's 1-1 draw with Manchester City. "There are a lot of fixtures to be played, tough ones - and it's not a fairy story," he continued, amazingly without recourse to cockney banter. Indeed, some observers today suggested that Tel may still need to win another manager-of-the-month award if Boro are to stay in the top flight next season. Although that's surely the last thing he needs.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Newcastle are about to offer Leeds £10m for former Sunderland striker Michael Bridges, claims Planet Football.

Bolton are hoping to sign Coventry duo Colin Hendry and John Aloisi.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Robbie Keane has won the Carling player-of-the-month award for January.

Sergei Rebrov has pledged his future to Spurs. "Tottenham are my team now and I am not leaving them," he said. "For me the English league is the best in the world. I have never had thoughts of leaving and I have no regrets about coming to England."

Liverpool are set to offer Sander Westerveld a new contract until July 2005.

Taribo West has committed himself to Derby County until the end of the season.

Fulham have denied reports that they are planning to share Millwall's New Den next season.

Wimbledon chairman Bjorn Gjelsten has stepped down to devote more time to his business interests. Vice-chairman Charles Koppel will take over.

Birmingham have signed Carl Tiler from Charlton and Peter Atherton from Bradford City on loan.

Hibernian have offered Toulouse striker Marc Libbra a three-month loan deal.

The following games have been postponed due to frozen pitches: Dundee v Hearts, East Fife v Hamilton, Brechin v East Stirling and Ross County v Clyde.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: World Football (2.50am) "Allo mate, Roger here from Roger's Removals. I've just come round to clear out all the topics of conversation that are never used on Hold The Back Page."

Sky Sports 1: Futbol Mundial (5pm) [hump, lug, shift]

webTitle: Global warming 'will kill thousands' in UK

fields.headline: Global warming 'will kill thousands' in UK
fields.standfirst: Main points of the report
fields.trailText:
Climate change in Britain will lead to explosion in skin cancer, heatwaves and food poisoning, says government report.
Main points of the report
Climate change will hit NHS
Special report: global warming
SocietyGuardian
fields.body:
Climate changes could result in thousands of lives being lost each year, according to a government report out today.

It says climate change in Britain over the next 50 years could lead to an extra 5,000 deaths from skin cancer each year; 3,000 extra deaths annually in heatwaves; and an extra 10,000 cases of food poisoning each year.

The report, being launched by the government's chief medical officer, Professor Liam Donaldson, is intended to assist with long-term planning on climate change and health.

The study, by the Expert Group on Climate Change and Health, also says that in 50 years' time malaria could take hold in some parts of Britain.

However, the warmer climate could reduce the number of winter deaths among the elderly by an estimated 20,000 each year.

It concludes that in general, the NHS should cope well with the impact of climate change given adequate planning.

Early preventative action could mitigate many of the possible health consequences, it says.

fields.headline: Dressed to frill
fields.standfirst: Saucy underwear has come out of the closet thanks to Agent Provocateur. Hadley Freeman meets Joe Corré and Serena Rees, who started the knicker revolution
fields.trailText: Saucy underwear has come out of the closet thanks to Agent Provocateur. Hadley Freeman meets Joe Corré and Serena Rees, who started the knicker revolution.
fields.body:
It was the bed that really stood out. There it was, four-postered, in the middle of the Connaught ballroom in London, while Madonna, Lady Victoria Hervey and assorted double-barrelled names teetered and tittered on their Gucci stilettos, celebrating the launch of Agent Provocateur's perfume in November.

On the bed, an improbably proportioned model writhed on the sheets. If this is how they launch a perfume, one suspects that Valentine's Day for Agent Provocateur's owners, Serena Rees and Joe Corré, will involve more than dinner for two at the local Italian and a box of Ferrero Rocher.

Rees and Corré are the acceptable and glamorous face of seduction in Britain. We meet at their second Agent Provocateur boutique in the depths of Knightsbridge. Rees, 32, beautiful with big, serious brown eyes, is wearing a Vivienne Westwood skirt and Prada high heels. Corré, 33, is the son of Malcolm McLaren and Westwood - the woman who made underwear-as-outerwear a fashion item long before Madonna donned her conical bra - although he briskly rejects the suggestion that his mother has influenced his line of work. He is best described by adjectives such as "dapper" and speaks in a laidback, devil-may-care voice that only the exceptionally well-heeled can afford.

Agent Provocateur is the stuff of high-fashion lingerie dreams: intricately lacy bras, delicate satin dressing-gowns. "The choice [for women's lingerie] used to be cheap and cheerful Soho sex shops or big department stores that were just boring," says Corré. "We knew there was a market for something else."

Since the first Agent Provocateur boutique opened in Soho in 1994, Britain's attitude to sexy lingerie has undoubtedly changed. The G-strings and lacy little things on sale in the high street now would have been outrageous a decade ago. What brought about this revolution? "We did," Corré replies bluntly. "And I'm not being arrogant here."

Corré remains coy about Agent Provocateur's turnover, or even how much its deal with Marks and Spencer, for whom it designs the Salon Rose line of lingerie, is worth (they deny that it was £1m). Nevertheless, Agent Provocateur has been a true success story. Its website received 23m hits in December; its two London locations are part of the Knowledge test cab drivers must learn. "Wanting to look and feel sexy, it's just a primal thing," states Corré.

Primal maybe, expensive certainly: a bra here can set you back £100, knickers up to £80 and a nightgown easily costs £200 (a crystal-studded whip, by the way, is £120). The day I went into the shop, all of the women musing their way through the racks were carrying either Prada or Dior bags, which pretty much sums up the clientele.

Corré and Rees met in 1992 ("Was it that long ago? Hmm, time flies!" he muses) and married last year. In the past nine years they have spent almost every day together. Do they ever find it claustrophobic to live and work together? They look surprised at the question, as though they had never even considered it.

They are glamorous, successful and happy but surprisingly defensive. Before the interview begins Rees asks sharply: "Can I just ask, what is the angle on this piece?"

They both keep their arms crossed and refuse to make eye-contact with anyone but each other for the first half hour. Just as their wariness is beginning to melt away, hackles are raised again at a reference to Ann Summers, the more outré, S&M-oriented chain. "Such comparisons are made by people who just don't have much experience in the subject," says Corré, bitingly.

Rees lays out on the table their recent campaign, which involved a series of publicity postcards of a woman's body, lovingly shot, clad in black bra, knickers and stockings. "I can't see that these are controversial," she says, looking at them tenderly. "I think they're beautiful."

They say their critics accuse Agent Provocateur of being a pornography shop (which, despite its over-the-top window displays, it is not) and therefore exploitative. "Germaine Greer and people like her say that you shouldn't wear things like this, that such adornments mean you're not part of the sisterhood," says Corré. "The whole point is letting women feel sexy and self-confident for themselves. Yes, it's nice for others to find you sexy, but it's about feeling good about yourself," Rees adds.

Anyway, back to Valentine's Day. Surely they must have some good gift suggestions? Unsurprisingly, their answer involves lingerie. "It's just so much more personal than that cliché of going out to dinner to a restaurant where all the other tables are set for two!" Rees cries, rolling her eyes.

But what about them, what will they be doing? "Ooh, I don't know yet," she smiles, looking towards her husband. "I don't even know where we'll be - maybe here, maybe LA. I've just found out that we might be shooting that day, actually." They both laugh. Alarming images of the two of them tracking grouse in Scotland pop up in my head. She elaborates: "Shooting a story that day." Thinking back to the advertising campaigns, even more distracting images come to mind.

There it was, four-postered, in the middle of the Connaught ballroom in London, while Madonna, Lady Victoria Hervey and assorted double-barrelled names teetered and tittered on their Gucci stilettos, celebrating the launch of Agent Provocateur's perfume in November. On the bed, an improbably proportioned model writhed on the sheets. If this is how they launch a perfume, one suspects that Valentine's Day for Agent Provocateur's owners, Serena Rees and Joe Corré, will involve more than dinner for two at the local Italian and a box of Ferrero Rocher. Rees and Corré are the acceptable and glamorous face of seduction in Britain. We meet at their second Agent Provocateur boutique in the depths of Knightsbridge. Rees, 32, beautiful with big, serious brown eyes, is wearing a Vivienne Westwood skirt and Prada high heels. Corré, 33, is the son of Malcolm McLaren and Westwood - the woman who made underwear-as-outerwear a fashion item long before Madonna donned her conical bra - although he briskly rejects the suggestion that his mother has influenced his line of work. He is best described by adjectives such as "dapper" and speaks in a laidback, devil-may-care voice that only the exceptionally well-heeled can afford. Agent Provocateur is the stuff of high-fashion lingerie dreams: intricately lacy bras, delicate satin dressing-gowns. "The choice [for women's lingerie] used to be cheap and cheerful Soho sex shops or big department stores that were just boring," says Corré. "We knew there was a market for something else." Since the first Agent Provocateur boutique opened in Soho in 1994, Britain's attitude to sexy lingerie has undoubtedly changed. The G-strings and lacy little things on sale in the high street now would have been outrageous a decade ago. What brought about this revolution? "We did," Corré replies bluntly. "And I'm not being arrogant here." Corré remains coy about Agent Provocateur's turnover, or even how much its deal with Marks and Spencer, for whom it designs the Salon Rose line of lingerie, is worth (they deny that it was £1m). Nevertheless, Agent Provocateur has been a true success story. Its website received 23m hits in December; its two London locations are part of the Knowledge test cab drivers must learn. "Wanting to look and feel sexy, it's just a primal thing," states Corré. Primal maybe, expensive certainly: a bra here can set you back £100, knickers up to £80 and a nightgown easily costs £200 (a crystal-studded whip, by the way, is £120). The day I went into the shop, all of the women musing their way through the racks were carrying either Prada or Dior bags, which pretty much sums up the clientele. Corré and Rees met in 1992 ("Was it that long ago? Hmm, time flies!" he muses) and married last year. In the past nine years they have spent almost every day together. Do they ever find it claustrophobic to live and work together? They look surprised at the question, as though they had never even considered it. They are glamorous, successful and happy but surprisingly defensive. Before the interview begins Rees asks sharply: "Can I just ask, what is the angle on this piece?" They both keep their arms crossed and refuse to make eye-contact with anyone but each other for the first half hour. Just as their wariness is beginning to melt away, hackles are raised again at a reference to Ann Summers, the more outré, S&M-oriented chain. "Such comparisons are made by people who just don't have much experience in the subject," says Corré, bitingly. Rees lays out on the table their recent campaign, which involved a series of publicity postcards of a woman's body, lovingly shot, clad in black bra, knickers and stockings. "I can't see that these are controversial," she says, looking at them tenderly. "I think they're beautiful." They say their critics accuse Agent Provocateur of being a pornography shop (which, despite its over-the-top window displays, it is not) and therefore exploitative. "Germaine Greer and people like her say that you shouldn't wear things like this, that such adornments mean you're not part of the sisterhood," says Corré. "The whole point is letting women feel sexy and self-confident for themselves. Yes, it's nice for others to find you sexy, but it's about feeling good about yourself," Rees adds. Anyway, back to Valentine's Day. Surely they must have some good gift suggestions? Unsurprisingly, their answer involves lingerie. "It's just so much more personal than that cliché of going out to dinner to a restaurant where all the other tables are set for two!" Rees cries, rolling her eyes. But what about them, what will they be doing? "Ooh, I don't know yet," she smiles, looking towards her husband. "I don't even know where we'll be - maybe here, maybe LA. I've just found out that we might be shooting that day, actually." They both laugh. Alarming images of the two of them tracking grouse in Scotland pop up in my head. She elaborates: "Shooting a story that day." Thinking back to the advertising campaigns, even more distracting images come to mind.

fields.headline: New Statesman round-up
fields.standfirst: Publication date: February 12
fields.trailText: February 12: What do Tony Benn, Prince William, Nigella Lawson, Sven Goran Eriksson and Eminem have in common? They're in the New Statesman fantasy cabinet.
fields.body:
Labour could lose a substantial number of seats in the general election if the Tories adopt the tactics of the Bush campaign, warns Steve Morgan, the man who handled the foreign media for Al Gore. Just as Bush overlooked the economy and aimed to win the moral heart of the country, the Tories may try to exploit the perception that there is a chasm between town and country, and traditional British values and multiculturalism.

The role played by Keith Vaz in the Hinduja passport affair is still unclear but his claim that, as a minister of Asian origin, he represents all Asians is a matter of record, writes John Lloyd. The view that an MP, or a minister, represents a constituency other than that of his parliamentary seat, or the brief he commands in parliament, is not known to British parliamentary practice.

The gap between France and Germany is widening but Britain should not be tempted to leap between them, argues David Lawday. The current conflict between Europe's chief architects is a major one, but they are turning to therapy, not to divorce. Both countries continue to recognise that there is no alternative to their joint leadership in Europe.

What do Tony Benn, Prince William, Nigella Lawson, Sven Goran Eriksson and Eminem have in common? They're all members of the New Statesman's fantasy cabinet. Send your nominations and a campaign slogan by February 19 for inclusion in the second round.

webTitle: Recruiting famous faces to support your cause

fields.headline: Recruiting famous faces to support your cause
fields.standfirst: How do you find a celebrity to come to your charity event? Toby Butler offers a beginners' guide
fields.trailText: For the big charities, with the resources and cachet to appeal to big names, finding celebrity backing is easy. Breakthrough Breast Cancer, for example, has recruited high-profile celebrities such as Geri Halliwell to raise awareness - and money.
fields.body:
For the big charities, with the resources and cachet to appeal to big names, finding celebrity backing is easy. Breakthrough Breast Cancer, for example, has recruited high-profile celebrities such as Geri Halliwell to raise awareness - and money.

Charity marketing is made easier when a widespread disease like cancer, which has touched many celebrities in some way, is combined with the perennial interest the media has in any picture story involving breasts. But for smaller charities it is not so easy, particularly if they are dealing with a difficult or unfashionable issue.

In its recent national campaign to recruit foster carers, the National Foster Care Association had trouble finding stars who were willing to promote foster care. "Fostering is a great cause, but we found it extremely hard to persuade celebrities with personal experience of the care system to help," says charity media consultant Henrietta Bond, who worked on the campaign. "Many feel stigmatised and do not want to be associated with foster care. It is a great pity, because they could be great role models," she says.

With persistence, however, sympathetic celebrities can be found. Ms Bond has worked on projects for Barnardo's with fashion designer Bruce Oldfield and footballer John Fashanu, both of whom have direct experience of the care system. "It can be very powerful when such celebrities get involved - people really respect the fact they understand the issue," she says. In deciding which celebrity to approach, most charities will try to find such a link between the star and the cause.

If a personality is not already a supporter of the charity, finding their contact details can be troublesome for the uninitiated. The agents of many well-known personalities can be found in the library, in the Spotlight directory, or if the celebrity has recently launched a product, the publisher or production company can be another useful lead.

According to Georgia Veats, press and public relations officer for deaf-blind charity Sense, the BBC has an artist index service that records the contact details of every star that appears on its channels. Strictly, the service is for BBC staff only, but charities will often get a sympathetic hearing if they call at a quiet time.

Once contact has been made, Ms Veats says the first proposal should be specific, clearly stating how the celebrity's involvement could make a difference and not require too much time. Handled carefully, a relationship can then be cultivated. Next steps might include sending more information about the charity's work and inviting them out to get a real feel for the cause: "Get them to see the service, away from the media," Ms Veats says. "I might take them to a family centre, where all the ground-breaking work is going on."

Having got an agreement from the celebrity to attend the press launch, visit or photo opportunity, the careful preparation begins. Press officers' recommendations include: sending a car to pick up the celebrity (it makes it harder for them to back out at the last minute, or turn up late); assigning a staff member to be with the personality throughout the event; and briefing them carefully about what exactly you want them to do.

Celebrity coordinator for Save the Children Wendy Bailey says time should be spent helping the celebrity understand the cause, but bombarding them with statistics can be confusing. "I often say: 'Forget the facts and figures. If you remember anything, speak from your heart - how do you feel about all the children in the world who are fighting as soldiers today?'"

All being well, after the press coverage, personal contact can be maintained and the celebrity will be willing to work with the charity again.

webTitle: Main points of the health effects of climate change report

fields.headline: Main points of the health effects of climate change report
fields.trailText: A new government report warns that climate change over the next 50 years could cause major death and destruction in Britain. This could overwhelm local NHS resources and cost local authorities billions of pounds.
fields.body:
A new government report warns that climate change over the next 50 years could cause major death and destruction in Britain. This could overwhelm local NHS resources and cost local authorities billions of pounds.

The main points of the report are:

&#149 Heat-related deaths are likely to increase to around 2,800 cases per year;

&#149 Cases of food poisoning are likely to rise by as much as 10,000 per year;

&#149 The effects of ozone damage are likely to increase, leading to several thousand extra deaths and a similar rise in hospital admissions;

&#149 Cases of skin cancer are likely to rise by 5,000 cases per year and cataracts by 2,000 cases per year;

&#149 Cold-related winter deaths are likely to decline significantly, by perhaps 20,000 cases per year;

&#149 The risk of major disasters caused by severe gales and flooding is likely to rise significantly;

&#149 The impact of air pollution on health is likely to decline, however;

&#149 Water-borne diseases may increase but the overall impact is likely to be small;

&#149 Insect-borne diseases may cause local problems but the overall impact is likely to be small;

&#149 Measures to reduce the rate of climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions could have beneficial effects on health.

fields.headline: Playing the fame game
fields.standfirst: Increasing numbers of celebrities are coming on board to help charities raise money and awareness. Toby Butler explains why
fields.trailText: Increasing numbers of celebrities are coming on board to help charities raise money and awareness. Toby Butler explains why
fields.body:
A character in Helen Fielding's novel Cause Celeb made the prediction: "Celebrities have been promoting causes since the first world war, but you watch; this will become huge. In five years time, no cause will be complete without an accompanying star to promote it."

The prophecy in the novel, which explored the bizarre situation that occurs when celebrities meet disaster zones, is fast becoming reality. Within two days of the earthquake shaking north eastern India, the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) had assembled a huge list of celebrities including Leslie Grantham, Pauline Collins and Mel from Big Brother to launch its appeal. As the first teams arrived in India to sift through the carnage, the press officers at the DEC, and at many of the fourteen charities it coordinates, were phoning agents all over the country to find household names to promote the appeal.

A stranger to our culture might wonder why Leslie Grantham's telephone is one of the first to ring when the world is confronted with a catastrophe. Amita Arya, DEC press officer, argues that charities have to take a pragmatic approach. "In an ideal world, the public will respond to a crisis from a humanitarian point of view," she says. "But people who are not familiar with a faraway country will respond more readily if the situation is explained by a familiar face that is trusted and seen every day on the television."

"We video-taped interviews with many of the celebrities, so that we can market them later to other media," she adds.

Ms Arya's language is revealing. Like it or not, charities working in the UK have to market disaster - preferably via television. Celebrities can get the message to the public at very little cost, in comparison to paying for an advertising campaign.

However, there is some expense. Many charities now have a full-time staff member devoted to work with celebrities. Two years ago, Save the Children recruited its first celebrity coordinator, Wendy Bailey, who brought a full contact book with her from working as a producer for the BBC. Her duties include finding, briefing and accompanying celebrities through the process of delivering the charity's message. Many large charities are following suit, creating a post that falls somewhere between public relations and fundraising.

Part of Helen Fielding's groundwork for her novel included research at Save the Children and Comic Relief. Ms Bailey says Cause Celeb was a perceptive lesson for charities: "In the novel, a celebrity visiting a refugee camp didn't have a clue why she was going out there. It is inappropriate to put someone in that situation without them having some understanding - or personal contact - with the cause."

Ms Bailey has recently worked with stars ranging from boy-band Westlife to TV chef Ainsley Harriot on Save the Children projects. At first glance, the association between the cause and the celebrity might seem tenuous, but Ms Bailey insists that celebrities are carefully chosen, either for their connection with children or their ability to inspire, on a project-by-project basis. "You don't always need a celebrity, but they come into their own when you need to engage with the public on an issue," she says.

According to Louise Tickle, a press officer who has worked with celebrities for Comic Relief and Community Service Volunteers, the call for celebrities from charities - and the public - is increasing. "The demand is just insatiable. Anything with a celebrity sells better," she says.

It seems we now need comedians and stars to deliver relief quickly. Is this another example of dumbing down? Are the press - or the public - really unable to grasp the tragedy of a flood or a famine, without the need of a celebrity chef to pull their heart strings? Ms Tickle doesn't think so. "It is easy to devalue it," she says. "When a celebrity is genuinely touched on film, the response to it is huge. If a celebrity can change people's perception towards a whole continent, because the public can relate better to them, then it is well worthwhile."

webTitle: Mentors a boost to black social services directors

fields.headline: Mentors a boost to black social services directors
fields.trailText: The Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS) has been taking steps to ensure that Daphne Obang, who was appointed to Bracknell Forest council this week, is not the only new black social services director for years to come.
fields.body:
The Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS) has been taking steps to ensure that Daphne Obang, who was appointed to Bracknell Forest council this week, is not the only new black social services director for years to come.

Horizons, a mentoring pilot scheme set up by the ADSS and the Improvement and Development Agency, is aimed at helping senior black staff progress to assistant director and director levels within social services departments.

The scheme was the brainchild of former ADSS president Roy Taylor and was officially launched last July, teaming up 15 "mentees" with 13 directors and two senior managers from the social services inspectorate (SSI) and the joint review team.

The pilot, which ended in December, involved residential courses, regular meetings between mentors and mentees and a full day of shadowing the mentor.

Neelam Bhardwaja took part in the scheme after being frustrated by her lack of promotion during her 17 years at Cambridgeshire council. Leaders of the pilot felt Ms Bhardwaja should have been higher up the career ladder than team manager. "I qualified in 1982 and reached manager post in 1987, but after that I was stuck on that level. I had applied for posts at the next grade up but wasn't successful and sometimes I wasn't convinced of the reasons given to me, which was usually that somebody else had a slight edge over me."

Since completing the course, Ms Bhardwaja has been appointed children's services manager at Peterborough council.

Mr Taylor said both the SSI and the Cabinet Office are currently looking at introducing similar mentoring projects. Efforts have been made to bring on board councillors who are hugely influential in the appointment of directors and assistant directors. "The training, experience and attitude that councillors bring to this is absolutely vital.

"There are parts of the country where it is really hard for black managers to make any headway. There are other areas where it seems possible to get to a certain level, say assistant director, and sometimes people don't want to go beyond that for various reasons."

Valerie Todd was appointed to Newham council 15 months ago and is one of five black assistant directors in the UK. She has benefited from having a black woman middle manager as an unofficial mentor in her first public sector job with Tower Hamlets council's housing department in 1986.

Before long, she was managing staff in a specialist team refurbishing housing stock and, by 1991, was heading a 200-strong team managing housing services. In 1994, she moved to Havering social services department, despite lacking a social work qualification. "Havering was looking for someone who had a good sense of running services and who had a business background," she says.

Having worked in other public sector fields, Todd doesn't believe social services departments are unique in having few black senior managers. "In social care, what makes it more unusual is that there are so many black social workers, team managers and service managers.

"The question is: 'What do we need to do to enable them to break through what barriers are there to progress to that level?' I don't know whether they apply and don't get appointed, or don't apply because they don't want the aggravation of senior management. It's an issue which needs to be explored."

Todd is encouraged by efforts being made by Newham council to look into the issue of the lack of black senior staff. "If the solution is to wait for more black managers to come in before more staff move up, then we'll end up with fewer black people entering the profession in the first place."

webTitle: Minimum standards needed to avoid council secrecy

fields.headline: Minimum standards needed to avoid council secrecy
fields.standfirst: The government must go further to reassure the public that guidelines governing 'key decisions' will not lead to greater council secrecy, says Andrew Ecclestone
fields.trailText: This week's House of Lords debate on access to council information marked a further stage in the government's slow and unwilling progress towards allaying fears that, unless central government sets clear minimum standards for openness, the new mayor and cabinet structures for councils will lead to greater secrecy.
fields.body:
This week's House of Lords debate on access to council information marked a further stage in the government's slow and unwilling progress towards allaying fears that, unless central government sets clear minimum standards for openness, the new mayor and cabinet structures for councils will lead to greater secrecy.

Some aspects of the government's new local authority openness regime are welcome. It requires, for instance, greater advance availability than at present of papers relating to a council's "key decisions" - those affecting more than two wards or involving significant expenditure. It also requires publication of the papers used by officers when taking key decisions, which the present regime does not. But there are several significant flaws in the regulations introducing this regime, and they require amendment.

The definition of a key decision is the pivotal issue under the regulations. Only when key decisions are discussed will executive meetings have to be open to the public, or will notice of forthcoming decisions have to appear on the authority's "forward plan".

However, the new regime leaves it entirely in the hands of local authorities themselves to decide the financial threshold for a key decision. This will lead to substantial arbitrary variations between authorities, with those less keen on scrutiny deliberately choosing high threshold figures. The decision to spend, say, £20,000 might be considered the threshold for a key decision by one authority, whereas it might be set at £100,000 by an adjacent authority - even in relation to provision of a similar service. Authorities may also choose high figures, not because they want to operate in secret, but because of an institutional interest in minimising the perceived extra "bureaucracy" surrounding key decisions.

The government, last night, finally appeared to concede that, as far as possible, the rights of the public in open decision taking was a matter for national standards, not local variation. Letting authorities choose the cash thresholds was not such a good idea after all. A consultation exercise will precede alterations to the guidance that "indicates" the thresholds above which a decision would become a key decision.

The second flawed test is whether a key decision is likely to have "significant" effects on people in "two or more wards". The critical failing of this test is that a decision significantly affecting people in one ward will not, therefore, be a key decision. Government openness guidance has itself highlighted the arbitrary nature of the regulation by saying that the reference to "two or more wards" can be ignored in rural areas where wards can be "very large". There, the authority "may wish to consider" specifying as a key decision anything which would have a "significant impact on one ward". The decision as to what is "significant" will largely be a subjective one.

If the decision-taker comes to the conclusion that a decision fails both the financial threshold and "significant effects" tests then it will merely be an "executive decision" - which requires no advance notice or availability of papers. It is going to be extremely difficult for the public, press or backbench councillor to challenge whether a decision is "key" or not before it is decided. In the unlikely event that they do somehow find out about it, the two routes open to them are political pressure or judicial review. In most cases, authorities will be able to operate without fear of prior challenge from anyone.

Finally, officers' claims for exempting papers for committee decisions from publication can, at present, be challenged by opposition councillors. However, under the regulations there is absolutely no mechanism for challenging the opinion that reports relating to the forthcoming decision contain exempt matter or the advice of a political adviser. This is carte blanche to suppress embarrassing information.

The effect of all this is that the public is unlikely to become aware of many decisions affecting them until after they have been made. Last night's alterations to the guidance, while desirable and helpful, will not suffice. The government's promise to review its new regime in June 2002 must result in substantial improvement of the regulations themselves.

fields.headline: Back to basics for Israel
fields.standfirst: The Israeli people wanted a return to traditional values when they voted for Sharon and, says Suzanne Goldenberg, they're likely to get it.
fields.trailText: The Israeli people wanted a return to traditional values when they voted for Sharon and, says Suzanne Goldenberg in Jerusalem, they're likely to get it.
fields.body:
Every victor in elections promises a new dawn and Israel's prime minister-elected, the arch-hawk, Ariel Sharon, was no exception. But does the Israeli voters' embrace of a man whose character was forged in the early years of a state struggling for survival against hostile neighbours, represent a bold leap into the future, or a slide backwards to the past?

Israeli media commentators today said the most signal element of Mr Sharon's huge election win was the unity he created in a society that is as sharply divided along religious and ethnic lines, as politics.

Mr Sharon took 63.6% of the Jewish vote, according to the final count published on Thursday. He had a commanding lead over the outgoing prime minister, Ehud Barak, in all the cities of Israel, bar Tel Aviv, and took 91.1% of votes cast by Jews living in West Bank settlements.

Aside from his slim lead in Tel Aviv, the only sector which stuck by Mr Barak was the kibbutzim, where he took 87.5% of the vote. The results are telling: the kibbutzim, or collective farms, which have been facing bankruptcy or re-organisation as Israel abandons its earlier agriculture-based economy, are the last bastions of his Labour movement. Tel Aviv, in contrast, is the last hold-out of the "new Israel" that Mr Barak, and the peace process, had symbolised.

Until the eruption of the Palestinian uprising last September, Israelis were beginning to debate whether they had arrived at a "post-Zionist" society. After the existential threats to Israel receded with the signing of peace treaties with Egypt and Jordan, and the start of negotiations with the Palestinians, and even Syria, Israel could now become like any other country.

The change was symbolised by the hi-tech boom, an industry that did away with borders, and eroded Israel's traditional feeling of isolation with business partnerships as far afield as Singapore and the US. At the same time, Israelis began to focus on internal problems that had for years been relegated to the backburner because of the security threat.

They began to chafe at the growing influence of the religious minority on the state, launching court actions for the rights of lesbian mothers, and for dispensing with the orthodox Jewish monopoly on marriage and divorce.

Environmental and consumer protection groups became more vocal, forcing Israel to think seriously about introducing a mass transit system, and about the pollution of its rivers. Shopping and clubbing and even the search for good restaurants were no longer deemed decadent activities. Last year, a researcher published a PhD on Israeli backpackers in India.

There was even concern within military circles that the years of peace were sapping the morale of Israel's citizen army, with adult males growing increasingly lax about fulfilling their reserve duty, and the hi-tech industry luring away intelligence and communications officers with lucrative job offers.

When he was elected in 1999, Mr Barak seemed to symbolise the shift. By the standards of Israeli politics, he was relatively young - aged 57 - when he came to power. He lived in one of the new bedroom communities near Tel Aviv, popular among professionals seeking a house with a garden, and though he emerged from the army, he was also trained as a systems analyst in the US.

He promised to modernise the economy, and he appointed an education minister who put a Palestinian nationalist poet on the state curriculum. But after the frightening spectacle of the Palestinian uprising, Israelis have turned their backs on all that Mr Barak represented. "Yes, it's true. I wanted him once," said Gvili Mantina, casting her vote in Jerusalem on Tuesday. "But look at what he did - he killed us. We can't go on this way."

At aged 73, Mr Sharon is most definitely part of the old Israel. He began fighting his country's wars in 1948, and he retains a narrow view of Israel as a nation perpetually under siege. On the campaign trail, he spoke of injecting "Zionist values" into the education, and into bolstering pride, as Israelis and as Jews.

"There are a lot of values that people have forgotten over the last few years, " Mr Sharon said recently, "love of country, love of Judaism, and unity." Even his choice of address is a throwback to the pioneer years of the state: he lives on a ranch in the southern Negev, answering the call of Israel's first prime minister to make the desert bloom.

Mr Sharon's main concession to modernity during the campaign was to moderate his hardline image. But even that may have to go, because the hard core nationalists, religious Jews, and ordinary Israelis who voted for him are looking for a strongman to restore their battered sense of security. In doing so, they are also turning their backs on the possibility of a broader vision of Israel.

Mr Sharon is fond of saying. "We have only one small country." Israelis, this week, agreed with him.

fields.headline: Desmond woos Hyland
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Richard Desmond is wooing David and Victoria Beckham's biggest Fleet Street enemy to spice up the Sunday Express's showbiz coverage, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Richard Desmond could be on the point of hiring David and Victoria Beckham's biggest Fleet Street enemy to spice up Sunday Express's showbusiness coverage.

He is trying to poach Sunday Mirror showbusiness columnist Ian Hyland as the new showbusiness editor of the Sunday Express.

Mr Hyland has carved out a niche as the scourge of Mr and Mrs Beckham, personal friends of Mr Desmond.

Victoria Beckham, in particular, has been the subject of a torrent of bitchy stories in the paper's gossip pages.

Mr Hyland was blacklisted by the Spice Girls after he claimed that Victoria wears a wig while on stage with the Spice Girls, that the Beckhams considered appearing in a Playboy shoot and that their house was infested with mould.

Insiders say a showbusiness desk involving Mr Hyland on a Desmond-run newspaper would make for an "interesting" political situation.

The move stresses the importance to Mr Desmond of showbusiness and celebrity news in the Express titles and may also be a sign that he is willing to be critical of celebrities despite the possible clash of interests with his sugary celebrity magazine, OK!

He wants to create greater "synergies" between his newspapers and the celebrity weekly OK! he owns.

fields.headline: Europe 'must step up armed forces'
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Britain's top military officer, General Sir Charles Guthrie, last night warned European allies that if they failed to modernise their armed forces, Nato would be "irrevocably damaged".
fields.body:
Britain's top military officer, General Sir Charles Guthrie, last night warned European allies that if they failed to modernise their armed forces, Nato would be "irrevocably damaged".

However, he dismissed claims by the Conservative leadership that a more assertive Europe would undermine Nato. Far from damaging the Atlantic alliance, a strong Europe would bolster it, he insisted.

"The key feature of the alliance is the engagement of North America in Europe", he said in a speech in Rome during his last days in the post of chief of the defence staff. But Sir Charles warned: "As Europeans we have to share the burden with the Americans, because if we don't do more, they will certainly do less - thereby weakening the alliance.

"Europe's weakness to provide for its own security interests is more damaging to the transatlantic relationship than a strong Europe, with the greater influence in decision-making that would go with a greater military contribution to the alliance."

The US, with just over a third of the population of all Nato countries, provided well over half its combined spending on defence, he pointed out. US defence expenditure per capita was about 125% higher than the Europeans'.

Europe's defence efforts were "nothing to be proud of", he said, noting that out of 2m service personnel, Europe had difficulty in providing just 2% of them for Kosovo. Commenting on promises by the European allies to increase their defence budgets, Sir Charles said: "I will believe that when it happens."

The EU's promise to be able to mount a joint rapid reaction force of up to 60,000 troops by 2003 would not come cheap, he said. "The governments of Europe will have to put more resources into defence if they want to use their forces to promote their policies more widely."

The Tory leadership, notably Iain Duncan-Smith, shadow defence secretary, has persistently attacked the EU's plans for a joint military force, seizing on concern expressed by the new Bush administration. The Tories claim that the project, pushed by Tony Blair, has been hijacked by France for its political ends.

Sir Charles turned the argument on its head, saying the US would do less in Europe, unless the European allies contributed more. He had been told as much by his American colleagues, he said.

However, he warned of the dangers of duplication: "More committees, more ambassadors and more generals will not give comfort to those on operations at sea, on land or in the air. Elegant institutions are to me less important than well-equipped forces, which are usable and trained together."

But he said the EU needed a small military staff "if it is take sensible decisions about security matters and particularly if it has to take responsibility for military objectives where Nato is not engaged".

webTitle: Ali G's Posh 'n' Becks interview leaks out

fields.headline: Ali G's Posh 'n' Becks interview leaks out
fields.trailText: 2pm: The BBC has been left red-faced after a transcript of Ali G's Comic Relief interview with Posh and Becks leaked out, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC had been hoping to keep Ali G's Comic Relief interview with Posh and Becks under wraps until the night of charity programming is broadcast next month.

But thanks to every office gossip's favourite communication tool, email, details of the decidedly one-sided barbfest began seeping out yesterday, much to the embarrassment of the BBC.

Mediatheguardian.com has obtained a full transcript of the interview, which will be broadcast on Comic Relief night on Friday March 16.

webTitle: Dispatch: the closure of the Brussels bird market

fields.headline: Sick as a parrot dealer
fields.standfirst: In an echo of the controversy over the feeding of pigeons in Trafalgar Square, the bird market on the capital's Grand Place is to be scrapped, reports Andrew Osborn
fields.trailText: In an echo of the controversy over the feeding of pigeons in Trafalgar Square, the bird market on the capital's Grand Place is to be scrapped, reports Andrew Osborn.
fields.body:
The raucous sound of twittering parrots and budgerigars has filled Brussels' gothic Grand Place every Sunday morning for the past hundred years. However, the city's bureaucrats are about to silence the birds once and for all.

The town's popular market, a favourite with tourists who love to stand and gawp at the exotic selection of birds from farflung corners of the globe on sale, has been ordered to shut up shop.

Brussels' minister for commerce and the environment, Philippe Decloux, is concerned that the birds are kept in cruel conditions and argues that many of them are diseased, posing a risk to public health.

The Royal Belgian League for the Protection of Birds also suspects that many of the birds are endangered species and believes that the market is little more than a cover for traffickers dealing in these protected species.

However, the decision to shut the market altogether rather than to force the 13 or so regular bird traders who gather there every week to clean up their act is certain to disappoint tourists and will anger aficionados.

The market, which is thought to have started hawking birds during the 19th century, sells exotic parrots from Africa and Asia as well as more common household pets such as canaries and budgerigars.

"It's not normal to shut down something which has existed for so long," says bird trader Arthur Mannaert. "It's because of the political parties and the bird protectors. They try to put everything in a bad light but I've been coming here for 34 years."

A few enlightened politicians have already raised the idea of reopening the market with much stricter controls on the birds sold but Mr Decloux, a member of the Green Party, is adamant that the closure is definitive... for now.

"We can't send veterinary officials to check up on the market every week," argues one of his officials when asked whether the market could be reopened. Even a casual onlooker could see that the birds were squeezed into cages which were blatantly too small for them and few would dispute that Mr Decloux is undoubtedly right to clamp down on some of the dodgy traders who hang out there.

However, many Bruxellois believe that the market is a regular fixture on the Brussels tourist trail and provides much needed colour in a town where it is too often lacking.

The traders, usually rotund moustachioed Belgians wearing flat caps, often gesticulate wildly and hold impassioned debates about their charges. Not much money ever seems to change hands but a curious crowd of onlookers is always present.

A decision to shut the market will also displease the Belgian tourist board which has ensured that it is cited in almost every guide to the city. Each of Brussels' 19 communes has its own market of some kind, often selling bric-a-brac or food. The Grand Place also hosts a regular flower market, another favourite with tourists which is not under threat - yet.
