fields.headline: NHS will suffer under thousands of deaths caused by climate change
fields.trailText: NHS resources "could be overwhelmed" by death and disease caused by major climate change over the next 50 years unless preventative action is taken now, a government report has warned today.
fields.body:
NHS resources "could be overwhelmed" by death and disease caused by major climate change over the next 50 years unless preventative action is taken now a government report warned today.

Local authorities also face huge costs to prevent "catastrophic" flooding that could cause widespread destruction and leave tens of thousands of people temporarily homeless. Billions of pounds may need to be spent on concrete flood defences while some coastal regions could even be abandoned.

The report, by the Expert Group on Climate Change and Health, is the first official assessment of the effect of global warming on health and has been launched by the government's chief medical officer, Professor Liam Donaldson.

The Health Effects of Climate Change recommends that efforts to reduce the impact of global warming should continue and an expanded research programme should be established "as a matter of urgency".

Prof Donaldson warned: "If global climate changes continue unchecked there will be an impact on the health of the population of this country."

Average temperatures in the UK are expected to rise by up to 2.3 degrees celsius, leading to hotter, drier summers and more intense heatwaves.

Heatwaves such as the one in 1976 are currently expected once in every 350 years. But by 2050, they could occur every five to six years.

This will cause a further 3,000 deaths - and 30,000 extra cases of skin cancer, unless pollution can be cut. There will also be 10,000 extra cases of food poisoning and another 2, 000 cases of cataract.

Malaria could also return to salt marsh districts, such as Essex, Kent and Norfolk, for the first time since the beginning of the last century.

The impact of the disease in the UK would be small but high-risk areas could be vulnerable to malaria for up to four months of the year.

Global warming could mean popular tourist destinations, such as Turkey, becoming increasingly tropical and vulnerable to the severest type of the disease - caused by plasmodium falciparum. Travellers could it back to the UK but it is unlikely to become established because conditions in this country are unsuitable for the species of mosquito that carries it.

Other insect-borne diseases such as the tropical west Nile fever could also be seen in the UK.

However, warmer winters should reduce deaths among the elderly by 20,000, with 2m fewer hospital admissions due to cold-related illnesses.

Prof Donaldson warned that gales and floods could cause the worst problems. The flooding of low-lying coastal areas will become more likely as sea levels rise due to the melting of the Arctic ice-cap, and storms worsen. "Flooding that spreads inland from coastal areas may be catastrophic," warns the report.

In the last 13 years, Britain has suffered three winter storms of a severity that would usually be expected once every 200 years.

The report also warns that gales could lead to more deaths and severe injuries, with people being crushed by collapsing buildings or falling trees.

Likely loss of electricity could cause further problems. The improved inspections for buildings, particularly hospitals, is recommended.

Information on the impact of climate change on public health is intended to help the government plan for long-term affects.

The report concludes that the NHS should cope well with the impact of climate change - if preventative action is taken early.

The government report comes as the inter-governmental panel on climate change prepares to finalise its third report on the global outlook next week.

webTitle: C4 lines up new comedy sketch show

fields.headline: Channel 4 readies new 'Friday Night Live'
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: A sketch show billed as the new Friday Night Live is being lined up to replace Chris Evans's TFI Friday on Channel 4, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
A sketch show being billed as the new Friday Night Live is being lined up to replace Chris Evans TFI Friday on Channel 4.

Avalon Television, the company behind the Frank Skinner Show, is to shoot a 60-minute broadcast pilot for the studio-based comedy show, which has the working title Head Farm, next month.

An Avalon spokeswoman said the show would be a "Friday Night Live-style" comedy format aimed at the old 6-7pm Friday night TFI slot.

Head Farm will feature eight comedians, with Jason Freeman hosting a line-up including Johnny Vegas, Dan Antopolski and Karen Taylor.

The programme will also showcase the comedy talents of Richard Ayoade and Matt Holness's act Garth Marenghi's Fright Knight and the Boosh, from Julian Barratt and Noel Fielding.

The potential TFI replacement is to be produced by Stewart Lee and directed by Peter Orton. Richard Allen-Turner and Jon Thoday will executive produce.

Head Farm has been commissioned by Channel 4 head of comedy and entertainment Caroline Leddy and comedy editor Iain Morris.

fields.headline: Partnerships in charities study launched
fields.trailText: A new research programme to measure the impact of voluntary organisations in partnership work has been unveiled by University College London.
fields.body:
A new research programme to measure the impact of voluntary organisations in partnership work has been unveiled by University College London (UCL).

The programme is being led by Les Hems, director of the centre for voluntary sector policy at UCL's school of public policy and a speaker at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations' annual conference held earlier this week.

At a seminar on the effectiveness of partnerships, Mr Hems told delegates that the programme would look at the nature of voluntary organisations in partnership mechanisms and assess their specific contribution.

Partnership work was important to the voluntary sector as it gave it a much greater role in delivering public policies, greater legitimacy and more resources, he said.

But work around evaluating partnerships has been focused on outcomes until now, making it difficult to assess what proportion of the outcomes can be attributed to the partnership, and to the voluntary sector in particular.

"We need to know what added value partnerships have brought to an organisation, the supra-organisational goals of what an organisation could not do without the partnership being there," Mr Hems explained.

Research will use established methods such as stakeholder analysis and baselines to measure overall impact of partnership work. It will then attempt to isolate the contribution made by voluntary organisations, by examining what would happen if they were removed or replaced in the partnership.

Mr Hems is talking to several local authorities in London to set up pilot projects, before the programme is rolled out more widely.

Voluntary organisations' financial resources or political clout will account for a large part of their contribution to partnership work, suggested Mr Hems' co-speaker Naomi Eisenstadt.

As head of the government's Sure Start unit set up to improve prospects for disadvantaged pre-school children, Ms Eisenstadt controls a budget of £1.4bn that will fund around 500 partnership programmes between now and 2004. "Size matters - the role of the voluntary organisation in the partnership is reflected by what it brings to the table," she said, provoking much visible and audible agreement from delegates.

Sure Start is spending £16.9m on evaluation over six years but Ms Eisenstadt said she was more interested in outcomes for the target group than the effect of partnership work on individual organisations.

"I don't care what effect this has on the voluntary sector; I just care about the impact on children, the effect on end-users," she declared.

It would be more interesting to see what impact parents were having on the board of an organisation rather than simply looking at the role of that organisation, she added.

"It's enormously important that community consultation is not seen as the same thing as working with the voluntary sector," Ms Eisenstadt stressed.

fields.headline: Millionaire blasts Star Trek premiere
fields.trailText: 2.45pm TV overnights: BBC1's Star Trek movie premiere did not boldly go very far in the ratings last night, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC1's Star Trek movie premiere did not boldly go very far in the ratings last night, losing out to Who Wants to be a Millionaire? on ITV.

The terrestrial premiere of Star Trek: First Contact - in which Enterprise captain Jean-Luc Picard leads his crew against old enemy the Borg - gained 6.3m viewers and a 26% share, according to unofficial overnights.

The movie was broadcast between 8.05pm and 9.50pm.

It was up against ITV's Who Wants to be a Millionaire? between 8pm and 9pm, followed by drama At Home with the Braithwaites from 9pm to 10pm.

Millionaire had 10.2m viewers, while the Braithwaites pulled in 8.6m.

Channel 5's repeat of Rutger Hauer thriller the Hitcher, screened as part of the broadcaster's Murder Week, pulled in 1.6m viewers and an 8% share between 9pm and 11pm.

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week twenty-four
fields.standfirst: Blue Square have given us £400 to gamble with on their site. Here are the latest punts
fields.trailText:

fields.body:
Current totals (from their initial £100 kitties):
Scott Murray = £175.80
Sean Ingle = £55.15
Football Unlimited Punters Collective = £29.12
Paul MacInnes = £28.14

Scott Murray: Celtic v Rangers - 0 or 1 goals scored - £5 @ 3/1

So to the biggest match in Scotland for over three days. Will you be giving up 795 of your new sterling pence to watch 22 millionaires kick seven colours out of each other? Or will you settle for the radio instead, and just hope Fernando Ricksen clatters someone in the mouth heavily enough for the pitch-side microphones to pick it up? It's a rare old choice, that's for sure.

Whatever you decide, chances are you'll get goals. It seems so obvious: the two teams have scored 18 between them in the last three derbies. However, there's at least one dire Old Firm game every season, and with a desperate Rangers sure to be playing it tight at the back and scrapping for every ball, this has as good a chance as any of being it.

Scottish title deciders are historically tight affairs as well. Save your eight pounds.

Sean Ingle: Chelsea to beat Manchester United - £8 @ 7/4

"Pick up a sesame seed but lose sight of a watermelon," advises an ancient - and no doubt wise - Chinese proverb. And if business execs with too much money (and often not much sense) can hang on the every word of Sun Tze or some other Chinese proverb-spinner, then so can I.

Backing Spurs to bore out a fifth successive 0-0 Premiership draw is tempting, especially at odds of 8-1. And Aston Villa v Middlesbrough hardly looks like a thrill a minute, either. But both those games represent the unattainable watermelon, and I'm looking for a sesame seed - which is why I've gone for Chelsea to beat Manchester United.

Chelsea have won six straight Premiership matches at Stamford Bridge. They also beat United 5-0 in the corresponding fixture last year. I'd back them to beat United more than four times in 11 (which is what the odds of 7/4 suggest) which is why I'm sticking £8 on it. Here's hoping: "With time and patience the mulberry leaf becomes a silk gown."

Paul MacInnes: Chelsea to draw with Man Utd - £5 @ 9/4

To be honest I am hoping for a plague of frogs to descend on Stamford Bridge this weekend. Not only am I fed up with losing, I also managed to get myself quite excited about last week's bet, only for that hairy so-and-so who sits in the clouds to scotch my enjoyment by postponing the Newcastle-Southampton match (in which I had backed Saints to be up at half-time) with just a couple of hours' notice.

So this week, I have just gone for a plump. A fat dumpy plump. Though only one of the past five meetings between Chelsea and Man Utd has ended in a draw, I think this one will. While Chelsea's home form is imperious, United have only lost once away this season. I think that a price of over 2/1 is good, especially seeing as a draw would suit United. So come on God, bring it on.

Mitch Pryce of the Guardian Unlimited Punters' Collective: £5 treble - Chesterfield to beat Cheltenham @ 1/2, Forest to draw with Blackburn @ 11/5, Port Vale to draw with Bournemouth @ 11/5.

Position desperate. We've sent for Joe Kinnear, but until he can wriggle out of his Luton commitments the Punters' Collective will have to limp on under the erratic aegis of motley caretakers. Mitch Pryce of Birmingham, the latest to pick up the poisoned pin, has this week boldly gone where Patrick Murray has told him not to and picked two draws in his treble. It will pay, we are assured, 14.36/1. And in one fell coup it will put the collective into profit.

fields.headline: The new old peace process
fields.standfirst: Once in office, Ariel Sharon will have to acknowledge the political realities of the Middle East situation and, of course, deal carefully with fellow new premier George Bush. Derek Brown reports on the future of the peace process
fields.trailText: Once in office, Ariel Sharon will have to acknowledge the political realities of the Middle East situation and, of course, deal carefully with fellow new premier George Bush. Derek Brown reports on the future of the peace process.
fields.body:
The Israeli-Palestinian peace process, as we know it, is dead. It has been officially killed off by Israel's prime minister-elect, Ariel Sharon, and by the new Bush administration in Washington.

Even the outgoing Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, says that his successor is not obliged to abide by any of the promises and offers made to Palestinian president Yasser Arafat before Tuesday's mould-breaking election.

So it's back to the drawing board, right? Wrong. The fact is that the peace process is more than a strategy; a particular and unalterable way of doing things. It is a fact on the ground. In 1993, when Yitzhak Rabin, Shimon Perez and Yasser Arafat shook hands on the White House lawn, they changed the map of the Middle East.

Sharon will not be able to revert to the old one, however much he may want to. The Palestinians control their own territory - not as much as they would like, but they still have a de facto mini-state. Israel has signed a peace treaty with Jordan, and ended its occupation of South Lebanon. Hafez Assad, the longterm ruler of Syria, has died, and although the regime has reinvented itself under his son Bashar, there are tentative signs of a new pragmatic approach to regional peace.

All these factors have changed the Middle East radically, in less than eight years. Now we see two more changes: Sharon in Jerusalem, and Bush in the White House. We are in a new phase, if not a new era.

It is impossible to overstate the importance of the US-Israel alliance in recent years. American taxpayers subsidise the Jewish state to the tune of more than £3bn a year. American diplomacy shields Israel from criticism in the United Nations and on the world stage, and American military might is the ultimate deterrent to any concerted Arab attack.

Yet that formidable relationship may be about to change, and none too subtly. President Bill Clinton was an unabashed, unqualified supporter of Israel and of the peace process which began with secret talks in Norway and produced the so-called Oslo accords. At times he was almost proprietorial in his approach.

His predecessor, George Bush, had much less patience with the region, and with intransigent Zionist supremacists, dragging them unwillingly into the abortive Madrid negotiations in the 1980s. Now George Bush mark II and his new diplomatic team are picking up the pieces from Israel's electoral earthquake.

The president himself is said to be little engaged with foreign policy in general and has shown not a scintilla of Clinton's emotional attachment to the Israel-Palestine issue. But his choice of top diplomats offers some intriguing clues about future strategy.

Close observers of the State Department have little doubt that Colin Powell, the new secretary of state, has brought to that office a radically new view of the region. As the former allied commander in Operation Desert Storm, he is understandably more concerned with Iraq, and to an almost equal extent Iran, as potential destabilisers in the region.

That does not mean that the USA will distance itself from Israel. Indeed, it could increase the importance of Israel in Washington's eyes, as America's closest and most dependable ally in the region. But the last thing that the Bush administration wants, is for a Sharon government to provoke a new surge of anti-Israeli - and anti-American - anger in the Arab world.

America and Israel need each other. But Israel needs America far, far more than the other way round. It is no coincidence that one of Sharon's first post-election moves was to dispatch a high-level mission to Washington to brief the Bush administration on his views. No doubt the exchanges were two-way, and the prime minister-elect in Jerusalem is under no illusions about the limits of American approval and support.

fields.headline: MMR vaccine
fields.standfirst: The combined vaccine for children and its disputed harmful side-effects are continuing to divide medical experts. Sarah Left explains
fields.trailText: The combined vaccine for children and its disputed harmful side-effects are continuing to divide medical experts. Sarah Left explains.
fields.body:
Why is it in the news now?
The combined measles, mumps and rubella (German measles) vaccine is back in the news because a study from the Boston University school of medicine found no link between MMR and a rise in cases of autism in the UK. The results contradict the findings of Andrew Wakefield, a consultant gastroenterologist at the Royal Free hospital in London. He claims that the vaccination was not tested thoroughly enough for safety before it was introduced in Britain in 1988, and he published a paper in the medical journal, Adverse Drug Reactions, which claims that children given the combined jab were not followed up for long enough to be sure that there were no side-effects.

Is the MMR vaccine dangerous?
The balance of medical evidence suggests it is not dangerous, despite earlier, smaller studies from Mr Wakefield and from researchers in the US that suggested MMR causes autism and Crohn's disease, a serious bowel disorder. Finnish researchers followed 2m children for 14 years after they received the MMR vaccine and found no evidence that the vaccination resulted in later health problems. The government says the vaccine is perfectly safe. But many parents are still concerned.

Who gets the MMR jab and when?
The vaccine is currently given to children twice, once at about a year old and the second time at about four years old. The second injection is intended to catch anyone who missed out on the first one and to provide protection to any children who may not have been fully immunised by the first jab. Before MMR, children received separate vaccinations for each disease.

What does the health profession say?
Nearly half of family doctors, health visitors and practice nurses have reservations about giving children their second dose of the MMR vaccine, according to recently published research. However, only 3% actually disagreed with the policy of giving two injections, and many of the objections had to do with subjecting children to two needles rather than with the health risks.

There's not much measles, mumps and rubella around today in this country, so why do we still need the vaccine?
The success of vaccinations in defeating diseases depends upon the vast majority - about 95% - of the population receiving the vaccine. If a significant number of parents stopped giving MMR to their children, then health experts say the diseases could reach epidemic proportions. The immunisation level in the UK has dropped to 88% overall and down to 75% in some areas. Government health experts say an epidemic could be just around the corner. The last UK outbreak in 1980 killed 17 people.

If the disease is dangerous and the vaccination is dangerous, what is the alternative?
Some suggest that it is safer to give children the separate vaccines for measles, mumps and rubella. It is only the combined vaccine that has been linked to autism and bowel disease.

So why not administer the vaccines separately?
The problem is that in the time between the vaccinations, children can catch one of the diseases. The head of vaccination at the Department of Health, Dr David Salisbury, sites the example of Japan, where the vaccinations are administered separately and 79 people died from measles between 1992 and 1997.

What should parents do?
Many parents are choosing to give their children only the first vaccination at between 12 and 15 months old. Of course some are choosing not to vaccinate at all, even though that carries the risk of a measles epidemic.

fields.headline: Icebox.com to close
fields.trailText: 2.45pm: Hollywood-backed entertainment website Icebox.com is to close, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
One of the last remaining Hollywood-backed entertainment dot.coms has thrown in the towel after failing to find additional funding to keep the company afloat.

Icebox.com, one of the most respected animated sites on the web, said there was no way of avoiding the inevitable meltdown of its business.

The high-profile entertainment broadcaster laid off its remaining 27 staff today and shut up shop.

Originally employing 106 staff, Icebox.com has undergone a number of streamlining initiatives over the past three months in a bid to cut costs, but still had trouble making ends meet.

Attempts at raising fresh financing attempts failed to bring in the funds to see the company through the rest of the year.

Icebox chief executive Steve Stanford said he had been made offers adding up to "a few million dollars" but that wasn't enough.

The company directors said they hoped to sell Icebox.com's library, which includes cartoons developed by veteran TV writers and producers who had previously worked on The Simpsons and Frasier, intact to a single broadcaster.

Launched 14 months ago, Icebox.com's mandate was to create a place where Hollywood talent could explore creative risks. Since its launch, it has burnt through $14.3m.

Icebox joins a large group of failed internet entertainment start-ups, including Steven Spielberg's Pop.com and Digital Entertainment Network.

The site is closing just as Channel 4 was starting to commission animated shorts from it for its new entertainment website, e4.com.

webTitle: MXR consortium lands Birmingham radio licence

fields.headline: MXR consortium lands Birmingham radio licence
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: A consortium led by Chrysalis has won the digital radio licence for the west midlands, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
A consortium led by Chrysalis has won the 12-year regional digital radio licence covering Birmingham and the west midlands.

The MXR consortium also includes Capital Radio, Guardian Media Group, Jazz FM and UBC Media Group.

It is planning to offer nine radio stations and a data service - supplied by UBC - over its digital multiplex from this summer.

Chrysalis, the biggest shareholder in MXR with a 39% stake, is to supply its adult rock format the Arrow, along with its 100.7 Heart FM and Galaxy 102.2 services.

MXR's west midlands franchise will also offer Capital Radio's children's format Fun, Jazz FM, Guardian Media Group's easy-listening service Smooth and the BBC Asian Network.

It will also provide rolling regional news service Digital News Network and, subject to agreement, Saga Radio.

The west midlands regional digital radio licence covers a potential adult audience of 3.3m and includes Birmingham, Wolverhampton and Coventry.

The MXR consortium, which also includes Ford and Psion, has already won the regional digital radio licences for the north-east and south Wales/Severn estuary.

Meanwhile, Forever Broadcasting has acquired the company that operates Wolverhampton FM station 107.7 the Wolf.

Forever Broadcasting is paying £4m in cash and £1m in shares for Wolverhampton Area Radio, which operates the Wolf.

WAR made a loss after tax of £68,000 in the year to March 31 2000 on a turnover of just under £394,000.

Forever Broadcasting is a Newcastle-based independent radio and new media outfit.

It owns Juice 107.6FM in Liverpool, Tower FM in Bury and Bolton and Surf 107.2 in Brighton.

fields.headline: Hayward quits JWT
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: Tim Hayward, who helped build J Walter Thompson's digital operation, is understood to be in talks with TBWA/London. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Tim Hayward, who helped build J Walter Thompson's digital operation digital@jwt, is leaving the agency and is understood to be in talks with TBWA/London.

Mr Hayward was not available for comment, but sources say he is talking to TBWA about setting up new digital operation at the agency.

TBWA refused to confirm or deny the reports. But chief operating officer Neil Christie said the agency was in talks with several people about expanding its digital capabilities.

"We already have a small digital operation which we are looking to expand in the context of the need to offer a total communications package," he said.

"We are talking to several people but nothing has been signed yet."

JWT said Mr Hayward's resignation signalled that his job at the ageny had been done.

"Tim's particular skills lie in building high growth entities and catalysing change," said digital@jwt managing director Jeremy Davies.

"We knew from the start that responsibility for the continued development and profitable running of the business beyond the initial growth phase would be handed off to different members of the team."

Mr Hayward will not be directly replaced at the agency.

fields.headline: Council to axe 450 staff
fields.trailText: Hundreds of Barnsley council workers are to lose their jobs as part of a round of budget cuts designed to balance the books and focus spending on frontline services, it was announced today.
fields.body:
Hundreds of council workers are to lose their jobs as part of a round of budget cuts designed to balance their employer's books and focus spending on frontline services, it was announced today.

Barnsley metropolitan borough council will axe 450 posts - mainly managerial - in the planning, transport, finance, corporate services, environment, trading standards, consumer protection, and culture and sports departments.

A two-year strategy to "re-shape" the council's budget will focus spending on education, social services and highways.

The education department will receive almost £3m extra, and the youth service will get £450,000. An extra £1.3m will go to improving social services and a further £2m to the capital repairs programme.

Council leader Stephen Houghton said: "This is not something we would like to see, but we are spending more than we've got and this year we have to bring income and expenditure back in line. We will do everything we can to help and support those who will be affected."

Council tax bills will nonetheless rise by 6.5% - which would mean an increase of almost £55 per year on the average bill. "This budget is all about the council shouldering the burden rather than the public," said Mr Houghton. His announcement follows a budget statement by the council last month that warned of "big changes for the council and its employees" because the authority had to become "leaner and fitter".

Barnsley was this week named as a beacon council for competitiveness and enterprise.

webTitle: Doc Martens kicks its way to 'superbrand' status

fields.headline: Doc Martens kicks its way to 'superbrand' status
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: Dr Martens and Pret a Manger have joined the list of 'superbrands' for the first time, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Pret a Manger, Lastminute.com and Dr Martens have all won places on a list of "superbrands" for the first time.

There were also some spectacular risers and fallers in the list, which is produced every two years by independent branding organisation Superbrands.

Personal organiser Psion jumped from number 326 to 75.

It eclipsed the paper organiser brand Filofax, which fell from 341 to 467.

The nation's obsession with decorating - and a successful advertising campaign - propelled Dulux from position 80 to 44.

Tetley Tea climbed from 194 to 138 and Persil rose from 108 to 42.

Also on the up were Kellogg's Corn Flakes, Mars and Virgin Atlantic, which were all in the top 10.

But Moss Bros, the troubled men's tailor, fell from 245 to 438.

A company restructure, new chain of stores and £1m rebranding campaign through ad agency McCann-Erickson may remedy the slide over the next two years.

Other brands to fall were Seiko, down from 175 in 1998 to 452 in 2000, Flymo fell from 202 to 443 and Hoover slipped from 257 position 378.

And the only internet brands to make it on to the list were Lastminute.com, Hotmail, AOL and Ask Jeeves.

The Superbrands organisation enlisted a council of nine marketing, advertising, branding, design and PR luminaries to judge what made a brand a superbrand.

The head of ad agency BMP DDB and New Labourite Chris Powell, Virgin corporate affairs director Will Whitehorn and BT head of design David Mercer were among the council members.

The criteria they used included marketing, advertising, strength of recall, strength of brand, image and brand values.

The list contained 600 brands, of which the top 100 are considered the superbrands.

Pret a Manger and Lastminute.com made it on to the list - at positions 136 and 106 respectively - courtesy of their strong presence in the minds of consumers over the past two years.

Forty-year-old brand Dr Martens made it to number 274 thanks to a brand revamp and advertising through TBWA/London.

Superbrands global chairman Marcel Knobil said: "The findings of the Superbrands council demonstrate great brands only maintain their strength with the benefit of ongoing excellent brand stewardship.

"However exceptional a brand, you cannot afford to neglect or mishandle it for long."

The organisation has produced a list of internet superbrands, called eBrandLeaders, for the first time.

The four web brands to have made it on to the consumer list were joined by 21store.com, Deal4Free and UpMyStreet.co.uk.

fields.headline: Bush's careful progress
fields.standfirst: With the US president applying himself surprisingly well to his new job, polarised opinion polls and the Florida debacle are slowly receding into the background, reports Martin Kettle
fields.trailText: With the US president applying himself surprisingly well to his new job, polarised opinion polls and the Florida debacle are slowly receding into the background, reports Martin Kettle in Washington.
fields.body:
The sentence I am about to write is guaranteed to enrage a lot of the people who will read it and to condemn me to a weekend flood of angry emails - but here goes anyway. So far, George W Bush is playing a blinder.

Just for the record, this assessment is not offered as a value judgment. It does not mean that the circumstances in which Mr Bush gained the presidency are either acceptable or forgotten. It does not mean that I either approve or disapprove of his policies. And it does not mean that he will continue to perform as successfully for the remainder of his four-year term.

What it means is merely this. Given the circumstances, Mr Bush could hardly have played his hand better than he has done. He has been smart. He has been consistent. And he is changing the terms of the American political contest in his favour.

In the three weeks since he claimed the White House, the new president has had a lot of luck. Much of it came courtesy of Bill Clinton. Some of it came from the realisation that the American media wants to be nice to the new president. But Mr Bush has also made some of it himself.

For one thing, Mr Bush has learned from the past. He has twigged that the fastest way for a Republican to lose credibility is to bang on about Mr Clinton. And he has worked out that if you stick to your headline promises, like tax cuts, people do not worry if you let the lesser ones slip, like instantly pumping money into the Pentagon.

Purely from a technical point of view, Mr Bush's management of the first three weeks of his presidency has been near perfect. He got his experienced cabinet sorted quickly. He has schmoozed the Democrats to such an extent that he has barely appeared to bother talking to members of his own party.

He led from strength in his first pronouncements, focusing on an issue on which he has always been strong and which is a top priority of the voters: education. A week ago, he dominated the agenda with his so-called "faith-based" initiatives. This week, he has done the same on tax cuts. As modern political management, it has been almost flawless.

To repeat. I am not offering approval, wide-eyed or otherwise. Nor disapproval either. The point is simply that Mr Bush very clearly knows what he is doing, and from his point of view, what he is doing is surely the right thing. That's one reason why the Democrats don't quite know how to respond.

In fact, Mr Bush is doing exactly what he did when he became governor of Texas in 1994, again after narrowly defeating a formidable incumbent Democratic opponent. He is being seen reaching out, being generous, appearing magnanimous, assiduously acquiring a considerate and civil image. He is cultivating approval by very consciously, and very deliberately, putting himself above the daily political battle. If you want to look at it this way, he is putting the presidency to work.

This week, the opinion polls delivered their first verdict on Mr Bush as president. After two weeks in office, Mr Bush had an initial approval rating of 57% in Gallup's regular monthly survey, with 25% disapproving and 18% unsure. The numbers tell several stories.

First, the approval rating is quite good. It is one point below Mr Clinton's first poll in 1993 and seven points higher than both his father's debut presidential rating in 1989 and, more interestingly, Ronald Reagan's in 1981.

Second, Mr Bush's disapproval rating is the highest since Gallup began tracking the question more than 50 years ago. In the past, presidents had to acquire their enemies. Mr Bush comes with them ready dressed (I was going to say "ready armed" but this is hardly the right week to put it that way).

Finally, and clearly the other side of the same coin, fewer people are unsure what they think about Mr Bush than about any president in the poll's history. When Mr Bush's father entered the White House 12 years ago, by contrast, 43% of Americans did not know what they thought about him, even though he was a wholly familiar figure who had served the previous eight years as vice-president.

What does this all add up to? It says that Mr Bush is a divisive figure, but the divisiveness is decreasing compared with the Florida aftermath. Next month's polls will make interesting reading, but look for a further improvement. Some tempers are abating, partly because Bush has set out so diligently to make them abate. Here's the point. It's a very focused strategy, and it is working, at least initially. This brings us to another lesson from Texas. Don't underestimate Mr Bush.

It is one point below Mr Clinton's first poll in 1993 and seven points higher than both his father's debut presidential rating in 1989 and, more interestingly, Ronald Reagan's in 1981. Second, Mr Bush's disapproval rating is the highest since Gallup began tracking the question more than 50 years ago. In the past, presidents had to acquire their enemies. Mr Bush comes with them ready dressed (I was going to say "ready armed" but this is hardly the right week to put it that way). Finally, and clearly the other side of the same coin, fewer people are unsure what they think about Mr Bush than about any president in the poll's history. When Mr Bush's father entered the White House 12 years ago, by contrast, 43% of Americans did not know what they thought about him, even though he was a wholly familiar figure who had served the previous eight years as vice-president. What does this all add up to? It says that Mr Bush is a divisive figure, but the divisiveness is decreasing compared with the Florida aftermath. Next month's polls will make interesting reading, but look for a further improvement. Some tempers are abating, partly because Bush has set out so diligently to make them abate. Here's the point. It's a very focused strategy, and it is working, at least initially. This brings us to another lesson from Texas. Don't underestimate Mr Bush. fields.headline: Mandelson - round three?
fields.standfirst:
If the former Northern Ireland secretary is cleared of the Hinduja slur, he could be perfectly placed to make an incredible second political comeback, says Matthew Tempest

Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText:
If the former Northern Ireland secretary is cleared of the Hinduja slur, he could be perfectly placed to make an incredible second political comeback, says Matthew Tempest.
Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.body:
The man who once harboured ambitions to take the most glamorous post in the cabinet - that of foreign secretary - has certainly been earning his airmiles in recent weeks.

For Peter Mandelson, a Christmas trip to the archaeological wonders of Syria (he went to the ancient ruins in Palmyra and the crusader castles at Krac de Chevalier) was followed by a weekend jaunt to Paris (where he took the fatal call from the Observer which was to lead to his downfall whilst perusing the exhibits of the Museum of Asiatic Art), and then, of course, the tearful flight to the States in the wake of his one undeniably unique achievement - a second resignation from frontbench politics.

Now rumours of a new jetsetting post are circulating the cramped press gallery of the House of Commons (if not Downing Street itself): that of European commissioner. Britain at present has two Euro commissioners, Neil Kinnock and Chris Patten, neither of whom has the public profile, access to the PM and organising abilities of the MP for Hartlepool.

The chance of an unheard-of third bite of the cherry is not as preposterous as it might seem to those whose interest in politics is confined to healthily dismissive headlines of the tabloids. While Peter Mandelson may never be able to persuade the rightwing press and the ordinary public he is a man of probity, he has opened up a window of opportunity for himself among the Westminster chattering classes - the only audience which has ever really mattered to him.

Because if, as seems increasingly possible, he is cleared by Sir Anthony Hammond QC in the inquiry currently underway into the Hinduja passports affair, then he presents Tony Blair with a problem without precedent in British politics: the minister who resigned for no reason. And thus a minister looking for reward, in lieu of revenge.

A return to cabinet-level government, even after the election, would be too politically damaging. Cleared or not, Mandelson is damaged goods and he has already watched his career being written off by cabinet colleagues Clare Short, Geoff Hoon and Alistair Darling - all in front of the TV cameras.

But a post at the heart of Europe, well away from Westminster, in an organisation as desperately in need of reform as Labour was in the 1980s? Well, there's one candidate ready, willing and able, currently "between jobs" and with a CV to die for.

The press campaign for resurrection has already begun - if a week is a long time in politics, a month or two is long enough for an entire political rebirth. The only question is how he can do all this without embarrassing Blair; but if he can, the Mandelson roadshow could be back in Brussels.

fields.headline: Acclaimed council faces £2.6m budget cut
fields.trailText: A council praised for the good quality of its social care staff and services is facing £2.6m cuts in social services.
fields.body:
A council praised for the good quality of its social care staff and services is facing £2.6m cuts in social services.

Torbay social services will meet next Wednesday to decide how to implement cuts amounting to around 9% of the departmental budget. Authority-wide savings are needed, according to the south Devon council, because of a "pitifully low" standard spending assessment for the coming financial year.

Councillors will be considering using special grants, such as the leaving care grant from this October, to make up the shortfall in some children's and adult services. But the Conservative-controlled council has warned that these grants could not be used for the same clients in future years. Three of Torbay's family centres, preventative services for children in danger of coming into care and rehabilitation and respite services for the elderly are likely to be hard hit.

The cuts come as a joint review team from the social services inspectorate and the Audit Commission reported that: "The council has some good quality services delivered by caring and competent staff." The team also found that, while better information about services would enable people to get help sooner, those "receiving services were generally positive about them". The council had good working relationships with other agencies, a commitment to learning from service users, experience in running "highly rated" services and some good personnel practices, such as staff appraisal.

However, the joint review team also called on the council to "bring its budget under control" and target resources better on areas of priority. The council also needed "a stronger sense of direction" and an overall plan with targets for social services, and better systems for judging its own performance.

Jain Wood, director of social services, said: "I think it's a very fair report, we had identified the majority of the issues that they identified."

The likelihood of cuts in preventative services appears to fly in the face of the team's recommendation to avoid crisis intervention through thorough assessments and effective early support for children in need.

Ms Wood said: "The family centres were praised as an example of good practice. Our dilemma in looking at the budget is that there isn't any fat to cut - and there's precious little bone left - and it will mean cuts in services.

"We are aware that preventive services do save money in the long run and are good for users but the demand for heavy-end services mean it could be dangerous to cut there. I know that cuts in one will lead to bigger problems at the other end. Clearly I am not happy to be having to consider this. There will be risks attached somewhere to making cuts of this size."

webTitle: Sharon and Barak meet, West Bank flares up

fields.headline: Sharon and Barak meet, West Bank flares up
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Israeli prime minister-elect Ariel Sharon met today with caretaker premier Ehud Barak to discuss the transition of power, as violence escalated with Palestinians and Israeli soldiers exchanging gunfire in the West Bank.
fields.body:
Israeli prime minister-elect Ariel Sharon met today with caretaker premier Ehud Barak to discuss the transition of power, as violence escalated with Palestinians and Israeli soldiers exchanging gunfire in the West Bank.

Mr Sharon's first priority is to form a government and at his meeting today with Mr Barak, the two discussed the possibility of a government of national unity.

"Barak informed Sharon of the latest developments in diplomatic and security issues," said a spokesman from the prime minister's office, where the two met for an hour.

During the meeting Mr Sharon renewed his offer to Mr Barak to keep his position of defence minister in the incoming government. Mr Barak, however, announced his resignation from parliament after his loss to Sharon in Tuesday's election by a 25% margin.

Both Mr Barak and former Labour prime minister Shimon Peres have indicated support for a national unity government with Mr Sharon so long as he pursues peace.

Mr Barak's peace deal, however, looks dead. Mr Sharon has said he will not be bound by negotiations that were happening with the outgoing government.

In words that rang even truer after a car bomb exploded yesterday in an ultra-Orthodox Jewish neighbourhood of Jerusalem, the Palestinians said today that the next few weeks would be "a test" of the peace process.

Nabil Abu Rudeina, a senior adviser to the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, said: "The change in the US administration and the change in Israel require a change in methods and contents. The next few weeks will be a test of the extent to which the peace process can go," he added.

The US president, George Bush, has abandoned Middle East peace plans championed by his predecessor, Bill Clinton, and has indicated that his administration will take a far more hands-off approach to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

Mr Sharon is "encouraged" that the Bush administration has distanced itself with the compromise peace proposals set forth by Mr Clinton, a spokesman for Mr Sharon said today.

He added that Mr Clinton himself told Mr Sharon that his peace compromises were not binding if the Israelis and Palestinians did not reach an accord before his administration left office.

Mr Barak had in principle accepted the Clinton plan, which called among other things for some Palestinian sovereignty in Jerusalem. Mr Sharon has said he will not consider a peace plan that divides Jerusalem.

However the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, told Mr Sharon that he risked increasing violence if he did not stick to the understanding reached by the previous Israeli government.

A statement issued by the presidency and published by Egyptian newspapers today said Mr Mubarak congratulated Sharon on his victory, but warned of dire consequences if the Arab-Israeli peace talks collapsed, adding that an attempt to "ignore the achievements of the peace process on any track" would trigger further tension.

Illustrating the point, an intense gun battle erupted between Israeli troops and Palestinians near the West Bank town of Ramallah. Israeli soldiers aimed machine gun fire at empty high-rise apartment buildings used by Palestinian gunmen as cover.

And in the Gaza Strip, the Islamic militant group Hamas threatened to carry out more suicide attacks against Israel. Some 2,500 Hamas supporters chanted "Destroy the centre of Tel Aviv" and burned effigies of Mr Sharon and Mr Bush.

One Hamas banner held up by the crowd read "Generals like Sharon only understand the language of resistance and holy war."

fields.headline: Mandelson tells of 'road crash' resignation
fields.standfirst: Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText:
In his first interview since his resignation from the government last month, Peter Mandelson today likened his fall from office over the "passports-for-favours" affair to a "ghastly road accident".
Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson today likened his fall from office over the so-called "passports-for-favours" affair to a "ghastly road accident".

In his first media interview since his dramatic resignation from the cabinet last month, he refused to be drawn on press reports that he now set his sights on a job as one of Britain's European commissioners.

Earlier, however, the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, lashed out at "friends" of the former Northern Ireland secretary who had been briefing journalists on his behalf, saying that they were "hardly friends of the Labour party".

Mr Mandelson took part today in a BBC Radio Cleveland phone-in at his Hartlepool constituency and said he still did not fully understand the events which led to his downfall.

But he acknowledged that he may have made mistakes. He said: "These things just happen completely out of the blue in politics and politics is like that.

"Life goes on and it's like suddenly finding yourself in a ghastly road accident in which your car is written off and which you step from the wreckage and continue your life.

"You don't know how the accident happened, probably it was a combination of different factors and mistakes, including your own. It is being investigated, as accidents are - and you cooperate with the investigation, and that's what I'm doing now. But I keep my views to myself in public on what happened. Others can speculate and of course they will do but my public views will be kept for the investigation."

He said that it would now be for Sir Anthony Hammond's inquiry to establish what really happened over his involvement in the passport application by the controversial Indian tycoon, Srichand Hinduja.

He insisted he would be running as Hartlepool MP in the forthcoming general election and said he was relishing the forthcoming battle with such candidates as the miners' union leader, Arthur Scargill.

However, according to unattributed press reports today, Mr Mandelson is seeking to secure a public acknowledgement from Tony Blair that the home secretary, Jack Straw, had been wrong to accuse him of having been "untruthful".

While he was said to have accepted that a return to the cabinet would be difficult, he did want to clear his name and resume a role in public life, possibly as one of Britain's commissioners in Brussels.

But Downing Street reacted coldly to reports that Mr Mandelson was seeking a role in Brussels.

A No10 spokesman said: "Peter resigned from the government for the reasons that he gave. I don't particularly intend to the get into the minutiae of what appear to be unsourced stories."

The reports also drew a scathing response from Mr Prescott, who said: "As I understand it, it is friends of friends. They are hardly friends of the Labour party," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme. I think we should wait for the inquiry. That is the proper thing to do."

However, Mr Prescott also stressed that it was Mr Mandelson's own decision to resign over the account he gave of his role in the naturalisation application by Mr Hinduja, who donated £1m to the Millennium Dome at a time when Mr Mandelson was the dome minister.

The latest reports about Mr Mandelson were said to have caused deep anger in Labour circles as they upstaged the Mr Blair's keynote speech yesterday in which he set out his stall for the forthcoming general election.

That was reflected by Mr Prescott who said: "It is all the froth of politics. It doesn't mean a damn. It is the next steps of this government that people are concerned with, not the next steps of Peter Mandelson."

fields.headline: Web firm considers legal action over Labour logo
fields.standfirst: The two logos: you decide
fields.trailText:
10.30am: Labour may be forced to scrap its new logo after internet firm Excite said it looked the same as theirs, writes Claire Cozens.
The two logos: you decide
Feb 5: Labour under fire over 'brutish' logo
fields.body:
Labour may be forced to scrap its new logo after bosses at internet company Excite said it looked exactly the same as theirs.

Excite is considering legal action against the party, which it says may have infringed its copyright on the symbol.

European chief executive Evan Rudowski has gone to the company's US headquarters to find out whether Excite can sue Labour over the logo. The company says it could be briefing lawyers by next week.

"Our trademark council in the US is looking at this very closely," said Lorraine Thomson, European marketing director at Excite.

"Excite takes these things very seriously - it's a bit like working for Coca-Cola, they're very hot on anything legal.

"No one wants their brand to be infringed and this is about us looking after our brand," she added.

Excite first saw the Labour logo - which is almost identical to its trademark -when it appeared in newspapers on Monday.

webTitle: Madonna on safe ground in new movie

fields.headline: Madonna on safe ground in new movie
fields.trailText: Madonna and 80s popster Debbie Gibson are to join forces on a film about two rival divas who come to blows at an awards ceremony
fields.body:
Madonna may be about to "play herself" in a new movie about rival popstars. According to peoplenews, the newly-married singer is to work with 80s singer-songwriter Debbie Gibson in Teen Queens, the story of two rival singers who end up fighting on stage at an awards ceremony.

A source close to the project says that La Ciccone, whose MadGuy productions will make the film, was keen to star. "The part is tailor-made for Madonna," he said. "If her schedule allows, I'm sure she'd love to act in a film like this. At the very least, she will be heavily involved with the production."

The project is said to be part of Madonna's four-movie deal with music station VH-1. Clearly, Madonna and Gibson (who now styles herself Deborah Gibson) are too old to play the feuding teenstars. Instead they are to write the score for the film.

Gibson, who had chart success in the 80s with Out of the Blue and Electric Youth, has not been quite as successful since. However, she has continued to perform, and according to her website, she has a new single and album out this month.

webTitle: Eminem evokes love and loathing in UK

fields.headline: Eminem evokes love and loathing in UK
fields.trailText: US rapper Eminem took the stage at his first British concert last night with around 15,000 fans, mostly girls aged 13 to 16, flicking hand gestures at gay students who had come to Manchester to tell them the singer's sexist, homophobic songs were unacceptable.
fields.body:
US rapper Eminem took the stage at his first British concert last night with around 15,000 fans, mostly girls aged 13 to 16, flicking hand gestures at gay students who had come to Manchester to tell them the singer's sexist, homophobic songs were unacceptable.

The protesters' message - that Eminem's lyrics such as "take drugs, rape sluts, make fun of gay clubs" were dangerous and offensive - fell largely on deaf ears.

Inside the Manchester Evening News arena, the rapper ran through songs such as The Real Slim Shady and the No1 hit Stan wearing his trademark white mask and wielding a chainsaw. Among the crowd was the Manchester United footballer David Beckham and his pop star wife Victoria.

Earlier, students from Sheffield, York and Liverpool arrived by bus for a protest organised by the National Union of Students' lesbian, gay and bisexual campaign and backed by gay rights' groups including OutRage!.

Outside the arena, they handed out flyers saying: "Eminem has gone too far!" "We want people to see that Eminem is affecting the day-to-day lives of lesbians and gays," said Daniel Murphy, NUS campaign representative.

"Manchester is proud of its diversity, women, gay and straight. Why should we give this bigot a warm welcome? Telling people to 'kill faggots' endangers people's safety and encourages gaybashing."

Phaedra Bell, 16, a fan from Southport, said: "We totally understand gay people's worries but they have read Eminem wrong. We don't take any notice of his lyrics."

webTitle: Shuttle readies for docking with space station

fields.headline: Shuttle readies for docking with space station
fields.standfirst:
Special report: space exploration
Interactive: International space station
fields.trailText: Astronauts on the space shuttle Atlantis prepared to dock with the international space station 225 miles above the Earth to deliver the $1.4 billion science laboratory Destiny.
fields.body:
Astronauts on the space shuttle Atlantis prepared to dock with the international space station 225 miles above the Earth to deliver the $1.4 billion science laboratory Destiny.

The lab is 28 feet long and 14 feet in diameter and is stuffed into Atlantis' payload bay. Hatches between Atlantis and space station Alpha were to open about two hours after docking today.

Astronaut Marsha Ivins, the robot-arm operator, will have just 2 inches of clearance when she slowly lifts the lab from its tight berth on Saturday before mounting it onto space station Alpha during the mission's first of three scheduled spacewalks.

Atlantis' crew of five astronauts will be the second group of visitors to come aboard Alpha since station commander Bill Shepherd and his two Russian crewmates began their four-month mission on the station on November 2 last year.

Shepherd, a US Navy officer, welcomed the crew of the space shuttle Endeavor in December. They were greeted as if boarding a ship at sea, with the astronauts requesting permission to enter.

"We'll probably stay away from naval tradition. I might get tripped up," said shuttle commander Kenneth Cockrell, who resigned his naval commission in 1987.

"I think it's just going to be big smiles and happy, joyous laughter going on among the eight of us."

After the two crews meet, they will transfer various supplies from the shuttle to the space station, including food, water, computers and some outfitting equipment such as computer hard drives and cables needed to activate Destiny when it is mounted onto Alpha.

Besides being a hub for science research, Destiny will provide a fourth room for the three men living aboard the space station.

Atlantis' astronauts spent their first full day in orbit on Thursday checking their spacesuits and the shuttle robot arm, in preparation for Saturday's spacewalk.

Destiny will enable astronauts and cosmonauts to begin major science work aboard the space station, although not for a while. No experiments are flying inside the lab because the shuttle cannot handle the additional weight; the first one is due to arrive in March.

Experiments will involve fluids, metals, semiconductors, flames, plants and even the astronauts and cosmonauts themselves. Nasa wants to learn more about the effects of radiation and weightlessness on the human body before it sends anyone to Mars.

fields.headline: Rivals slam 'anti-competitive' BT Openworld
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: A row has broken out between BT and its rivals over ADSL installation, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
A row has broken out between BT and rival internet service providers over alleged anti-competitive practices.

Freeserve and AOL Time Warner are threatening legal action, claiming BT gives unfair preference to its own broadband service when it sends engineers to install ADSL lines.

Companies that want to offer ADSL have to buy the service wholesale from BT.

But Freeserve, Britain's biggest ISP with more than 2m subscribers, has complained that BT Ignite, the division of BT that sells the ADSL lines, only allowed engineers to make 16 installations a day.

In contrast, BT Openworld, the consumer broadband division of BT, is connecting up to 2,000 subscribers to ADSL a week.

AOL's and Freeserve's gripe is that these figures show the supposed level playing field is heavily sloped in BT Openworld's favour.

"BT's revelation is a shocking admission," said Freeserve chief executive John Pluthero.

"It is institutionally restricting the market share of Freeserve and other competing broadband providers.

"At the current pathetic levels of allocation granted to us by BT, it would take us three to four years to get to where BT Openworld says it is today.

"UK consumers would be thoroughly justified in demanding the resignation of the entire BT board."

AOL Spokesman Matt Peacock said: "If these reports [of the rate of Openworld connections] are true, one of the options will be substantial and immediate legal action against BT."

But BT is claiming the complaints are merely "sour grapes".

"I will be amazed if this threat of legal action comes to anything - it is Freeserve and AOL playing their usual games," said a BT spokesman.

Oftel, the industry regulator, said it was taking the complaints seriously and investigating the matter.

From this summer, BT will have to open up its local exchanges to enable competitors to offer their own version of ADSL.

However, this "unbundling" process has hit a number of snags.

Countless operators have pulled out, citing unreasonable behaviour by BT and insurmountable costs.

fields.body:
ITV is expected to be allowed to scale back key public service television obligations once the new communications act comes into force.

BBC director general Greg Dyke has confirmed an increased spend of £450m on programming and services by the end of 2003.

BBC Radio networks look set to exceed their 10% voluntary targets for indie productions in the next financial year.

Channel 5 has finally completed a multimillion pound movie deal with Warner Bros.

The designer of TiVo is having to reprogramme the service to respond to an increase in last-minute scheduling changes by the BBC and ITV.

Endemol Entertainment UK creative director Peter Bazalgette is stepping up his bid to gain back indie status for his company.

fields.headline: Beefing about freedom of information
fields.standfirst: Lord Phillips' inquiry into the BSE crisis has reiterated that Labour has fallen prey to that most governmental of foibles, a love of secrecy, says David McKie
fields.trailText: Lord Phillips' inquiry into the BSE crisis has reiterated that Labour has fallen prey to that most governmental of foibles, a love of secrecy, says David McKie.
fields.body:
The BSE crisis and the subsequent problems over CJD would have been grievous at any time, but one clear conclusion of Lord Phillips' inquiry into the issue was that characteristic Whitehall secrecy, the disposition to hide the truth and hope that the issue would go away, made things far worse.

That finding, on all past performance, will be warmly endorsed by both sides of the Commons. Whether it will have any lasting effect is an utterly different matter. Most oppositions come into office pledging themselves to end the culture of secrecy. Most governments, once their feet are under the table and they start accruing secrets they want to hide, begin backtracking.

John Major, to do him justice, did more than most, introducing a code of practice which, while falling well short of open government in the generally accepted sense, removed some at least of the wrappings in which ministers and civil servants like to shroud themselves.

Labour, in opposition, condemned the code as no more than a dipping of toes into a turbulent ocean. They echoed and endorsed the findings of the Scott report into arms sales to Iraq, which diagnosed the climate excessive secrecy as an essential part of the scandal.

As the party's 1997 manifesto put it: "Unnecessary secrecy in government leads to arrogance in government and defective decisions. The Scott report to Iraq revealed Conservative abuses of power. We are pledged to a Freedom of Information Act leading to more open government."

But that, again, was before their feet were under the table. Once they were in, perceptions began to change. The first draft for their Freedom of Information bill was a disappointment; the bill itself was worse.

Maurice Frankel, director of the Freedom of Information Campaign, examined it in the light of the Scott report and concluded that John Major's code afforded a better defence against such clandestine malpractices than this bill would do.

Some Labour MPs, in line with Scott's specific recommendation that MPs should put up more of a fight for openness, attacked the bill and wrung concessions out of its progenitor, the home secretary, Jack Straw. But a wholesale battering down of old tradition-encrusted walls this legislation is not.

It fails an essential philosophical test. True freedom of information starts with the principle that the public has an inherent right to know what is being done in its name, which can only be curtailed when curtailment can be demonstrated to serve the public interest.

Labour's version works the other way round. It makes some gracious and not insubstantial concessions to make operations more open. But these in the end are sops from the great men's table - not the fruits of a principled conversion to openness as a right.

The secrecy which the Phillips report identified belongs, like Scott, to the Tory years. The essential question to be asked as this government responds to the findings is whether things would have been all that different under Labour .

That is doubtful indeed. One only has to look at the way the Ministry of Defence initially handled the issues of depleted uranium to suggest that secrecy - coupled with obfuscation - remains an irresistible addiction to government.

Even though, as the MoD exercise shows, it is often counterproductive. So often it comes unstuck in the end; the effect on public opinion is more damaging when they finally have to own up than it would have been had they confessed in the first place.

Labour is hardly likely to pay an electoral price for defaulting on its commitment to tear down the walls of secrecy. But disillusion with government and with politics as a profession is deepened with every episode in this sad old story.

fields.headline: Dale Evans
fields.standfirst: Sporting an outfit of fringes, satins and studs, she was the Queen to Roy Rogers, 'King of the Cowboys'
fields.trailText: Sporting an outfit of fringes, satins and studs, she was the Queen to Roy Rogers, 'King of the Cowboys'.
fields.body:
Dale Evans, who has died aged 88, was most famous for being married to singing cowboy star Roy Rogers, but was an accomplished performer and personality in her own right. In fact, it was she who wrote their famous theme song Happy Trails To You, and introduced Rogers to God.

Happy Trails was written in 1950, while Evans was preparing for a radio show. She decided Rogers needed a theme song and since he signed all his autographs with Trails of Happiness or Happy Trails, the title came easily.

Evans scribbled the lyrics down on an envelope and taught the melody to Rogers and the Sons of the Pioneers 40 minutes before show time.

As for God. .. Rogers explained: "It began one day when Dale shared a new excitement with me: 'I've just made the greatest decision of my life. Today I dedicated my life to Jesus Christ. It's wonderful,' she told me. I could see the change in Dale but didn't understand her new joy. Finally, one Sunday morning, Dale was preparing to take the children to church. I came downstairs and informed her, 'If you're going to church, I am going with you.' As we sat in the service I bowed my head for a long time, thinking about the decision I should make. Then I sat up and turned to Dale. 'Mama, I'm going to accept Jesus Christ as my saviour.'"

This decision dictated the rest of their lives together until Rogers died in July 1998. Married in 1947, they raised nine children: two by his previous marriage, one by hers, one of their own, four by adoption and one fostered. Three of them died young, including their own daughter, who suffered from Down's syndrome.

In 1953, Evans published Angel Unaware, in which she described the bringing up of the child, intending to give hope to other parents in a similar position. Among her other "inspirational" books was Say Yes to Tomorrow, in which she explained how several familiar Bible stories related to her own experiences.

Born Frances Octavia Smith in Uvalde, Texas, Dale Evans spent her teen years in Arkansas, where she was married at 16 and widowed at 17. To earn a living and support her baby son, she worked as a stenographer for an insurance company, before getting a job as nightclub vocalist with the Anson Weeks Orchestra, as well as appearing on numerous radio programmes, with a regular spot on the CBS News and Rhythm Show. In 1941, after a brief marriage to Dale Butts, a musician, Evans applied to Paramount for a part opposite Bing Crosby in Holiday Inn. She didn't get it, but her screen test was seen at 20th Century-Fox, who gave her a year's contract. After a couple of bit parts in films, including Orchestra Wives (1942), in which she was billed merely as "Girl at Soda Fountain", Evans was offered bigger roles at Republic Pictures, when a producer there heard her on the Edgar Bergen Radio Show. At Republic, she was cast opposite Roy Rogers in The Cowboy and the Senorita (1943).

Wearing an outfit of fringes, satins and studs that matched her husband sartorially, she became Queen to his "King of the Cowboys" in a further 25 B-Westerns, he on his horse Trigger, and she on Buttermilk, her bright personality counterbalancing his rather staid nature.

Most of the films had titles derived from songs featured in them: The Yellow Rose of Texas (1944), Don't Fence Me In (1945), Belles of Rosarita (1945), Apache Rose (1947), and interchangeable plots in which Rogers usually helped Evans overcome baddies while singing his way into her heart. She once said that her favourite role was the newspaperwoman in Don't Fence Me In, a rare departure from "the namby-pamby heroines who just stand around while men do violent and admirable things".

webTitle: MTV signs Klum for supermodel finale

fields.headline: MTV signs Klum for supermodel finale
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: MTV has signed Heidi Klum to present the finale of a Europe-wide talent hunt for new supermodels, writes Jessica Hodgson
fields.body:
Heidi Klum has been signed by MTV to present the grand finale of a Europe-wide talent hunt for new supermodels.

Ms Klum, touted as one of the rising stars of the new generation of supermodels, will present a live special when judges announce the winner of the competition, which will take place in Milan in April.

Judging will begin next month in Dublin, and judges will trawl Europe for new modelling talent.

And the grand finale, called MTV Fashionably Loud Europe, will show the results of the search.

Signing Ms Klum, who has been a model for lingerie label Victoria's Secret and appeared alongside Michael J Fox in the sitcom Spin City, is a coup for MTV.

fields.headline: NBC orders 13-part series of Weakest Link
fields.trailText: 12pm: The BBC has secured its first quiz show commission from a US network, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The BBC has secured its first quiz show commission from a US network, with a series order from NBC for the Weakest Link.

And in another first, the US version of the show is to be fronted by UK host Anne Robinson.

NBC has ordered 13 episodes of the Weakest Link, which will go into production in the US next month and begin transmission in April.

The US broadcaster is also planning a second version of the hit BBC2 quiz show for the lucrative syndication market.

BBC Worldwide, the corporation's commercial arm, is now on track to earn up to £30m in the next few years from overseas sales of the Weakest Link format.

An Australian version is already on air on the Seven Network.

Worldwide has sold the format to broadcasters in 10 other countries and is negotiating deals in another 14 territories.

fields.headline: Betinternet boosts turnover by 103%
fields.trailText: 11.30am: The Isle of Man-based gambling site's turnover has reached £24m, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Betinternet.com has demonstrated the money-spinning potential of online gambling by posting a massive rise in revenues.

The Isle of Man-based company only runs a telephone operation in the UK because of legal restrictions.

However, it can target online customers on the European mainland and in the Asia Pacific region.

Betinternet said turnover for the six months to November 2000 was £23.8m, a 103% rise on the previous 12 months.

"Today's results show betinternet is well placed amongst its competitors.

"Each month we are seeing a significant increase in new internet customers," said Vincent Caldwell, chairman of betinternet.

Mr Caldwell said the far eastern market offered exciting opportunities for the company.

Japan and South Korea will host the World Cup in 2002.

"We are attracting significant numbers of new customers from the Asia region," said Mr Caldwell.

"We are particularly excited by the prospect of the 2002 World Cup in Japan and Korea - an event and a region where betting is incredibly popular."

However, betinternet's bottom line is suffering while the company expands.

Losses increased from just over £1m to £1.46m as a result of rising technology and marketing costs.

The dot.com focuses on sports with international appeal, such as formula one, golf and soccer.

European internet gambling revenues are expected to rocket from £138m in 1998 to £2bn by 2002.

Meanwhile, arch-rival Firststake.com today called in receivers, putting 30 jobs under threat.

fields.headline: Merchandising blitz backs Mr Bean
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Children could soon be playing interactive games starring the soon-to-be-animated Mr Bean, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Move over Lara Croft. Children could soon be playing interactive games starring a very different character - Mr Bean.

The new Mr Bean animated cartoon series due to go out on ITV later this year will be supported with a range of merchandise including computer games, confectionery, clothing, soft toys, books and stationery.

Entertainment Rights, the intellectual property rights group which specialises in children's programming, has secured the UK licensing and merchandising rights for the new series, which is being produced by Tiger Aspect Productions.

Mr Bean is one of the best known comedy brand in the UK. The TV series holds the record of being UK television's all-time best selling video and the film, Mr Bean - The Ultimate Disaster Movie, grossed over $240m at the box office.

Entertainment Rights intends to capitalise on the success of the brand with plans for a comprehensive range of licensed products.

Rowan Atkinson will voice the 26-part cartoon series which has been created with the help of Richard Curtis, Mr Bean co-creator and writer of Notting Hill and the Vicar of Dibley.

The star of the live-action series is being filmed for each new 30-minute show so the animators can replicate Atkinson's unique movements for the cartoon Mr Bean. As with the original series, the animated version will have little dialogue.

Relevant story

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate | Quick bites | On the menu
fields.body:
Cheapskate Where to eat out for under £15

The Gallery Restaurant and Millsy's Cafe Bar 20 Earlsdon Street, Coventry Tel: 024-7671 3222

This former newsagent's in the prosperous suburb of Earlsdon is a classy joint where it's just possible to tuck away a two-course dinner for £15, including Cajun spiced fishcakes, avocado salsa and cucumber relish; mille feuille of aubergine, red pepper and forest mushrooms with a garlic and watercress puree. For dyed-in-the-wool guzzlers there are the light lunchtime meals in the cafe-bar downstairs. Choices range from bangers and mash with onion gravy to bruschetta with caramelised smoked haddock, spiced scrambled eggs and herb cream sauce, at £4.95 each. House wines: £8.95 a bottle.

Quick bites Where to eat out in 15 minutes

Browns Cafe Bar and Restaurant Earl Street, Coventry Tel: 024-7622 1100

Another beacon of local family enterprise. Set in a - what shall we say? - distinctive modern building which almost backs on to the ruins of the old cathedral. The food is robust, aims for the big flavour and is excellent value for money. For a fiver you can have three vegetables, roast, garlicky or new potatoes and a substantial portion of the many meat, fish or vegetarian choices available - lamb in yogurt with spiced aubergines or with leeks and a creamy mustard sauce; Thai fish cakes and cajun salmon; and up to 14 vegetarian options. Full English breakfasts from 9am. Other meals from noon until closing time which, on Fridays and Saturdays, is 1am. No under-18s.

On the menu: White chocolate

Ooh, my favourite. Sweet and sexy. Only it isn't really chocolate at all. Come again.

It's not proper chocolate, according to some of the experts. An improper chocolate, perhaps?

Not chocolate at all. What is it then?

A bit of cocoa butter, a few milk solids, a whole heap of sugar and a splash of flavourings. And why doesn't that add up to chocolate?

Because it has no chocolate mass. Chocolate mass?

What's left when you mash cocoa beans after roasting them. It gives the real choco kick. Spoil sport. You won't be my Valentine.

On the net: Deliverance

There's just something about flaky pastry on the eiderdown which ensures that few things rival patisserie in bed for fuelling the passions and firing the loins. You barely need to leave your bedchamber this Valentine's Day, for deliverance.co.uk will convey mini croissants, pain au chocolat, tarte aux fraises, jam, smoked salmon, apple and orange juice, chocolate truffles, filter coffee and, of course, a red rose, direct to your door, for a mere £28.50. And for a further £9.50, they will also include a quarter bottle of chilled Moët et Chandon. Breakfast is served between 7.30am and 11.30am. Alas, this marvellous service is only available in central London.

Just out: Waitrose organic lemon juice

Form: cloudy yellowy grey liquid.

Flavour: strong, lemon essence smell; essential oil from skin dominates flavour, which is sharp and distinct.

Verdict: As always seems to be the case with organic gear, the juice is taken from lemons grown in the traditional way by some fiercely proud artisan producer (in this case Giovanni Saputo, of Carini in northern Sicily). Actually, this is high-octane stuff and a useful standby if you run out of the real thing. It's slightly more aggressive and less purely fruity than if you squeeze your own. Get a bottle in for Shrove Tuesday (February 27) or use in dressings, ceviche, etc.

Price: 89p for 250ml.

The taste test: champagne

I know that fizz from various parts of the world can give champagne a run for its money, but when it comes to romance, for St Valentine's Day, then nothing quite has the cachet of la vrai chose.

webTitle: In brief: Salman Rushdie - the new Humphrey Bogart?

fields.headline: Salman Rushdie - the new Humphrey Bogart?
fields.standfirst: Plus: Film Council keen to fund Altman's Brit pic
fields.trailText: Plus: Film Council keen to fund Altman's Brit pic
fields.body:
 Salman Rushdie wants to be an actor. According to peoplenews, the novelist is looking for more bit-part roles after his cameo appearance in the upcoming Bridget Jones film (where, not stretching himself too much, he plays himself). "Salman accepts that he'll only ever get cameos," a friend is quoted as saying. "But in his heart he'd like to play the Humphrey Bogart character in a remake of The Maltese Falcon."

 First London-based Capitol Films agreed to put money into Robert Altman's first film set in Britain (see earlier story), now it looks as if The Film Council is also keen to bring the great American maverick across the Atlantic. According to Screen Daily, the body is negotiating to help fund the 1930s satire, Gosford Park, as its first high profile UK-US collaboration. The movie would be the first to receive the greenlight from Robert Jones, head of the Film Council's commercial-oriented production wing, the Premiere Fund. Altman wants to secure an ensemble cast of leading British talent, including, naturally, Jude Law, as well as Kristin Scott Thomas, Emily Watson, Helen Mirren and Jeremy Northam.
