fields.headline: Beeb.com makes phantom offer
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Senior staff working at Beeb.com, the BBC's commercial online venture, have been offered 'phantom' share options in the business. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Senior staff working at Beeb.com, the BBC's commercial online venture, have been offered "phantom" share options in the business.

A spokeswoman for BBC Worldwide, which houses the corporation's commercial arm, confirmed that a handful of people working for the venture have been given the opportunity for significant payouts from the plan. In return, staff joining the controversial scheme are being forced to give up their right to BBC benefits including the corporation's pension scheme.

The plan is a jolt to traditional thinking in the corporation and reflects the willingness at the BBC to take an increasingly commercial approach. The value of the awards will be determined according to "growth in the valuation" of the business. Because it is a private company, the valuation will be determined at certain dates by independent analysts.

The BBC has not ruled out a stock market flotation of Beeb Ventures, which owns Beeb.com, potentially turning the phantom options into the real thing. The spokeswoman said the incentive plan was intended "to attract the best possible people" to the company. "Beeb Ventures needs to be in tune with the marketplace," she said.

Some staff are known to be nervous about accepting the plan, given the shaken confidence in the internet sector. The BBC opened the way to a flotation of Beeb.com last year when it sold a 13.5% stake in the business to a US venture capital firm for £32.5m. The agreement valued the business at £240m.

The US firm, TH Lee Global Internet Managers, would typically look to recoup its investment within three to five years through a flotation but the move in this case would need approval from the BBC's board of governors and the government. The incentives are confined to the commercial venture and do not affect employees of the licence fee-funded news and sports services.

Beeb.com, originally a website focused on the sale of merchandise related to programming, was relaunched in autumn last year with a £7m marketing campaign including a two-month roadshow. The service was repositioned as a guide to shopping on the internet, utilising the trust the public has in the BBC brand. The portal has a series of sites based around BBC brands including Top of the Pops and Gardeners' World which, in the case of the former, provide links to online retailers of CDs, books, videos and tickets.

Beeb.com has a growing number of commercial partners and takes a cut from sales as well as banner advertising. Profits, along with the rest of the money made by BBC Worldwide is channelled back into the corporation to pay for programming.

The relaunch of Beeb.com has attracted fierce criticism from other commercial websites which feel the BBC is over-reaching its remit. Although not funded by the licence fee, they argue that public money has built the programme brands on which it is based. The online operations of the BBC have been at the sharp end of the corporation's more commercial approach. It is now planning the launch of an international version of its online news service which will also carry advertising.

The service was repositioned as a guide to shopping on the internet, utilising the trust the public has in the BBC brand. The portal has a series of sites based around BBC brands including Top of the Pops and Gardeners' World which, in the case of the former, provide links to online retailers of CDs, books, videos and tickets. Beeb.com has a growing number of commercial partners and takes a cut from sales as well as banner advertising. Profits, along with the rest of the money made by BBC Worldwide is channelled back into the corporation to pay for programming. The relaunch of Beeb.com has attracted fierce criticism from other commercial websites which feel the BBC is over-reaching its remit. Although not funded by the licence fee, they argue that public money has built the programme brands on which it is based. The online operations of the BBC have been at the sharp end of the corporation's more commercial approach. It is now planning the launch of an international version of its online news service which will also carry advertising.

fields.headline: Shortcuts
fields.trailText: Oversubscribed: Autograph shoes | Overheard: 'WML' | Pretend you know all about: In Style UK
fields.body:
Oversubscribed: Autograph shoes

Why do high-street shoe designers insist on those ugly, squared-off toes? Where will this madness end?

The answer lies at dear old Marks and Spencer. In its Autograph shoe collection for this season, it has picked up on the fact that sexy, dainty, curved shoes are far more elegant and upmarket looking than their chunky, squared-off counterparts.

Even better, their shoes are bang on the, er, toe this season. Styles such as the open-toed high-heel thong, for example, bear a remarkable resemblance to those seen in the collections by Gina and Bottega Veneta.

For those who prefer style to fashion, there is a stiletto sandal with ankle strap and an ultra-low mule, which is lovely and delicate. These are shoes which look as if they come from Bond Street, not the high street. Incredibly, the designer behind this collection is not one of the high-profile names from the Autograph stable (such as Hussein Chalayan and Julien Macdonald), but the Autograph in-house designer, Lisa Supple.

The range is not available until the end of February, but any of the red shoes would make a perfect, belated Valentine's gift. Worth hinting for, and worth waiting for.

 Stockist enquiries number: 020-7268 1234. Prices £75-£165

Overheard: 'WML'

This is for all you anti-Valentiners out there. This abbreviation, which must be uttered with a Clueless-like lilt, stands for "Whatever, major loser" and should be accompanied by appropriate finger gestures spelling out the letters. "I can't believe he didn't even get me a card this year! WML!"

Pretend you know all about: In Style UK

It is the addictive American magazine that fashion hates to love, and it is coming to Britain. In Style, chronicler of all matters trivial, first appeared in the US seven years ago, instructing an enthralled public as to whether it's OK to wear leather trousers with leather shoes ("You should!"), and why Dawson's Creek's Katie Holmes loves Giorgio Armani ("I love his clothes").

Higher brow magazines sneered, until they noticed the sales: the current circulation is 1.5m. Typical contents might be where to go for an eyelash extension, and a tour through David Copperfield's penthouse. In other words, think Hello! crossed with Through the Keyhole, with a little fashion advice on top - and, darn it, that's why we love it.

We love it so much that many Britons have been forking out £3 a month to subscribe to the US edition. But we will no longer have to make do with exfoliating tips from unknown American celebrities - we can get them from our own stars because In Style UK goes on sale next Friday. At last, we can learn how Martine McCutcheon arranges her scented candles and where Nicola Formby buys her quilted eiderdowns. Stop laughing - you know you'll read it.

fields.headline: Martin Clunes realigns his mojo
fields.standfirst: Martin Clunes's coffee advert may try to lay to rest his Man Behaving Badly persona, but it will take more than a soothing mug of Nescafe to alter his horsey Sagittarian style.
fields.trailText: February 9: Maggie Hyde tells us it will take more than a soothing mug of Nescafe to alter Martin Clunes' horsey Sagittarian style.
fields.body:
Martin Clunes' current coffee advert may try to lay to rest his Man Behaving Badly persona, but it will take more than a soothing mug of Nescafe to alter his horsey Sagittarian style.

Clunes's horoscope (November 28 1961) shows the Sagittarian Archer at his best, a good-natured, larger-than-life character, an inherently funny clown who can bellow and fart and laugh at himself, like fellow Sagittarian Billy Connolly.

Clunes also has macho Mars in this sign, bringing out the lustful drives of the Centaur, and this planet is most associated with Clunes's acting success.

In private, he's a proud Dad and a dab hand at DIY, and since the success of Men Behaving Badly in the early 90s, Clunes has shot various Sagittarian arrows towards serious acting and directing in an attempt to escape the lager-lout image.

A strong touch of classic Capricorn in his horoscope no doubt gives him yearnings for something more substantial, but even in Shakespeare In Love, it's the large codpiece we remember, and his 1999 drama Sex 'n'Death brought together the raunchy and the religious side of Sagittarius with images of female sectarian mud wrestling and a mock crucifixion.

In Clunes's horoscope, the bad lad shows as a close square of Mars to defiant Pluto.

This often indicates "someone not at all in touch with the effect they have on others" and "there is often a wide discrepancy between how they experience themselves and how they come across to others. This discrepancy creates havoc in all their relating." (Love & Sexuality, Babs Kirby & Janey Stubbs).

Whatever aspirations Clunes may have for a change of image, he is still lumbered with Men Behaving Badly, and even the coffee advert plays on the same theme. This year, progressed Mars and Pluto are bringing the bad lad back again.

It is magical totem, the secret of his power, and rather than trying to suppress it, he should run with it and make further provocative attempts to realign his mojo.

PS: What exactly is a mojo? (a) a magic charm, spell or influence. (b) any un-named object: a thingummy. The word can be used for anything, but is characteristically employed for sex organs or drugs.

webTitle: Jane Fonda denies she plans return to acting

fields.headline: Jane Fonda denies she plans return to acting
fields.trailText: The legendary double Oscar winner says that an appearance on the New York stage does not signal a return to acting
fields.body:
A year after splitting up from media mogul Ted Turner, Jane Fonda says that there is no chance of her resuming her acting career. According to Reuters, Fonda, 63, has told Barbara Walters, who hosts 20/20 on ABC television, that there is no reason to go back to acting.

In the interview, to be screened today in the United States, Fonda, a two-time Oscar winner, says that although she appeared in the New York production of the Vagina Monologues, it was "absolutely not" the start of a renewed acting career.

"I am so happy and so productive," she tells Walters. "And my mind is free to go into new kinds of places. And showing up on a set - I mean it's like - no movie part would ever be as interesting as my life. And so, why go back?"

After her successful acting career, she garnered much publicity for her work-out videos in the 1980s. However, she says that she has now largely given up exercise and is writing a book about her days as an anti-war activist. Fonda, who gave up acting when she married Turner in 1991, says that the couple remain close.

fields.headline: Unilever pioneers interactive adverts on ITV
fields.trailText: 11am: Unilever has linked up with Carlton to run the first interactive commercials on ITV, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Unilever is to be the first advertiser to run interactive commercials on ITV as part of a deal with Carlton.

A campaign for two Unilever brands - Colman's sauces and Olivio spread - will break on March 1 and run for 10 days.

Digital terrestrial TV viewers will be able to click on a strap that appears the bottom of the screen.

This will take them to the interactive part of the advert, which will include special offers and product information.

The commercial will then reduce in size to a quarter of the screen so the viewer can watch TV programmes at the same time as looking at the advertising.

"These interactive commercials are a fantastic way of connecting a TV message directly to a trial offer," said Natasha Bell, brand activation manager at Unilever.

"They also offer an extra level of interest. By providing extra information on the brands, the medium, in effect, turns a 30-second commercial into a 10-minute one."

The adverts were produced by Ogilvy and Carlton Active, Carlton's interactive TV sales and production facility.

The campaign was planned and bought by Initiative Media, which arranged the deal with ITV.

"Unilever is prepared to invest in learning new techniques in a medium that has reinvented itself," said Richard Baker, head of interactive TV at Initiative.

"The prospect of selling the benefits of the brand at such proximity to the TV ad is truly exciting."

fields.headline: Why we hate February
fields.standfirst: The dullest, wettest, cruellest month is upon us. Oh well, at least it's short. Here's our guide to February - with the best links
fields.trailText:
The dullest, wettest, cruellest month is upon us. Oh well, at least it's short. Here's our guide to February - with the best links.

More NetNotes
fields.body:
1. The January sales are over, and February is credit card bill payback time. So you're skint as well.

2. You've broken all your new year's resolutions and it's 10 months until you can make new ones.

3. February can change its length. So monthly public transport passes are more expensive during February than in any other month.

4. Unless involved in a loving relationship, the only role of Valentine's Day is to act as a depressing reminder of loves lost, cheated on and foolishly dumped when you were drunk.

5. Then there's the weather. The snow and rain is expected to continue until - yes, you guessed it - the end of the month.

6. There's not much on telly. Noel from Popstars will continue to give Wales a bad rep by laughing like an idiot at the slightest thing. Now there's a boy who's a few groupies short of an orgy.

7. The election campaign has started. Cue more arguments about the euro. Yawn.

8. Your favourite football team has a much higher chance of being knocked out of the FA Cup. Forget about the league - Manchester United have already won it.

9. All in all, February is really boring. Oh well, at least there's no 29th this year.

10. But don't despair. If you're really bored you could always go back to work.

fields.headline: HIT confirms £190m Barney deal
fields.trailText:
10.15am: Bob the Builder creator HIT Entertainment has confirmed its takeover of Lyrick Corporation, writes Dan Milmo.
Feb 8: Bob buys Barney
Feb 1: Hit suspends shares
fields.body:
Bob the Builder creator HIT Entertainment has confirmed its £190m takeover of Lyrick Corporation, home of Barney the Dinosaur.

The UK-based company hopes the deal will give it much needed overseas success.

HIT relies heavily on Bob the Builder and realises it needs to strengthen its portfolio.

"While we will be assisted in extending our existing brands into the US, we will also be able to position Barney as a global brand," said Peter Orton, chief executive of HIT.

"This deal positions HIT as arguably one of the leaders in world pre-school programming."

Barney is one of the best known children's characters in the US, having sold more than 55m videos and 68m books to parents and children.

"HIT is a wonderful company, which espouses the same values as we do - creating quality programmes for the pre-school market," said Dick Leach, founder of Lyrick.

Both companies have reached a conditional agreement on the deal, which is expected to go through early next month.

HIT will also use its new-found access to the US market to launch its lesser known characters, such as Kipper and Angelina Ballerina.

Before the Lyrick acquisition, HIT had already signed a licensing deal with toymaker Mattel.

It had also sold a package of Bob the Builder programmes to children's channel Nickelodeon.

Analysts say a breakthrough in the US market is vital if the company is to boost its shares beyond their current level of 440p.

webTitle: JWT names Simon Bolton chief executive

fields.headline: JWT names Simon Bolton chief executive
fields.trailText: 9.15am: J Walter Thompson has ended months of speculation by naming Simon Bolton as its UK chief executive. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
J Walter Thompson has finally ended months of speculation by naming Simon Bolton as its UK chief executive.

He replaces Stephen Carter, who left last year to join JWT client NTL as chief operating officer.

The British-born Mr Bolton, who is chief executive of FCB in San Francisco, was widely expected to get the job after talks with numerous other outside candidates broke down.

"Simon is a premier addition to our UK management team," said Michael Madel, president and chief executive of JWT Europe.

"He has excelled at building leading brands using the full spectrum of communications channels.

"He brings energy, passion and an ability to connect with clients and colleagues alike to deliver highly creative business solutions.

"We're confident he will accelerate the growth momentum our agency has achieved in recent years."

Mr Bolton added: "It is a tremendous honour to lead JWT UK and I accept this exciting challenge with pride.

"JWT has achieved prominence for more than a century helping to launch, sustain and renew many of the world's great brands."

Mr Bolton began his career at Ogivly & Mather London as a graduate trainee. He later moved to FCB and has held the posts of regional director of FCB Asia and managing director of FCB Malaysia.

fields.headline: Class rebels silenced as teacher gives the answers
fields.trailText: There are lies, damned lies and David Blunkett's statistics.   The education secretary yesterday shouted out more numbers over 50 minutes than a bingo caller going for the record at a PTA do to raise funds for a new classroom.
fields.body:
There are lies, damned lies and David Blunkett's statistics. The education secretary yesterday shouted out more numbers over 50 minutes than a bingo caller going for the record at a PTA do to raise funds for a new classroom.

There was 2% of this, £31,000 of that, 2,200 of another and point one of 1% of something in secondary schools that nobody seemed to catch.

Never before had the pupils of Westminster Comp (term ends on May 3) been bombarded with so many figures so few could understand.

Never forgetting his Sheffield municipal roots, Mr Blunkett made the lesson harder to follow by slipping into town hall bureaucrat speak with "uplifts" replacing increases. Nor, unlike some of his former colleagues (that's you, young Mandelson), has he been seduced by the bright lights of London.

"I'm always up for a trip to Scarborough," he told a surprised MP, "preferably when the weather is a lot better and the crabs are freshly in from the sea."

Given the quality of the Conservative opposition, Mr Blunkett could just as easily answer questions from a deckchair overlooking the resort's North bay with a hankie on his head. His opposite number, Theresa May, a large silver patch leaving her looking as if she's accidentally rubbed against the blackboard, accused him of breathtaking hypocrisy and getting his figures wrong.

Playground name calling had him accusing her of ranting like Arthur Scargill, which was ridiculous. Mr Scargill has too little hair to tint. Parliamentary tradition had been broken on Wednesday when Tony Blair gave a straight answer to a straight question on the single currency. MPs are unsure who was more shocked; Mr Blair who said it, or William Hague who heard it.

But lightning never strikes twice. Until yesterday and the strange case of university tuition fees. David Heath, a Liberal Democrat who enjoys a spot of pig breeding in his spare time, took a leaf out of the Hague book of political tactics, a very slim volume previously thought to be out of print.

"Can he categorically rule out top-up fees for the lifetime of the next parliament," he pressed Mr Blunkett. "That question has only two possible answers. Yes or no?" Mr Blunkett paused, rambled on, then thought if it was good enough for the PM, it was good enough for him.

"In the next parliament there will be no levying of top-up fees if we win the next election," he said. No ifs, no buts, just no. Hapless Mr Heath looked as if he had unjustly been given 200 lines rather than a prize as he slumped dejectedly on the green bench.

Step forward the chubby shape of Timmy Boswell, the Billy Bunter of the Tory front bench. Timmy had done his homework for an evasive answer and, though on his feet, was unable to think on them. Doing a decent imitation of a Scarborough crab flipped on its back by Mr Blunkett, Timmy waved his arms like a pair of blunted claws as he tried to pretend he had not heard the answer.

Where will this Labour honesty trip end? Gordon Brown admitting taxes have gone up? Alan Milburn you might have to go private? John Prescott on how he's failed? Derry Irvine that, yes, that wallpaper was a little on the pricey side?

As MPs pondered the imponderable, the government was back on course two hours later in the House of Lords where Charlie Falconer, the First Flatmate of the Blair government, suggested without any trace of irony that Alastair Campbell was a model public servant. Perhaps Lord Falconer was anxious not to end up like Peter Mandelson.

Doing a decent imitation of a Scarborough crab flipped on its back by Mr Blunkett, Timmy waved his arms like a pair of blunted claws as he tried to pretend he had not heard the answer. Where will this Labour honesty trip end? Gordon Brown admitting taxes have gone up? Alan Milburn you might have to go private? John Prescott on how he's failed? Derry Irvine that, yes, that wallpaper was a little on the pricey side? As MPs pondered the imponderable, the government was back on course two hours later in the House of Lords where Charlie Falconer, the First Flatmate of the Blair government, suggested without any trace of irony that Alastair Campbell was a model public servant. Perhaps Lord Falconer was anxious not to end up like Peter Mandelson.

webTitle: Hannibal set for record opening in the US

fields.headline: Hannibal set for record opening in the US
fields.trailText: The sequel to The Silence of the Lambs is being given the widest release in the history of MGM for its opening weekend
fields.body:
Hannibal, which is released in the UK on February 16, is set to have one of the biggest opening weekends in American film history. The horror movie, starring Anthony Hopkins and Julianne Moore, can be seen in the United States from today in 3,230 locations on 4,900 screens.

According to Variety, the huge opening is also the widest in the history of MGM. "It's in the top five of all time (industrywide)," Variety quotes MGM Distribution President Larry Gleason as saying. "And it's because of the film and its perception in the marketplace as a big hit. Everybody would like to play it."

The World Is Not Enough, which opened in November 1999 with 3,100 engagements, is MGM's most profitable opening, but Gleason said he hopes that Hannibal will surpass the Bond film's $35.5m (£24.57m) opening weekend gross.

The sequel to The Silence of the Lambs is being trumpeted as the first "must see" movie of the year. Lambs, which grossed $277m (£191m) worldwide, also won Oscars for Best Film, Best Adapted Screenplay, Best Actor (Anthony Hopkins), Best Actress (Jodie Foster) and Best Director (Jonathan Demme).

fields.headline: Ministers confirm council secrecy concessions
fields.trailText: The government last night made key concessions on controversial council secrecy proposals, in order to head off an embarrassing defeat in the House of Lords.
fields.body:
The government last night made key concessions on controversial council secrecy proposals, in order to head off an embarrassing defeat in the House of Lords.

Regulations allowing council committees, operating under new "cabinet-style" structures, to meet in secret for all but "key" decisions will be reviewed next year, junior environment minister Lord Whitty announced.

He also said that the government would issue statutory guidance to local authorities about the circumstances in which committees can exclude the press and public.

The concessions were announced during Lords debate on the Local Authorities (Executive Arrangements) (Access to Information) (England) Regulations, which brought the new regime into force last month.

Tory and Liberal Democrat peers had threatened to reject the regulations if major concessions were not announced. But the two parties fell out over their parliamentary tactics, the Liberal Democrats prepared to accept concessions, the Tories hoping to wreck the regulations and maintain the status quo in which the vast majority of council meetings are held in public.

The Tory bid to reject the regulations failed by 63 votes to 116, giving a government majority of 53.

Under the government's original proposals, mayors and cabinets would be forced to meet in public only when they are taking so-called "key decisions", those which affect more than two wards or incur significant expenditure as defined by individual councils.

The government last night confirmed that it will forward a closer definition of which decisions are "key", and reviewing the regulations after their first year in operation in order to make them "more robust."

These changes would not necessarily mean scrapping the regulations, but could initially be done by amending government openness guidance.

If the regulations were scrapped, it could severely delay the introduction of new directly elected city mayors and Westminster-style council cabinets, as civil servants scramble to prepare new proposals.

webTitle: Opportunity knocks for Hartson as Coventry look for backbone

fields.headline: Opportunity knocks for Hartson as Coventry look for backbone
fields.standfirst: Jim charts the ups and downs that led from Luton to the Sky Blues
fields.trailText: Jim charts the ups and downs that led from Luton to the Sky Blues.
fields.body:
John Hartson must have felt like that girl in the Popstars television series, who took herself to every regional audition round the country in the desperate hope of eventually catching Nasty Nigel's eye and making it to the big time.

On four occasions in the past six months Hartson has been about to leave Wimbledon and return to top-flight football. And four times, with Tottenham, Rangers, Charlton and initially with Coventry, he failed the audition. He must have wondered if it was ever going to happen for him.

"The image he has on the field is not how he really is," says Jonathan Barnett, Hartson's agent. "Of course he has this tough, Welsh, manly exterior and he didn't want to show it but he was hurt by those set-backs. I was the one who had to break the news each time and I saw it in his face. I knew it hurt."

At last, yesterday, Hartson found himself back in the big time at least for the rest of this season. Coventry City at the moment hardly represent the safest of havens for a man whose stated intention is to play at the top level for the rest of his career. But for the past 30 months Hartson has been defined by failure: failed medicals, failed transfers, a failure to keep his foot out of range of hanging baskets outside pubs in Swansea. After that lot, anyone showing an interest is in danger of having his hand bitten off.

"What you have to remember, he is still only 25," says Barnett. "With respect, 25-year-old footballers are not the most worldly-wise creatures and I think most of them would have buckled under what John has gone through."

Certainly many a player would have torn his hair out; so at least he did not have that problem. The question is, given the baggage he carries with him, why would anyone want to sign Hartson at all?

The answer lies in his time at West Ham, after he had been bought from Arsenal for £5m towards the end of the 1996-97 season. Here, by scoring the goals that kept West Ham in the Premiership, he developed a reputation as a fire fighter, a man for a crisis, a man who relishes a challenge.

The following year he was the second highest scorer in the division, with 24 league goals, most of which were supplied by Eyal Berkovic. This was a nice irony as Hartson's Upton Park career was effectively finished the moment he was filmed kicking Berkovic in the head during a training session. When Wimbledon offered £7.5m for him soon after that incident, the great wheeler-dealer Harry Redknapp felt it a tidy bit of business for a player with a fragile temper. To complete the circle, his Coventry debut is likely to be Monday's encounter with the Hammers.

Despite the video evidence, Joe Kinnear, then Wimbledon manager, had no doubts in buying Hartson. Yes, he had a temper on him; yes, he behaved as if every referee was out to get him; but he was a player in the old Crazy Gang mode, a player Kinnear says "would put his head in the blades of a combine harvester if that's what it took to get a goal".

"He's a special talent," says Terry Burton, latterly his manager at Selhurst Park. Besides being big and strong, Burton applauds a remarkably shrewd touch and a fierce eye for a goal. "He is the best finisher I have ever worked with."

These are qualities which brought Hartson high-profile admirers. When he was Alex Ferguson's assistant, Brian Kidd thought him a better bet for Manchester United than Dwight Yorke, though to be fair Ferguson, in his autobiography, cites Kidd's affection for Hartson as a sign of his weakness as a potential manager: "Hartson: are you serious?" Ferguson splutters. "Do you really think of John Hartson as a Manchester United player?"

Maybe not but the thing about Hartson is that he is no Stan Collymore: his commitment is total. Some might say he tries too hard. In Wimbledon's last few days in the Premiership, when he came back from a long-term injury determined to effect a single-handed rescue, Hartson's snarling Welsh dragon act was as much a distraction as a benefit.

Against Bradford in a desperate match at the tail-end of last season, too much of his energy was wasted over-doing the Crazy Gang heritage; he was accused by Gunnar Halle of kneeing Stuart McCall in the tunnel before the match had started, though McCall declined to take action.

Hartson's agent feels he may have learned from that experience. That, plus the very disappointments he has been through, may have forged a more focused, more rational, though no less determined character. After all, he now has a big point to prove.

"He has a real inner strength," says Barnett. "He loves a challenge and the harder the challenge, the more he is up for it. But he has a family now, he is much more settled in his private life. I honestly believe Coventry will get the best out of him."

Certainly Craig Bellamy, his Welsh international colleague who is already at Highfield Road, cannot wait for him to be match fit. "He's an awesome talent," says Bellamy. "He strikes the ball brilliantly."

Even though he has not played since December and not scored since November, Hartson is a virtually risk-free signing for Coventry. In a time of simmering discontent in the stands they have bought an instant crowd favourite. Everyone loves a hard man when he is being hard for their side.

For a team who would latterly have wilted against a bunch of girl guides, they have bought instant backbone and, in an innovative pay-per-play deal, the club will fork out no more than £15,000 every time he pulls on a sky blue shirt. Twelve big performances between now and the end of the season will cost only £180,000 but could save millions in lost revenues.

"He wanted to play in the Premiership again and now he's back," says Barnett. "It's really down to him to make sure he is still there with Coventry next season."

webTitle: Part-time staff win backdated pensions fight

fields.headline: Part-time staff win backdated pensions fight
fields.trailText: Thousands of part-time public sector workers yesterday won pension rights dating back to 1976, in a House of Lords ruling which will cost employers billions of pounds.
fields.body:
Thousands of part-time public sector workers yesterday won pension rights dating back to 1976, in a House of Lords ruling which will cost employers billions of pounds.

The ruling will put further pressure on the already stretched finances of the NHS and local government, and could land them with an administrative headache as they attempt to process claims from former employees stretching back nearly a quarter of a century.

But many staff who could have claimed the rights - the majority of them women - will lose out because they failed to lodge claims for back-dated pensions within six months of leaving employment.

The victory marks the end of a long legal battle by six unions, backed by the TUC, to win part-timers the same rights to an occupational pension as full-time workers.

The TUC estimates that around 40,000 workers in the public and private sectors will be entitled to back-dated rights under the ruling, while a further 20,000 will be barred by the time limit. Estimates of the possible cost to employers range from £10bn to £17bn.

Employers hardest hit by the ruling include the NHS and local education authorities, which all employ large numbers of part-time workers, including nurses and ancillary staff such as cleaners and domestics.

Public sector union Unison, which has been a driving force behind the claim with around 10,000 members waiting for the ruling, welcomed the decision as "good news for some but not for all."

Unison general secretary Dave Prentis said: "It has been a long hard battle but we have won justice for pensioners at last. Many thousands of people can now make a succesful claim, and the decision will mean the difference between living on the poverty line and purchasing a decent pension to enjoy a more secure and comfortable retirement."

Unions won a ruling from the European court of justice in 1994 that excluding part-timers from pension schemes breached European law on equal pay.

Employers were forced to admit part-timers to schemes, but they argued that rights should be backdated only two years, in line with UK equal pay rules. The unions argued that employers should have to pay contributions back to 1976, the date European law first required equality in pensions.

The law lords yesterday upheld the union's argument on backdating, but decided against them on the time limits for lodging claims. The unions had sought a six-year limit, but the law lords ruled that only those who had filed claims within six months of leaving their jobs could qualify.

The TUC's general secretary, John Monks, said: "This is good news for thousands of retired workers, mainly women, who will now be able to receive the pension they have been denied. Justice has been won for the women who until today faced a very bleak retirement.

"Now they can look forward to old age, safe in the knowledge that they will be more financially secure. But the TUC is very disappointed that the Lords failed to listen to the union case for extending the current cut-off for making pension claims.

"Many women who logged pension claims against their employers more than six months after leaving work will now get nothing."

The law lords ruled claims could be made up to six months after the end of a "stable employment relationship", which could include a succession of regular short-term contracts.

The banking union UniFI said it was confident that 95% of its claims, covering 6,000 women, against 57 employers, would now be met. Cases will go on to employment tribunals for decisions on entitlement, probably in groups. Former nurses, for example, would go in one batch and teachers in another. Lawyers said it could take years before all claims were determined.

webTitle: Jeanette Winterson on the female orgasm

fields.headline: Advent of the orgasmatron
fields.standfirst: American doctors claim to have developed an electronic device that allows women to have an orgasm at the flick of a switch. So is it the end for the faked female climax? Not likely, says Jeanette Winterson, who fears using the new contraption could set off her car alarm. Meanwhile, Joan Smith asks why women are still so unhappy in bed
fields.trailText: American doctors claim to have developed an electronic device that allows women to have an orgasm at the flick of a switch. So is it the end for the faked female climax? Not likely, says Jeanette Winterson, who fears using the new contraption could set off her car alarm. Meanwhile, Joan Smith asks why women are still so unhappy in bed.
fields.body:
In the 19th century the non-orgasmic woman was considered normal. In the early 20th century she was re-marketed as frigid. In the 21st century, it's just a matter of electronics. Now that science and technology are going to solve all our problems, it's no surprise that the latest White Coat Wonder can turn any woman into a throbbing mass of pleasure at the touch of a button. Forget the vibrator. The egg whisk approach to orgasm is as out of date as the missionary position. Women who live in rural backwaters will no longer have to worry about power cuts. There will be no need for the Saturday-night dash down to the garage for a bottle of Blue Nun and "something for the weekend, madam?" - a packet of Duracell. What price a new invention that you can hide in your buttocks instead of your sock drawer? The implant orgasm has arrived.

I pity Dr Stuart Meloy, the surgeon who discovered by chance that electrical impulses have recreational value. He was just playing with his voltmeter, like any regular guy, when his patient started "exclaiming emphatically" - that's science-speak for coming on like a hot bunny - and then she said: "You're going to have to teach my husband to do that."This is the nub, or the rub; if your husband doesn't turn you on, is it that he just hasn't found the switch?

While poor Dr Meloy predicts only a tiny take-up for the cigarette-packet-size transmitter, it is clear that millions of husbands will be buying these things for their wives every Valentine's Day, Christmas and birthday. No more erectile dysfunction. No more Viagra on the black market. No more head down for hours with occasional gasps into an oxygen cylinder.

If a woman doesn't come, she has failed to do her shopping properly. How can you blame your man when it's just a wiring problem? I am all for pleasure. I love sex. Sex is about being aroused by someone else and being happy in your own body. If neither applies to you, it's time for a change. All the gadgetry in the world won't make you pleased with yourself or attracted to another person. Electronic sex is another way of faking it.

So much for the moral high ground. What about the practical problems? Electrical pulses are sensitive to their environment. At the moment of ecstasy, will you set the car alarm off? Will the car alarm set you off? I don't want to be routinely doing the beep in Waitrose carpark, only to find myself writhing over the windscreen like a photoshoot for Nude Reader's Wives.

What happens on aeroplanes when the captain announces that all electronic devices must be switched off? What happens if your partner has a pacemaker fitted? I guess a hearing aid is safe enough. Sex makes you deaf anyway doesn't it, or is that only masturbation - and which is this?

I have not read whether the device comes with a timer. Could you programme it like those burglar light switches that go and off at random? That would at least leave the element of surprise that comes with real sex. It might be a turn-on, wondering where you'll be, and with whom, when the first tingle starts.

I predict that a remote control device will soon be invented, allowing unscrupulous persons to orgasm their target at will. With this in mind I propose a control group for clinical trials. How about traffic wardens, tax inspectors and Ann Widdecombe?

All talk and no action
Joan Smith

A device to produce female orgasms? Excuse me, but I think we've been here before, and I'm not talking about the penis - whose value in this context has long been the subject of debate - or the kind of battery-driven vibrator you can buy in sex shops. It was mooted as long as 32 years ago, in Roger Vadim's sci-fi movie Barbarella, when Jane Fonda found herself wired up to a machine called an Orgasmatron.

But that was very much a male fantasy and this, apparently, is real life, an implant created by an American doctor that will give women a controlled number of orgasms, via a hand-held remote control.

Such an invention immediately raises all sorts of questions, the most obvious being whose hand will be on the remote, not to mention what happens if your dog buries it in the garden. There is also, inevitably, a plan to include a regulator in the device to limit the number of orgasms each woman is permitted to have. "But whether it's once a day, four times a week - who am I to say?" its inventor, Dr Stuart Melroy, a surgeon from Winston-Salem in North Carolina, says.

Melroy discovered how to give women orgasms by accident, while researching implants to control pain. His patient, who had been suffering severe back and leg pain, was having electrodes implanted near the base of her spine in order to direct a soothing current into her nervous system. But the electrodes stimulated her third sacral nerve and produced an orgasm, apparently leading her to exclaim: "You are going to have to teach my husband to do that!" Melroy went on to develop an implant for women who have not, for one reason or another, been able to achieve orgasms "naturally".

Not every woman would want to have a titanium generator, attached to more than 40 electrodes, implanted under the skin at the top of her buttocks. But it might strike some women as preferable, and no less mechanical, than a bunk-up in a restaurant broom cupboard with the former Wimbledon champion Boris Becker, who has just accepted responsibility for a child conceived in just these circumstances.

Reports that the former tennis ace "made love" with Anna Ermakova in a Mayfair restaurant stretch the familiar euphemism to breaking-point, as well as acting as a reminder of the laddish, performance-orientated culture we currently inhabit.

Sex is everywhere, in the form of endless stories about footballers and rap artists doing it five times a night, but the emphasis is as relentlessly on numbers as it was in the old pre-feminist days of the sexual revolution.

When Germaine Greer suggested that "giving yourself a few jolts from a titanium implant is about as bad as sex can get", she may have temporarily forgotten the anguished discussions that went on in the 1970s as women talked openly for the first time about how difficult it was to have orgasms.

Indeed Vadim's Orgasmatron appeared in exactly the same year as one of feminism's ground-breaking texts, The Myth of the Vaginal Orgasm, by Anne Koedt, which challenged Freud's insistence on the primacy of the vaginal orgasm. Koedt pointed out that "since the clitoris is not necessarily stimulated sufficiently in the conventional sexual positions, we are left 'frigid' ".

This label was so widely feared, in the 1960s, that many women had learned to give Oscar-winning performances in bed.

Koedt's confident article opened the floodgates, building on the work already published by Masters and Johnson in Human Sexual Response in 1966. Suddenly everyone was talking about the female orgasm, a creature that turned out to be as elusive in some corners as the sighting of a very rare bird; in consciousness-raising groups, it was those of us who had not encountered the problem who felt awkward, staying silent for fear of seeming to boast.

Feminists drew on the work of sexologists to support their angry discovery that women were not getting what they wanted in bed, with statistics pouring out from all kinds of sources. Only a third of the women studied by the sexologist Alfred Kinsey reported experiencing orgasm; Seymour Fisher found in 1973 that almost two-thirds of the women in his study did not have them with any consistency, while nearly 6% never had them at all; Shere Hite's survey in 1976 put the figure for non-orgasmic women even higher, at 11.6%.

You can't help thinking that, if similar figures suddenly emerged about the number of men failing to achieve orgasm, there would be a royal commission on Sexual Dysfunction at the very least. We would see a rash of magazines articles on "How to please your man", and it would almost certainly merit a story strand involving Roy and Hailey or Ruth and David in The Archers.

It is true that the combined effect of research and feminist rhetoric in the 1970s was dramatic, on women at least. Some feminists questioned whether heterosexual sex was capable of satisfying women at all; as they were quick to point out, placing the emphasis on the clitoris rather than the vagina effectively dethroned the penis from its primary role in straight sex, at least as far as women were concerned.

Up and down the country, women enthusiastically set about examining their own bodies, blaming their lovers for their failure to stimulate them to orgasm instead of accepting Freud's dismissal of the clitoral orgasm as inferior. There was an urgent need, everyone agreed - or so it seemed at the time - for men to get their act together and start pleasing their partners, which usually involved lots of foreplay.

So what happened? As recently as 1986, the feminist author Lisa Tuttle was still suggesting that "normal" sexuality needed to be reconsidered and redefined, with women's preferences at last taken into account. "Anatomy alone," she declared, "can no longer be used to explain why women should continue to choose men as sexual partners." Yet eight years later, in 1994, Hite reported that more than half the women in her latest survey were faking orgasm, with only 42% getting there with a male partner. More recently, studies have put the number of women who don't come regularly as high as 58%.

What this suggests is that all those discussions, and revelations about the amazing size and sensitivity of the clitoris, have not in the end got us very far. On the contrary, they imply that large numbers of women are unsatisfied in bed, but have learned to do without orgasms or believe their partners don't understand their needs. The latter may well be true in some cases, although there is the question of whether men can't understand a very different pattern of arousal or can't be bothered to try.

Of course this isn't true of all men, or there wouldn't be that happy fortysomething per cent of women who say in surveys that they come regularly with their lovers. But the chief difference between now and 30 years ago, as far as the female orgasm is concerned, is the fact that women have stopped talking about it. Clearly it is as problematic as ever, but in a laddish culture there seems even less point complaining. No more erectile dysfunction. No more Viagra on the black market. No more head down for hours with occasional gasps into an oxygen cylinder. If a woman doesn't come, she has failed to do her shopping properly. How can you blame your man when it's just a wiring problem? I am all for pleasure. I love sex. webTitle: Lucie Blackman: police find a body

fields.headline: Lucie Blackman: police find a body
fields.trailText: The remains of a woman were found buried on a beach near Tokyo today by police searching for missing British bar hostess Lucie Blackman.
fields.body:
The remains of a woman were found buried on a beach near Tokyo today by police searching for missing British bar hostess Lucie Blackman.

Investigators have been looking for Ms Blackman, 22, since July, when she disappeared after telling a friend she was going on a drive to the ocean with a client. Ms Blackman had been working as a bar hostess in a Tokyo nightclub prior to her disappearance.

Her father, Tim Blackman, said Japanese police had told him of the discovery.

"They have told us that something has been found but they haven't been able to confirm who it is," he said from his home on the Isle of Wight. The Blackman family has repeatedly gone to Tokyo pleading with police and lawmakers to find Lucie and has offered a £100,000 reward for information about her whereabouts.

Today's discovery has not been formally linked to Ms Blackman, but the Tokyo metropolitan police said investigators are focusing their search for clues into her disappearance on the area around the beach, just southwest of Tokyo.

A police spokeswoman said that the unearthed body parts included a hand, a pair of feet, a head and a torso. She said it was not immediately clear whether the victim was dismembered before being buried.

The remains were found near the seaside apartment of a Japanese businessman who pleaded not guilty in December to drugging and raping a Canadian hostess and another Briton, police said. He is also charged with the rape of two other women.

Joji Obara, 48, was allegedly a regular at bars in Tokyo where foreign women pour drinks for clients. In a statement provided to the media by his lawyer, Mr Obara said he met Ms Blackman only once at a bar but denied responsibility for her disappearance. He has not been charged in relation to her disappearance. Police have reportedly found hair that may belong to Ms Blackman in Mr Obara's seaside flat.

webTitle: Bank cuts rates to fend off US slide

fields.headline: Bank cuts rates to fend off US slide
fields.trailText: The Bank of England took out an insurance policy yesterday against the recession in the United States spreading across the Atlantic when its nine-strong monetary policy committee (MPC) cut interest rates for the first time in 20 months.
fields.body:
The Bank of England took out an insurance policy yesterday against the recession in the United States spreading across the Atlantic when its nine-strong monetary policy committee (MPC) cut interest rates for the first time in 20 months.

Leading mortgage lenders reacted swiftly to the reduction in base rates from 6% to 5.75%, helping to boost the pre-election feelgood factor by chopping nearly £10 a month off the cost of a typical £60,000 home loan.

Employers' organisations and trade unions welcomed the decision, which follows 12 months in which the Bank had left interest rates on hold.

The move had been expected in the City, where dealers were confident that the committee would follow the lead set by America's central bank, the Federal Reserve, despite concerns that falling unemployment in the UK might push wages up.

The Bank made no comment on the decision, which followed a 5-4 vote last month to keep rates at 6%. Minutes of yesterday's meeting will be released in a fortnight.

Kate Barker, chief economist at the Confederation of British Industry, said: "This cut has come at the right time. Companies needed this cut to bolster their confidence and to sustain investment, which is vital to the UK's long-term future. Low inflation gives room for a cut now without damaging stability."

However, with underlying inflation at 2% comfortably undershooting the government's 2.5% target, there were calls for yesterday's reduction to be the first of many.

John Monks, general secretary of the TUC, said: "This is the first faltering step towards stabilising the economy, encouraging a more competitive exchange rate and helping manufacturing out of the doldrums. But with inflation still well below target, the Bank has no reason not to cut again, and soon."

Stephen Radley, chief economist at the Engineering Employers' Federation, said: "The MPC's move will give a much needed boost to growth, confidence and investment. This should be the first in a series of cuts."

After yesterday's noon announcement, Abbey National cut its standard rate from 7.74% to 7.49%, a shade below Halifax, which cut its rate to 7.5%, effective from March 1.

But Nationwide said it would not be cutting its rates for the time being, because borrowers had already benefited from a 0.2% unilateral cut in December, which took its standard rate to 7.09%.

HSBC stood by its strategy of undercutting all other lenders on standard variable rate, reducing its rate from 6.75% to 6.5%.

But for many home buyers the rate cut translates into only small savings. Halifax said the average mortgage was £30,000, so yesterday's rate cut resulted in a saving of only £4.74 a month. Nearly a third of borrowers will not benefit at all because they are on fixed rates.

The winners are the increasing number who, aware of the likelihood of future rate cuts, have shunned fixed products in favour of "discount" mortgages. Mortgage brokers say that in recent months up to three-quarters of house buyers have opted for discount mortgages, which typically give 1.5%-2.25% off the standard variable rate for two to three years. The true "pay rate" on most new mortgages therefore fell from 5.5% to 5.25%.

The former MPC member Sir Alan Budd said the Bank had been right to cut rates. "This is an insurance against the risk that a very sharp slowdown in the US would affect us," he told BBC Radio 4's The World at One programme. "It is sensible just to put a little more demand into this economy just to keep it plugging along in a comfortable way."

The move had been expected in the City, where dealers were confident that the committee would follow the lead set by America's central bank, the Federal Reserve, despite concerns that falling unemployment in the UK might push wages up. The Bank made no comment on the decision, which followed a 5-4 vote last month to keep rates at 6%. Minutes of yesterday's meeting will be released in a fortnight. Kate Barker, chief economist at the Confederation of British Industry, said: "This cut has come at the right time. Companies needed this cut to bolster their confidence and to sustain investment, which is vital to the UK's long-term future. Low inflation gives room for a cut now without damaging stability." However, with underlying inflation at 2% comfortably undershooting the government's 2.5% target, there were calls for yesterday's reduction to be the first of many. John Monks, general secretary of the TUC, said: "This is the first faltering step towards stabilising the economy, encouraging a more competitive exchange rate and helping manufacturing out of the doldrums. But with inflation still well below target, the Bank has no reason not to cut again, and soon." Stephen Radley, chief economist at the Engineering Employers' Federation, said: "The MPC's move will give a much needed boost to growth, confidence and investment. This should be the first in a series of cuts." After yesterday's noon announcement, Abbey National cut its standard rate from 7.74% to 7.49%, a shade below Halifax, which cut its rate to 7.5%, effective from March 1. But Nationwide said it would not be cutting its rates for the time being, because borrowers had already benefited from a 0.2% unilateral cut in December, which took its standard rate to 7.09%. HSBC stood by its strategy of undercutting all other lenders on standard variable rate, reducing its rate from 6.75% to 6.5%. But for many home buyers the rate cut translates into only small savings. Halifax said the average mortgage was £30,000, so yesterday's rate cut resulted in a saving of only £4.74 a month. Nearly a third of borrowers will not benefit at all because they are on fixed rates. The winners are the increasing number who, aware of the likelihood of future rate cuts, have shunned fixed products in favour of "discount" mortgages. Mortgage brokers say that in recent months up to three-quarters of house buyers have opted for discount mortgages, which typically give 1.5%-2.25% off the standard variable rate for two to three years. The true "pay rate" on most new mortgages therefore fell from 5.5% to 5.25%. The former MPC member Sir Alan Budd said the Bank had been right to cut rates. "This is an insurance against the risk that a very sharp slowdown in the US would affect us," he told BBC Radio 4's The World at One programme. "It is sensible just to put a little more demand into this economy just to keep it plugging along in a comfortable way."

fields.headline: First Popstars, now Supermodels
fields.trailText: After the wannabe Popstars come the girls who dream of being supermodels as ITV launches its new quest for a hit docusoap, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
After the wannabe Popstars come the girls who dream of being supermodels.

The five singers who made the band in ITVÕs most talked about show have not even released a single, yet the production company which holds the global rights to the hit series has begun touting its own next big thing.

Search for a Supermodel follows the same docusoap format trailing hopefuls from the first cattlecall through to bookings as a professional model. The egos, beautiful girls and high camp have already proved to be a potent mix in Australia where the show ran for three months and regularly occupied the number two or three spot in the ratings.

The show has been offered to broadcasters around the world including ITV which yesterday said it was considering whether to commission the series.

The potential rewards for the girl chosen at the end of the series and awarded a contract with Ford Models New York could dwarf those from what seems likely to be a fleeting pop career.

Models on the agencyÕs books have included Lauren Hutton, Rachel Hunter, Jerry Hall and Christie Brinkley.

The showÕs producers hope it will have the same Òwater cooler TVÓ effect as Popstars. The success of shows like Big Brother, Survivor, Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and now Popstars has led to broadcasters wanting more Òevent TVÓ Ñ running series that become the topic of conversations in the office as well as the nationÕs dining rooms.

Almost 12m viewers watched in the UK as the final five were chosen to be in the Popstars band making it one of the biggest draws.

The early episodes of Search for a Supermodel also have a dose of the other prevailing trend in entertainment Ñ public humiliation. Like Popstars, the early episodes have a strong cringe factor, encouraging snide comments on the capacity for self delusion as much as picking potential winners.

The show features not just the hopefuls but their parents, model agency staff and stylists whose views are meted out inthe style of PopstarsÕ ÒNastyÓ Nigel Lythgoe.

Thousands of girls are narrowed to a smaller group who are deposited in a modelsÕ boot camp. The Australian version also had its villains among the girls, including Sophie, a 19-year-old law student from Adelade with an acerbic wit.

LWT, which produced Popstars, is also considering a show based on the search for a soapstar.

The supermodel camera crews have latched on to an annual competition run by the Ford model agency now in its 21st year. The contest has expanded to 37 countries with one winner from each nation going through to a final. Each locally-produced series would follow its own contestant.

Geoff Brown, the Australian boss of Sportsworld Media Group which is behind Search for a Supermodel, said the company had the idea after a Sydney girl working in a fish and chip shop won the competition in 1999.

Alyssa Kealy, 20, won a $250,000 contract and was photographed for Marie Claire and Elle during her first week in New York. Francesca, the Syndeysider who won the televised series in Australia lost out to a young Russian girl. ÒThis is compelling television,Ó said Clive Burcham at Sportsworld.

Sportsworld, a company listed on the London stock exchange which had specialised in extreme sports programming, stumbled across Popstars when it was buying an Australian production business. It has a 50% share in Five Divas, the company which owns the Popstars format. After a succesful run in New Zealand and Australia which produced the all-girl band Bardot, Popstars has now been rolled out to the US and there are plans for shows in Canada, India and the Phillipines.

webTitle: Jeremy Hardy on malpractice and the medical profession

fields.headline: Men in white coats
fields.standfirst: They can't say 'Blimey, he's bonkers!' They have to say 'The rare Weird Bastard Syndrome'
fields.trailText: Suddenly, it appears, there is no confidence in the medical profession. Without wishing to detect the malpractice of spin-doctors in everything we see and hear, this is all very convenient writes Jeremy Hardy.
fields.body:
Suddenly, it appears, there is no confidence in the medical profession. Without wishing to detect the malpractice of spin-doctors in everything we see and hear, this is all very convenient. Increasingly, the failings of services are attributed to individuals or "a culture of..." which means individuals making each other worse in the canteen.

Driver error, incompetent teaching and the arrogance of doctors are much easier to broach than mismanagement, politics, underfunding and the values of the marketplace. Individuals can be dismissed or made to undergo retraining, without damage to the whole. The number of individuals targeted can vary according to the prominence of the problem and which gallery you are playing to. And a system of privileges for good behaviour both sweetens the measures and discourages us from taking a collective view of our own jobs or other people's. We are in competition and on the look out for enemies and rivals.

I am not an expert on the workings of the human mind. Neither, I suspect are psychiatrists. We have always rarefied and mystified the "professions". Because of linguistic confusion, doctors and lawyers are almost alone in being "professional people", as though the rest of us haven't a clue what we are doing and could never be trusted to tell whether a photo is a true likeness of a passport applicant.

Lawyers have an advantage over doctors, because they are allowed to look things up if they don't know. The books are huge so that we'll think: "Fair enough, I suppose he can't be expected to memorise all that." But if our GP took The Bluffers Guide to Osteoporosis down from the shelf, we'd lose all confidence.

Some would say that it is because we demand too much from doctors that some of them treat all patients as malingerers. If you tell certain GPs that blood comes out when you urinate, they will say: "Well, don't do it then." If you tell them that your child has come off her bike and hit her head, they may parry: "What do you expect at her age?" If you say that you suffer heavy periods, they tell you: "We normally recommend removal of the abdomen in women over 25."

Arrogance involves not only self-belief but also contempt for others, although I am not wholly persuaded by the emergent theory that there is a continuum of medical arrogance stretching from poor bedside manner to the mass-murder of patients.

Psychiatrists have not, as far as I know, done much work in the field of arrogance, perhaps because they themselves can't admit they don't know everything. The less is known about something, the more the practitioner must puff a cloud of mystery over the gaps. A psychiatrist can't say: "Blimey, this guy's bonkers!" He has to say: "Ah, a rare and hitherto unheard-of condition now known as Weird Bastard Syndrome."

The best bet for the explanation of arrogance would be the discovery of a cocky gene. Geneticists can also get away with saying anything, because no one else can see what they're looking at, so they are accorded the mystique once hogged by clairvoyants.

It might be that professional arrogance is a product of education. The problem with looking at this theory is it opens up a can of worms. Private education, examination and selection all encourage the idea that some of us are worth more than others, that being the justification for capitalism. The government, anxious to avoid the wastage of resources on the unworthy pupil, the bogus exam-sitter, wants to test as early as possible. The genome project will assist this. And, since we are judged by the length of time we spend in education, doctors, who don't qualify until they are middle aged, might be expected to feel like an elite.

Moreover, being a junior doctor involves a prolonged period of sleep-deprivation torture. After this feat of endurance, perhaps the ones who haven't cracked and confessed to things they did not do are inculcated into sublime self-belief. Having wrongly diagnosed and accidentally killed patients in a torpid blur might make one doubt that it really happened and become inured to one's own mistakes.

However, I'm not sure I believe that there is a specific strain of medical egomania. There are too many cases of dedicated, compassionate doctors who are not even slightly impressed with themselves. The ones who are vain and pompous and more interested in golf, money and status than humanity would probably be like that if they were judges, politicians or bankers. The ones who will do anything to cover up abuses would do well in the crown prosecution service or the Catholic church.

Moreover, doctors do not run the health service. They are not removing hospitals unnecessarily. The government's "patient power" is not about power at all. It is about turning patients into anxious consumers. Health will not be spared cuts and closure because of the will of the people. There is nothing more arrogant than the government, after all.

webTitle: Pregnant women to be given assistance in extension of anti-poverty strategy

fields.headline: Pregnant women to be given assistance in extension of anti-poverty strategy
fields.trailText: The government is to extend its sure start programme to pregnant mothers, offering advice from conception that is designed to improve the health of the foetus and mother.
fields.body:
The government is to extend its sure start programme to pregnant mothers, offering advice from conception that is designed to improve the health of the foetus and mother.

Health minister Yvette Cooper will announce the strategy today when she reveals that the sure start programme for under-fours will be extended to pregnant mothers.

The government has announced 500 sure start areas as a centrepiece of its anti-poverty programme, and will be offering poor families £60m worth of advice.

The move to intervene at the point of conception follows findings from the Medical Research Council that show a clear link between low birth weight and poor cognitive ability. American studies have shown that low birth weight babies are more likely to suffer from chronic health conditions during adult life.

Ms Cooper said yesterday: "Low birth weight babies tend to have higher blood pressure by the age of 11, and higher risk of coronary hearth disease." Such children also end up with lower educational qualifications.

A mother's health and diet while pregnant is seen as an important factor.

The sure start programmes bring together local services from different health, social services and voluntary groups. The quickly expanding programme is seen as central by the government in its drive to prevent children entering school with low learning abilities, or emotional difficulties.

Ms Cooper, who is making the announcement at a seminar for the Institute of Public Policy Research, said: "We have to intervene at the point of pregnancy ... the facts show poor pregnant women hve lower iron intake, and decisions taken in pregnancy can permanently set the life chances of their child.

"We may have universal maternity services at present, but poor parents need advice on benefits, as well as health checks and advice in their own home ... they also need social support groups which can make a huge difference during pregancy."

The government intends to spend £500m a year on the scheme in 2003-4, with 500 programmes nationwide, typically covering 700 children.

webTitle: Mark Lawson on Hague's Question Time

fields.headline: Baldly facing up to a hairy Question Time
fields.standfirst:
The Hague on TV is merely the latest construct of his handlers

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: William Hague's TV persona is merely the latest construct of his handlers, writes Mark Lawson.
fields.body:
Both the BBC and the House of Commons use the title Question Time for their most important sessions of political debate. The usual wisdom is that William Hague is best at the Question Time chaired by Betty Boothroyd, while Tony Blair most convinces in the version hosted by David Dimbleby. But the consensus also holds that performance in the padded black chair has more impact on the electorate than answers given on the green leather benches.

So Thursday's hour-long edition of BBC1's Question Time - with Hague as the only guest - was the most significant test yet of the skills and opinions of a man who, as Dimbleby noted with commendable evenness, "believes he may be in Downing Street a year from now".

It can't have helped Hague's nerves that the first two questions concerned the circumstances in which he might hand over to Michael Portillo, either voluntarily or unwillingly. It is a measure of the Conservative problem that since at least 1988, the leader at any given time has been measured against the alternative charisma of a colleague. Thatcher was stalked by Heseltine; Major by Thatcher and Redwood among others. Now Hague, the first Tory leader to skip free of Thatcher's shadow, finds another spectre beside him. Admittedly the BBC built this up by placing the vice-presidential questions first. I don't want to sound Tebbitite about it, but was it really fair to begin the programme by questioning Hague's political legitimacy?

Perhaps the producers were placing the least boring material in the foreground. It must be rare for a 60-minute interview with a party leader to produce no newspaper headlines at all. But, if England's openers played a bat as straight as Hague's on Question Time, the West Indies wouldn't have taken a wicket yet this summer.

Though uneasy when pressed on immigration policy by non-white questioners, he pulled back from his recent hissy populism on Europe and the right to murder burglars.

Tony Blair spent the two years before the 1997 election being as boring as possible on television. This was a deliberate attempt to avoid giving hostile newspapers lines to twist which might frighten the horses of Middle England. But Blair was offering himself as a more cautious alternative to a regime seen as having over-reached itself. When the main voter dissatisfaction with Blair is inaction, it is hard to see what Hague gains by offering himself as a stabiliser. His populist rhetoric may have been unpleasant but it was at least an alternative.

Hague's main distance tactic - a disparaging reference to "focus groups", which he claimed not to use - showed that he's trying to position himself as a spin-homeopath, making no use of the media doctors who surround Blair. But this position is ridiculous. In his short time as party leader, Hague has been successively repackaged according to theories of what might appeal to media and voters.

Watching his Question Time performance, it seemed to me that Hague has - like Margaret Thatcher before him - been receiving vocal coaching. Because he doesn't use focus groups, it can't have been those who took against his Yorkshire growl, so presumably it was a friend: he seemed deliberately to be pitching his voice higher and softer. Hague also seemed to be copying the most unfortunate of New Labour's TV tactics: the sudden smile (as practised with equal inefficiency by Gordon Brown and John Prescott), which attempts to show that strong questioning is welcome.

In fact, Mr Hague's image-makers should take him away to have a brass neck fitted if they intend to continue his claims to be the enemy of political spin. The Hague seen on TV is merely the latest construct of his handlers, who are currently trying keep-the-pound speeches and a No 1 haircut.

Ah, the hair. The great political columnist Alan Watkins has long maintained that, since the blip of Churchill who had other qualities, the English have always voted for the main party leader with the most impressive head of hair. Hence Margaret Thatcher's Boadicean helmet did for the exposed scalps of Callaghan and Kinnock. In 1997, choosing between two comb-users, the electorate favoured Blair's bouncy brown over Major's flat grey. According to this theory, John Smith would never have been prime minister and William Hague never can be as long as the many trichological consultants rumoured to be in touch with No 10 hold back the peep-through genes from his bald dad tugging at the prime minister's roots.

The problem for the hirsute Mr Watkins is that scalp fashion has recently changed dramatically. Mr Hague is the first bald party leader to run in a culture of elective-slaphead men, in which footballers and pop stars deliberately shave off impressive barnets. Therefore the distinction between the smooth men and the hairy men is theoretically less. Mr Hague's scalp doctors have played to this by shaving back the stubbornly fluffy bits at the sides. He does look better, if somewhat butch. But - judging from his biggest TV test - Hague's problem will not be his shiny scalp but the sparseness of his policies. It doesn't look too hairy yet for Blair.

But this position is ridiculous. In his short time as party leader, Hague has been successively repackaged according to theories of what might appeal to media and voters. Watching his Question Time performance, it seemed to me that Hague has - like Margaret Thatcher before him - been receiving vocal coaching. Because he doesn't use focus groups, it can't have been those who took against his Yorkshire growl, so presumably it was a friend: he seemed deliberately to be pitching his voice higher and softer. Hague also seemed to be copying the most unfortunate of New Labour's TV tactics: the sudden smile (as practised with equal inefficiency by Gordon Brown and John Prescott), which attempts to show that strong questioning is welcome. In fact, Mr Hague's image-makers should take him away to have a brass neck fitted if they intend to continue his claims to be the enemy of political spin. The Hague seen on TV is merely the latest construct of his handlers, who are currently trying keep-the-pound speeches and a No 1 haircut. Ah, the hair. The great political columnist Alan Watkins has long maintained that, since the blip of Churchill who had other qualities, the English have always voted for the main party leader with the most impressive head of hair. Hence Margaret Thatcher's Boadicean helmet did for the exposed scalps of Callaghan and Kinnock. In 1997, choosing between two comb-users, the electorate favoured Blair's bouncy brown over Major's flat grey. According to this theory, John Smith would never have been prime minister and William Hague never can be as long as the many trichological consultants rumoured to be in touch with No 10 hold back the peep-through genes from his bald dad tugging at the prime minister's roots. The problem for the hirsute Mr Watkins is that scalp fashion has recently changed dramatically. Mr Hague is the first bald party leader to run in a culture of elective-slaphead men, in which footballers and pop stars deliberately shave off impressive barnets. Therefore the distinction between the smooth men and the hairy men is theoretically less. Mr Hague's scalp doctors have played to this by shaving back the stubbornly fluffy bits at the sides. He does look better, if somewhat butch. But - judging from his biggest TV test - Hague's problem will not be his shiny scalp but the sparseness of his policies. It doesn't look too hairy yet for Blair. comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Merchandisers drool over Planet of the Apes remake
fields.trailText: 8.30pm: Tim Burton's £62.5m remake of Planet of the Apes will be supported by a massive merchandising campaign, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Tim Burton's £62.5m remake of Planet of the Apes, tipped to be the biggest film release of the year, will be supported by a massive merchandising campaign, including branded chess sets.

The remake of the Charlton Heston classic stars Mark Wahlberg as astronaut Leo Davidson, who gets pulled through a timewarp and crash-lands on a strange planet where talking apes rule over the human race.

With the help of sympathetic chimpanzee activist Ari, played by English actress Helena Bonham-Carter, and a small band of human rebels, Leo leads the effort to evade the advancing gorilla army, led by General Thade, portrayed by actor Tim Roth.

The quest leads Leo to the forbidden zone, which holds the shocking secrets of mankind's past and the key to its future

A tide of toys, games and accessories for both children and adults will be launched to coincide with the movie's release.

In the UK, merchandising firm Character Options is to launch a range of Planet of the Apes-branded sculpture puzzles retailing at £15.99, chess sets at £24.99, a range of computer mouse-mats at £5.99 and CD wallets featuring scenes from the movie at £8.99.

There will also be watches and clocks for adults and children - from metal designs to teen fashion watches with interchangeable faces.

A "back to school" stationery and luggage range, including A4 ringbinders, spiralbound notebooks, mobile phone covers, backpacks and purses, will aim to cash in on the timing of the movie release.

A gift range includes collectable bean bag toys and cuddly toys, 3D keyrings and a variety of glassware & photographic mugs.

Character Options saw its share price shattered after overestimating demand for products relating to Star Wars: The Phantom Menace and was forced to cut 100 jobs.

It was not the only problem caused by the weakening power of the Force - book publisher Dorling Kindersley had to be sold after a fiasco in which the company was left burdened with 10m unsold Star Wars books.
