fields.headline: Pfizer smartens up with 'functional foods' launch
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The company which gave the world Viagra is now set to spice up the confectionery market, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The company which gave the world Viagra is now set to spice up the confectionery market.

Pfizer's Adams division, manufacturer of brands including Dentyne and Halls, is launching a range of chocolate and fruit chew bars called Body Smarts.

The products, which contain added vitamins and minerals, aim to take the guilt out of eating chocolate and chew bars.

A $70m marketing campaign will launch Body Smarts in the US and Canada this summer. A company spokeswoman said a global roll-out was being considered.

New York advertising agency Bates USA is creating an ad campaign with the theme, "Sweet just got smart", DVC Worldwide is working on PR and a sampling and in-store promotional push will support.

The eight-strong Body Smarts range represents the breakthrough of so-called functional foods into the confectionery market.

Functional foods contain added ingredients, which claim to be beneficial to general health or good for particular areas such as the heart or bones.

Food and pharmaceutical companies are rushing to develop enriched products for this new, lucrative market. In the UK consumer groups have demanded legislation to regulate health claims on functional foods..

Novartis Consumer Health, the consumer brand of the Swiss pharmaceutical giant, launched its functional food brand Aviva in to Europe with a £20m advertising spend; Johnson & Johnson launched Benecol margarine which claims to cut cholesterol; Kellogg and Nestle have also launched functional products.

Pfizer's Body Smarts will be available as crunch bars and fruit chews in Chocolate Peanut Crunch, Yogurt Berry Crunch, Strawberry Creamy Fruit Chews and Assorted Creamy Fruit Chews variants.

"Consumers are looking for real nutrition as opposed to products what simply have less of the 'bad stuff'," said Adams USA president John Craig.

fields.headline: City Slickers hopeful of avoiding prosecution
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The former 'City Slickers' have been told by their lawyers proceedings against them are 'extremely unlikely', writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Former City Slickers Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell have been told by their lawyers that proceedings against them for insider dealing by the Department of Trade and Industry are "extremely unlikely".

Lawyers acting for the pair, the key players in the "Mirrorgate" share-tipping scandal, believe that the difficulty of proving insider dealing will deter DTI lawyers from prosecution.

The scope of the inquiry, launched last year by DTI investigators after the scandal, is being widened beyond the City Slickers and other Mirror editorial staff to look at internet sites operated by share-tippers and day traders.

Investigators have been concerned about how tips from the pair leaked to the City before publication in the Mirror.

Among emails sent to and from the City Slickers and other Mirror staff were emails that suggest City traders were being given advanced warning that the Slickers were to tip a share in the newspaper.

But it is thought it will be hard to prove that the pair were actively involved with insider trading.

The DTI is thought to be focusing on allegations of "market manipulation" - a new crime established under financial legislation brought in last year.

Lawyers for Mr Bhoyrul and Mr Hipwell are thought to have been fairly successful in establishing that the City Slickers offered few share "scoops", as the majority had appeared on internet sites beforehand.

This week it emerged that Mr Bhoyrul has settled an unfair dismissal dispute with Mirror owners Trinity Mirror out of court.

Meanwhile, Mr Hipwell, who is now working for publicist Max Clifford, has been told he will not be called to give evidence in front of the investigators.

Mr Bhoyrul and Mr Hipwell were fired from the popular City Slickers column they produced on the Mirror after it emerged that the paper's editor, Piers Morgan, had bought shares in computer manufacturer Viglen shortly before the column tipped the shares.

Although censured by the Press Complaints Commission, Mr Morgan was cleared of wrongdoing in an internal inquiry by Trinity Mirror.

Mr Bhoyrul has been approached by Express Newspapers owner Richard Desmond to work for the Daily Star, but the job offer is dependent on the outcome of the DTI inquiry.

webTitle: BBC could fund free digital boxes for all

fields.headline: BBC could fund free digital boxes for all
fields.trailText: The BBC is considering whether to use licence fee payers' money to fund a mass giveaway of digital set-top boxes, director general Greg Dyke revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
The BBC is considering whether to use licence fee payers' money to fund a mass giveaway of digital set-top boxes, director general Greg Dyke revealed yesterday.

Mr Dyke said the corporation is discussing how to ensure all viewers can receive digital pictures by the time the government wants to switch off the analogue system. His remarks were unexpected as the subject of a giveaway of set-top boxes has been something of a taboo in the broadcasting industry, which regards subsidised equipment - unless linked to subscription deals - as a last resort.

BBC sources later attempted to play down Mr Dyke's remarks, saying that most people would be attracted to digital TV by the corporation's proposed new services such as BBC3 and 4, and children's channels.

While it is unlikely that the BBC would unilaterally fund a digital subsidy or giveaway, Mr Dyke's remarks aired a problem that has exercised the broadcasting industry: how to persuade an estimated 30% of viewers who are either unwilling or unable to transfer to digital.

Responding to questions from MPs at the Commons media select committee yesterday, Mr Dyke said he hoped the BBC's new channels would be a significant driving force. But he indicated that the BBC could become involved in a future giveaway or subsidy of boxes.

"We have been doing a lot of work on this. Could you give them away, and could the BBC fund them?" The government wants to switch off the analogue TV signal between 2006 and 2010. Chris Smith, culture secretary, has said 98% of viewers in a transmitter area must have converted to digital before the analogue signal can be switched off, so viewers will not be left with blank screens.

The digital take-up rate in Britain is healthy: about 6m homes, around 30%, have digital television. However, industry estimates suggest that will level off at 75%. The main pay-TV operators, Sky and ONDigital, have tried to lure customers with subsidised or free equipment, but viewers are tied to subscription deals.

It is difficult for viewers to buy equipment outright, simply to watch free-to-air services such as the BBC's digital channels. For those who do not want to sign up for pay-TV services, a giveaway or subsidy may be the only way to persuade them to convert. It is likely, at that stage, the government and the TV industry will consider a means-tested scheme to give away or subsidise digital equipment.

Some industry figures believe the government has not thought hard enough about the problem: there was little mention of it in the recent communications white paper. Some industry sources believe the BBC must be involved in any such scheme. A policy expert at one digital TV operator said: "If you add it up, the BBC will have spent the best part of £1bn on its digital services. Think of how many boxes that could have bought. And most of the BBC's new services will not attract people, such as the elderly, who are reluctant to convert."

At the committee hearing, ITV accused Rupert Murdoch's BSkyB of abusing its monopoly over the satellite broadcast network. ITV, which is not currently on the Sky Digital platform, said the company had hiked its charges for carrying channels by 50% at the end of last year.

It claimed that ITV would have to pay £20m a year to be broadcast on Sky Digital. Kate Stross, ITV's director of finance, asked the government to force Sky into offering cheaper rates for public service broadcasters. BSkyB and ITV have been in a long-running row about the network's absence from the Sky platform.

fields.headline: GE capitulates over Equitable
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: GE Capital last night gave up its £1.5bn ambition to take over Equitable Life, which rebuffed the American's intervention as "thirteenth hour" and "significantly inferior" to the rescue plan agreed with the Halifax.
fields.body:
GE Capital last night gave up its £1.5bn ambition to take over Equitable Life, which rebuffed the American's intervention as "thirteenth hour" and "significantly inferior" to the rescue plan agreed with the Halifax.

The financial services arm of General Electric of the United States left the door open for Equitable Life to return to the negotiating table as it conceded defeat after a six month sales process which saw a line of potential bidders walk away from the beleaguered mutual insurer.

GE Capital's bid - of which £400m was a loan rather than cash - threatened to disrupt Equitable's £1bn deal with the Halifax, which yesterday insisted the integration process was already underway.

The Halifax deal was agreed over the weekend although GE Capital had continued to stalk Equitable, which yesterday insisted the Americans had consistently submitted the lowest bids. Equitable had been looking for a buyer ever since the law lords ruled in the summer that it had treated 90,000 holders of guaranteed annuity policies unfairly, leaving it with a hole of at least £1.5bn in its finances.

Even though both Halifax and Equitable Life insist their arrangement is legally binding, they are yet to unite the warring factions of policy holders which yesterday remained disunited. The Equitable Members' Action Group (Emag) insisted GE Capital had not been given a fair hearing. But Stuart Bayliss, head of the Equitable Life Guaranteed Annuity Rate Action Group, said: "I believe that the more we have learned about the Halifax deal, the more appropriate it seems to be." He said GE Capital's track record in the UK was not impressive and that the conditions linked to its offer were likely to be more onerous than the Halifax's provisions.

Halifax's £1bn bid involves a £500m payment for the asset management, IT and sales force of Equitable with £500m payable later provided policyholders agree to limit the bill for the guaranteed annuities and sales targets are met.

Equitable said the £1.5bn bid by GE Capital, which refused to comment last night, involved a £400m loan and several conditional payments in three stages over five years. A source close to the GE Capital bid said last night that the company disagreed with Equitable's analysis of its offer but that decided to withdraw.

"[GE Capital] remains committed to building financial services in the UK and elsewhere and if Equitable would like to come back to GE Capital then it is happy to talk to them," the source said.

Chris Headdon, chief executive of Equitable Life, described the GE Capital offer as a "break up proposal that is highly conditional, contains elements which will work against the interests of policyholders and which will work against the interests of policy holders".

webTitle: Fuel protesters warn of electoral backlash

fields.headline: Fuel protesters warn of electoral backlash
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: A wave of verbal protests last night followed the announcement of record profits at Shell with fuel campaigners and motoring organisations warning of potential political fallout at the elections.
fields.body:
A wave of verbal protests last night followed the announcement of record profits at Shell with fuel campaigners and motoring organisations warning of potential political fallout at the elections.

The Dump the Pump campaign, which was involved in organising blockades last autumn, said the chancellor, Gordon Brown, should divert taxes from the pump price and on to the oil companies.

Garry Russell, organiser of the campaign, said Shell's level of earnings was "immoral" given that petrol was an essential item for so many people.

"It is a sad day when oil giants are profiting in this way. It is about time the chancellor looks at taxing these oil companies instead of the consumer. I think this is going to send quite a shockwave through the populace, who will make their voice heard at the ballot box," he said.

The RAC motoring organisation said British drivers would be "shocked and appalled" by the high level of earnings coming to Shell while they paid such a high level of prices on the forecourt.

"Shell might argue that it makes little money on petrol but the average motorist will not understand nor care whether this is true or not. What they will see is that the group as a whole is making record profits."

Sue Nicholson, a campaigns officer at the RAC, said Shell might try to fight back in the public relations war but there would still be a lot of work to do before it was successful.

The Freight Transport Association voiced its concern at the slow speed with which oil companies reduced prices when the cost of crude fell compared with the haste with which they put up petrol prices when crude costs rose. But an FTA spokesman believed the biggest concern of its members was the level of taxation rather than oil company profits.

Friends of the Earth said ecologists would be angry that these record profits came as Shell was moving into new environmentally sensitive areas such as a national park in Pakistan and a mangrove forest in Bangladesh vital for the preservation of tigers. "Shell is on the take both from consumer and from the planet, " said FoE corporate campaigner Craig Bennett.

webTitle: Shell profits are now at £1m an hour. So will pump prices come down? No

fields.headline: Shell profits are now at £1m an hour. So will pump prices come down? No
fields.standfirst: Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: Shell, Europe's largest oil company, yesterday put the issue of high petrol prices back on the political agenda by revealing an 85% increase in annual profits to $13.1bn (£9.4bn) - more than £1m an hour.
fields.body:
Shell, Europe's largest oil company, yesterday put the issue of high petrol prices back on the political agenda by revealing an 85% increase in annual profits to $13.1bn (£9.4bn) - more than £1m an hour.

The oil giant combined the announcement with a public relations offensive to head off criticism from the transport lobby over its biggest ever profits, which come just months after fuel protests crippled the country in the autumn.

Shell insisted that it was making no money from selling fuel in Britain and instead blamed the government for high prices by saying that taxes accounted for 80% of the pump price.

Malcolm Brinded, chairman of Shell UK, said his company had failed to make any money out of petrol retailing in Britain for six years, adding that 90% of group profits came from abroad.

"The story that can all too easily be written is the suggestion that we are making profits at the expense of the UK motorist because of what he pays at the pump. Nothing could be further from the truth," he added.

Mr Brinded put record profits down to a mixture of higher oil prices, a leap in the amount of crude being produced by Shell's platforms and a high-profile company cost-cutting drive. Yesterday the price of North sea oil soared $1.25 to just under $30 per barrel, a level which promises to bring further gains to oil companies but which will anger motorists.

The issue of petrol prices will be kept on the boil next week when BP reports its annual profit figures, which are expected to be 100% higher than last year.

Despite the promise of even bigger profits, the oil companies claimed to be looking for even more savings. Shell's manager of UK retailing, Ian Sutcliffe, said things were getting so tough on the forecourt that it might have to make swingeing cutbacks. The group had already reduced the number of its petrol stations from 2,500 to 1,100 over the past 12 years and might consider disposing of all of them if it could not justify keeping them open.

"There are analogies with the loss of post offices in rural areas. Many petrol stations are only running because they combine selling fuel with acting as the village shop or motor repairer," he said.

Criticism

Shell was evaluating ways of reducing costs but planned to make a decision about the future of those interests within 18 months. It had already started a joint venture with the supermarket Sainsbury to try to improve profits through selling food and other non-fuel items on the forecourt. Mr Brinded also fought back against consumer criticism of the oil companies by pointing to the major contribution the group had made to the UK economy. He said that Shell employed 15,000 staff in the UK but its operations had a further 80,000 UK jobs dependent on it. Forty per cent of dividends from global earnings were paid to UK shareholders.

In a move which reflects a new found public awareness, the formal release of Shell's annual financial figures was preceded by letters to motoring organisations and other "stakeholders" from Mr Brinded.

The Shell executive said he was writing "given that the financial performance of oil companies has been the subject of much media focus in the UK in recent months, particularly linking the profits of oil companies to the price of petrol at the pumps".

This was followed by a briefing at the Shell Tower headquarters yesterday where the UK chairman argued government taxes rather than oil company profits explained the high cost of fuel in the UK.

He pointed out that 80% of the price of a litre of unleaded fuel was made up of tax and duty with only 6p per litre left over for refining, transportation and retail.

He said that the high level of taxation had not been raised when oil companies were hauled before the prime minister during the fuel blockades. Then relations between government and the oil industry had hit rock bottom amid allegations that oil bosses had not put enough pressure on their staff to keep tankers moving through fuel blockades.

Shell officials privately admitted yesterday they had not done enough to argue their case in public while executives from another oil company said they would try to avoid being tarnished with what was essentially a tax problem.

The same line has been taken by ministers from the Organisation for Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) who say western governments are seeking to blame Arab oil producers in order to mask their own part in high pump prices.

As Ali Rodriguez-Araque, Opec's new secretary-general, told the Spectator magazine this week: "The irony is that they try to put pressure on us to reduce prices, but when prices drop, they don't drop taxes."

But Shell's arguments about its poor returns in Britain were questioned by City experts. "There are some advantages to low margins on the forecourt for integrated oil companies (which bring the oil from the ground as well as refining it and selling it on) because it can keep out the competition from independent retailers," said Peter Lynch, an oil analyst with US investment bank Merrill Lynch.

Meanwhile the oil world is split on the question of whether the current high cost of oil is here to stay but all agree that they are going to remain "volatile".

North sea prices averaged $28.50 per barrel last year compared with $17.95 in 1999. Shell believes that uncertainties over both economic growth and oil supply mean crude prices will continue to swing wildly.

Slowdown

Merrill Lynch warned that its long-term outlook last year was that oil prices would rise above their "10-year historical average".

Some analysts argue that a US economic slowdown should reduce the price of crude over the coming year but experts have been constantly wrongfooted.

Yesterday's burst in higher oil prices was partly triggered by freezing weather in the North sea which forced Norway to reduce its production.

webTitle: Comment: we have to join the euro

fields.headline: The country is on notice - we have to join the euro
fields.standfirst:
Labour's avoidance of the single currency issue hasn't helped their cause

Special report: election countdown
Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Labour's avoidance of the single  currency issue hasn't helped their cause.
fields.body:
Here is a morality tale. In the autumn of 1997, when the sheen of the new Labour government's surprisingly large electoral victory was still glimmering, one of the architects of that success, Mr Philip Gould, arrived at an internal strategy meeting flourishing the latest findings of one of his celebrated focus groups. It concerned the tricky question of the British public's view of membership of the European single currency.

Mr Gould, the man usually described as the prime minister's favourite pollster, had ascertained that 40% of his representative sample were in favour of Britain joining the single currency while, perhaps unsurprisingly considering the acrimonious political debate that had taken place within the previous government in the run-up to the election, 60% were against.

This news was received with equanimity by those present at the meeting. It was a result that was roughly in line with the known state of public opinion at the time. One man there reflected openly that it was as much as the government could have expected but, given the period of time that would elapse before the next election, the majority against was not insuperable. It could still be realistically possible, he suggested, to get public opinion lined up behind the government's support "in principle" for British membership and for there to be a majority in any referendum on the subject when the time came.

He did not anticipate what happened next. Philip Gould looked at him and said: "But we're not interested in getting them lined up with us. We're in the business of getting lined up with the 60%."

It is a startling story which reveals rather a lot. It explains something about Mr Gould. It says a great deal about a government which the passage of time has repeatedly shown is almost always far more ready to react to any given political situation in preference to taking any other course. And it may also help to elucidate how it is that the current state of public opinion on the euro is so overwhelmingly negative. According to yesterday's publication of the latest eurobarometer poll, an analysis of opinion throughout all the member states, the figure for those in favour in Britain has nearly halved during the last three years and now stands at a record low of 21%, the lowest in the European Union.

This is, it could be argued - whatever you think about a single currency - some measure of the success of Mr Gould in pursuit of his declared objective. If the government wished to identify with majority opinion in Britain on a single currency throughout Europe, the easiest course, and the one that it has certainly seemed to follow, would be to do exactly nothing. The voters were not interested in joining the euro and, anyway, there were plenty of other things for the government to get on with. The idea of an early referendum in the course of the current parliament was quickly ruled out. Presumably under direction from above, most ministers avoided public discussion of the subject and the government as a whole failed to engage in the debate.

That didn't mean that a debate didn't take place, however, and by vacating the public platform, the Labour party left it open instead to a Eurosceptic Conservative party which in the populist pursuit of the lowest common denominator has succeeded in awakening even further a nationalistic hostility to all things European - except, of course, holidays, football and wine which don't count because they do not, as far as the British public is concerned, have a political dimension.

But now the government has got a bit of a problem. There is clearly a growing recognition within the administration that whatever the state of public opinion, in the country's own interests Britain is going to have to join the single currency at some point. That was what lay behind the foreign secretary's interview this week in which Robin Cook optimistically asserted that a majority would vote in favour of the euro in a referendum. It may have sounded like a statement based more on optimism than political judgment, but Mr Cook is well aware that he spoke the truth: it is obvious that the government won't hold a referendum that it won't win.

That was the significance, too, of Tony Blair's two-year timetable for reaching an assessment, at least, of the economic circumstances (which he announced deliberately at prime minister's questions on Wednesday). It was two years' notice of the fact that the British electorate is to be softened up for the eventual referendum to which the government is so inconveniently committed.

But if any further compelling evidence was required that a change is under way, it comes from within the Treasury. There is a prevailing atmosphere of mild Euroscepticism among civil servants in the Treasury - one that is apparently scarcely different from the view held five years ago when the other lot were in office, and it has been given some encouragement by the approach of the present chancellor throughout his tenure.

Now Gordon Brown has recently evinced a discernible change in his attitude. He has, for example, in the last few weeks for the first time responded positively to invitations with a European flavour and there has been some surprise at the fact that he has specifically expressed an interest in meeting visiting commissioners when they are in the country.

It has been obvious to a large section of the business and industrial community for a very long time that there is little choice for the UK to remain a member of the European Union without joining the single currency, nor has there been much doubt that it will happen whenever the government decides for political reasons that the pressure has become irresistible. Several of the government's prominent business supporters are fiercely critical, nevertheless, about the way in which the government has failed to address the subject and about the lack of political foresight in its approach.

Some explanation is provided by the anecdote about Philip Gould recited above, but perhaps Mr Blair would have done better to have paid more attention to a less cynical assessment Mr Gould offered in his invaluable work, The Unfinished Revolution. He wrote there: "Focus groups do not of necessity involve dilution of principle or compromise - to say that implies that the voters are fools, which they are not. They want politicians who are tough, honest and courageous and who govern with principle... The public want leaders who lead, they want governments that tough it out." And so say all of us.

webTitle: Japan 'more positive on UK and euro'

fields.headline: Japan 'more positive on UK and euro'
fields.standfirst:
Anxieties are easing as currency firms up, says Tokyo ambassador

Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: Anxieties are easing as currency firms up, says Tokyo ambassador.
fields.body:
Japanese investors are feeling more positive about Britain's position on the euro, the ambassador to Tokyo, Stephen Gomersall, said yesterday in comments that underpin the government's growing confidence on the currency issue.

In a leaked memo in July, the ambassador warned that doubts about the single currency were putting investments at risk because Japanese companies did not see Britain as a safe bet. Despite a year of job and production cuts at the British operations of several leading Japanese corporations, Mr Gomersall said that the European currency's recent rises and a clearer communication of London's position had eased concerns in Tokyo.

"Our impression is that, as the euro has firmed up and with the greater understanding of the complexity of the issues on the UK side, the level of concern expressed publicly by Japanese companies has abated considerably."

Since his warning, the euro has gained significantly against the pound and the British government has reassured Japanese executives that they will not have to wait much longer for a decision on the single currency. Tony Blair added further clarification yesterday when he said that the question would be put to the electorate within two years of the next parliament if Labour wins the next election.

Gomersall said Japanese businessmen continued to see the euro as a key factor in investment calculations, but that other issues were now in play. Japanese car manufacturers, such as Toyota and Honda, have learned to live with the strong pound by cutting costs and shifting the burden of foreign exchange fluctuations on to suppliers.

"The picture is tougher for suppliers. It would not be surprising if there is some reduction of UK content. That's inevitable, given the market," the ambassador said. He welcomed the decision earlier this month by Nissan to build its new Micra model at the company's plant in Sunderland - although the move was only made after managers promised to cut costs by 30% and the government offered a £40bn grant.

He noted, however, that the pattern of Japanese investment into Britain was shifting from lower paid manufacturing operations at economically depressed regions, such as South Wales, to high paid research facilities close to London or at universities. Last year, he said, Japanese companies cut 3,500 jobs from their combined UK workforce of 70,000. New research investments failed to fill the gap, creating only 1,000 to 2,000 jobs.

webTitle: Interview with visionary Swedish filmmaker Roy Andersson

fields.headline: Funny Peculiar
fields.standfirst: His movie features singing tube passengers, 1,000 plywood actors and Benny from Abba... . yet Roy Andersson doesn't think cinema is serious enough. The visionary Swede tells Jonathan Romney  why
fields.trailText: His movie features singing tube passengers, 1,000 plywood actors and Benny from Abba... . yet Roy Andersson doesn't think cinema is serious enough. The visionary Swede tells Jonathan Romney why
fields.body:
The appropriate word for Roy Andersson's new film, Songs From the Second Floor, is "apocalyptic". It is a surreal panorama of social collapse set in a chilly, cheerless world inhabited by pallid, ghost-like beings. Blank-faced tube commuters burst into angelic chorus; hosts of the dead are resurrected in a stretch of wasteland; rats scuttle across a deserted street. Lugubrious as these visions are, an absurdist comedy routine is never far away - almost Dave Allen-ish moments, like the sketch where a stage magician does his saw trick a little too effectively. For every glimpse of the abyss, a belly laugh. And all the time, the camera only moves once.

When Andersson took Songs to Cannes last year, few people knew who this mystery outsider was, or why Lars von Trier had apparently mentioned him as the only Palme d'Or competitor he feared. In fact, for 25 years, Andersson had built a reputation as one of Scandinavia's leading commercials directors - the best in the world, according to Ingmar Bergman - and as a perfectionist who does things entirely on his own terms. When he visited London recently, I didn't know what kind of monster I was going to meet: a remote Scandinavian Kubrick, surely?

But Andersson doesn't fit that image at all. He's a soft-spoken, stocky, middle-aged man with a red face and a denim shirt - a Roy through and through. Songs is nothing more or less than Andersson's personal statement on the human condition. He has been planning it since the early 1980s, when he discovered the lines by Peruvian poet Cesar Vallejo that run as a theme of universal benediction through the film. "Originally," he says, "the film was a mixture of two very different ideas. One was a very poetic, very simple film that I thought would be shot in an almost documentary style, based on the poem. But I also had another idea that was more polemical, satirical, political, and I managed to mix the two."

The result is an eerie mix of the cartoonish and the spiritual. Andersson admits he is a religious film-maker, but only in the way that Bunuel was. "He loved human beings and he loved people who are religious, but not priests. The Vallejo poem is almost religious in the sense that it's so respectful of vulnerable human beings. I'm not religious in the sense that I think we have connections to heaven, but I do have full respect for the Sermon on the Mount - 'Do to others as you would have them do to you.'"

Andersson's compassion doesn't stop him from turning his players into monstrous puppets, slouching around in a world with a colour palette reduced to grey and bilious yellow. Years ago, Andersson realised he "was tired of pure realism - it got to the point where I'd have to stop and find another job, or try and develop the language of cinematography". He found his new direction by looking to painting, especially Germans such as Otto Dix and Georg Grosz, and to the theatre of Beckett and Strindberg. Hence his characters' wraith-like make-up: "I wanted them to be more universal than individuals. They represent us."

In fact, Andersson's cast members are not actors playing faceless figures, but non-professionals who bring their physical peculiarities (pretty extreme peculiarities at that) to bulk out his dream world. Some of them are familiar to Swedish TV viewers as regulars in Andersson's commercials; nearly all are fished at random from Swedish society. They include a lawyer, a retired insurance clerk, and a former embassy chauffeur. The whale-like Lars Nordh, who plays a depressive businessman, was spotted shopping at Ikea; he's since become famous as a mean-spirited farmer in Andersson's dairy ads.

"I've been collecting characters for years," Andersson says. Recruiting, he admits, isn't always easy. "You have to behave very respectfully. Sometimes I wonder how Fellini could get all those characters. We don't go as far as Fellini, but it's always a little hard to go up to people. I meet them in stores, restaurants, gas stations, and I also send out researchers. It's worse if you're not known, of course - especially if I were going up to young girls and saying, 'I'm in the film business.' It's always very delicate."

If Andersson's people are real, their habitat isn't. Everything in Songs is the result of elaborate trompe l'oeil set-dressing - even a massive traffic jam is done in-house. Occasionally, he leaves his own Studio 24 for the real world, but always altering it. A scene in which thousands of onlookers gather at an outdoor ceremony of sacrifice is not the digital illusion we are used to - Andersson found it cheaper to hire a thousand extras, and then knock up another thousand out of plywood. The film's final scene alone, a long single shot, took over a month to set up: "We even built the city in the distance - it's miniature, but three-dimensional."

It isn't that Andersson is not interested in the real world. "But to describe it, it's not certain that the best thing is to be realistic. Waiting for Godot says a lot about our time, but it's a timeless play. The characters are just talking gossip, nonsense, but at the same time they're talking about us."

Andersson's perfectionism goes to extraordinary lengths. Rather than write scripts, he likes to "sketch" individual scenes by shooting 35mm tests for them, reworking them until he is satisfied. For one role in Songs, he tested 1,000 young actors, before changing the part entirely. So how did he become this monster of control? Very slowly, over more than a quarter-century. Even before graduating from film school, he had signed to make his first film in 1969, A Swedish Love Story, a lyrical teenage romance made under the influence of the Czech new wave; it has only hints of today's Andersson, but you can spot his touch in a demented chase through fog following a drunken night of crayfish-guzzling.

That film was a major critical and commercial hit. His second, Giliap, made in 1975, was a flop that went over budget and made Andersson something of a pariah in Swedish cinema. It's a bizarre deadpan comedy about a hotel waiter that shows Andersson developing his particular gag style. Giliap left Andersson in debt, so he gladly accepted the offer to shoot commercials. His years of ads, especially one in 1985 for the leftwing Social Democrat party, let him develop a new style - punctiliously-timed sight gags, usually in single shots, and increasingly using his distinctively strange lighting, "a light without mercy, where there was no possibility to escape or to hide - but in a soft way, naked".

The 25 years between his second and third features make Andersson cinema's champion absentee, beating even Terrence Malick and Victor Erice. That time also allowed him to set up his Studio 24, make two shorts (one of them a phenomenally depressing Aids information film) and to write a book called Our Fear of Seriousness in Our Time - "about moral questions, arbitrariness, guilt, morals and art".

Andersson is big on seriousness. "I felt it was not fair that painting should be regarded as visually richer than a movie. When I decided to be a director, it was the period of Wajda, Antonioni, Bunuel. Nowadays that seriousness is very rare. I try to work for that to come back. We have to get back the responsibility and respect for quality and seriousness."

It's hard to reconcile such moral severity with the fact that Songs was scored by no less a Swedish pop icon than Abba's Benny Andersson (no relation) - admittedly, in a rather more sombre key than Fernando or Super Trouper. In fact, Andersson looks a little pained when I ask about the Abba connection. "No, I knew him through his work with a Swedish painter. I was never an Abba fan. Though I admire some so-called riffs or fills." And he hums the cod-Rachmaninov piano frill from Dancing Queen.

We may not have to wait another 25 years for Andersson's next film. He has two in mind, one of them an adaptation of Céline's sublimely misanthropic novel, Journey to the End of Night. In less than a year, Andersson's reputation has undergone a metamorphosis - he's now widely regarded as a world-class auteur, not just a superior commercials specialist. Mind you, someone who can sell insurance policies and yoghurt to Ingmar Bergman was always bound to be a force to reckon with.

Songs From the Second Floor is released next Friday.

For every glimpse of the abyss, a belly laugh. And all the time, the camera only moves once. When Andersson took Songs to Cannes last year, few people knew who this mystery outsider was, or why Lars von Trier had apparently mentioned him as the only Palme d'Or competitor he feared. In fact, for 25 years, Andersson had built a reputation as one of Scandinavia's leading commercials directors - the best in the world, according to Ingmar Bergman - and as a perfectionist who does things entirely on his own terms. When he visited London recently, I didn't know what kind of monster I was going to meet: a remote Scandinavian Kubrick, surely? But Andersson doesn't fit that image at all. He's a soft-spoken, stocky, middle-aged man with a red face and a denim shirt - a Roy through and through. Songs is nothing more or less than Andersson's personal statement on the human condition. He has been planning it since the early 1980s, when he discovered the lines by Peruvian poet Cesar Vallejo that run as a theme of universal benediction through the film. "Originally," he says, "the film was a mixture of two very different ideas. One was a very poetic, very simple film that I thought would be shot in an almost documentary style, based on the poem. But I also had another idea that was more polemical, satirical, political, and I managed to mix the two." The result is an eerie mix of the cartoonish and the spiritual. Andersson admits he is a religious film-maker, but only in the way that Bunuel was. "He loved human beings and he loved people who are religious, but not priests. The Vallejo poem is almost religious in the sense that it's so respectful of vulnerable human beings. I'm not religious in the sense that I think we have connections to heaven, but I do have full respect for the Sermon on the Mount - 'Do to others as you would have them do to you.'" Andersson's compassion doesn't stop him from turning his players into monstrous puppets, slouching around in a world with a colour palette reduced to grey and bilious yellow. Years ago, Andersson realised he "was tired of pure realism - it got to the point where I'd have to stop and find another job, or try and develop the language of cinematography". He found his new direction by looking to painting, especially Germans such as Otto Dix and Georg Grosz, and to the theatre of Beckett and Strindberg. Hence his characters' wraith-like make-up: "I wanted them to be more universal than individuals. They represent us." In fact, Andersson's cast members are not actors playing faceless figures, but non-professionals who bring their physical peculiarities (pretty extreme peculiarities at that) to bulk out his dream world. Some of them are familiar to Swedish TV viewers as regulars in Andersson's commercials; nearly all are fished at random from Swedish society. They include a lawyer, a retired insurance clerk, and a former embassy chauffeur. The whale-like Lars Nordh, who plays a depressive businessman, was spotted shopping at Ikea; he's since become famous as a mean-spirited farmer in Andersson's dairy ads. "I've been collecting characters for years," Andersson says. Recruiting, he admits, isn't always easy. "You have to behave very respectfully. Sometimes I wonder how Fellini could get all those characters. We don't go as far as Fellini, but it's always a little hard to go up to people. I meet them in stores, restaurants, gas stations, and I also send out researchers. It's worse if you're not known, of course - especially if I were going up to young girls and saying, 'I'm in the film business.' It's always very delicate." If Andersson's people are real, their habitat isn't. Everything in Songs is the result of elaborate trompe l'oeil set-dressing - even a massive traffic jam is done in-house. Occasionally, he leaves his own Studio 24 for the real world, but always altering it. A scene in which thousands of onlookers gather at an outdoor ceremony of sacrifice is not the digital illusion we are used to - Andersson found it cheaper to hire a thousand extras, and then knock up another thousand out of plywood. The film's final scene alone, a long single shot, took over a month to set up: "We even built the city in the distance - it's miniature, but three-dimensional." It isn't that Andersson is not interested in the real world. "But to describe it, it's not certain that the best thing is to be realistic. Waiting for Godot says a lot about our time, but it's a timeless play. The characters are just talking gossip, nonsense, but at the same time they're talking about us." Andersson's perfectionism goes to extraordinary lengths. Rather than write scripts, he likes to "sketch" individual scenes by shooting 35mm tests for them, reworking them until he is satisfied. For one role in Songs, he tested 1,000 young actors, before changing the part entirely. So how did he become this monster of control? Very slowly, over more than a quarter-century. Even before graduating from film school, he had signed to make his first film in 1969, A Swedish Love Story, a lyrical teenage romance made under the influence of the Czech new wave; it has only hints of today's Andersson, but you can spot his touch in a demented chase through fog following a drunken night of crayfish-guzzling. That film was a major critical and commercial hit. His second, Giliap, made in 1975, was a flop that went over budget and made Andersson something of a pariah in Swedish cinema. It's a bizarre deadpan comedy about a hotel waiter that shows Andersson developing his particular gag style. Giliap left Andersson in debt, so he gladly accepted the offer to shoot commercials. His years of ads, especially one in 1985 for the leftwing Social Democrat party, let him develop a new style - punctiliously-timed sight gags, usually in single shots, and increasingly using his distinctively strange lighting, "a light without mercy, where there was no possibility to escape or to hide - but in a soft way, naked". The 25 years between his second and third features make Andersson cinema's champion absentee, beating even Terrence Malick and Victor Erice. That time also allowed him to set up his Studio 24, make two shorts (one of them a phenomenally depressing Aids information film) and to write a book called Our Fear of Seriousness in Our Time - "about moral questions, arbitrariness, guilt, morals and art". Andersson is big on seriousness. "I felt it was not fair that painting should be regarded as visually richer than a movie. When I decided to be a director, it was the period of Wajda, Antonioni, Bunuel. Nowadays that seriousness is very rare. I try to work for that to come back. We have to get back the responsibility and respect for quality and seriousness." It's hard to reconcile such moral severity with the fact that Songs was scored by no less a Swedish pop icon than Abba's Benny Andersson (no relation) - admittedly, in a rather more sombre key than Fernando or Super Trouper. In fact, Andersson looks a little pained when I ask about the Abba connection. "No, I knew him through his work with a Swedish painter. I was never an Abba fan. Though I admire some so-called riffs or fills." And he hums the cod-Rachmaninov piano frill from Dancing Queen. We may not have to wait another 25 years for Andersson's next film. He has two in mind, one of them an adaptation of Céline's sublimely misanthropic novel, Journey to the End of Night. In less than a year, Andersson's reputation has undergone a metamorphosis - he's now widely regarded as a world-class auteur, not just a superior commercials specialist. Mind you, someone who can sell insurance policies and yoghurt to Ingmar Bergman was always bound to be a force to reckon with. Songs From the Second Floor is released next Friday.

webTitle: Another look at Breakfast at Tiffany's

fields.headline: She's a real phoney
fields.standfirst: When Breakfast at Tiffany's was released in 1961, Audrey Hepburn was hailed as the embodiment of the chic, liberated, modern woman. Now her femininity looks like a shallow, male construction. By  Joan Smith
fields.trailText: When Breakfast at Tiffany's was released in 1961, Audrey Hepburn was hailed as the embodiment of the chic, liberated, modern woman. Now her femininity looks like a shallow, male construction. By Joan Smith
fields.body:
In 1961, when Truman Capote was considering an actress for the part of Holly Golightly in the film adaptation of his novel Breakfast at Tiffany's, Marilyn Monroe was his choice. But Paramount insisted on giving the part to Audrey Hepburn, the waifish former model who was far more in the style of Jackie Kennedy, the country's new first lady, than the troubled Hollywood star.

Capote was dismayed by the choice, but Hepburn went on to make the role her own, so much so that her image in the movie - swept-up hair, little black dress - has come to evoke an entire era. Standing outside Tiffany's jewellery store in New York in the film's opening scene, impossibly soignée in a sculpted evening gown, Hepburn represents both the elegance of the period and a sense of class barriers about to break down. Locked out of the shop, which has not yet started business for the day, Hepburn still manages to convey - as she does throughout the film - an unshakeable conviction that its doors will one day open for her.

"She's a phoney," says Martin Balsam, playing a visiting Hollywood agent who knows Golightly's secret small-town background, "but she's a real phoney." The film is set in a time of optimism, two years before Jack Kennedy's assassination, and of innocence, just before the sexual revolution arrived to sweep away both its certainties and its paradoxes.

Golightly seems like a girl on the make, a sophisticated New Yorker with her sights set on a rich husband. But through all the wild parties, she remains untouched, gradually revealing her true self to George Peppard, playing an impoverished author who has moved into the apartment upstairs. Hepburn lives on her own, in a stylish flat, but she inhabits a moment when a woman's career consists of a good marriage and virginity remains a unit of exchange. (Is Holly, as she appears to be in the film, a virgin? In one of its many ambiguities, she assures a bemused Peppard that her marriage to a Texan horse doctor was annulled rather than ending in divorce.)

Holly may be brittle and sophisticated, but she is also unknowing, claiming not to realise that the "weather reports" she carries for a drug dealer in Sing Sing are coded messages to his accomplices. The movie relies heavily on her childlike screen presence to preserve the pristine sentimentality that lies beneath its couldn't-care-less facade. This is most evident in the final scene between Hepburn and an extremely wet (in both senses) Peppard, but it also emerges earlier in the film, when Hepburn climbs through a window in his apartment at four in the morning, escaping from an over-enthusiastic admirer, and finds him in bed. "Do you mind if I just get in with you for a minute?" she asks, snuggling up beside him. Peppard holds her like a child until she wakes in tears from a nightmare and exits through the same window.

After a performance that appears to mistake dullness for reticence, and asexuality for inexperience, it isn't surprising that Peppard never made the leap into the major roles predicted for him. But the scene is striking for other reasons: one of them a sense of how differently Monroe would have played it, the other a realisation of the paradoxical qualities that made Hepburn a major star, but only briefly.

Unlike Monroe and Doris Day - with whom she perhaps has more in common - Hepburn does not feature in Women in Film: an International Guide, the authoritative volume edited by the feminist critic Annette Kuhn, with Susannah Radstone. She is famous for a handful of movies, including My Fair Lady in 1964, but her film career was effectively over by 1968, when she divorced her first husband, the actor Mel Ferrer, and moved to Rome with her second, an Italian psychiatrist called Dr Andrea Dotti. A brief comeback in the 1970s produced only two movies, both of them undistinguished. Robin and Marian, in 1976, cast Hepburn improbably as Maid Marian in a medieval caper in which a middle-aged Robin Hood returns to Sherwood Forest after years in exile; and Bloodline, an adaptation in 1979 of a Sidney Sheldon novel, which was candidly described by one critic as "unbearable".

A few more films followed in the 1980s, after her divorce from Dotti, but it seemed as thoughHepburn's heart was no longer in cinema. Towards the end of her life she lived with another actor, Robert Wolders, who shared her Dutch background, and threw herself into a new career as a roving ambassador for the UN children's agency, Unicef. When she died of colon cancer at her home in Switzerland in 1993, her first husband was a pall-bearer at her funeral, signalling her capacity for enduring friendship in an industry notorious for feuds and rivalries.

What is not clear is whether Hepburn tired of cinema or whether she recognised, pragmatically, that she was too much of her era to enjoy a lengthy acting career. An exact contemporary of Jackie Kennedy - both were born to wealthy parents in 1929 - Hepburn's background was cosmopolitan. Born near Brussels, Edda Kathleen van Heemstra Hepburn-Ruston has often been described as Dutch because she grew up in the Netherlands with her parents, a Dutch baroness and an Anglo-Irish banker. Commenting on her gamine appearance, critics recalled that she spent her childhood in Nazi-occupied Holland, where food was in short supply and the family was sometimes reduced to eating tulip bulbs.

Yet this ignores the fact that Hepburn began her modelling career as slenderness was becoming the order of the day; her willowy good looks were the precursor of a style that would, within a few years, be democratised by Twiggy and Jean Shrimpton. And even if Hepburn was perceived as having class, it was not in a straightforward way; Holly Golightly cheekily appropriates the manners of the rich in Breakfast at Tiffany's and Eliza Doolittle, three years later in My Fair Lady, has painfully to acquire them. This suggests that Hepburn's most important films are about reinvention, specifically what it means to be a woman, at a time of increasing gender insecurity.

Unlike Monroe, only three years older but seeming to belong to an earlier generation, she does not use her sexuality in an overt way. The threat her beauty might pose is instead deflected by an emphasis on her infantile and androgynous qualities. "It was a face beyond childhood, yet this side of belonging to a woman," Capote wrote of Golightly, perfectly capturing the yearnings and anxieties with which men were beginning to regard women shortly before the sexual revolution got going.

Yet if Hepburn's screen persona represents an experiment in the modernisation of femininity, its limitations are also writ large - and not just because of its dependence on her youth. She had actually been around as an actress since the early 1950s, when she won an Oscar for Roman Holiday, and was 32 by the time she took on Holly Golightly; when she retired in 1968, aged 39, she may not have relished the character parts that would soon beckon in an incorrigibly ageist business.

Yet there is also a sense in which Hepburn's onscreen modernity, like Holly Golightly's, was only skin-deep. Her trademark look, all sculpted hair, cigarette holder and picture hats, was the antithesis of the hippie déshabillé that came into fashion as the 1960s progressed. It was also, again like Golightly, essentially the product of a series of male constructions, principally the couturier Hubert de Givenchy, who dressed her for Breakfast at Tiffany's and came to regard her as something of a muse. It is here that the parallel with Jackie Kennedy becomes most insistent. At the beginning of the 1960s, the first lady and the Oscar-winning actress looked like a new type of woman: chic, daring, informal, breaking with postwar convention. Within a few years, the shallowness of that alteration would be exposed by a much more radical reappraisal of contemporary femininity, rethinking everything from the shape of women's underwear to the desirability of marriage. It marked the end of a brief, intoxicating phase in which women had been offered a new vision of themselves, only to discover it was mostly cosmetic.

Hepburn herself, the most reticent of stars, may have been happy to step back and allow other actresses such as Julie Christie and Jane Fonda to carry on the experiment in movies such as Darling and Barbarella. Both these films - released in 1965 and 1968 respectively - are so quintessentially products of the nascent sexual revolution that they put Breakfast at Tiffany's, and its androgynous star, in their proper perspective. With her huge eyes and parted lips, Hepburn may have looked for a moment like the face of the 1960s. But, as the new print of Blake Edwards's film reveals, both she and the forces that created her belong firmly in the previous decade.

It is perhaps this paradox that makes her perfect for nostalgic revivals. Hepburn's short heyday was on the cusp of two extraordinary decades, a social change which her teasing image - child-woman, both innocent and experienced - embodies. As a former model, she may have had more awareness than some of her contemporaries that her shelf-life was limited, leaving the screen by choice - unlike Monroe - before her audience became jaded. Never achieving superstar status, she also managed, as her perennial return to the fashion and arts pages confirms, to remain something of an enigma.

Breakfast at Tiffany's is reissued next Friday.

fields.headline: Matshushita job cuts
fields.trailText: Poor results from Matsushita Communication's British operations could be the prelude to a cutback in the UK by Japan's largest maker of mobile phones.
fields.body:
Poor results from Matsushita Communication's British operations could be the prelude to a cutback in the UK by Japan's largest maker of mobile phones.

The company said its UK manufacturing business would lose 1.2bn yen (£6m) in the six months to March, compared to an earlier estimate of ´85m profit. The losses could seal the fate of the group's packaging plant in Portsmouth, which employs 250; it warned last month it was considering a closure of the facility.

Analysts said Matsushita may bring forward the start of operations at a new plant in Pardubice in the Czech Republic that is scheduled to open in October. With lower labour costs, the Czech plant is expected to be more competitive than the group's factories in Portsmouth and Thatcham, Berkshire, which has 660 staff.

However, Jeffrey Suff, senior director of Matsushita Communication in Britain, said the company would not close all of its UK operations.

fields.headline: Private lives
fields.standfirst: My partner's three children and his vasectomy are coming between us - I want a baby of my own, so should I leave him?
fields.trailText: My partner's three children and his vasectomy are coming between us - I want a baby of my own, so should I leave him?
fields.body:
I have lived with my partner for eight months (we had dated for two years). I knew he had three children (now 12, 17 and 19) but was naive to the emotional complications involved. I can't seem to come to terms with sharing him with three significant others he in turn shares with someone else. I'm 37, have led a full life, have no children and would like a family with this man whom I love dearly. He recently underwent a vasectomy reversal which was unsuccessful. He seems to have so much in terms of his "other life". I fear that I will always feel a poor second to his children. I've tried getting to know them by inviting them to stay occasionally and joining us on holiday (it allowed me to see them as individuals and we did get along fine). I've also tried distancing myself. My partner tells me they are not competition but feels I'd be better off with a "free" man who could give me children as he doesn't want to be the cause of any future bitterness for me. We want desperately to stay together but I don't know how to achieve it.

Get to know them

I faced the same question 15 years ago. My partner had two children and was unable to have more. I had to ask myself whether I was prepared to lose what we had in the hope that I might meet someone with whom I could have children and have the same quality of relationship. There was no choice.

We have now been happily married for more than 11 years. My relationship with my two "stepchildren" is close and a joy. So cultivate your relationship with his children by getting to know them better, inviting them frequently and becoming part of the life they have with their father. Remember that we always share those we love with others: it would be selfish not to.
Name and address withheld

Accept reality

If you cannot come to terms with the fact that your partner already has a family and that you will not be able to have your own family with him, then you should look for a "free" man as he suggests. If you are able wholeheartedly to accept these two facts then you may well have a happy future ahead of you.

You said you got on well with your partner's children when you had been with them. This is a good sign as it must be a great deal worse for them than it is for you seeing their father living with someone other than their mother. All children whatever age want their parents to be together. So if you are already friends then you are only a step away from being an addition to his family.
Margaret Francis, London

Rethink motherhood

A baby after the age of 37 is a big shock all round, however delightful, and very time consuming. I know - I've done it. My second husband was much older than me and I have older stepchildren. The children of my first marriage have had a savage relationship with their stepmother who could not accept that she could make a good relationship with them without excluding me. As a result she has missed out on knowing two people and a stepgrandchild.
Name and address withheld

Counselling can help

Your partner says to you that he feels you would be better off with a "free" man who could give you children. I am curious that, in your next sentence, you share that you both want to stay together. I wonder what it is that you both really want? What we say and what we feel can often get mixed up, and it is clear from your letter that the gap between thinking and feeling is causing great pain in your relationship with him.

As a counsellor, I am aware that the way we live our lives today makes it not uncommon that one or both partners often bring other people, their children, into the equation. This can either be viewed as "baggage" or an opportunity for some personal development work together. If you couldn't have children, is your love strong enough to hold you together? If you feel a poor second to his children, who one day will leave home and make their own way in the world, how can you address this situation in the here and now? Couples counselling together could be a good place for this exploration towards clarity.
Mic Morgan, Oxford

There's no competition

You say that you desire children, however the main emotional thrust of your problem seems to be that you feel threatened or upstaged by your partner's three children. This problem should be resolved first.

Surely you must realise that your partner loves his children in a completely different way to how he loves you? He does not live with them or have sex with them and relates to them in a very different fashion. In one aspect, they occupy all his attention - in another aspect, they do not exist.

This is where you must show your maturity and let go of your jealousy. They are not really a menace to you. If you cannot do that, the only answer is working on the problem with a therapist.
Name and address withheld

Next week

In November I was diagnosed with a malignant ovarian tumour and, following a hysterectomy, am on chemotherapy. A side effect is hair loss. I found this difficult, not being a hat or scarf sort of person, and avoided deciding what to do until the need arose. I discussed it with some close, supportive friends and family.

My sister-in-law (husband's brother's wife), with whom we have little intimate contact, sent me two headscarves with a note that this was an unbirthday present. I was devastated and reminded that something I was dreading was round the corner. The scarves were no doubt meant kindly, but I was left a weeping heap. She then emailed me to ask if I liked them. Do I tell her how I felt or lie to avoid offence? Since then, my hair has fallen out rapidly. I have had my head shaved and been on a shopping expedition. But I have to reply to my sister-in-law.

fields.bodyText: I have lived with my partner for eight months (we had dated for two years). I knew he had three children (now 12, 17 and 19) but was naive to the emotional complications involved. I can't seem to come to terms with sharing him with three significant others he in turn shares with someone else. I'm 37, have led a full life, have no children and would like a family with this man whom I love dearly. He recently underwent a vasectomy reversal which was unsuccessful. He seems to have so much in terms of his "other life". I fear that I will always feel a poor second to his children. I've tried getting to know them by inviting them to stay occasionally and joining us on holiday (it allowed me to see them as individuals and we did get along fine). I've also tried distancing myself. My partner tells me they are not competition but feels I'd be better off with a "free" man who could give me children as he doesn't want to be the cause of any future bitterness for me. We want desperately to stay together but I don't know how to achieve it. Get to know them I faced the same question 15 years ago. My partner had two children and was unable to have more. I had to ask myself whether I was prepared to lose what we had in the hope that I might meet someone with whom I could have children and have the same quality of relationship. There was no choice. We have now been happily married for more than 11 years. My relationship with my two "stepchildren" is close and a joy. So cultivate your relationship with his children by getting to know them better, inviting them frequently and becoming part of the life they have with their father. Remember that we always share those we love with others: it would be selfish not to. Name and address withheld Accept reality If you cannot come to terms with the fact that your partner already has a family and that you will not be able to have your own family with him, then you should look for a "free" man as he suggests. If you are able wholeheartedly to accept these two facts then you may well have a happy future ahead of you. You said you got on well with your partner's children when you had been with them. This is a good sign as it must be a great deal worse for them than it is for you seeing their father living with someone other than their mother. All children whatever age want their parents to be together. So if you are already friends then you are only a step away from being an addition to his family. My second husband was much older than me and I have older stepchildren. The children of my first marriage have had a savage relationship with their stepmother who could not accept that she could make a good relationship with them without excluding me. As a result she has missed out on knowing two people and a stepgrandchild. I am curious that, in your next sentence, you share that you both want to stay together. I wonder what it is that you both really want? What we say and what we feel can often get mixed up, and it is clear from your letter that the gap between thinking and feeling is causing great pain in your relationship with him. webTitle: Unilever enjoys City welcome for refocused marketing

fields.headline: Unilever enjoys City welcome for refocused marketing
fields.trailText: Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer products group, yesterday revealed it had axed 630 brands as part of a major restructuring and would reap rich rewards from focusing on its 400 best selling products.
fields.body:
Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer products group, yesterday revealed it had axed 630 brands as part of a major restructuring and would reap rich rewards from focusing on its 400 best selling products.

The company said it was enjoying bumper sales from its leading names, which include Dove and Flora, but the reorganisation costs dragged it into the red by Û620m (£394m) in last year's final quarter.

Chairman Niall FitzGerald - pictured above, right, with Peter Lack of Birdseye - insisted that the firm's "path to growth" programme, announced last year, was on track with sales of the top brands increasing by almost 5% at the end of 2000.

He said the firm, which last year spent Û28bn on acquisitions such as SlimFast, Ben & Jerry's ice-cream and Bestfoods, had cut the head count by over 5,000 and brands would be cut to 400 in four years. The past 12 months has also seen various disposals, including Elizabeth Arden and the Oxo and Batchelors operations.

Underlying operating profits were up 16% at Û5.3bn, but exceptionals at the end of the year brought the full year pre-tax profits down 39% at Û2.6bn. The annual dividend was up 5% at 13.07p.

The City's reaction, however, was low key, with shares falling 5p at 531p last night. This is well below the 590.5p year's high, but comfortably ahead of the 324p low. Analysts were pleased with the figures, but pointed out the 1.8% overall sales growth was fairly humble compared to rivals Danone and Nestl.

"They are pretty good numbers, but I would like to see them hurry up the divestments," one analyst said. Mr FitzGerald said the firm would launch 20 "major initiatives" over the coming year and was investing £20m in Enjoy, its boil in the bag range which will also be sold in petrol stations and video shops.

He also expects to complete the sale of Bestfood's fresh baked foods US business early next month.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • The Diary seeks a volunteer, no more than 5ft 7in tall, for a quick and lucrative job. With rumours seeping from the Home Office that Hinduja whitewash man Skippy Hammond is becoming a little, well, jumpy about his new celebrity, urgent steps are required to settle his nerves. Clearly, with the kangaroo court decision already announced twice (by Messrs Straw and Campbell), Skippy has an unnerving amount of time to kill, and needs something to keep him occupied. To this end we are having a huge jigsaw made from a picture of Mr Tony and Cherie enjoying the Hindujas' company. All we now require is someone to deliver this to him one morning next week at the Home Office, while wearing the kangaroo suit we are hiring from theatrical costumier Angels and Bermans. This will only fit someone of 5ft 7in or less. Applications must arrive by Monday lunchtime, and the fee is £100.

With rumours seeping from the Home Office that Hinduja whitewash man Skippy Hammond is becoming a little, well, jumpy about his new celebrity, urgent steps are required to settle his nerves. Clearly, with the kangaroo court decision already announced twice (by Messrs Straw and Campbell), Skippy has an unnerving amount of time to kill, and needs something to keep him occupied. To this end we are having a huge jigsaw made from a picture of Mr Tony and Cherie enjoying the Hindujas' company. All we now require is someone to deliver this to him one morning next week at the Home Office, while wearing the kangaroo suit we are hiring from theatrical costumier Angels and Bermans. This will only fit someone of 5ft 7in or less. Applications must arrive by Monday lunchtime, and the fee is £100.

 I am sad to note signs of uncertainty in the press about the level of Skippy's independence from Jack Straw (absurd: the fact that, on Today recently, Jack called him "Wally", an alternative nickname used by intimate colleagues, means nothing). On Wednesday, the Mail devoted a page to the subject, while yesterday both the FT's Brian Groom and Telegraph enforcer Boris the Jackal Johnson raised major doubts about Mandy's guilt. Perfect timing, then, for Stephen Glover's Spectator piece headlined "What happened to all Peter's friends in the newspapers?"

 Surveillance: Helen Brinton, during last Friday's rush hour at Westminster tube station, tripping down the stairs, showering the ticket hall with the contents of her handbag and gaily yelling : "It's the shoes! It's the shoes!"

 As if Sharon's election weren't enough, our Jewish community is struck by scandal. Children's charity Norwood Ravenswood refuses to accept money raised for it at Finchley Synagogue, the Jewish Chronicle reports, because the event was a stag night featuring strippers performing "sexually explicit acts". Although the Torah fails expressly to ban this fundraising method, Finchley Rabbi Ephraim Mirvis is "disgusted at what they did". (If anyone knows precisely what they did do, please, let us know: the JC is elliptical on the point). Charles Smith of the event organisers mounts a stout defence. "It happened at the end of the show, and wasn't part of what we booked," he tells the JC. "The girls carried on with the extra act at the end." A freebie from strippers ... terrible thing.

 Thrilling news of the woman whose personal fuse supply was plundered at the height of the Times plug crisis. Religion correspondent Ruth Gledhill has been selected for the Great Britain ballroom dancing team! There is nothing on www.ruthgledhill.com yet, but we expect further details forthwith.

 Hats off to Phil Hall, onetime raven-haired News of the World editor who has suddenly allowed himself go quite grey in the quest for the gravitas required in his new post. Phil is now the editor of Hello!, and his first edition is a triumph. The big exclusive is "intimate pictures of where Prince William will be studying". Turning eagerly to the pages, we find snaps of furniture in a St Andrews hall of residence bedroom. In fact this is all wrong (William will live in a private flat), but so what? Some material is so strong as to excuse a certain licence with the facts.

 Lonrho's annual report is out, and predictably Tiny Rowland's old firm has good news from Africa, where among much else it owns hotels. "Mozambique was devastated by floods during the year," observes the chief executive's review. "The resulting influx of aid agency personnel and world press increased occupancy at the Hotel Cardoso." How enchanting.

webTitle: Green tax scheme flawed, say auditors

fields.headline: Green tax scheme flawed, say auditors
fields.trailText: Britain's first green tax credit scheme has "fundamental weaknesses", the national audit office reports today.
fields.body:
Britain's first green tax credit scheme has "fundamental weaknesses", the national audit office reports today.

The examination of the running of the scheme by parliament's financial watchdog backs up an investigation by the Guardian last year which disclosed its flaws.

The landfill tax credit scheme was set up by the Tories in 1996 to make polluters pay - so far it has brought in £350m to help the environment. It allows waste firms to avoid paying up to 20% of the £11 a tonne tax if they donate the proceeds to environmental trusts. The scheme created a private company, Entrust, to regulate. It also allowed waste companies to set up their own environment trust if they did not have a majority on the board.

The Guardian investigation revealed the scheme had been dominated by the waste industry, was prone to conflicts of interest between waste companies and local councils, and had been defrauded of at least £5m. Some councils made contractors, bidding for refuse collection, give money to favoured environmental bodies or not be considered for the work.

Now the auditors have confirmed that "there are some fundamental weaknesses in the design of the scheme and in the arrangements for its oversight by Entrust".

"There is a risk that Entrust's board may appear to be biased - even unintentionally," said the report. "This is because the decisions of the board on the regulation of the scheme could be influenced unduly in favour of site operators with their large grouping on the board, and especially as the waste management industry also provides the funds".

The auditors concluded the scheme should be simplified; called for waste companies' representation on Entrust's board to be diluted; questioned whether refuse firms should set up their own environmental trusts; and said councils should be banned from requiring waste contractors to give cash to favoured environmental trusts. They also revealed Entrust had not been monitoring funds properly.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Peace summit in Colombia
The Colombian president, Andres Pastrana, flew into guerrilla territory yesterday for a summit aimed at rescuing peace talks. Mr Pastrana was due to meet Manuel Marulanda, the commander of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc). The rebels walked out of formal talks in November. The rebels demanded that Mr Pastrana crack down on rightwing paramilitary militias and scale back an anti-drug drive.
AP, San Vicente del Caguan
fields.body:
Peace summit in Colombia

Mr Pastrana was due to meet Manuel Marulanda, the commander of the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (Farc). The rebels walked out of formal talks in November. The rebels demanded that Mr Pastrana crack down on rightwing paramilitary militias and scale back an anti-drug drive.
AP, San Vicente del Caguan

Burundi rebels clash with army
Burundian Hutu rebels claimed yesterday to have killed 113 government soldiers in renewed fighting. The Forces for the Defence of Democracy said that the fighting took place in late January in the province of Makamba when rebels responded to army attacks. An army spokesman said that five soldiers and "many" rebels had died in the clashes.
AP, Nairobi

Unrest rocks central Vietnam
Soldiers, riot police and helicopters patrolled two provinces in central Vietnam yesterday after protests by ethnic hill farmers over religion and land. The foreign ministry said 20 people were arrested in Gia Lai province for "provocative acts" and damaging state property in what diplomats called Vietnam's worst unrest for years. A ministry spokeswoman said members of the security forces were hurt in clashes.
Reuters, Hanoi

War crimes suspect hunted
Croatian police yesterday began a search for former general Mirko Norac, Croatia's most senior military war crimes suspect, after he failed to hand himself in by an agreed deadline. Mr Norac was the military commander of the Gospic area at the start of the war in Croatia, when scores of Serb civilians were shot by the local army and police. Reuters, Zagreb Kosovo church attacked A blast virtually destroyed an Orthodox church in in the village of Gornji Livoc, eastern Kosovo, late on Wednesday, a spokesman for the Nato-led peacekeeping force said yesterday. Dozens of Serb Orthodox Christian churches have been destroyed by ethnic Albanians since Yugoslav forces pulled out of Kosovo.
AP, Pristina

£4m diamond eludes police
Police have yet to find a trace of a pink diamond worth at least £4m that disappeared during an air shipment from Geneva to South Africa, where it was to be cut and polished. The packaging for the 162.4-carat stone arrived in Johannesburg on January 24 but the diamond was not inside. A £200,000 reward is on offer for its return.
AP, Zurich

Night in cell for Miami mayor
The mayor of Miami spent a night in his own city's jail despite his wife's efforts to convince officials that her husband did not mean to hurt her when he hit her with a terra cotta tea caddy. Maria Ledon Carollo told police on Wednesday that Joe Carollo struck her on the head with the canister. Mr Carollo, 45, was charged with simple battery and was due to be released on a bond yesterday.
AP, Miami
