fields.headline: My week: Don Hale
fields.standfirst: Don Hale is the editor of the Matlock Mercury and a long-time campaigner for Stephen Downing, who was released from prison on Tuesday
fields.trailText: Don Hale is the editor of the Matlock Mercury and a long-time campaigner for Stephen Downing, who was released from prison on Tuesday.
fields.body:
Most of Monday we were talking to the Downing family, covering queries going back 25 or 27 years, checking witness statements with Stephen's parents and his barrister - just making sure we were prepared. I also double-up as sports editor on the paper, so I had the darts and doms to cover, and the leagues for the kids' football, and Matlock are doing well in the FA trophy at the moment ... trivial things, but it brings you down to earth.

There was already a bit of media build-up on Monday. The media interest this week has been tremendous. I've had camera crews in from all over the world, from Canada and Germany and Holland and the US. I've done interviews with Trevor McDonald and Channel 5.

On Tuesday we were just trying to wrap things up as soon as possible so we could get away to London early on Tuesday night. Wednesday morning was going to be an early start because it was the day of the hearing and we had to be there by 9.30. The BBC was doing a fly-on-the-wall documentary with me, and they were filming from 4.30 on Wednesday morning, when I had to get up to do GMTV.

I suppose it does put an extra stress and strain on you, when you're crossing your fingers that you've done everything you can, and they're watching which way you squeeze your toothpaste. And all the camera crew and everyone were ladies, which was a bit difficult to get used to, when you're getting changed and things.

It was press day for the Matlock Mercury on Wednesday, too, and we had to get everything finished by lunchtime. We're only a small team, - a news editor and three reporters, and there's a lot to do. Marcus, one of our reporters, came down to London with me and he filed my copy. By the end of the day I had done 48 television and radio interviews.

I felt pretty exhausted on Thursday, as if I'd got a hangover. I've not seen my wife, really, to speak to since Sunday - we've just been leaving messages on the fridge and speaking on the phone.

It's a combination of emotions. I went up to see Stephen this morning. He said he had slept like a log. He had his first pint and a meal out last night. Of course he would like to be out, walking around the town, down by the river ... but it's not possible at the moment.

The press have been camped outside his house, and mine. We've been besieged. When I went to the paper shop this morning, people were coming up to me, hugging and kissing me and saying, well done. It took me 40 minutes to buy a paper!

It hasn't stopped all week. I've just been focusing on Stephen Downing and his case, really. His life becomes my life in a lot of ways.

It was press day for the Matlock Mercury on Wednesday, too, and we had to get everything finished by lunchtime. We're only a small team, - a news editor and three reporters, and there's a lot to do. Marcus, one of our reporters, came down to London with me and he filed my copy. By the end of the day I had done 48 television and radio interviews. I felt pretty exhausted on Thursday, as if I'd got a hangover. I've not seen my wife, really, to speak to since Sunday - we've just been leaving messages on the fridge and speaking on the phone. It's a combination of emotions. I went up to see Stephen this morning. He said he had slept like a log. He had his first pint and a meal out last night. Of course he would like to be out, walking around the town, down by the river ... but it's not possible at the moment. The press have been camped outside his house, and mine. We've been besieged. webTitle: French may give parents the right to say what's in a name

fields.headline: French may give parents the right to say what's in a name
fields.trailText: The French national assembly yesterday voted to overturn more than 200 years of male privilege by giving parents the legal right to choose their child's surname.
fields.body:
The French national assembly yesterday voted to overturn more than 200 years of male privilege by giving parents the legal right to choose their child's surname.

"The revolutionaries must be turning in their grave," the rightwing newspaper Le Figaro said yesterday, pointing out that the law requiring children to take their father's surname was created on Fructidor 6 in the year II (1793).

In 1985, a new law allowed French parents to choose a double-barrelled surname, using the father's and mother's surnames in any order. If the parents are unmarried, the child can have the mother's name if she is first to declare parentage to the authorities.

The reform, proposed by socialist deputy Gerard Gouzes, was overwhelmingly approved yesterday.Only one deputy, Jacques Myard of the rightwing RPF party voted against the measure, saying that it represented a return to "primitive matriarchal societies".

Lionel Jospin's government will now decide whether time should be allotted to debate the reform in the senate. The justice minister Marylise Lebranchu said she wanted it redrafted within the context of wider reform of family rights. Psychoanalyst Michel Tort warned yesterday: "This law will not bring peace. There will be conflicts over the choice of surname just as there are over choices of first names."

webTitle: French court links armed robbers to terrorist network

fields.headline: French court links armed robbers to terrorist network
fields.trailText: French police have uncovered an international terrorist network, with links to the millionaire Saudi dissident Osama bin Laden, which smuggled Islamic militants into western Europe on false papers, a Paris court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
French police have uncovered an international terrorist network, with links to the millionaire Saudi dissident Osama bin Laden, which smuggled Islamic militants into western Europe on false papers, a Paris court heard yesterday.

The network, which had members in three continents but is believed to have its roots in Bosnia, also has links with an armed gang which was responsible for a spate of armed robberies and a possible terrorist attack in the north of France in the mid-90s.

Police suspicions about the "Roubaix gang" were raised following the robbery of a Brink's security van in a supermarket car park near Roubaix in northern France in March 1996, using grenades, machine guns and rocket launchers.

Four days later in Lille, a bomb partially exploded in front of the city's main police station. If it had worked properly the bomb would have "devastated everything within a radius of 300 metres of the blast". The attack occurred two days before Lille played host to a G7 conference of finance and social affairs ministers.

Investigators believed that the two attacks and several other armed robberies were perpetrated by the same small gang operating from a house in Roubaix. When officers from the anti-terrorist police unit (the GIGN) raided the house in the spring of 1996, there was a gun battle in which four suspected members of the gang were killed.

The surviving members of the gang tried to flee western Europe immediately afterwards. Two of them, Lionel Dumont, a Bosnian who converted to Islam, and Mouloud Bougelane, also known as Souleymane, were involved in a shoot-out with police officers in Belgium a few days later. But they escaped and, according to police information, went to Bosnia. Dumont was later arrested there, but escaped from his prison cell.

In Paris yesterday, 28 people appeared in court accused of being members of a network which had supplied false papers to militants, most of them former Bosnian and Afghan soldiers. French, Turkish and Italian police forces collaborated to expose what a French police witness called "a triangular network in the traffic of false documents between Belgium, Canada and Turkey". French members of the network are believed to be linked to Bin Laden.

The president of the court, Michele Bernard-Requin, said that some of the accused had links with the Roubaix gang, but most had only participated in smuggling illegal immigrants in and out of France. The court heard that the network is headed by four men and was at one time based in Quebec. Only one of them, Fateh Kamel, was present in court yesterday. Another suspected leader, Ahmed Ressam, faces trial in the US on charges of carrying explosives through customs and the other two are on the run.

Several men suspected of belonging to the Roubaix gang will go on trial next month at Douai in northern France, accused of armed robbery and attempted murder.

The French revelations come to light in the same week as four suspected terrorists, all believed to have been collaborating with Bin Laden, appeared in a US court, charged with the murders of 224 people at US embassies in Tanzania and Kenya in 1998. Yesterday Pakistan's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, said in an interview with an Egyptian newspaper that the Taliban might hand over Bin Laden for trial by Islamic judges in a Muslim country, but would never send him to the US. He added that he did not see why a third country could not be the trial venue, as in the Lockerbie bombing case.

webTitle: Ex-gambling boss takes on Philippine betting rings

fields.headline: Ex-gambling boss takes on Philippine betting rings
fields.trailText: The self-confessed corrupt gambling lord whose explosive revelations sparked the crisis that led to the fall of the former Philippine president Joseph Estrada completed his rehabilitation yesterday when he was appointed a government corruption-buster.
fields.body:
The self-confessed corrupt gambling lord whose explosive revelations sparked the crisis that led to the fall of the former Philippine president Joseph Estrada completed his rehabilitation yesterday when he was appointed a government corruption-buster.

The announcement came as the official ombudsman, Aniano Desierto, who has powers of prosecution, ordered nine banks to hand over details of accounts - thought to contain a total of £135m - he believes belong to Mr Estrada.

Properties and other assets, allegedly acquired with ill-gotten wealth during Mr Estrada's time in office and totalling a further £135m, are also to be seized.

Luis Singson, a provincial governor and one-time drinking and betting buddy of Mr Estrada, has been named an anti-corruption consultant in the interior department. His mission: to wipe out the illegal gambling rackets that pervade the country. His salary: one peso, or 1.4 pence, a year.

"We need sincerity from all concerned to stop [it]," Mr Singson said.

Mr Singson is among the best placed people to take on such a task. For more than two years he allegedly collected millions of pounds from illegal gambling syndicates and took the money to Mr Estrada in the presidential palace.

The governor claims he also helped deliver Mr Estrada's alleged pay-offs from tobacco taxes and various business deals. He blew the whistle on the scams in October last year after saying he got sick of the president's greed. Others claim he was cut out of a deal. Mr Singson's testimony resulted in Mr Estrada's impeachment trial, which collapsed amid uproar last month when the president's supporters among the judges in the senate refused to admit potentially damning evidence.

The public outcry, backed by a mass military defection, was so great that within four days Mr Estrada had been forced out of office and replaced by his deputy, Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. She has given her full backing to efforts to bring Mr Estrada to justice. Prosecutors are investigating him on seven counts, including plunder, which carries the death penalty.

Mr Estrada, who is desperately trying to persuade the supreme court to declare his removal illegal, has until Monday to answer the complaints. If he fails in his legal action and is charged, he is likely to be detained.

Rumours swept Manila yesterday that Mr Estrada was about to flee the country, ostensibly for long-planned medical treatment in the United States, even though he has had a travel ban placed on him, along with his wife and several other relatives, mistresses and cronies. But one of his sons, Jinggoy Estrada, told a TV news programme that his father would stay and fight to prove his innocence.

"We have no plans to leave the country," Jinggoy said. "We were surprised about the reports because we never even thought of travelling to another country."

Ms Arroyo yesterday began working with her new vice president, the senate minority leader Teofisto Guingona Jr, whose nomination was approved by the congress and senate on Wednesday. A veteran politician, Mr Guingona, is seen as a safe choice and no threat to Ms Arroyo's plan to run for re-election when Mr Estrada's term in office expires in three years.

webTitle: EC changes its tune on tied aid

fields.headline: EC changes its tune on tied aid
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the European commission
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: The European commission appeared to shift its ground yesterday by pledging not to stand in the way of an international deal to cut the strings attached to aid donations to the world's poorest countries.
fields.body:
The European commission appeared to shift its ground yesterday by pledging not to stand in the way of an international deal to cut the strings attached to aid donations to the world's poorest countries.

In an interview with The Guardian, Poul Nielson, the commissioner in charge of development policy, said: "If the DAC [development assistance committee of the OECD] moves on the least developed countries the commission will go with it."

After negotiations lasting more than 30 years, the DAC is attempting to reach a deal by May on ending the long-established practice of making aid conditional on the purchase of goods and services from the donor country. The draft agreement excludes certain forms of aid, including food, and is limited to the world's 48 least developed countries but it is seen as a first step towards a more comprehensive agreement.

While in favour of allowing developing countries to bid for contracts in certain regions, the commission had been opposed to allowing industrialised countries that are not members of the EU to compete for its business. However, Mr Nielson's remarks during a visit to the UK suggest the commission has had a change of heart.

Clare Short, the international development secretary, who has pledged to untie all British aid whether or not an international deal is reached in the DAC, said the commission was moving in the right direction but should be much bolder.

She said: "I am disappointed by commissioner Nielson's stand on untying. This concession is still only for untying aid to the least developed countries. We want a comprehensive agreement to maximise the benefits of aid which should be focused on eliminating poverty, not furthering commercial interests."

fields.headline: Edward Miller
fields.trailText: The historian Edward Miller, who has died aged 85, was one of the important group of scholars working on the economy and society of the middle ages who began their careers before 1939 and transformed the subject in postwar years.
fields.body:
The historian Edward Miller, who has died aged 85, was one of the important group of scholars working on the economy and society of the middle ages who began their careers before 1939 and transformed the subject in postwar years. A quiet and genial man, he performed a variety of roles, all successfully, but without fuss or pretension. He ended his career as Master of Fitzwilliam College, Cambridge, from 1971-81.

Born in Northumberland, Miller was educated at King Edward VI Grammar School, Morpeth, before going to St John's College, Cambridge. He became a research student in 1937 and served as a soldier between 1940 and 1945 before returning to St John's as a popular tutor. In the early 1960s he acted as warden of Madingley Hall, Cambridge's department of adult education, and then took up the chair of medieval history at Sheffield (1965-71), before his final move back to Cambridge.

Miller cut his teeth as a historian on a study of the estates of Ely cathedral (1951), but his sympathies with the common man meant that he devoted much attention to the peasants whose labours created the wealth of the bishops and monks. He also wrote a valuable local study of the peasants' revolt of 1381, on the rebellion in Cambridgeshire.

Continuing his interest in the medieval countryside, he wrote (with John Hatcher) a survey of the medieval rural economy. His study of medieval York for the Victoria County History, 1961, reflects his interest in urban history, and still ranks as one of the best studies of a medieval town in print. A general account of medieval towns, again with Hatcher, appeared in 1995. Miller took an interest in government policy, and the effects of taxation and war on the economy.

His interpretation of the economy helped to establish a view of changes in the middle ages which emphasised growth until about 1300, culminating in a crisis as the population expanded to a level that could not be sustained. This view was informed by his background as a farmer's son and with meticulous justification from his extensive knowledge of the documents. His writing was closely related to his teaching, and a generation of students outside Cambridge and Sheffield had cause to be grateful for the clear and skilful explanations in his pamphlet on The Origins of Parliament.

Miller's enthusiasms included the north of England, where he had grown up and spent the central part of his career. He wrote about the farming and towns of the medieval north, and supported the journal Northern History. His commitment to St John's, Cambridge, resulted in a short history published in 1961, but of much greater influence was the lively and amiable tutoring he provided for history students there.

And last, but not least, was his interest in sport, initially on the field and later as a spectator. His support for the college teams at Fitzwilliam helped him to establish good relations with the students, and in later life watching rugby and cricket still gave him great pleasure. Miller chaired committees of the Victoria County History and the History of Parliament Trust, but was not a lover of committees.

Informal and irreverent, his great strength was his ability to establish good relations with colleagues and students, and it was his easy manner and friendly support that those who knew him will always remember. Still active in retirement, he continued to write, and completed the editing of the third volume of the Agrarian History of England and Wales. The British Academy elected him a fellow in 1981. He is survived by Fanny, his devoted wife of almost 60 years and his son John, who is also a professor of history.

 Edward Miller, historian, born July 16 1915; died December 21 2000

webTitle: EU unites to get tough on immigrants

fields.headline: EU unites to get tough on immigrants
fields.standfirst:
Britain leads moves towards cooperation on asylum seekers

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Britain leads moves towards cooperation on asylum seekers.
fields.body:
EU interior ministers agreed yesterday to speed up coordination of asylum policies to cut the number of illegal immigrants, but pledged not to spurn refugees fleeing persecution. Meeting in Stockholm, ministers broadly backed calls by Jack Straw, the British home secretary, for closer collaboration in an area of increasing concern across the EU.

No formal decisions were made, but Swedish diplomats running the union's rotating presidency said immigration officials would hold talks in London next week on practical moves to clamp down on trafficking humans from the Balkans.

The risks of trafficking were highlighted last summer by the deaths of 58 Chinese immigrants found suffocated in a Dutch-owned truck which arrived in Dover from Belgium. Illegal immigration is also expected to be high on the agenda of an Anglo-French summit in Cahors, southern France, today.

Mr Straw, who will be with the prime minister in France, called earlier this week for a new approach to the United Nations refugee convention, bringing criticism that there was a danger of fostering a Fortress Europe mentality. He denied yesterday that he wanted to abandon the principles of the 1951 convention, but said: "We have to modernise the practices because the world today is different from what it was 50 years ago."

Last year 390,000 people applied for asylum in the EU, with Britain receiving the largest number of applications, 97,900, followed by Germany with 78,800. Ruud Lubbers, the newly appointed UN high commissioner for refugees, has called on the union to be more generous in its attitude to refugees and asylum seekers.

Mary Robinson, the UN human rights commissioner, has also opposed any change to the 1951 convention. Most EU member states agree that their different laws have been exploited by traffickers. "We are very anxious to coordinate EU action against the source of this smuggling," said Mr Straw.

Sweden's migration minister, Maj-Inger Klingvall, said: "The goal is that the first stage of our harmonisation work should be completed in 2004." Mr Straw made a distinction between "genuine" refugees and others, but called for a tougher line towards "those who have unfounded claims for asylum and who are using the very complicated and contradictory practices of the different EU nations as a means of evading normal immigration controls".

Diplomats said the level of yesterday's discussions marked a new sense of urgency since the 1999 Tampere summit in Finland. It was then that EU leaders set a strict timetable for improving cooperation among their police forces, easing the extradition of criminals, recognising each other's judicial decisions and combating money laundering, drug smuggling and illegal immigration.

Sweden has made immigration and asylum a high priority for its EU presidency, but more progress is expected when Belgium takes over in July, not least because it has more immigrants per head than any other EU country.

Britain is pushing for measures to stop "asylum shopping", whereby an applicant chooses to go to the EU member state which is most likely to grant residence. It wants to find a replacement for the Dublin convention, which came into force in 1997, but which has failed to allow the easy transfer of asylum seekers back to their point of entry into the EU. fields.headline: Downing urges new murder inquiry
fields.trailText: Stephen Downing enjoyed his first full day of freedom yesterday and said he wanted the police to reopen the investigation into the murder he insists he did not commit.
fields.body:
Stephen Downing enjoyed his first full day of freedom yesterday and said he wanted the police to reopen the investigation into the murder he insists he did not commit.

Mr Downing, 44, was released from Littlehey prison, Cambridgeshire, on Wednesday, after spending 27 years in jail. He was convicted in 1974 of killing Wendy Sewell in the churchyard where he worked in Bakewell, Derbyshire.

He has been freed on bail pending an appeal hearing which the crown concedes is likely to succeed because of serious questions about the admissibility of his confession. He returned to Bakewell to the home he had shared with his parents, Ray and Juanita, before he was arrested.

Don Hale, editor of the Matlock Mercury, who helped to win Mr Downing's freedom by uncovering fresh information about the case, said after meeting him yesterday: "He is looking forward to fully clearing his name and he would like the case to be reopened.

"He feels that there should be a full inquiry to convict the right person. It would be vindication for him."

Derbyshire police yesterday repeated that the chief constable would not consider reopening the murder inquiry until he knew the result of the appeal.

webTitle: Customs blunder led to loss of £620m

fields.headline: Customs blunder led to loss of £620m
fields.trailText: Customs and excise has lost £620m of revenue by bungling surveillance operations on professional criminals selling tax-free drink to pubs and clubs, a report by the national audit office reveals today.
fields.body:
Customs and excise has lost £620m of revenue by bungling surveillance operations on professional criminals selling tax-free drink to pubs and clubs, a report by the national audit office reveals today.

The revelation was described by David Davis, Tory chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, "as the most serious breakdown in controls that we have witnessed". The report reveals that over four years excise officers kept watch on gangs who were diverting huge amounts of wine, beer and spirits held in warehouses in Britain destined for export. But they never made arrests because they wanted to gather more information to prosecute them.

By the time they acted they could only recover £45m out of £668m - because the criminals had already sold the drink on the black market and it could no longer be traced.

The scandal came at a time when alcohol smuggling was growing rapidly because of rising excise duties on drink and the ease with which large quantities could be brought into Britain through the "white van" trade from France and Belgium. But the bonded warehouse trade - where alcohol and tobacco are stored before being shipped abroad at ports - was not a priority for the excise officers.

Thieves began targeting the warehouses because it provided bigger profits than smuggling lower duty-paid drink from France. There was also a growing market in clubs and pubs for cheap alcohol.

Customs said yesterday that it took a long time to prosecute the gangs. A spokesman said it took months to bring one case to trial and involved prosecuting 97 people. Details of warehouses and gangs who got away have been sent in a secret internal report to ministers. The auditors are scathing that customs knew about the growing market in diverting drink bound for export to the home market but did nothing about it for such a long time.

Sir John Bourn, the comptroller and auditor general, said: "It is estimated that half of the revenue would not have been lost if customs had decided to intercept the fraudulent consignments, rather than seeking to obtain sufficient evidence to prosecute themselves by allowing the goods to be diverted to the home market and letting the investigations continue." The scandal came to light when the new head of customs and excise, ex-businessman Richard Broadbent found that some investigations had been mishandled. He immediately informed Dawn Primarolo, the paymaster-general, and set up an internal inquiry.

Since then customs has tightened up its investigation procedures and an external inquiry is also investigating the mishandling of so many cases. The national audit office has now sent in a team of auditors to make a full report on the fiasco which will be presented to parliament later this year.

Mr Davis said: "Officials had been aware of the threat and scale of the fraud as early as 1994 but did not take effective action to curtail it until 1998. "They took a further two years before ministers knew the scale of losses involved. This shows an astonishingly reckless disregard for the interests of the taxpayer and the attitude displayed to ministers and to parliament borders on contempt." A customs spokesman said they welcomed the auditors' decision to prepare a report for parliament.

webTitle: Champagne crooks jailed for millennium fraud

fields.headline: Champagne crooks jailed for millennium fraud
fields.trailText: Two businessmen who convinced investors they could make a fortune out of bulk buying champagne and selling it to the highest bidders in the run-up to the millennium have been jailed for conspiracy to defraud.
fields.body:
Two businessmen who convinced investors they could make a fortune out of bulk buying champagne and selling it to the highest bidders in the run-up to the millennium have been jailed for conspiracy to defraud.

Lee Rosser, 31, of Bournemouth, and Julian Blee, 32, of Luton, along with Craig Dean, 35, of Redditch, Worcestershire, duped thousands of customers into paying inflated prices by claiming the champagne supply was in danger of running out before the "biggest party for a thousand years".

Trading as the House of Delacroix, the trio promised to store the champagne in warehouses before auctioning it for huge profits at Sotheby's or Christie's. After placing adverts in glossy lifestyle magazines, they employed a team of telesales operators, who took up to £4.5m in sales revenue.

But an investigation by the serious fraud office found the offer was a sham, the shortage failed to materialise, and the "second-rate" champagne was only worth a fraction of the price paid. Jonathan Fisher, prosecuting, told Southwark crown court that: "This fraud was executed in a slick and professional manner." It played up the possibility that Earth's partygoers would end up 45m bottles of champagne short to celebrate the new millennium.

Rosser pleaded guilty and was jailed for 18 months. Blee also admitted guilt and was jailed for a year. Dean, 35, who was found guilty, will be sentenced on March 6.

The court was told that Rosser and Blee, along with another man, Lewis Daulby, were found guilty late last year of a similar fraud involving whisky investments. Rosser and Blee were sentenced to seven and four years respectively for that fraud.

webTitle: Democrats bend to Bush's tax cut

fields.headline: Democrats bend to Bush's tax cut
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: George Bush launched the flagship of his domestic agenda for the first year of his presidency yesterday when he sent his plan for billions of dollars of tax cuts to the US Congress.
fields.body:
George Bush launched the flagship of his domestic agenda for the first year of his presidency yesterday when he sent his plan for billions of dollars of tax cuts to the US Congress.

Mr Bush's $1.6 trillion, (£1,100bn) 10-year tax-cut programme was the centrepiece of his election campaign last year and it is now seen by most Republicans as the key to the party's congressional hopes in midterm elections in November 2002.

Opposition Democrats responded by announcing plans to fight the package, but in terms markedly less confrontational than those they put forward during the election campaign. Both parties recognise that the tax cuts could go a long way to deciding whether the Bush administration secures re-election in 2004, so the political manoeuvring is more than usually charged with significance.

Mr Bush is determined to deliver on a key election pledge, but he also revealed yesterday how much the context of his proposals has changed in just a few months. When he was campaigning for the White House, he advocated the tax cut on the grounds that a booming economy and a soaring federal budget surplus permitted a windfall for all Americans. But with the recent slowdown in the US economy, the president now says that the tax cuts are needed to reinvigorate demand.

"A warning light is flashing on the dashboard of our economy and we just can't drive on and hope for the best," Mr Bush said at the White House yesterday, while promoting his tax plans. "We need tax relief now. In fact, we need tax relief yesterday."

The Bush plan focuses on reducing the current five federal income tax rate bands to four lower bands; at present, individual US taxpayers face five bands ranging from 15% to 39.6%. Mr Bush's proposal would replace them with bands of 10%, 15%, 25%, and 33%. The plan also calls for the expansion of child credits for parents, a change in the tax position of married couples and the phased repeal of estate taxes or death duties, which are only paid by the rich. Tax breaks on charitable contributions will also be eased further.

Mr Bush plans to backdate the changes to January 1. "I urge the Congress to pass my tax-relief plan with the swiftness these uncertain times demand," Mr Bush said.

Republicans are hoping that they can get the tax cuts signed into law by the Independence Day holiday on July 4, but the eventual shape of the package is likely to be very different from the plan outlined by Mr Bush this week.

While Democrats are likely to press for reductions in the handouts, the most likely changes in the package could be those which are backed by Mr Bush's Republicans, many of whom believe that the time is ripe for even more extensive cuts than those proposed by the White House. In particular, the bill is certain to be a prime target for corporate lobbying interests which are planning to attach a range of business tax breaks to the legislation before it emerges from Congress.

The White House press secretary Ari Fleischer reiterated yesterday that Mr Bush remains "firmly committed'" to the $1.6 trillion plan and that he thinks it is important to stick to the figure he promoted. "The president believes that whether you're a Republican or whether you're a Democrat, the bill shouldn't be loaded up," Mr Fleischer said.

Democrats criticised the package for a lack of specifics and claimed that the total package could add up to $1 trillion more than the White House acknowledges. If true, party leaders said, the tax cuts could eat up 96% of the federal surplus at a time when revenues were likely to be reduced because of the slowdown.

There was a notable change of tone in the Democratic attacks, however. During the election, Mr Gore repeatedly charged that the Bush plan favoured the rich at the expense of middle-and working-class Americans. But Mr Bush stressed the plan's alleged attractions for "ordinary folks" this week and Democrats are now more cautious about labelling the package as merely a rich persons' ramp.

webTitle: Hollywood reporter: Most Christian movies are rubbish

fields.headline: Rude awakenings
fields.standfirst: God's army confesses: most Christian movies are rubbish
fields.trailText: God's army confesses: most Christian movies are rubbish
fields.body:
Three days after the restoration of the Bush dynasty was officially solemnised on the steps of the Capitol building, fate afforded us one of those eerie, almost too precise metaphors for what the Age of Dubya might hold. The huge oil tanker that ran aground near the unique Galapagos Islands is a glib metaphor that novelists might avoid, but it resonates nicely enough for me. The tanker, of course, is the starkest possible symbol of the boy-prince and his oil-lubricated administration's contempt for fragile, Galapagos-like arrangements such as drilling-bans, national parks, arms-control agreements, Roe vs Wade, and three-day waiting periods for psychotic assault-rifle buyers. Anyone who cherishes these hard-won victories should feel Dubya's cultural-political oil slick lapping around their ankles any day now.

I bet the man who laughed loudest at this eco-tastrophe was John Ashcroft, the new attorney general. Ashcroft is a veteran of the long march of the American right, from the fundamentalist revival of the early 1980s to his current eyrie at the US Justice Department. He was nominated by Bush despite being so unpopular as senator for Missouri that voters dumped him for a corpse - Mel Carnahan, who died mid-campaign.

Thanks to the Galapagos, Charles Darwin was able to give us The Origin of Species, and the theory of evolution that Christians like Ashcroft are still contesting today. The Christian Right has tried for a century to displace evolution in American schools with its own "creationist" agenda, viewing Darwinism as a socialist monkey-science, foisted on god-fearing pupils by the "secular-humanist" indoctrination factories of the US Department of Education (schools, we call them). For them, even a partial revenge on Darwin must be sweet indeed.

Voices like Ashcroft's are suddenly more audible, not only in politics but also at the movies. An independently financed Christian movie called Left Behind made this week's US box office chart by a whisker, and almost broke the record takings for a Christian movie set a year ago by The Omega Code. It looks as though Christian groups, sick of Hollywood, are building an entirely separate, parallel production-and-distribution infrastructure to support their own kind of film-making. They've been using the jungle drums of the fundamentalist right - TV and radio preachers and their massive audiences - along with congregation-based word-of-mouth. The moderate success of Left Behind in 900 cinemas this weekend suggests they've finally gained a toehold in the national consciousness - though probably only in the half of it that voted Republican.

The title refers to those poor souls (like you and me) who'll get left behind when The Rapture comes. When this happens, all true believers and children will be sucked up to Heaven, and those who remain must endure seven years of The Tribulation, during which the earth will be ruled by the Antichrist himself. Just where the movie is coming from politically can be judged by the way it portrays this guy. Surprise, surprise, he's the leader of the United Nations, he has an eastern European accent and his name is Nicolae Carpathia. What better bete noire for the paranoid far right? He's part of the new world order, chances are he's a commie, and with that last name he's probably a vampire too. Somewhere out there are folks who get scared by all this.

Whatever happened to Christians and Hollywood? Jesus used to have it so sweet in Tinseltown, what with the amazingly durable religious epic genre. It used to be Ben-Hur this, Ten Commandments that, Quo Vadis the other, boffo box-office takings and Oscars all round, until Time magazine said "God Is Dead" in 1965.

Things change. These days Hollywood looks at the southern Baptists who protested The Last Temptation of Christ and figures they're a bunch of anti-semitic hillbilly inbreds - snake-handlers, speakers-in-tongues and sheetless klansmen. And God's army regards Hollywood as a festering swamp of liberal hedonism and the most "explicit" and "permissive" strains of secular-humanism, a place that makes Sodom and Gomorrah look like Minneapolis-St Paul.

But if Christian movies made money then Hollywood would be churning them out two a week. Since they haven't shown any box office legs since Vatican II, no one risks making them any more. If they do - as with Last Temptation - the ensuing protests immediately force all religious projects into turnaround until whenever the next Great Awakening heaves into view. And so, believing that the next Awakening will be the Rapture itself, and therefore rude indeed, the Christians have been taking matters into their own hands.

As even they ruefully admit, most Christian movies so far have been crap. All of them seem to be set at the moment of the apocalypse, and to depict the end of the world one needs good special effects - and so cash in abundance. No independent Christian movie has ever had that. So the end of the world often arrives in a cloud of ill-lit dry ice and cheesy special effects knocked up on the Reverend's iMac over the weekend.

America's Baptists are not noted for their aesthetic sensibilities - just look at the decor on any US televangelist's show - and keeping the kids away from visually sophisticated studio godlessness won't help their movies much. The Christian film-making signature falls halfway between a characterless made-for-TV movie and a finger-wagging after-school special. All this may rock their world down at Jerry Falwell's Liberty Baptist college in Lynchburg, Virginia, but at my multiplex, given the choice between The Omega Code and The Omen, or Left Behind and The Exorcist, I know which way I'm jumping. Straight into the lake of fire - I've got my asbestos trunks on under these goat-legs.

America's Baptists are not noted for their aesthetic sensibilities - just look at the decor on any US televangelist's show - and keeping the kids away from visually sophisticated studio godlessness won't help their movies much. The Christian film-making signature falls halfway between a characterless made-for-TV movie and a finger-wagging after-school special. All this may rock their world down at Jerry Falwell's Liberty Baptist college in Lynchburg, Virginia, but at my multiplex, given the choice between The Omega Code and The Omen, or Left Behind and The Exorcist, I know which way I'm jumping. Straight into the lake of fire - I've got my asbestos trunks on under these goat-legs.

fields.headline: Flooding returns with a vengeance
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Flooding returned to Britain with a vengeance yesterday, leaving a policeman dead and troops deployed in several areas to evacuate threatened homes.
fields.body:
Flooding returned to Britain with a vengeance yesterday, leaving a policeman dead and troops deployed in several areas to evacuate threatened homes.

The traffic control officer was killed by a van as he diverted traffic after an accident on a flooded stretch of the A12 dual carriageway at Kelvedon, near Colchester, Essex - one of 92 areas now under official flood warnings.

An inshore lifeboat ferried 20 people to safety on the Sussex coast, leaving homes waist-deep in water. In Yarm, Stockton-on-Tees, more than 50 families were taken to bed-and-breakfast accommodation as the river Tees came close to bursting its banks.

In North Yorkshire, where 300 families are still unable to return to houses wrecked in the October floods, a school bus was marooned after sliding into a ditch hidden by floodwater. Farmers from Appleton Roebuck and Bolton Percy, near Tadcaster, used tractors and trailers to ferry 30 children from the bus to dry land, in time for school.

In Kent, 40 soldiers used semi-amphibious Pinsgauer jeeps to help marooned elderly villagers near Canterbury, where 2,000 sandbags have been issued by the city council. The environment agency said last night that problems in the southern region, where there are nine severe flood warnings, had been caused by heavy rain.

The Thames has seven flood warnings and an environment agency spokeswoman warned the situation "could become serious" between Benson and Hurley in Oxfordshire.

Heavy rain overnight brought the Thames to the brink of bursting its banks once again, said the environment agency. East Anglia was also hit by flooding from the river Cam which left several roads impassable and part of the centre of Grantchester, near Cambridge, under water.

Last night the situation had eased in some areas, including Lincolnshire, where the agency was hoping to remove flood warnings for the northern part of the county, and along the Wear in County Durham.

But in Barham, Kent, where the river Nailbourne broke its banks, many residents have moved to the upper floors, and the landlady of the Black Robin pub, Jill White, 49, said: "We are in the middle of a lake - it's never been this bad before. We have not decided if we are going to evacuate yet. We are putting up a fight, piling sandbags all around the place. The water in the road is about 3ft deep and the current is very strong."

The flood defence committee in the Yorkshire region will meet for the third time today to try to end a two-month deadlock over meeting a £6.4m increase in the annual levy to pay for repairs and new river walls. The chairman of the environment agency, Sir John Harman, published an open letter to the committee last night, appealing to local council members to accept the need for the rise.

He said: "There is already public disquiet about the committee's inability to agree a levy which will provide funding for the much needed increase in capital investment.

"I recognise the short term impact the proposed levy increase will have on local authority finances but I would urge you to give urgent consideration to the levy reports and the needs of the communities which are at risk.

"It would be a sad irony if our region of the country, worst affected by the autumn floods, was the only one to fail to take up the additional funding of £51m announced by the deputy prime minister in November."

webTitle: Call to uncover IRA activity in protest

fields.headline: Call to uncover IRA activity in protest
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Relatives of those killed on Bloody Sunday called for an end to the "wall of silence" over IRA activity on that day as a witness to the new inquiry refused to name a civilian gunman he saw firing shots.
fields.body:
Relatives of those killed on Bloody Sunday called for an end to the "wall of silence" over IRA activity on that day as a witness to the new inquiry refused to name a civilian gunman he saw firing shots.

William Harley, 65, told the tribunal in Derry's Guildhall yesterday that he saw a man he knew from work fire five or six shots from a revolver after the army opened fire during a civil rights protest in the Bogside on January 30, 1972.

Thirteen unarmed Catholic men were killed and a 14th died five months later in hospital. Another witness, Anthony Joseph Coll, has identified the gunman as Tony Rush, which Mr Rush denied.

But Mr Harley, who watched events from his home on the top floor of Rossville flats, refused to confirm theclaim. "Perhaps I only think I know who it was," he said. "It would be a terrible thing indeed if I were to name the wrong man, as apparently someone has already done."

He said the shots landed harmlessly on the ground just a few feet from the gunman, adding: "I think there are very few of us that have not some incident in our past of which we are thoroughly ashamed. I would not be guilty of naming the man who carried out that silly action. I just can't do it."

Tribunal chairman, Lord Saville, said Mr Harley's position put him in a quandary, and pointed out that the same problem could arise with other evidence. "As well as carrying out a full, open and thorough inquiry, we must also do it in a fair manner and apply the same standards to all," he said.

Arthur Harvey QC, representing many of the bereaved and injured, said the families were "deeply saddened" that some people had so far refused to cooperate with the inquiry, but believed steps could be taken to help them do so.

Earlier this year, Christopher Clarke QC, counsel for the inquiry, said that with some exceptions, the hearing had encountered a "wall of silence" surrounding the IRA and what orders members had received.

fields.headline: EVC changes tack
fields.trailText: It was as if the good old days of the dot.com bubble had returned and the Durlacher phenomena had never happened. But shares in EVC Christows rose 4.25p, or 73%, to 10p yesterday following the stockbroker and technology incubator's latest move toward becoming a technology focused investment bank.
fields.body:
It was as if the good old days of the dot.com bubble had returned and the Durlacher phenomena had never happened. But shares in EVC Christows rose 4.25p, or 73%, to 10p yesterday following the stockbroker and technology incubator's latest move toward becoming a technology focused investment bank.

The cause of the excitement was the acquisition of technology research house Evolution Capital for £12.5m. Following the completion of the deal - effectively a reverse takeover - Evolution's executive management team of Richard Griffiths, the man who refinanced Osmtech, James Chilcott, a former strategist at Mercury Asset Management, and James Kenny, a former director of ABN Amro Rothschild, will take control of EVC's board.

Traders expect deals in the new and potentially lucrative field of nanotechnology in the near future.

webTitle: How Ridley Scott's Hannibal came to be made

fields.headline: 'But Dino, I don't want to make a film about elephants...'
fields.standfirst: So said Ridley Scott when he was first asked to direct Hannibal, the long-awaited sequel to The Silence of the Lambs.  Jill Bernstein, who gained extraordinary access to the film's cast and crew, reveals how it came to be made
fields.trailText: So said Ridley Scott when he was first asked to direct Hannibal, the long-awaited sequel to The Silence of the Lambs. Jill Bernstein, who gained extraordinary access to the film's cast and crew, reveals how it came to be made
fields.body:
The only person watching Clarice Starling more closely than Hannibal Lecter is director Ridley Scott. In a Los Angeles sound studio, Scott sits behind a console as the opening scene from his new movie, Hannibal, plays on a large screen across the room and on a nearby monitor.

"Pretty busy today," Starling mouths, via a hidden mike, to a fellow FBI agent at a fish market, where a sting operation is about to go tragically wrong. "Pretty busy today," comes the simultaneous voice of Julianne Moore, talking in New York in a bicoastal looping session to ensure that the scene's background noises do not drown out her dialogue. Scott presses a lighted square on a little black box. "That was good," he says. "It's going to be quite loud. Project as much as you dare, considering what your face is doing." He takes his hand off the button and whispers, "Can I get some coffee?" as the footage is cued for replay. "Pretty busy today," Moore says again.

Sound technicians scrutinise the playback, making sure that the words match the lip movements, and give Scott a nod. For the next few hours, he will remain supremely attuned to the nuances of Starling's voice, the logic of her actions and the nature of her character. Everyone connected with Hannibal knows there is a lot at stake. Three months from now, Moore will appear before millions of fans who have waited 10 years to see Lecter and Starling play cat and mouse again.

Italian is the first language spoken at Martha and Dino De Laurentiis's production office on the Universal lot in the Hollywood hills. Dino, the 81-year-old veteran of such films as La Strada, Ulysses and War and Peace, still speaks heavily accented English. He is a short man, sporting large, dark-rimmed glasses and a coral shirt under a tweed jacket. His wife and partner, 46-year-old Martha, sits beside him. Nearby, a dark, wooden desk big enough to roller-skate on is covered with awards. But today they are talking about the one that got away.

In 1985, the couple bought the rights to Thomas Harris's bestselling thriller Red Dragon, from which they produced the 1986 movie Manhunter, directed by Michael Mann. The film, which features the first, brief screen appearance of the serial killer Hannibal Lecter (then spelled Lektor and played by Brian Cox), was inventive, frightening and well-received, but it grossed $8.6m, less than the cost of its print ads. The De Laurentiises were disappointed. "Manhunter was not Red Dragon," Dino says. "Manhunter was no good." And so when Harris completed The Silence of the Lambs, neither Dino nor Martha bothered to read it, even though they owned the screen rights to the Lecter character (who figured much more prominently in this new novel). "Big mistake" is how Dino now characterises this lack of interest.

Harris and director Jonathan Demme came to him, wanting to set the project up elsewhere; Dino agreed and lent the now-defunct Orion Pictures the character of Hannibal Lecter - for free. "We were afraid to make the movie," Martha explains. "You could be terrible and say no, or you could demand money, which was kind of, 'Why be greedy?' Or you let them use it, and if it's successful, your asset has value." The Silence of the Lambs was released on February 14, 1991. It grossed $131m and received five Oscars, including best actor for Anthony Hopkins, best actress for Jodie Foster, and best picture.

The De Laurentiises suddenly found themselves sitting on a valuable asset. Even before the movie came out, there was manoeuvring for a stake in a potential Silence sequel. Tom Pollock, then-chairman of Universal (and a former attorney who represented De Laurentiis during the making of Manhunter), asked Dino, who still controlled the Lecter character, to make any sequel at Universal. The De Laurentiises felt that Pollock was using other films they were partnering on as leverage for this request; Pollock felt they had reached an oral agreement to do the sequel. A conflict ensued, and the producers filed a $25m lawsuit against Universal. The parties ultimately settled; the studio got the participation it had wanted.

All of this planning was still hypothetical, of course - Harris, a notoriously slow writer, was years away from finishing the next instalment. Every year, the eager De Laurentiises would fly down to Miami, with their personal chef in tow, and have dinner with Harris. ("Tom is a great gourmand," Martha says.) "Finally, I receive a call from Thomas," Dino recalls in his gravelly voice. " 'Dino, I did it.' He finish." Hannibal picks up 10 years after Silence left off, with Lecter on the loose (he spends a chunk of time, to the De Laurentiises' delight, in Italy) and keeping a watchful eye on Clarice Starling - who will be used to smoke the serial killer out.

The novel received mixed reviews but pushed Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets off the top of the best-seller list. Dino purchased the rights for a record $10m (£6.9m). Before publication, the manuscript went out to Hopkins, Foster, and Demme, who had expressed interest in directing the sequel. Dino and Martha flew from Malta, where they were filming Universal's U-571, to New York to meet with Demme and begin structuring a deal. Later, however, Dino received a call from Demme's agent, CAA's Rick Nicita. "He say to me, 'Dino, I have-a no good news for you. Jonathan Demme pass.' I say, 'Rick, when the Pope-a die, we create a new Pope-a. Good luck to Jonathan Demme. Good-bye.' "

It wasn't long before a new leader had been chosen. Ridley Scott (director of Blade Runner, Alien, Thelma & Louise), who had worked with Dino briefly on 1984's Dune, was in Malta filming Gladiator next door to U-571. He invited Dino in for a cup of espresso. Five days later, Scottt recalls, Dino brought him "a giant manuscript that said Hannibal", which prompted the response: "I said, 'Dino, I don't want to do elephants coming over the Alps. I'm doing a Roman movie now .' "

After reading the book (which features vicious boars rather than elephants), Scott accepted the job - although not without some hesitation. He had qualms about the ending, in which Clarice and Hannibal ride off amorously (and, to many readers, inconceivably) into the sunset. "I couldn't take that quantum leap emotionally on behalf of Starling. Certainly, on behalf of Hannibal - I'm sure that's been in the back of his mind for a number of years. But for Starling, no. I think one of the attractions about Starling to Hannibal is what a straight arrow she is." Universal was also wary of the ending. "I said to Dino: 'I'd really like to talk to Tom [Harris] to see how much licence we've got.' Tom said, 'Well, what would the interpretation be?' I said, 'I really don't know.' "

Untangling that meant hiring a screenwriter. Ted Tally, who'd won an Oscar for his Silence adaptation, turned down the sequel. An offer went out to Steven Zaillian, the writer of Schindler's List, who also turned it down. "I was busy," Zaillian says. "And I wasn't sure I was interested. You can almost never win when you do a sequel." David Mamet then wrote a version, but according to Scott and the De Laurentiises it needed major revisions. Dino and Scott went back to Zaillian, who was willing to reconsider at that point. "I had found out that David Mamet was working on it," Zaillian says, "and I started to feel like, What sort of a jerk am I? You know? Who am I?" Besides, he adds, "It's hard to say no to Dino once, and it's almost impossible to say no to him twice."

Still, Zaillian would not commit to the project until the ending was resolved. Somehow, Dino convinced the reclusive Harris to fly to Los Angeles, where the author spent four days brainstorming with Scott and Zaillian in his hotel suite. "Tom had said, 'I don't really do this, you know?'" Scott recalls. "But after four days of sitting around the table, his comment was, 'This has been really fun. I'll do this again.'" Harris would remain closely involved with the project, even sending handwritten notes to Universal chairman Stacey Snider on issues like casting.

"I think the ending is more tonal as to what could possibly be in her mind at that moment," Scott says, shrugging and lighting a small cigar. "He's quite specific. She is more enigmatic." The film, he adds, contains "an interesting postscript, which, if nothing else, I think is fun. Some people think it's sick." The character of Clarice became an obsession for the entire production, for two reasons: first, when the De Laurentiises turned down the chance to make The Silence of the Lambs, they also passed on the rights to Clarice. To obtain them again, they had to go through MGM, which acquired Orion's properties after the company's demise. A co-production deal, including equal shares of the profits, was struck between Universal and MGM.

The second problem was what Snider calls "a hiccup with the casting". As far as Lecter was concerned, "everybody felt like there was nobody [but Anthony Hopkins] who could play him", says Kevin Misher, Universal's president of production. The actor willingly came on board. "I never thought a sequel would come up," Hopkins says. "And then it did, and I thought, 'OK, fine, let's see what it's like.' I tend to be low-key about things like that." Hopkins had recently returned from a brief, self-imposed exile from Hollywood, following a trying experience making Titus. He read Harris's manuscript but formed no opinion of it. ("I go into neutral. I don't make very much of things," he says.) Then he read the screenplay. "I liked the script. I didn't know what the problem was. I said yes. It was as simple and matter-of-fact as that. It's a living. It's just work." This is the kind of work, however, that would net him $11m in salary alone.

Foster reacted very differently. (She declined to be interviewed for this story.) Some say she had sequelitis. Others contend that she either disliked the book, didn't want to do it without Demme and/or was slated to direct another film. A final possibility is that when she saw the film's profits already being divided up between Harris, Dino, Hopkins, and Scott, it got her back up. "I call the agent of Judy Foster," recalls Dino, who comically mispronounces the actress's name. "He say to me, 'I have instruction. She no want to read the script if you no give her an offer of $20m and 15% of the gross.' And I say, 'Give my love to Judy Foster, goodbye.' That's a crazy demand." Besides, he says, "I don't believe Judy Foster from day one was right when I read the book."

Universal took Foster's decision much harder. "We went back to her, like you go back to any actor who has passed, and said, 'Come on, this is Clarice Starling. This is the character that really was yours,'" Misher says. Scott, who worked with the actress in the early 1990s, spoke with her too, but to no avail. Hopkins stayed out of it. "I think actors who get involved in that stuff must need a good psychoanalysis," he says. "Just give me my plane ticket, and I'll show up. I keep my life much simpler that way." Misher says: "It was one of those moments when you sit down and think, 'Can Clarice be looked upon as James Bond, for instance? A character who is replaceable? Or was Jodie Foster Clarice Starling, and the audience will not accept anyone else?'"

To find out, Universal quietly floated the possibility around town, and soon several A-list actresses (Cate Blanchett, Angelina Jolie, Hilary Swank, Ashley Judd and Julianne Moore) had shown interest. "I think it emboldened us," Misher says. Moore quickly rose to the top of the list. She was someone with "impeccable credentials who was also a star," Misher says. "She was kind of it," adds Scott. Before offering her the role, however, Scott consulted Hopkins, because the franchise "was more his than mine. He said, 'Oh, yes. Jolly good.' "

Moore was hired for a reported $3m. Even the internet rabble-rousers seemed pleased. Scott considers her a fitting successor to Foster, seeing in her "a certain kind of gravitas, an intelligence, which is very similar. But you know, honestly, most good actors are really smart. Some producers will say that's nonsense," he adds with a chuckle. "No. I've got to work with them."

Lecter's mind may be a creepy place, but Hopkins had no trouble moving back into it. "I just learned the lines and showed up and walked around as Hannibal Lecter," he says. The actor did, however, pop in a tape of Silence before shooting began. "I thought, 'Do I repeat that performance, or do I vary it?' Ten years had passed, so I changed it a bit. Because I've changed." Today's Hannibal is "a bit mellower", Hopkins says. "He's probably a much richer character." Rivalling Lecter in the villainy department is Mason Verger, a paedophile and the only one of Hannibal the Cannibal's victims who remains alive (though not quite intact). Verger uses his enormous wealth to search for Lecter and plot a gory revenge. The role required hours of prosthetic make-up, and Scott found his man in the chameleon-like Gary Oldman.

"We had a funny situation with Gary," Martha De Laurentiis says. "He wanted a prominent credit. Now, how can you do a prominent credit with Hannibal? The characters are Hannibal and Clarice Starling. So we really couldn't work something out [at first]." For a while Oldman was out, then he came back, asking to go unbilled. His casting was announced by Dino at a press conference in Florence just before the start of shooting, "so we couldn't deny that he was in the movie", Martha says. "They [Oldman and his camp] got really pissed off. And to have a pissed-off actor . . ." She changes tone abruptly. "You'll have to see the film to see if it's Gary Oldman or not." (Oldman's manager declined to comment.)

Even then, audiences might not recognise the actor. Oldman has been completely transformed, thanks to a translucent silicone that make-up artist Greg Cannom says he and his associate, Wesley Wofford, invented for Bicentennial Man. "I knew we could get away with more with him than some other actor," says Cannom. "The first thing he said was, 'Can we stretch my eye open?' " No lips, no cheeks, no eyelids. "It's really disgusting," Cannom says. "I've been showing people pictures [of Oldman as Verger], and they all just say, 'Oh my God,' and walk away, which makes me very happy."

Verger wants Lecter dead. Most of all, he wants to watch him suffer. To this purpose, he has been breeding an especially vicious pack of wild pigs, "hip-high to a man," Thomas Harris writes, "intelligent little eyes in their hellish faces . . . capable of lifting a man on their great, ripping tusks." Animal coordinator Sled Reynolds looked at more than 6,000 pigs across North America before finding what he calls "the biggest ones I could", more than a dozen 350-600lb breeding boars from a Canadian dealer. After a quarantine, the tusked, long-haired beasts, with teeth four or five inches long, arrived to train with Reynolds on his California ranch. "They're supposed to look very violent and mean, but they're also supposed to stand around in a crew of 150 people and have Gary Oldman lying among them and not eat him," Reynolds says. "So, obviously, their aggression has to be trained."

He quickly discovered the animals to be very intelligent. "I really grew fond of the little buggers." Cinematographer John Mathieson says the "rather charming" creatures would "come up and wipe their noses on the cameras and get pig schnoz all over the front." One "particularly nasty" task was left to an animatronic boar, which "grabbed [a dummy's] face and ripped it right off," Cannom says. "The other one grabbed his entrails. People were getting sick. I don't think they will show much of that." Another of the movie's stomach-turning set pieces involves a cosy dinner that Hannibal arranges for himself, Clarice, and her justice department nemesis, Paul Krendler (Ray Liotta).

"He has the opportunity and the know-how to make [Starling's] life miserable," Liotta says of Krendler, "so that's what he does." Liotta used a little know-how of his own to nab the role: he caught Scott off-guard at a gym in Los Angeles before production began. "He was walking out," Liotta recalls, "and, like two or three movies that I've gotten, I just went up to him and said, 'I'd love to work with you.' " "That worked," Scott says, still amused by Liotta's tactic. "I was struggling at the gym and he was sitting on a bicycle, reading a newspaper. I had never met him, but I knew he knew who I was. I was walking out to the car park and he said, 'I know what you're doing. Is there anything in there for me?' I thought about it and said, 'Well, why not?' "

A $70,000 animatronic dummy of Liotta was created for the climactic dinner scene, giving the actor an unusual opportunity to stand off-camera and watch himself acting. Liotta, who endured a full head and body cast and shaved his head for the role, says he had a ball playing someone who's "filled with drugs, yet is still awake while all this is happening. I think people will definitely remember this scene." Those who've read the book certainly do. But even they may be in for a surprise. "If anything, it's more explicit than in the book," he says.

I t's the morning after Halloween. Taped to the door of an editing room is a reduced copy of the Hannibal poster, which has been doctored with a strip of paper near Hopkins's mouth that reads: TRICK OR TREAT. DO YOU HAVE SOMETHING I CAN EAT? Ridley Scott emerges from a chat with editor Pietro Scalia and Dino De Laurentiis and goes right into a meeting with members of a Manhattan design studio, who've come to pitch ideas for the film's opening title sequence. They present Scott with storyboards offering a tour through the chambers of Lecter's mind and discuss using the aptly named type font Chianti. Scott seems pleased but warns against making the sequence "whimsically gothic". He suggests that instead of music - or in addition to it - the journey could be accompanied by "the sound you get from blood when it moves through the vein" or "old secrets whispered over books".

Scott may not be quite through with Hannibal Lecter yet. The De Laurentiises have announced plans to capitalise on their investment by remaking Red Dragon at Universal; the studio's Stacey Snider says it will include new, Lecter-related plot lines. It is very unusual for a contemporary novel to be made into a movie twice within 20 years. Michael Mann, who directed the original 1986 version, declined to be interviewed.
