fields.bodyText: The only person watching Clarice Starling more closely than Hannibal Lecter is director Ridley Scott. In a Los Angeles sound studio, Scott sits behind a console as the opening scene from his new movie, Hannibal, plays on a large screen across the room and on a nearby monitor. "Pretty busy today," Starling mouths, via a hidden mike, to a fellow FBI agent at a fish market, where a sting operation is about to go tragically wrong. "Pretty busy today," comes the simultaneous voice of Julianne Moore, talking in New York in a bicoastal looping session to ensure that the scene's background noises do not drown out her dialogue. Scott presses a lighted square on a little black box. "That was good," he says. "It's going to be quite loud. Project as much as you dare, considering what your face is doing." He takes his hand off the button and whispers, "Can I get some coffee?" as the footage is cued for replay. "Pretty busy today," Moore says again. Sound technicians scrutinise the playback, making sure that the words match the lip movements, and give Scott a nod. For the next few hours, he will remain supremely attuned to the nuances of Starling's voice, the logic of her actions and the nature of her character. Everyone connected with Hannibal knows there is a lot at stake. Three months from now, Moore will appear before millions of fans who have waited 10 years to see Lecter and Starling play cat and mouse again. Italian is the first language spoken at Martha and Dino De Laurentiis's production office on the Universal lot in the Hollywood hills. Dino, the 81-year-old veteran of such films as La Strada, Ulysses and War and Peace, still speaks heavily accented English. He is a short man, sporting large, dark-rimmed glasses and a coral shirt under a tweed jacket. His wife and partner, 46-year-old Martha, sits beside him. Nearby, a dark, wooden desk big enough to roller-skate on is covered with awards. But today they are talking about the one that got away. In 1985, the couple bought the rights to Thomas Harris's bestselling thriller Red Dragon, from which they produced the 1986 movie Manhunter, directed by Michael Mann. The film, which features the first, brief screen appearance of the serial killer Hannibal Lecter (then spelled Lektor and played by Brian Cox), was inventive, frightening and well-received, but it grossed $8.6m, less than the cost of its print ads. The De Laurentiises were disappointed. "Manhunter was not Red Dragon," Dino says. "Manhunter was no good." And so when Harris completed The Silence of the Lambs, neither Dino nor Martha bothered to read it, even though they owned the screen rights to the Lecter character (who figured much more prominently in this new novel). "Big mistake" is how Dino now characterises this lack of interest. Harris and director Jonathan Demme came to him, wanting to set the project up elsewhere; Dino agreed and lent the now-defunct Orion Pictures the character of Hannibal Lecter - for free. "We were afraid to make the movie," Martha explains. "You could be terrible and say no, or you could demand money, which was kind of, 'Why be greedy?' Or you let them use it, and if it's successful, your asset has value." The Silence of the Lambs was released on February 14, 1991. It grossed $131m and received five Oscars, including best actor for Anthony Hopkins, best actress for Jodie Foster, and best picture. The De Laurentiises suddenly found themselves sitting on a valuable asset. Even before the movie came out, there was manoeuvring for a stake in a potential Silence sequel. Tom Pollock, then-chairman of Universal (and a former attorney who represented De Laurentiis during the making of Manhunter), asked Dino, who still controlled the Lecter character, to make any sequel at Universal. The De Laurentiises felt that Pollock was using other films they were partnering on as leverage for this request; Pollock felt they had reached an oral agreement to do the sequel. A conflict ensued, and the producers filed a $25m lawsuit against Universal. The parties ultimately settled; the studio got the participation it had wanted. All of this planning was still hypothetical, of course - Harris, a notoriously slow writer, was years away from finishing the next instalment. Every year, the eager De Laurentiises would fly down to Miami, with their personal chef in tow, and have dinner with Harris. ("Tom is a great gourmand," Martha says.) "Finally, I receive a call from Thomas," Dino recalls in his gravelly voice. " 'Dino, I did it.' He finish." Hannibal picks up 10 years after Silence left off, with Lecter on the loose (he spends a chunk of time, to the De Laurentiises' delight, in Italy) and keeping a watchful eye on Clarice Starling - who will be used to smoke the serial killer out. The novel received mixed reviews but pushed Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets off the top of the best-seller list. Dino purchased the rights for a record $10m (£6.9m). Before publication, the manuscript went out to Hopkins, Foster, and Demme, who had expressed interest in directing the sequel. Dino and Martha flew from Malta, where they were filming Universal's U-571, to New York to meet with Demme and begin structuring a deal. Later, however, Dino received a call from Demme's agent, CAA's Rick Nicita. "He say to me, 'Dino, I have-a no good news for you. Jonathan Demme pass.' I say, 'Rick, when the Pope-a die, we create a new Pope-a. Good luck to Jonathan Demme. Good-bye.' " It wasn't long before a new leader had been chosen. Ridley Scott (director of Blade Runner, Alien, Thelma & Louise), who had worked with Dino briefly on 1984's Dune, was in Malta filming Gladiator next door to U-571. He invited Dino in for a cup of espresso. Five days later, Scottt recalls, Dino brought him "a giant manuscript that said Hannibal", which prompted the response: "I said, 'Dino, I don't want to do elephants coming over the Alps. I'm doing a Roman movie now .' " After reading the book (which features vicious boars rather than elephants), Scott accepted the job - although not without some hesitation. He had qualms about the ending, in which Clarice and Hannibal ride off amorously (and, to many readers, inconceivably) into the sunset. "I couldn't take that quantum leap emotionally on behalf of Starling. Certainly, on behalf of Hannibal - I'm sure that's been in the back of his mind for a number of years. But for Starling, no. I think one of the attractions about Starling to Hannibal is what a straight arrow she is." Universal was also wary of the ending. "I said to Dino: 'I'd really like to talk to Tom [Harris] to see how much licence we've got.' Tom said, 'Well, what would the interpretation be?' I said, 'I really don't know.' " Untangling that meant hiring a screenwriter. Ted Tally, who'd won an Oscar for his Silence adaptation, turned down the sequel. An offer went out to Steven Zaillian, the writer of Schindler's List, who also turned it down. "I was busy," Zaillian says. "And I wasn't sure I was interested. You can almost never win when you do a sequel." David Mamet then wrote a version, but according to Scott and the De Laurentiises it needed major revisions. Dino and Scott went back to Zaillian, who was willing to reconsider at that point. "I had found out that David Mamet was working on it," Zaillian says, "and I started to feel like, What sort of a jerk am I? You know? Who am I?" Besides, he adds, "It's hard to say no to Dino once, and it's almost impossible to say no to him twice." Still, Zaillian would not commit to the project until the ending was resolved. Somehow, Dino convinced the reclusive Harris to fly to Los Angeles, where the author spent four days brainstorming with Scott and Zaillian in his hotel suite. "Tom had said, 'I don't really do this, you know?'" Scott recalls. "But after four days of sitting around the table, his comment was, 'This has been really fun. I'll do this again.'" Harris would remain closely involved with the project, even sending handwritten notes to Universal chairman Stacey Snider on issues like casting. "I think the ending is more tonal as to what could possibly be in her mind at that moment," Scott says, shrugging and lighting a small cigar. "He's quite specific. She is more enigmatic." The film, he adds, contains "an interesting postscript, which, if nothing else, I think is fun. Some people think it's sick." The character of Clarice became an obsession for the entire production, for two reasons: first, when the De Laurentiises turned down the chance to make The Silence of the Lambs, they also passed on the rights to Clarice. To obtain them again, they had to go through MGM, which acquired Orion's properties after the company's demise. A co-production deal, including equal shares of the profits, was struck between Universal and MGM. The second problem was what Snider calls "a hiccup with the casting". As far as Lecter was concerned, "everybody felt like there was nobody [but Anthony Hopkins] who could play him", says Kevin Misher, Universal's president of production. The actor willingly came on board. "I never thought a sequel would come up," Hopkins says. "And then it did, and I thought, 'OK, fine, let's see what it's like.' I tend to be low-key about things like that." Hopkins had recently returned from a brief, self-imposed exile from Hollywood, following a trying experience making Titus. He read Harris's manuscript but formed no opinion of it. ("I go into neutral. I don't make very much of things," he says.) Then he read the screenplay. "I liked the script. I didn't know what the problem was. I said yes. It was as simple and matter-of-fact as that. It's a living. It's just work." This is the kind of work, however, that would net him $11m in salary alone. Foster reacted very differently. (She declined to be interviewed for this story.) Some say she had sequelitis. Others contend that she either disliked the book, didn't want to do it without Demme and/or was slated to direct another film. A final possibility is that when she saw the film's profits already being divided up between Harris, Dino, Hopkins, and Scott, it got her back up. "I call the agent of Judy Foster," recalls Dino, who comically mispronounces the actress's name. "He say to me, 'I have instruction. She no want to read the script if you no give her an offer of $20m and 15% of the gross.' And I say, 'Give my love to Judy Foster, goodbye.' That's a crazy demand." Besides, he says, "I don't believe Judy Foster from day one was right when I read the book." Universal took Foster's decision much harder. "We went back to her, like you go back to any actor who has passed, and said, 'Come on, this is Clarice Starling. This is the character that really was yours,'" Misher says. Scott, who worked with the actress in the early 1990s, spoke with her too, but to no avail. Hopkins stayed out of it. "I think actors who get involved in that stuff must need a good psychoanalysis," he says. "Just give me my plane ticket, and I'll show up. I keep my life much simpler that way." Misher says: "It was one of those moments when you sit down and think, 'Can Clarice be looked upon as James Bond, for instance? A character who is replaceable? Or was Jodie Foster Clarice Starling, and the audience will not accept anyone else?'" To find out, Universal quietly floated the possibility around town, and soon several A-list actresses (Cate Blanchett, Angelina Jolie, Hilary Swank, Ashley Judd and Julianne Moore) had shown interest. "I think it emboldened us," Misher says. Moore quickly rose to the top of the list. She was someone with "impeccable credentials who was also a star," Misher says. "She was kind of it," adds Scott. Before offering her the role, however, Scott consulted Hopkins, because the franchise "was more his than mine. He said, 'Oh, yes. Jolly good.' " Moore was hired for a reported $3m. Even the internet rabble-rousers seemed pleased. Scott considers her a fitting successor to Foster, seeing in her "a certain kind of gravitas, an intelligence, which is very similar. But you know, honestly, most good actors are really smart. Some producers will say that's nonsense," he adds with a chuckle. "No. I've got to work with them." Lecter's mind may be a creepy place, but Hopkins had no trouble moving back into it. "I just learned the lines and showed up and walked around as Hannibal Lecter," he says. The actor did, however, pop in a tape of Silence before shooting began. "I thought, 'Do I repeat that performance, or do I vary it?' Ten years had passed, so I changed it a bit. Because I've changed." Today's Hannibal is "a bit mellower", Hopkins says. "He's probably a much richer character." Rivalling Lecter in the villainy department is Mason Verger, a paedophile and the only one of Hannibal the Cannibal's victims who remains alive (though not quite intact). Verger uses his enormous wealth to search for Lecter and plot a gory revenge. The role required hours of prosthetic make-up, and Scott found his man in the chameleon-like Gary Oldman. "We had a funny situation with Gary," Martha De Laurentiis says. "He wanted a prominent credit. Now, how can you do a prominent credit with Hannibal? The characters are Hannibal and Clarice Starling. So we really couldn't work something out [at first]." For a while Oldman was out, then he came back, asking to go unbilled. His casting was announced by Dino at a press conference in Florence just before the start of shooting, "so we couldn't deny that he was in the movie", Martha says. "They [Oldman and his camp] got really pissed off. And to have a pissed-off actor . . ." She changes tone abruptly. "You'll have to see the film to see if it's Gary Oldman or not." (Oldman's manager declined to comment.) Even then, audiences might not recognise the actor. Oldman has been completely transformed, thanks to a translucent silicone that make-up artist Greg Cannom says he and his associate, Wesley Wofford, invented for Bicentennial Man. "I knew we could get away with more with him than some other actor," says Cannom. "The first thing he said was, 'Can we stretch my eye open?' " No lips, no cheeks, no eyelids. "It's really disgusting," Cannom says. "I've been showing people pictures [of Oldman as Verger], and they all just say, 'Oh my God,' and walk away, which makes me very happy." Verger wants Lecter dead. Most of all, he wants to watch him suffer. To this purpose, he has been breeding an especially vicious pack of wild pigs, "hip-high to a man," Thomas Harris writes, "intelligent little eyes in their hellish faces . . . capable of lifting a man on their great, ripping tusks." Animal coordinator Sled Reynolds looked at more than 6,000 pigs across North America before finding what he calls "the biggest ones I could", more than a dozen 350-600lb breeding boars from a Canadian dealer. After a quarantine, the tusked, long-haired beasts, with teeth four or five inches long, arrived to train with Reynolds on his California ranch. "They're supposed to look very violent and mean, but they're also supposed to stand around in a crew of 150 people and have Gary Oldman lying among them and not eat him," Reynolds says. "So, obviously, their aggression has to be trained." He quickly discovered the animals to be very intelligent. "I really grew fond of the little buggers." Cinematographer John Mathieson says the "rather charming" creatures would "come up and wipe their noses on the cameras and get pig schnoz all over the front." One "particularly nasty" task was left to an animatronic boar, which "grabbed [a dummy's] face and ripped it right off," Cannom says. "The other one grabbed his entrails. People were getting sick. I don't think they will show much of that." Another of the movie's stomach-turning set pieces involves a cosy dinner that Hannibal arranges for himself, Clarice, and her justice department nemesis, Paul Krendler (Ray Liotta). "He has the opportunity and the know-how to make [Starling's] life miserable," Liotta says of Krendler, "so that's what he does." Liotta used a little know-how of his own to nab the role: he caught Scott off-guard at a gym in Los Angeles before production began. "He was walking out," Liotta recalls, "and, like two or three movies that I've gotten, I just went up to him and said, 'I'd love to work with you.' " "That worked," Scott says, still amused by Liotta's tactic. "I was struggling at the gym and he was sitting on a bicycle, reading a newspaper. I had never met him, but I knew he knew who I was. I was walking out to the car park and he said, 'I know what you're doing. Is there anything in there for me?' I thought about it and said, 'Well, why not?' " A $70,000 animatronic dummy of Liotta was created for the climactic dinner scene, giving the actor an unusual opportunity to stand off-camera and watch himself acting. Liotta, who endured a full head and body cast and shaved his head for the role, says he had a ball playing someone who's "filled with drugs, yet is still awake while all this is happening. I think people will definitely remember this scene." Those who've read the book certainly do. But even they may be in for a surprise. "If anything, it's more explicit than in the book," he says. I t's the morning after Halloween. Taped to the door of an editing room is a reduced copy of the Hannibal poster, which has been doctored with a strip of paper near Hopkins's mouth that reads: TRICK OR TREAT. DO YOU HAVE SOMETHING I CAN EAT? Ridley Scott emerges from a chat with editor Pietro Scalia and Dino De Laurentiis and goes right into a meeting with members of a Manhattan design studio, who've come to pitch ideas for the film's opening title sequence. They present Scott with storyboards offering a tour through the chambers of Lecter's mind and discuss using the aptly named type font Chianti. Scott seems pleased but warns against making the sequence "whimsically gothic". He suggests that instead of music - or in addition to it - the journey could be accompanied by "the sound you get from blood when it moves through the vein" or "old secrets whispered over books". Scott may not be quite through with Hannibal Lecter yet. "I don't know if that makes the whole of the world crazy, but . . . there are dark sides to human nature." From Premiere magazine. © 2000, Hachette Filipacchi magazines. fields.headline: At this price? Signet
fields.trailText: Jewellers have been having a sparkling time recently and Signet, the company formerly known as Ratners, is no exception.
fields.body:
Jewellers have been having a sparkling time recently and Signet, the company formerly known as Ratners, is no exception.

The shares rose 2.25p to a year's high of 71p yesterday following news of a good Christmas performance. Overall like-for-like sales for the year rose 6.8% and underlying sales for the fourth quarter were up 3.3%.

Signet's US operation has the largest turnover per store among American multiple jewellers, and the UK side of the group - the H Samuel and Ernest Jones stores - saw an underlying rise of 7.9% on like-for-like sales in the 13 weeks to the end of January.

Over the last 10 years the company has been turned around and brought back from the brink of near bankruptcy. The US portfolio has been upgraded and the management team has kept a handle on the finances and been able to sit back and watch people buy jewellery in a strong economy.

Terry Burman, Signet's chief executive, was upbeat about the results for the year. "During the quarter the US business demonstrated resilience and increased market share, against the background of a marked slowdown in the economy."

But here lies the problem for the company. The US economy is heading for a slowdown if not outright recession, and so the future might not be quite as bright. The 1,604 specialist retail jewellery stores Signet operates - particularly the 999 in the US - might not be the popular destinations they have been in the recent past.

Indeed, there are already signs that sales may be starting to be affected. The company's US shops, which have traditionally been the strongest part of the business and which accounted for 70.7% of the total sales for the fourth quarter saw like-for-like sales rise by just 1.1%.

With growing concerns about the economic climate in the US, the company's recent strength may not continue. The shares are no more than a hold.

webTitle: All right for commuters to stand 30 minutes, says rail boss

fields.headline: All right for commuters to stand 30 minutes, says rail boss
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: The rail director of Stagecoach, one of Britain's biggest transport operators, last night said it was acceptable for commuters to stand for up to 30 minutes in the rush hour on a crowded train.
fields.body:
The rail director of Stagecoach, one of Britain's biggest transport operators, last night said it was acceptable for commuters to stand for up to 30 minutes in the rush hour on a crowded train.

Graham Eccles said he supported the plan for improved services put forward by Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the strategic rail authority, so long as commuters were not packed in "nose to armpit".

Sir Alastair submitted the plan as one of his eight commandments when the SRA was set up. He said trains should be comfortable and that "standing for 20-30 minutes in the rush hour is not unacceptable".

Mr Eccles, who was launching Stagecoach's £3.5bn bid to transform its rail subsidiary, South West Trains, which operates more than 1,700 trains a day, said: "We agree with Sir Alastair. It's time to move fast.''

Overcrowding has become a big issue for commuters travelling into big cities, exacerbated by a 30% increase in passengers over the past four years. The SRA has the ultimate responsibility for overcrowding, but has been unable to exercise much control.

Brian Souter, Stagecoach chairman, yesterday attacked the current sub-contracting system exposed by the Hatfield rail disaster. He said it did not work because many sub-contractors failed to return the track to train companies on time. This often led to cancellations and inconvenience to the public.

Mr Souter said: "I would very much like to do away with this system and replace it with people of our own. We would be able to kick their backsides if they failed us. We want to be able to run the railway properly.''

The main elements of the Stagecoach bid, which has been submitted to the SRA, are for South West Trains to be allowed to rebuild 10 miles of track between Waterloo and Surbiton, Surrey, the busiest part of the network.

Mr Eccles said stations would be lengthened over the proposed 20 year franchise and new trains, similar to those on the Heathrow Express service from central London and valued at £1.5bn, would be introduced before the end of 2004. He said: "We can and will deliver more seats on more trains more quickly than anybody else.''

Mr Eccles said South West Trains had vastly more experience in running a commuter network than Great North Eastern Railway, another bidder, which only operated 120 trains each day. Recalling the early days of South West Trains, when it sacked too many drivers and its service almost collapsed, Mr Souter admitted: "We have had our problems, but we have learned our lessons. We have got to love it, warts and all."

fields.headline: Market forces
fields.trailText: It is all turning nasty. Investment bank Merrill Lynch is standing by its trading department's "sell" recommendation on knowledge management company Autonomy.
fields.body:
It is all turning nasty. Investment bank Merrill Lynch is standing by its trading department's "sell" recommendation on knowledge management company Autonomy.

The news, which emerged after the market closed last night alongside a statement from leisure group Enic that it intends to sell all or part of its 2.8% stake in the company, is expected to trigger fresh selling of Autonomy shares today. Yesterday they climbed 118p to £19.33 - the best performer in the FTSE 100 - on the expectation that Merrill Lynch would retract the note.

On Wednesday, Autonomy complained to City regulators about the note, which alleged that the company had lost key staff and was facing competition from Microsoft. But while Merrill has agreed to correct its assertion that certain Autonomy staff had moved to Microsoft, it is standing behind the "sell" advice.

"We are standing by the idea, but the reference to the individuals was incorrect," a Merrill spokesperson said.

The central thrust of the note was that Autonomy would no longer be able to charge hefty licensing fees as Microsoft was developing a similar knowledge management product. The claim was dismissed by Autonomy boss Mike Lynch.

But traders are starting to wonder if Mr Lynch is a little too sensitive to criticism. Back in January, he took the unusual step of issuing a trading update after analysts at ABN Amro issued a note drawing a comparison between Autonomy and a US technology firm, Inktomi, which had just issued a profits warning.

In the wider market it was a busy day for traders, with the Bank of England trimming interest rates by 25 basis points and six blue chip companies reporting results.

But with the figures from AstraZeneca, down 41p to £29.63p and BT, off 60p to 620p, in particular proving disappointing, the FTSE 100 ended the session down 19.5 points at 6,206.1. However, the FTSE Techmark 100 closed up 5.95 points at 2,641.33, with telecom testing specialist Spirent rising 24p to 514p on the back of an ABN Amro recommendation. Apparently the Dutch broker was telling its clients that Spirent was better positioned than many telecom equipment firms to weather the slowdown in the US economy.

Railtrack, 23p higher at £10.08, made a rare appearance near the top of the FTSE 100 leaderboard as one of London's biggest brokers, Deutsche Bank, came out in support of the rail network operator. Repeating its "strong buy" stance, Deutsche said it expected Railtrack's operation performance to improve in the coming months.

Over in the media sector, advertising group WPP - 15p weaker at 840p - was groaning under the weight of a downgrade from HSBC Securities. Citing the impact of a US recession on advertising spend, the broker lowered its rating WPP to "reduce" from "buy".

On the takeover front, Powergen dipped 10p to 704p on fears that German utility E.On might walk away from discussions with the group. According to industry gossip, E.On is thinking about biding for Spain's second biggest power firm, Iberdrola.

IT services group Sema was going the other way, improving 29p to 470p on reports that a takeover bid from US group Schlumberger is on the way. Market professionals expect the bid - likely to be a mixture of Schlumberger paper and cash - to be tabled to today.

Matalan rose 28.5p to 555p on the back of positive comments from Goldman Sachs. Following a chat with company executives last night, Goldman reckons the problems that led to January's profits warning have been solved.

fields.headline: Appreciation: John Prebble
fields.trailText: Brian Wilson and David Craig write.
fields.body:
Brian Wilson writes: Particular recognition is due to John Prebble (Obituary, January 31) for his massive contribution to popular awareness, at home and abroad, of Highland history and the unwelcome challenge which this presented to Scottish academic historians.

There is no doubt that Prebble did more than any individual to restore recognition of the brutal forces, largely generated from within Scotland itself, which had driven Gaelic society to the verge of destruction. To an extraordinary degree, these events had been written out of the Scottish historical script.

Prebble was born in Middlesex, but grew up in the largely Scottish township of Sutherland in Saskatchewan, established by a descendant of the Strath of Kildonan clearances. At 16, his first novel was about a Scottish island he had never seen. He became a communist, established his career as a writer and did his war service in the Royal Artillery. But there was always an interest in Scotland's history, of which he had heard so much as a child, and in particular the forces that had driven so many Gaels to the far corners of the earth.

Visiting Culloden in the 1950s, he looked at the memorials to the Highland dead and wondered what stories lay behind their names. The result was the eponymous book, published in 1961, which he defined as "an attempt to tell the story of the ordinary men and women involved in the last Jacobite rising, often against their will." Logically, he followed its huge success with The Highland Clearances which he initially assumed - quite wrongly - would contain nothing that every Scottish schoolboy did not know.

Much of the Scottish academic establishment held Prebble in ill-concealed contempt, loathing his choice of subjects almost as much as his commercial appeal. His success in popularising the history of the common people and presenting it in terms of conflicting economic and social interests was, by definition, an indictment of their own refusal to tread the same path.

This conflict spilled over into a splendid public spat in the early 1980s when the Historiographer Royal, the late Professor Gordon Donaldson of Edinburgh University, hit back at the renaissance of interest in Highland history which Prebble had done so much to generate. He described Prebble's work as "utter rubbish" and complained: "I am 68 now and until recently had hardly heard of the Highland Clearances. The thing has been blown out of proportion." That was indeed the Establishment view. There was actually a book written in the 1950s by a respected Scottish historian under the title The Highland Economy 1750-1850 which did not mention the clearances at all. The bibliography for Prebble's work on the subject confirms that virtually nothing had been written on it in the 20th century. It took a journalist, reared in Canada and living in Surrey, to change all that.

The refusal of the Scottish academic community to recognise Prebble's contribution, even in his advancing years, irritated some of us and a campaign was launched to secure for him an honorary degree from a Scottish university. This met with success when Professor Ted Cowan took over the history chair at Glasgow University and had no difficulty in recognising that John Prebble "has interested more people than anyone this century in Scottish history, both in Scotland and worldwide."

When I last spoke to Prebble, he was expanding upon the autobiography of his grandmother, written in jotters and chronicling her life in rural, radical Kent before moving to service in the suburbs of London. As usual, she followed the route which economics and employment dictated, which is the reality of most people's history. It was always this history of the common people - the crofters, the soldiers, the servants - which motivated him. The history of kings and queens could safely be left to others. But if future historiographers royal have also heard of the Highland Clearances, it will be due in no small part to the life's work of the great John Prebble.

David Craig writes: John Prebble did not suggest, and would never have thought, that it was the "English rich" who evicted Highland small tenants to make room for sheep farms and deer forests. What The Highland Clearances describes in unsparing detail is the often heartless actions of the lairds and their factors, most of whom were Scottish.

The "bloodstained episodes of Scottish" history Prebble narrates - the massacre in Glencoe, the battle at Culloden, the commercial fiasco of the Darien Scheme, the suppression of mutinies and risings - were not engineered by "English monarchs" - let alone Cromwell - since they all happened not less than 90 years after the Union of the Crowns and were invariably executed by Scottish high heid yins, especially aristocrats. Prebble, who helped me generously with my own work on the clearances, was much too clear-sighted a socialist to misuse history for the sake of jingoistic propaganda.

fields.headline: Corrections  and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report headed Strong cast, Good Book, big hit, page 19, yesterday, we referred to the film, Dogma, "in which God was portrayed on the screen as a black woman." In fact, the part is played by a white woman, Alanis Morissette.
fields.body:
In a report headed Strong cast, Good Book, big hit, page 19, yesterday, we referred to the film, Dogma, "in which God was portrayed on the screen as a black woman." In fact, the part is played by a white woman, Alanis Morissette.

A photograph, page 28, Finance, yesterday, captioned "Alistair Riddell, Pharmagene's chief executive", actually showed the company's chief scientific officer, Robert Campbell. Apologies to both.

In a report, page 8, February 7, Police battle to rescue rail passengers, we described Wick as "the most northerly town on the British mainland". The title rightfully belongs to Thurso.

The solicitor mentioned in a panel on page 12, yesterday, who has announced she is to stand as a Socialist Alliance candidate in the next election, is Louise Christian, not Laura Christian. At the end of an article about War on Want, page 16, February 7, we said that its author, Mark Luetchford, was writing a history of the charity. In fact he is writing it jointly with Peter Burns, a former general secretary of War on Want.

We understated the size of the cast in the Chisinau National Ballet's Nutcracker at the Hammersmith Apollo, page 20, Reviews, yesterday. We said "just over two dozen". In fact, the full count is more than twice that number.

fields.headline: Barry Cockcroft
fields.standfirst: Television film-maker who ferreted out the grit and beauty of Yorkshire life - and introduced Hannah Hauxwell to the world
fields.trailText: Television film-maker who ferreted out the grit and beauty of Yorkshire life - and introduced Hannah Hauxwell to the world.
fields.body:
Barry Cockroft, who has died aged 68, was a highly original television director and film-maker who made his name when he clambered over a drystone wall in 1973 and had tea with a white-haired Yorkshirewoman whose home had neither mains power nor running water. As the kettle simmered - following a trip to the well and a match to the wood-stove kindling - Cockroft knew he had found a matchless combination in shrewd and witty Hannah Hauxwell and her majestic Pennine surroundings.

Too Long a Winter, the first and best of four films about Hannah's austere but contented life, was an international success, but only one of more than 100 TV documentaries made by Cockroft. During a 20-year connection with Yorkshire Television, dating from the station's first day in 1968, he brought the character of the county's lonely places, and the people determined to live and work in them, to an enormous audience.

Cockroft was always known as "Dino" to colleagues, because of his love of grand, sweeping shots which suggested that Ben-Hur's chariot or Lawrence of Arabia's camels might suddenly appear in Upper Wensleydale or along the Tees. The tag was coined on his first foreign outing for YTV - actually the first travel "freebie" ever offered to the station - to Rome, where Dino de Laurentiis was filming Monte Carlo or Bust. Cockroft came back with a bagful of neat, brief films (notably one on variations in the price of his beloved cappuccino), plus the nickname, which stuck.

Like many of the canniest observers of distinctive places, he was actually an outsider - a Lancastrian from Rochdale, who started work as a teenage proof-reader on the Rochdale Observer, but soon found work as a reporter and feature writer. Writing remained a lifelong talent; after moving to the Manchester office of the News Chronicle and then the local Evening Chronicle (both of which closed under him), he wrote scripts for Coronation Street. His best TV documentaries were always accompanied by well-written, linked books.

His strong visual sense, however, took him from print journalism to Granada TV, where brief documentary films for the local opt-out, Scene at 6.30, attracted attention. He jumped at the chance to join YTV's brave new venture in Leeds, initially recruited by Donald Baverstock to work on Scene's Yorkshire equivalent, Calendar. Cockroft was soon in demand as a director for grander projects, and his cheerful delight in good food and wine was fuelled by trips around the world with Alan Whicker.

But in between those luxurious documentaries, he was starting to ferret out the distinctive - and very Yorkshire - combination of grit, graft and natural beauty, which reached its apogee when he lighted on Birk Hatt Farm in Baldersdale. His connection with Hannah Hauxwell over two decades brought out the best in both; even when translated to Paris and New York, in what seemed a gimmicky bit of ratings-based exploitation, Hannah remained resolutely her excellent self, and Barry's filming stayed in keeping. Meanwhile, there were many other, less famous "Hannahs", from North Sea fishing crews to Cornish farmers, whose lives were celebrated in more than 100 networked YTV documentaries.

Cockroft was a personable man, which not only endeared him to Hannah Hauxwell, but to colleagues in a competitive trade. He almost invariably worked with the same crew, from Mustafa Hammuri as cameraman to Julie O'Hare taking charge of research. In keeping with his "Dino" nickname, there were many others involved; a Cockroft descent on a lonely dale deliberately brought something of the glamour and buzz of bigtime film-making. Cockroft moved to Cornwall after the death of his first wife, but never really retired in spite of suffering from motor neurone disease in his last year. He was working on another Hauxwell book at the time of his death, and enthusiastically helping a young people's theatre in St Ives, Kidz R Us, with publicity and TV work. He is survived by his wife Celia, their daughter Lucy, and two daughters from his first marriage, Julie and Sarah, who followed his footsteps into TV production.

 Barry Cockroft, TV director, film-maker and author, born October 4 1932; died February 4 2001

webTitle: Leader: advice on cannabis being ignored

fields.headline: Why are they so afraid?
fields.standfirst:
Wise advice on cannabis is being ignored

Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Who says this is a populist government? Almost half the public believes cannabis should not be illegal and 99% of us think it should have the lowest policing priority. Yet pot continues to dominate the policing of drugs: more than 90% of all offences are for possession, of which 75% involve cannabis.
fields.body:
Who says this is a populist government? Almost half the public believes cannabis should not be illegal and 99% of us think it should have the lowest policing priority. Yet pot continues to dominate the policing of drugs: more than 90% of all offences are for possession, of which 75% involve cannabis. It drives police stop and search operations - more than 1m in four years - with 90,000 people a year nicked for possession of pot. And yet this week ministers have once again refused to reclassify the drug.

This government also claims to believe in evidence-based policymaking. A two-year study by the Police Foundation's national commission on the misuse of drugs showed the classification of harmfulness by the 1971 Act no longer reflected scientific, medical or sociological evidence. The commission included a leading pharmacologist, two chief constables, and eminent drug advisers. They documented the degree to which cases involving the drug distort the criminal justice system, with huge variations in police cautions (from 22% to 72% of all cases depending on the force) and equally large disparities in sentencing. So much for improving young people's respect for the law. Far from providing the certainty that good laws create, cannabis has become a legal lottery. The commission urged ministers to downgrade cannabis from B to C class, making it a minor non-arrestable offence.

It has taken the Commons select committee on home affairs to prompt this week's ministerial response to the report's 80 recommendations. Only two concessions have been made. The 50% of offenders who get cautions will no longer have to declare them to prospective employers; and new guidelines will urge a more lenient approach to people caught supplying friends. Even the Daily Mail found this a totally inadequate response. There will be no sensible debate this side of the election, but will ministers please be bolder post voting day.

fields.headline: Court to look into 1950 hanging
fields.trailText: The court of appeal is to consider the case of a Liverpool man hanged for a double murder more than 50 years ago.
fields.body:
The court of appeal is to consider the case of a Liverpool man hanged for a double murder more than 50 years ago.

The decision was announced yesterday - the 51st anniversary of the conviction at Liverpool assizes of George Kelly. His case was the oldest referred by the criminal cases review commission since it began work four years ago, said a commission spokesman.

Kelly's daughter, Catherine, is represented by a veteran Liverpool solicitor, Rex Makin, peripherally involved in the case when it came to court. "We cannot bring the man back, and money cannot compensate,'' said Mr Makin. "But we want justice. There was so much police malpractice then that it needs to be exposed so it can never happen again.''

On March 19, 1949, Kelly, 28, and Charles Connolly, 26, set out to rob the Cameo cinema in Wavertree. They were alleged to have shot dead the manager, Leonard Thomas, and his assistant, John Catterall, in an office.

Police investigations were stalled until detectives received an anonymous letter offering information in return for protection. Officers accepted the deal in an advert in the Liverpool Echo, and eventually met James "Stutty" Northam, who had been involved in planning the raid. He said Kelly had planned to carry out the robbery while Connolly kept watch.

Kelly and Connolly were tried but the jury failed to agree at the end of a 13-day hearing. The two were then tried separately. Kelly was convicted on February 8, 1950, and sentenced to be hanged. His appeal was turned down, and he was executed on March 28 at Walton jail, where he was buried.

The prosecution offered no evidence on the murder charge against Connolly, who was jailed after admitting robbery and conspiracy charges. "Members of Mr Kelly's family have always nursed a sense of injustice, and applied to the commission,'' said Mr Makin yesterday.

"The whole case was a farce and it could never happen today. It was a fit-up and was based on little or no evidence. What there was was verbal evidence from prostitutes and informers and prison yard conversations. The solicitor involved was alleged by Kelly's brothers, Frank and Joe, to have acted improperly.

"I was then a very young solicitor, making a living by the sweat of my tongue. Frank and Joe came to see me not long before Kelly was to be hanged to complain about how George had been represented and about the injustice being done to their brother.

"I could do nothing about it, and their faces haunt me to this day.''

The prosecution offered no evidence on the murder charge against Connolly, who was jailed after admitting robbery and conspiracy charges. "Members of Mr Kelly's family have always nursed a sense of injustice, and applied to the commission,'' said Mr Makin yesterday. "The whole case was a farce and it could never happen today. It was a fit-up and was based on little or no evidence. What there was was verbal evidence from prostitutes and informers and prison yard conversations. The solicitor involved was alleged by Kelly's brothers, Frank and Joe, to have acted improperly. "I was then a very young solicitor, making a living by the sweat of my tongue. Frank and Joe came to see me not long before Kelly was to be hanged to complain about how George had been represented and about the injustice being done to their brother. "I could do nothing about it, and their faces haunt me to this day.''

webTitle: Census-takers prepare to map India's millions

fields.headline: Census-takers prepare to map India's millions
fields.standfirst: The largest number-crunching exercise in world history is expected to count more than a billion people
fields.trailText: The largest number-crunching exercise in world history is expected to count more than a billion people.
fields.body:
In the office where Jayant Kumar Banthia works there is a list of names on the wall. Most of them are forgotten British civil servants - E A Gait and W C Plowden, for example - whose ungarlanded endeavours helped to shape the contours of an empire.

But Mr Banthia, India's census commissioner, has a bigger task ahead of him than they did. Over the next three weeks, he is the man responsible for carrying out what is destined to become the largest statistical exercise in human history - India's latest, epic census.

"We have been putting in hard work over the last four years to ensure that every geographical area is covered," Mr Banthia said yesterday. "You can't afford to miss a single village - even it if it is in deep forest, in the Himalayas, in the desert, or surrounded by river."

India has held a census every decade since 1872, a series unbroken by war and civil strife. But this latest census differs from the 14 previous ones in the breadth of its ambition. Some 2m enumerators, most of them local teachers, set off yesterday to visit households in 650,000 villages and 5,500 Indian cities. They are expected to cover the subcontinent, for £25 each, by camel, moped, canoe and on foot.

"They are very sincere. They are local people with familiar faces who are respected," the commissioner said. Their immediate aim between now and February 28 is to confirm what most demographers already agree on: that India is now home to more than a billion people, one sixth of the planet's population.

The last census, in 1991, recorded a population of only 846m. This time the census-takers will be asking new questions - on disability, age at marriage, employment and commuting patterns. It is bigger and more detailed than China's census, completed last October and it is being carried out in 16 languages. The idea is to build up a portrait of a nation undergoing largely unmapped change.

The census coincides exactly with a new period of economic liberalisation over the last decade, and with increased migration from villages to towns, Mr Banthia said.

The census may also confirm several dismal trends. In at least three Indian states, Punjab, Haryana, and Uttar Pradesh, the ratio of women to men is alarmingly low - way below the national level of 927 women to 1,000 men. The scarcity of women can, it seems, be attributed to widespread female infanticide in rural areas.

India's influential Parsis, meanwhile, who fled Iran several centuries ago, are waiting to see whether the census confirms what elders have long feared: that their community is dying off because of emigration and a reluctance to marry.

Lieutenant-general A M Sethna, of India's national commission for minorities, yesterday urged all Parsis to take part in the census. In an open letter he asked: "Is the Zoroastrian community alive and thriving? Are newborn babies replacing the older members who die so that the community numbers remain stable and grow?"

The census is also expected to show that India's literacy rate has risen - though it is not clear by how much. In 1991 only 64% of men and 39% of women could read. As in previous surveys, respondents are asked to give their religion, and to identify whether they are members of a scheduled "caste" or "tribe". For the first time slumdwellers are being included.

The data from this vast exercise are expected to be crunched next month. Mr Banthia predicts an accuracy rate of 98.3%. "Compared to some western countries we are doing a very good job," he said. The snowbound areas of India - Jammu and Kashmir and foothill villages in the Himalayas - have already been surveyed and the census will be "rescheduled" in districts flattened by last month's earthquake in the western state of Gujarat, which is thought to have killed at least 30,000.

"Psychologically people there may not respond at the moment," Mr Banthia admitted. But the census commissioner said he drew "inspiration" from his unsung British colonial predecessors, whose careful and thorough methodology he has inherited. "When I look at Mr Richy who carried out the 1901 census, he was dealing with only 200m people," he said. "But his area was more. One shouldn't forget he had Pakistan too, as well as Aden and Burma."

fields.headline: Boys 'planned school massacre like Columbine'
fields.trailText: Three teenage boys from Colorado have been charged with plotting a gun massacre at their school, which is just 60 miles from Columbine high school, where 15 people died in an armed rampage by two pupils in April 1999.
fields.body:
Three teenage boys from Colorado have been charged with plotting a gun massacre at their school, which is just 60 miles from Columbine high school, where 15 people died in an armed rampage by two pupils in April 1999.

Two of the teenagers have been charged with conspiracy to commit first degree murder at Preston junior high school in Fort Collins. A third has been charged with conspiracy to commit assault.

Police in Fort Collins named the three boys as Alexander Vukodinovich, 15, Scott Parent, 14, and Chad Meininger, 15. Vukodinovich and Parent are being held in custody and could face up to five years in juvenile prison. Meininger was released into the custody of his parents but could face a sentence of up to two years.

Investigators were tipped off about the plot on January 12 after pupils reported that the three were planning an attack. All three were suspended from school four days later and are facing expulsion as well as criminal charges.

"A comment was made that they were going to redo Columbine," Larry Abrahamson of the local district attorney's office said. "It was serious enough to take action."

Police say they discovered detailed sketches of the school in one teenager's locker. One included a diagram of where the three boys would station themselves during an attack.

A search of their homes revealed an extensive arsenal including two rifles, one double-barrelled shotgun, a .36 calibre handgun and a semi-automatic handgun similar to one used in the Columbine assault. Police also found large stores of ammunition and a propane gas tank which was believed to form part of their plot. The boys are said to have boasted that they would attack on the second anniversary of Columbine.

Vukodinovich's lawyer, Eric Fischer, said his client regretted what he had said but that he never planned to hurt anybody: "There is no evidence, and he has consistently denied, that there was ever any attempt to carry out these alleged incidents or threats."

Nevertheless, police authorities felt this was more than just a run-of-the-mill case of pupils muttering threats. A local school district spokesman, Gary Bamford, said: "You have some kids from time to time that will make some reckless irresponsible comments, but this became a pattern, and reached a level beyond that."

The Fort Collins incident is the third alleged Columbine "copycat" incident in the past month in the US.

fields.headline: Blast tests Sharon's resolve
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A car bomb in an ultra-orthodox Jewish neighbourhood of Jerusalem put the mettle of hardliner Ariel Sharon to the test yesterday, less than 48 hours after his huge election victory.
fields.body:
A car bomb in an ultra-orthodox Jewish neighbourhood of Jerusalem put the mettle of hardliner Ariel Sharon to the test yesterday, less than 48 hours after his huge election victory.

Mr Sharon ducked the issue, saying that the blast in Beit Israel, which injured one woman and left nine others in shock, was a "tragedy", but that it was up to the prime minister, Ehud Barak, to respond as he remains in charge until a new government is formed.

But Mr Sharon, who rode to power promising to make Israelis feel safe from a violent Palestinian uprising, added: "It obliges us to unite in order to work in a determined way against terror." He also reaffirmed his policy of holding no talks with the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, until the uprising ends.

Two previously unknown groups, the Popular Palestinian Resistance Forces and the Victims of Sabra and Shatila, claimed responsibility for the bomb, which exploded near Jerusalem's largest yeshiva, or religious seminary, attended by hundreds of overseas students.

By tradition, the ultra-orthodox do not vote in Israeli elections, and the people of Beit Israel had no hand in Mr Sharon's win. But even here, they were quick to realise the challenge posed to Mr Sharon.

"It's a very hard position for the new prime minister. Whatever he does he will get criticised. If he does not fight, he will seem weaker than Mr Barak, but if he fights back, the world will say he is using excessive force," said Sruly Bernstein, a yeshiva student from Australia.

Mr Sharon has spent his first hours trying to reassure a world that knows him as the man who orchestrated Israel's invasion of Lebanon in 1982.

But a senior adviser, Zalman Shoval, said Mr Sharon rejected the Palestinian demand to pick up the thread of negotiations from last month's talks at the Red Sea resort of Taba, where the two sides came close to agreement on territory and other issues. Mr Shoval is to visit Washington next week to gauge the response of the Bush administration to the rolling back of the peace process.

Mr Sharon turned his attention to the domestic front yesterday, with Likud party negotiators opening talks with Mr Barak's Labour party on forming a national unity government. An alliance with Labour would give Mr Sharon greater stability in the fractured parliament he inherited from Mr Barak. But some Labour leaders are balking at the prospect of joining a coalition with partners far more extreme than Mr Sharon.

webTitle: Gun police doubled to combat Liverpool 'turf war'

fields.headline: Gun police doubled to combat 'turf war'
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in Britain
fields.trailText: Police stepped up armed patrols in Liverpool yesterday after a teenager was killed in the fifth shooting in three weeks, sparking fears of a gangland turf war.
fields.body:
Police stepped up armed patrols in Liverpool yesterday after a teenager was killed in the fifth shooting in three weeks, sparking fears of a gangland turf war.

Hussein Obad, 19, was found dead in the car park of a Toxteth housing estate late on Wednesday night. He was well known on the city's estates and had been arrested and bailed over the death of a man shot dead in front of his son last year. Police said Mr Obad's shooting might be linked to criminal activity. Three men have been arrested.

A series of shootings have taken place in the clubland area of the city in the past three weeks. Francis Burke, 18, was shot dead by a masked gunman as he chatted to a friend outside the Pulse Club in Liverpool last Sunday. A 20-year-old man was yesterday arrested and charged with his murder and the attempted murder of his friend.

The previous weekend a bouncer was shot as he stood outside the New Streets bar, and five clubbers, a DJ and another bouncer were wounded when a shotgun was fired into the Buro bar in the city centre. Others have been injured when shots were fired through front doors in residential areas.

Merseyside police said each shooting was being considered individually. There did not appear to be a link between the nightclub and residential shootings, nor was there evidence of a battle over control of door security in nightclubs. The shootings, said the police, all involved men between the ages of 17 and 21, resolving their disputes with firearms where once they would have used fists or broken glasses.

Assistant chief constable Bernard Hogan-Howe said the number of armed officers would be doubled in Liverpool this weekend to combat gun crime.

In Operation Reassurance Merseyside police will also double unarmed patrols and increase stop-and-search checks of known criminals. Road checks will also be increased. Mr Hogan-Howe said: "The message to all those people who are thinking about arming themselves with guns is that we will detect you. If you go out and use the gun, and shoot at someone, there is a very good chance you will be stopped by a police officer with a gun."

He added: "There have always been guns around but the thing that is most worrying over recent months, and not only in Merseyside, is that very young people are involved."

Last week Merseyside police revealed the force was heading a nationwide programme to identify and log every firearm in circulation. Mr Hogan-Howe said it was relatively difficult and expensive to get a gun on Merseyside, but arms might be coming in from different parts of the country.

Merseyside became one of the first British forces to sanction officers openly carrying weapons to combat gun crime after a series of gangland shootings five years ago. Then the shooting of gang leader David Ungi was followed by six shootings in seven days. The shootings were put down to a turf war or battles for control of nightclub door security.

fields.headline: Flooding returns with a vengeance
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Flooding returned to Britain with a vengeance yesterday, leaving a policeman dead and troops deployed in several areas to evacuate threatened homes.
fields.body:
Flooding returned to Britain with a vengeance yesterday, leaving a policeman dead and troops deployed in several areas to evacuate threatened homes.

The traffic control officer was killed by a van as he diverted traffic after an accident on a flooded stretch of the A12 dual carriageway at Kelvedon, near Colchester, Essex - one of 92 areas now under official flood warnings.

An inshore lifeboat ferried 20 people to safety on the Sussex coast, leaving homes waist-deep in water. In Yarm, Stockton-on-Tees, more than 50 families were taken to bed-and-breakfast accommodation as the river Tees came close to bursting its banks.

In North Yorkshire, where 300 families are still unable to return to houses wrecked in the October floods, a school bus was marooned after sliding into a ditch hidden by floodwater. Farmers from Appleton Roebuck and Bolton Percy, near Tadcaster, used tractors and trailers to ferry 30 children from the bus to dry land, in time for school.

In Kent, 40 soldiers used semi-amphibious Pinsgauer jeeps to help marooned elderly villagers near Canterbury, where 2,000 sandbags have been issued by the city council. The environment agency said last night that problems in the southern region, where there are nine severe flood warnings, had been caused by heavy rain.

The Thames has seven flood warnings and an environment agency spokeswoman warned the situation "could become serious" between Benson and Hurley in Oxfordshire.

Heavy rain overnight brought the Thames to the brink of bursting its banks once again, said the environment agency. East Anglia was also hit by flooding from the river Cam which left several roads impassable and part of the centre of Grantchester, near Cambridge, under water.

Last night the situation had eased in some areas, including Lincolnshire, where the agency was hoping to remove flood warnings for the northern part of the county, and along the Wear in County Durham.

But in Barham, Kent, where the river Nailbourne broke its banks, many residents have moved to the upper floors, and the landlady of the Black Robin pub, Jill White, 49, said: "We are in the middle of a lake - it's never been this bad before. We have not decided if we are going to evacuate yet. We are putting up a fight, piling sandbags all around the place. The water in the road is about 3ft deep and the current is very strong."

The flood defence committee in the Yorkshire region will meet for the third time today to try to end a two-month deadlock over meeting a £6.4m increase in the annual levy to pay for repairs and new river walls. The chairman of the environment agency, Sir John Harman, published an open letter to the committee last night, appealing to local council members to accept the need for the rise.

He said: "There is already public disquiet about the committee's inability to agree a levy which will provide funding for the much needed increase in capital investment.

"I recognise the short term impact the proposed levy increase will have on local authority finances but I would urge you to give urgent consideration to the levy reports and the needs of the communities which are at risk.

"It would be a sad irony if our region of the country, worst affected by the autumn floods, was the only one to fail to take up the additional funding of £51m announced by the deputy prime minister in November."

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: £140,000 for transsexual | Mouldy sports drinks recalled | Suicide risk for the rich | Artists hope to score | Speeding fine for Beckham | Megaphone diplomacy | Heart benefit in breast feeding | Elephant injures keeper | Free rides for Ulster's elderly | 'Bombs' arrest |
fields.body:
£140,000 for transsexual

A transsexual Harley Street doctor was yesterday awarded £140,000 after winning a claim for sex discrimination against the National School of Hypnosis and Advanced Psychotherapy. Tracie O'Keefe, a clinical hypnotherapist and psychotherapist, complained that she was denied access to the register which gives access to NHS patients.

Mouldy sports drinks recalled

Stocks of the Umbro Hypotonic sports drink have been recalled by the food standards agency after some bottles were found to be contaminated by moulds.

Suicide risk for the rich

Rich people with a history of mental illness appear two to three times more likely to kill themselves than poorer patients, according to a study published today in the British Medical Journal.

Artists hope to score

Artists including U2, Badly Drawn Boy, Moby and Michael Nyman are among acts hoping to provide a signature tune for the Des Lynam-fronted football highlights show on ITV.

Speeding fine for Beckham

England footballer David Beckham was issued with a £60 fixed penalty speeding ticket after being pulled over on the M6 in Staffordshire when returning from a charity event. A driving ban was quashed in December 1999 after he told a court he was speeding to escape a photographer.

Megaphone diplomacy

The mayor of Bude, north Cornwall, has scared away thousands of starlings by prowling the streets at dusk armed with a £600 megaphone which makes a sound imitating the birds' distress call. John Wooler said: "I spent about two hours and now all the starlings are gone. London mayor Ken Livingstone could even try it to get rid of his pigeons [from Trafalgar Square]."

Heart benefit in breast feeding

Breast-fed babies have lower blood pressure in later life and may have less risk of heart disease, a report in the medical journal the Lancet said yesterday. London's Great Ormond Street hospital studied 216 children aged 13 to 16.

Elephant injures keeper

fields.headline: Belgo man on the run
fields.trailText: Police have issued an arrest warrant for flamboyant businessman Tim Power, former operations director of the Belgo restaurant chain, after he failed to answer a string of minor motoring charges.
fields.body:
Police have issued an arrest warrant for flamboyant businessman Tim Power, former operations director of the Belgo restaurant chain, after he failed to answer a string of minor motoring charges.

Mr Power, 35, who drives a £70,000 Ferrari convertible, jumped bail while facing allegations of displaying an invalid number plate and tax discs belonging to other vehicles. Last night mystery surrounded his disappearance.

Police are believed to be investigating claims he went overseas after failing to answer the charges at Blackfriars Crown Court in London. A spokeswoman for the Metropolitan Police said Mr Power had been charged with fraudulent use of a number plate and tax discs last June, but had failed to appear in court last month.

Solicitor Upali Jayatilaka, of Rango & Co, who is understood to be representing Mr Power, insisted the matter had been blown out of all proportion. Branding Mr Power as "charming and personable", he said the charges against him were petty and it was "absolute nonsense" to suggest he had disappeared.

Mr Power had the reputation of being a City high flyer after playing a key role in Belgo's £25m takeover of top London restaurants such as Le Caprice and The Ivy - a regular haunt of senior media figures and politicians. A former barman, he earned an annual salary of around £66,000 and was a regular seen driving around London in the Ferrari, which displayed the personalised registration plate POWER.

But the last few years have seen a dramatic decline in the fortunes of the man who once predicted he could make Belgo a bigger name than Terence Conran's restaurant chain. He has suffered a string of personal and professional traumas which can be traced back to the period surrounding the collapse of his marriage to Chantal Brenninkmeyer, an heiress to the C&A fortune. He abruptly resigned from Belgo a year ago, just a few weeks after the company admitted its restaurant openings in Dublin and New York had been disappointing.

The company issued a statement at the time insisting the split was "mutually agreed", but sources have since indicated that he chosen to jump rather than being pushed. Since that time a number of Mr Power's business ventures have failed to get off the ground.

Friends of Mr Power were quoted yesterday saying he had "simply gone AWOL," while his father Richard reportedly said: "He occasionally comes here with his kids but we haven't seen him for some time."

webTitle: Cornish resort gets tough with 'snob yob' drinkers

fields.headline: Cornish resort gets tough with 'snob yob' drinkers
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A Cornish seaside resort popular with public school "snob yobs" has introduced a ban on outdoor drinking because of vandalism and all-night noisy parties.
fields.body:
A Cornish seaside resort popular with public school "snob yobs" has introduced a ban on outdoor drinking because of vandalism and all-night noisy parties.

North Cornwall district council yesterday said the bylaw had been passed to prevent people drinking in public in Rock. Anyone who continues drinking after being warned by police could be fined up to £500.

The area is popular for surfing and is especially crowded in the weeks leading up to publication of GCSE and A-level results. Tyrrell Sandry, a district councillor who lives in Rock, said it was a situation that could not be allowed to continue. "The big problem is when 30 or 40 of them congregate across the road. These children are aged from about 13 and they are having drink they are not accustomed to, so they tend to behave differently.

"They are nice enough kids when you met them on their own, but people are different in groups."

Paul Tyler, Liberal Democrat MP for North Cornwall, who had highlighted problems caused by vandalism and all-night noisy parties, said he supported the bylaw. But he added: "It is only part of a larger package.

The snob yobs have spread all along this bit of the coast right along to Daymer Bay and Polzeath. It is impossible to police an alcohol ban all along these beaches. "It is quite unacceptable that people, simply because they go to a posh school, think they can destroy people's boats and fences for a beach bonfire. We have to get through to the parents they have to take more responsibility.

"Dropping 11- and 12-year-olds off at the beach with a stash of alcohol for all-night parties is totally unacceptable. They would complain bitterly if people from another social stratum started doing it elsewhere."
Press Association

webTitle: One in 10 toddlers are obese, say researchers

fields.headline: One in 10 toddlers are obese, say researchers
fields.trailText: About one in 10 children under four are classified as obese, a proportion that has nearly doubled in a decade, researchers said today. A study of around 64,000 children also showed that more than one in five is overweight, with problems in young boys accelerating.
fields.body:
About one in 10 children under four are classified as obese, a proportion that has nearly doubled in a decade, researchers said today. A study of around 64,000 children also showed that more than one in five is overweight, with problems in young boys accelerating.

The increases are happening between babyhood and pre-school age, said the study's authors. They call for a national programme aimed at encouraging parents to exercise their toddlers more and to feed them less fatty food.

Writing in the British Medical Journal, they warn that intervention is needed to prevent children developing heart conditions and other diseases leading to premature death when they become adults. The researchers, reviewing height, weight and body mass of children examined by health visitors in the Wirral, north-west England, between 1989 and 1998, found the percentage who were overweight rose from 14.7% to 23.6% and those who were obese from 5.4% to 9.4%. Children's height had remained unchanged.

Peter Bundred, reader in primary care at Liverpool University, who led the study, said: "We know that teenagers have become fatter, but for the first time we are seeing rapid increases in weight throughout the childhood years 

"The problem with toddlers is that we now have a situation where many mothers work, come home and need to do the housework, so sit their children in front of a television or video. People are also eating a lot more ready meals, which have a higher fat content."

webTitle: Scientist's vision of a genetically modified future

fields.headline: 30 years  on ... a brave new genetic world
fields.standfirst:
Scientist's vision of how to enhance evolution and head off diseases

Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: Within 30 years, humans could be debating whether to take charge of their own evolution. The average lifespan in the developed world will be 90 and diseases will be diagnosed before symptoms appear, according to Francis Collins, one of the leaders of the project to sequence the entire human genome.
fields.body:
Within 30 years, humans could be debating whether to take charge of their own evolution. The average lifespan in the developed world will be 90, diseases will be diagnosed before symptoms appear, many humans will already be genetically modified and patients with heart diseases, or cancer or dangerous infections will be treated with prescriptions tailored to their own genetic makeup, according to Francis Collins, one of the leaders of the project to sequence the entire human genome.

As scientists in Britain, France, Germany, Japan and the US prepare to publish the discoveries locked in the 3bn letter genetic code of humanity, Dr Collins spelled out the step-by-step attack on disease and mental illness and the elimination of hereditary afflictions such as haemophilia and porphyria.

By 2010, he told a major international biotechnology forum in France yesterday, there could be predictive tests for at least 12 hereditary conditions and scientists would understand the role that genes played in most common diseases. Embryos developed by in vitro fertilisation methods would be routinely scanned for genetic illnesses. Legislation to prevent genetic discrimination - the creation of an underclass denied healthcare, employment or insurance because of this genetic knowledge - could be in place within 10 years. "I hope we won't have to wait nearly that long," he said. "Unless we continue to make this a serious priority it will continue to be a serious problem, and the inequities that we see about us now are unlikely to be improved,"

Designer drugs

By 2020, the designer drugs based on research on the human genome will be coming on to the market. The pharmaceutical industry would have produced powerful treatments for diabetes, hypertension, heart disease and schizophrenia. "Cancer will be perhaps the earliest and most powerful beneficiary of this revolution, as we are already learning so much about the genetic basis of malignancy."

By then, doctors would study the patient's genetic make-up before writing a prescription. "We are certainly close to understanding hereditary contributions to manic depressive illness, to schizophrenia, to obsessive compulsive disorder, to autism," he said. "That should lead us at last to a better understanding of these problems and perhaps an opportunity to stop blaming victims and treat them as victims of diseases that deserve compassion and better opportunity for therapy."

By 2020, too, scientists would have learned to repair genes before they appeared in the next generation. "Right now we don't know how to do that," he said. "But if we were successful in another 20 years at learning how to go in and very surgically change a single base pair in the genome into something that was not going to cause disease, then it would be tempting to begin to contemplate this in a more serious way, and perhaps in another 20 years we will have that capability. If you are not dizzy yet, we will go on another 10 years," he told the Biovision 2001 conference in Lyon.

By 2030, if all went well, there should be comprehensive healthcare based on genetic knowledge, with individual medicine based on individual risk instead of a "one size fits all approach." Doctors would understand better the links between genes and environmental factors. Illnesses would be detected much earlier, by molecular surveillance, even before symptoms appeared and therapies would be more effective - and more available. "If all goes well, at least in the developed world perhaps the average lifespan will extend to to something like 90 years."

Opposition

He said that by 2030, there would be opposition to such research which could only be overcome by education and debate. He also foresaw that by 2030, people would be arguing "as Stephen Hawking already is" that humans could start to take charge of their own evolution by altering their genes to improve the species.

"I must say I find this an interesting but somewhat chilling discussion because it implies that somebody would know what an improvement was, and it also implies we will be sure enough about the safety issues to contemplate altering our very biology. I think from my own perspective, that is an enterprise that I hope we would not undertake for a long time, if ever."

 Jacques Chirac, president of France, opened the Biovision 2001 conference with an indirect rebuke to Britain over its decision to authorise research into embryo stem cells. "Therapeutic cloning" to develop treatments for disease could lead to reproductive cloning, and a possible traffic in human eggs, he warned.

fields.headline: Barclays chief may lose £30m bonus
fields.trailText: Barclays' chief executive Matt Barrett is missing the performance targets that could entitle him to a £30m payout, despite the bank making profits of £111 a second.
fields.body:
Barclays' chief executive Matt Barrett is missing the performance targets that could entitle him to a £30m payout, despite the bank making profits of £111 a second.

The charismatic boss, announcing his first full year profits figures yesterday, now has his work cut out to push the return for shareholders above that of its international peers in order for him to achieve his bonus in three years' time.

Mr Barrett defended the bank's 2000 profits - boosted by Woolwich, which it took over in October - as evidence that its customers were happy because of the volume of new business it had attracted.

Barclays, which produced a 42% increase in profits to £3.5bn, plans to roll out Woolwich's Open Plan all in one savings and borrowings account to its own customers. It also intends to focus the Woolwich brand in the mortgage market on its mid-market customers, keeping the Barclays brand for more affluent clients. The bank also plans to introduce new "wealth management" products aimed at the so-called mass affluent.

Mr Barrett was coy about any plans Barclays might have to make further acquisitions in Britain - where it has been touted as a potential buyer for Bank of Scotland if the latter's attempted merger with Abbey National is scuppered by Lloyds TSB. He said there were still some "sub-scale players".

In Europe - where he indicated he would like to expand the business - Mr Barrett acknowledged that cultural and regulatory difficulties made acquisitions tough. Instead, he intended to attack Europe through alliances and mergers in different parts of business which he likened to "25 speedboats rather than a big tanker". This is part of a strategy to boost revenues from its domestic market from 20% to 50% in the future.

The bank, which closed 171 branches last year to much public criticism, has 1.7m on-line customers, up from 500,000 in 1999. These online customers buy 2.7 products from Barclays - more than those who use traditional methods, where the average is 2.3. The bank made 4,200 staff redundant last year with another 2,100 to go in 2001. It said it now expected to save £400m in costs - up from £240m - as a result of the Woolwich takeover, although the cost of implementing the deal will be a higher £200m.

The City was broadly supportive of Barclays' results, boosting its share price by 33p to £22.07. The bank will pay a 58p dividend. However, Jon Kirk, a banking analyst at Fox-Pitt, Kelton, raised some concerns that Barclays appeared to be taking on more risks at a time when the economy risked a slowdown. Barclays' provision against bad debts rose by 32% to £817m.

In Barclays Capital, the investment banking arm, the bank insisted there were no problems lurking in its business in the United States - despite rumours linking it to exposure to the troubled Californian utility sector. Of the five divisions, the retail financial services arm contributed £1.7bn of operating profit, Barclays Capital a 30% rise to £403m, Barclaycard a 4% rise to £418m, corporate banking a record £1bn and Barclays Global Investors, the fund management business, £65m.
