webTitle: Investor anger grows as rising debt hits BT profits

fields.headline: Investor anger grows as rising debt hits BT profits
fields.trailText: The chances of a full-scale revolt among institutional investors against British Telecom increased yesterday after the telecoms group failed to convince the City that it had an adequate strategy to tackle its worsening debt problem.
fields.body:
The chances of a full-scale revolt among institutional investors against British Telecom increased yesterday after the telecoms group failed to convince the City that it had an adequate strategy to tackle its worsening debt problem.

As shares in BT fell a further 60p to 620p, moving the price down to levels not seen since early 1998, one fund manager said: "This management is stumbling from one statement to another without ever managing to explain to shareholders how and when the business will be restructured. We want detail and we are not getting it."

Announcing a slump in third-quarter revenues, with profits having collapsed to £326m at the pre-tax level from £665m a year ago, BT insisted that its programme to reduce projected borrowings was still on track, despite the recent stock market turmoil in the telecoms sector. An important part of this plan is the flotation of a 25% stake in BT Wireless, which is still pencilled in for the autumn. Worries over the demerger timetable and the amount of money likely to be raised - already heightened by this week's decision by rival France Telecom to cut the flotation price of its Orange mobile subsidiary - intensified yesterday after news that Belgium's auction of third generation mobile licences had attracted only three bidders for the four licences on offer.

A strong hint from new finance director Philip Hampton that BT could cut its year-end dividend also hit sentiment, as did a poor trading performance at Concert, the group's international joint venture with America's AT&T.

"The numbers were pretty much in line with consensus, but the results were only half of today's statements," said Hannes Wittig, analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein. "People were much keener on hearing about the restructuring, and BT didn't provide any tangible details."

As well as the sale of the Wireless stake, BT is looking at off-loading 25% of Yell, its directories business, and would like to float its holding in Airtel, the Spanish mobile phone company.

BT has indicated that the Wireless and Airtel sales might bring in a combined £6bn, supplemented by £1bn from the Yell float.

The remainder of a promised £10bn reduction in debt should come from other asset disposals and about £2bn in property sales.

Sir Peter, who has appointed investment bankers to oversee the sale of Wireless, dismissed fears that his plans would be damaged by the 18% drop in Orange's flotation price.

"France Telecom set huge expectations for Orange," Sir Peter said. "We always said we'd be more conservative in a fickle market. The market has been spooked by the Orange situation but we're getting on with the programme we set."

Analysts were less certain BT Wireless could fetch the necessary price tag, however.

 Vodafone yesterday launched a A$15.3bn (£5.7bn) bid for Australian mobile phone operator Cable & Wireless Optus.

BT has indicated that the Wireless and Airtel sales might bring in a combined £6bn, supplemented by £1bn from the Yell float. The remainder of a promised £10bn reduction in debt should come from other asset disposals and about £2bn in property sales. Sir Peter, who has appointed investment bankers to oversee the sale of Wireless, dismissed fears that his plans would be damaged by the 18% drop in Orange's flotation price. "France Telecom set huge expectations for Orange," Sir Peter said. "We always said we'd be more conservative in a fickle market. The market has been spooked by the Orange situation but we're getting on with the programme we set." webTitle: AstraZeneca accuses analysts of hyping ulcer drug

fields.headline: AstraZeneca accuses analysts of hyping ulcer drug
fields.trailText: Britain's second largest drugs company, AstraZeneca, faced some hostility in the City yesterday after delivering a stark warning that sector analysts had over-hyped its new ulcer drug, Nexium.
fields.body:
Britain's second largest drugs company, AstraZeneca, faced some hostility in the City yesterday after delivering a stark warning that sector analysts had over-hyped its new ulcer drug, Nexium.

Chief executive Tom McKillop said the company's earnings in 2001 would be "in the lower half" of forecasts, with profits growth in its biggest therapeutic area, digestive medicines, likely to slow to zero. He said: "I've constantly said that it would be a complex situation with a series of conflicting events affecting the outcome."

Mr McKillop was speaking as AstraZeneca announced a 16% increase in annual profits to $4.11bn (£2.8bn). The shares slumped 118p at one point, before recovering to close down 41p at £29.63.

A third of AstraZeneca's revenue is from ulcer treatment Losec, which is due to lose its US patent in October. Industry experts are divided on whether AstraZeneca's follow-up drug, Nexium, will be similarly successful.

Nexium is scheduled to be launched in the US imminently, but the company is still waiting for clearance from the US food and drug administration. Mr McKillop said: "We are still expecting to launch Nexium in the first quarter. Yes, it has taken a little longer than anticipated but we are now moving towards closure."

AstraZeneca is thought to be concerned about the recent launch of rival ulcer drugs, which have pushed down the price of medicines in the US. The firm is still fighting 70 legal battles which will affect its ability to protect Losec from generic competition until October, when its patent expires. One analyst said: "This is the second bad quarter they've had in a row, and there have been lots of missed promises. It does not bode well for the credibility of the management, especially as it is a relatively new team in charge."

AstraZeneca revealed in October that it would fail to meet its target of double-digit sales growth this year. There was a question mark yesterday over whether it had delivered a promised profit margin of 25% - AstraZeneca said it had achieved 25.6%, but critics said this included exceptional gains on the sale of businesses.

Mr McKillop said the company had high hopes for Symbicort, an asthma medicine due to be launched this year which gives patients the flexibility to adjust their inhaled doses. AstraZeneca is also set to file Crestor, a heart drug which analysts expect to command annual sales of £2bn. One analyst said: "It's all very much jam tomorrow. We're reining back forecasts for 2001."

However, a rival analyst said she still expected $900m of sales from Nexium this year, and the only significant setback for AstraZeneca would be on currency translation - the strong dollar is likely to shave a few cents off its earnings per share. She said: "Every time AstraZeneca reports figures, their shares slump because the bears find some niggle to complain about."

webTitle: Freeserve ready to sue BT over ISP access row

fields.headline: Freeserve ready to sue BT over access row
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The UK's two largest internet companies are threatening to sue BT over holding up access to high speed internet services.
fields.body:
The UK's two largest internet companies are threatening to sue BT over holding up access to high speed internet services.

AOL Europe, part of media group AOL-Time Warner and Freeserve, owned by France Télécom's Wanadoo, say BT has given its own internet arm 10 times more high speed capacity than they have been allowed.

The companies have called on regulator Oftel to intervene. If that fails, they have instructed lawyers to take court action.

BT is allowing its service provider, Openworld, to sign up 2,000 customers per week while AOL and Freeserve are restricted to 200 customers each.

A spokesman for AOL Europe said that it was only this week that it had discovered the extent of the disparity between access granted to Openworld and other providers. The dispute is over digital subscriber lines, a technology that lets customers access the internet up to 10 times faster than a standard phone line.

Under the terms of its licence BT must offer other operators wholesale access to the service. "This is a blatant and unlawful abuse of BT's market position," said a spokesman for AOL. "If Oftel and BT don't respond to calls for transparency, we will take legal action." Oftel confirmed that it received a complaint from the two companies in December and is investigating the charges. BT called the threats "sabre-rattling".

"This French-owned company and American-owned company are saying 'yah boo, it's not fair'," said a spokesman. "Yes, BT is serving more customers than they are, but this is not because of unfairness. Some of our competitors are trying to find excuses for [their] competitive difficulties."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: BMW to boost UK investment | City Centre shelves plans | William Baird to sell Van Gils | Bob the Builder to buy US firm | Dreamticket in liquidation | TWA uncovers another suitor
fields.body:
BMW to boost UK investment

Luxury car maker BMW said yesterday it would invest a further £1bn in production plants in Britain by the end of next year, despite having shed its Rover business last year. BMW officially opened a new engine plant in Hams Hall, near Birmingham. The UK is BMW's third biggest market after Germany and the United States.

City Centre shelves plans

City Centre Restaurants has shelved plans to expand its chain of upscale Italian restaurants, Caffe Uno. The firm said recent openings had performed poorly, while costs had run out of control due to "management instability". The news emerged in City Centre's second profits warning in six months. The shares fell 5.5p to 44p. City Centre said its Mexican chain, Chiquito's, and its Asian restaurants concept, Est Est Est, were also trading poorly.

William Baird to sell Van Gils

British textiles group William Baird said yesterday it had agreed to sell its Dutch menswear business Van Gils to Vilenzo International for £6.94m in cash. Baird, which last year cut 4,000 jobs after losing a key Marks & Spencer contract, said the proceeds would go to reduce the group's borrowings. The disposal was consistent with Baird's strategy to simplify its business activities and focus on the growth of its successful womenswear and active sportswear brands.

Bob the Builder to buy US firm

Bob the Builder creator HIT Entertainment is today expected to confirm that it is buying Barney the Dinosaur owner Lyrick Studios. The deal, first revealed by The Guardian last week, has been given clearance by the federal trade commission in the United States. Barney is one of the most popular children's characters in the US. Texas-based Lyrick is valued at more than HIT - which is worth £440m - so the deal is classed as a reverse takeover.

Dreamticket in liquidation

Online package holiday specialist Dreamticket is to go into liquidation despite beating revenue and gross profit forecasts. Chief executive Lawrence Hunt said market conditions were to blame. He said: "We've performed ahead of our plan but investors just don't want to be associated with the word dot.com because it looks bad."

TWA uncovers another suitor

A new company formed by aviation experts and investors said it would bid nearly $1bn (£692m) to acquire TWA, doubling the amount American Airlines said it would pay to take over the carrier. Jet Acquisitions Group of Arizona, wants to eliminate TWA's debt, retain most of its employees, modernise its facilities and eventually expand the airline.

fields.headline: Defiant Mandelson risks Labour wrath
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Peter Mandelson
New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson risked reopening schisms within the Labour hierarchy last night as newspaper stories about him took the gloss off Tony Blair's agenda-setting speech.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson risked reopening schisms within the Labour hierarchy last night as newspaper stories about him took the gloss off Tony Blair's agenda-setting speech.

The former cabinet minister is understood to have defied No 10 in a high-stakes drive to salvage his reputation in a series of briefings, although in none of the papers is Mr Mandelson directly quoted.

Mr Mandelson reportedly said he was seeking a public acknowledgment from Mr Blair that the home secretary, Jack Straw, was wrong to accuse him of being "untruthful" over his role in the Hinduja passport affair. He also made clear he wants to be appointed Britain's European commissioner.

Details of his demands were published today after he visited the Tory-supporting Daily Mail and Daily Telegraph yesterday just hours before Mr Blair delivered his keynote speech.

The timing of the intervention will inevitably strain Mr Mandelson's relationship with former allies in No 10 and at party headquarters in Millbank, and raise fresh questions about his judgment in the wake of the passport affair.

The former Northern Ireland secretary's decision to speak to the two newspapers, insisting the conversations were off the record, will also anger Sir Anthony Hammond, who had asked all sides not to comment while his inquiry into the Hindujas' passport applications was in progress.

As speculation swept Westminster that Mr Mandelson was poised to quit his Hartlepool seat, a source close to Downing Street said: "A period of silence would be much advised from Mr Mandelson. I think everyone would find it in the party's best interest if he were to step down." The source added: "He has to lay off. You can give someone so much rope. He's starting to pull. We're not going to have it."

One of those present at yesterday's meetings said Mr Mandelson believed Mr Blair's press secretary, Alastair Campbell, had been at fault.

The former minister also said he was "completely gobsmacked" when the premier said he had to resign.

Mr Mandelson was confident he would be cleared of any wrongdoing and even cast doubt on whether he actually made a disputed phone call to the immigration minister, Mike O'Brien, about SP Hinduja's passport application in 1998.

Making clear he would relish a post in Brussels where Neil Kinnock and Chris Patten are Britain's commissioners is unlikely to endear him to No 10 when he has yet to be cleared by the Hammond inquiry.

The Times today carries a story inspired by Mr Mandelson's comments, while the FT yesterday ran a full page chronology of the events that led to his resignation, including the most favourable interpretation of events for the former minister.

The FT story under the headline "Was Blair right to sack his trusted ally?" seemed to pin some of the blame on Mr Campbell, who was said to have "incorrectly" represented the position and "may have misconstrued" a crucial conversation with Mr Mandelson.

But the private media offensive by Mr Mandelson, Labour's former director of communications, appears to fly in the face of public assurances he gave at the weekend.

On returning from a week-long break in the US, during which he also spoke off the record to a number of journalists, Mr Mandelson said he would "do nothing to harm" the party of his political friends. "My party's interests mean everything to me, and they always have done," he said.

 Labour could be vulnerable at the next election to William Hague, who could emulate the victory achieved by President George Bush, according to an adviser to the defeated Democrat, Al Gore.

Steve Morgan, a member of Mr Gore's inner circle who formerly worked at Labour's Millbank headquarters, has said in a memorandum to Mr Blair and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, that Mr Hague's populist approach could undermine their stewardship of a healthy economy and cost them the election, the New Statesman reports today.

webTitle: US tries to head off UN plan to reform sanctions

fields.headline: US tries to head off UN plan to reform sanctions
fields.trailText: The US is fighting behind the scenes in New York to water down UN proposals aimed at overhauling sanctions policy.
fields.body:
The US is fighting behind the scenes in New York to water down UN proposals aimed at overhauling sanctions policy.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, set up a special committee last April to examine sanctions policy after a string of failures over the past decade, especially over Iraq. He was particularly concerned about the humanitarian impact of sanctions on civilian populations.

The committee, which is due to report next week, is to recommend a shift towards so-called "smart sanctions" that are more clearly defined and better targeted.

But the US, which is intent on maintaining tough sanctions against Iraq with the backing of Britain, will almost certainly succeed in cutting out two key recommendations: one setting a time limit on sanctions and the other introducing majority voting on sanctions committees. Critics of sanctions claim they usually fail to undermine the targeted regimes, and that the criteria for imposition and the lifting of sanctions are too vague. The UN committee, which is chaired by Bangladesh's representative at the UN, Anwarul Chowdhury, tries to address these concerns.

In a draft copy of its report the committee says: "Sanctions regimes, in particular the security council resolutions that enact them, must be carefully designed, clearly establishing their goals, identifying the targets, tailoring the type of sanctions imposed so that they are adequate to the situation, specifying clear criteria that need to be satisfied in order for the sanctions to be suspended or lifted."

Other recommendations include: targeting the finances of leaders rather than the general population; greater punishment for countries found to be breaking sanctions; and a carrot-and-stick approach which would see a gradual lifting of sanctions in response to partial compliance with UN resolutions.

Echoing Mr Annan's concern about the impact on civilian populations, the committee recommends: "Sanctions regimes should be, therefore, designed to minimise the potential for adverse humanitarian impacts and to maximise the ability for humanitarian goods and services to reach civilian populations."

The committee also recommends that "food, medicine and medical supplies be excluded from sanctions regimes".

The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, signalled on taking office that while he agreed there were too many sanctions in place, he wanted tighter restrictions in the case of Iraq. The US, while agreeing to most of the committee's report, wants to cut out a proposal that "sanctions be imposed for limited periods of time, taking all factors into account".

Iraq is demanding a timetable for the lifting of sanctions in return for agreeing to allowing UN weapons inspectors into the country. The US is also opposed to a proposal that the UN sanctions committees, which oversee the embargoes, should "consider majority voting for reaching decisions either of a procedural nature or related to humanitarian exemptions".

Decisions at present are by consensus: if the reform went ahead, Britain and the US would face the prospect of defeat on the Iraqi sanctions committee. Meanwhile, the US has ended its long-running dispute with the UN over funding. The Senate voted unanimously on Wednesday to release $582m (£400m) that the US owes in back dues. The US withheld the money until other countries agreed to take a bigger share of the finance. Before Christmas, Richard Holbrooke, who served as the Clinton administration's UN representative, brokered a deal to reduce US dues for the first time in more than 28 years.

fields.headline: Michael Stone to be retried
fields.standfirst: Appeal court rejects plea to free man jailed for double murder
fields.trailText: Appeal court rejects plea to free man jailed for double murder
fields.body:
Steven Morris and Audrey Gillan Michael Stone, the man jailed in 1998 for the murders of Lin Russell and her daughter Megan and the attempted murder of her other daughter, Josie, was yesterday told he will face a retrial.

Stone, 40, who dramatically won his appeal earlier this week, was in the dock at the appeal court in London to hear three judges formally quash his conviction. The decision was welcomed by Stone and his family.

Speaking outside court his solicitor, Derek Hayward, said: "Michael Stone is very pleased that his convictions have been quashed and is looking forward to a chance to prove his innocence at the retrial."

It was the end of a long, tense wait for Stone. The judges ruled on Tuesday that his appeal "must succeed" on the basis of the unreliability of key prosecution witness Barry Thompson, who claimed during the trial at Maidstone crown court in 1998 that Stone had confessed to the killings while on remand. The crown admitted at the last minute that Thompson could not be relied upon as a "witness of truth" after he admitted he told the jury "a pack of lies". The judges then adjourned proceedings to consider the question of whether or not Stone - who remained in custody pending the decision - should face a new trial.

Yesterday, Stone's counsel, William Clegg QC, argued that he could not have a fair trial because of the huge amount of prejudicial publicity surrounding the case. "No jury could try his case fairly and any conviction resulting would inevitably be unsafe," he said. He claimed that the case was still very much at the front of public consciousness, as illustrated by recent front-page headlines, television coverage and a book and television documentary, Josie's Journey, about the surviving sister.

Mr Clegg told the court: "You have only to mention the Christian name of Josie Russell or the name Michael Stone for the ordinary man in the street to know exactly what you are talking about."

Nigel Sweeney QC, for the crown, said a retrial was in the public interest. "We in the criminal courts invest juries who try cases... with good sense, good judgment and an ability within the trial to put out of their minds anything they might have heard before," he said. Stone, wearing a white sports top, showed no emotion as the judges ordered the retrial, nor as Mr Clegg indicated that he would not be applying for bail on his client's behalf. A new trial is not likely to take place until the autumn and will probably be held away from Kent, where the crimes took place.

His sister, Barbara, 38, said: "We are thrilled to bits that the convictions have been quashed. At last he's got a chance to prove his innocence. Michael is happy that his conviction has been quashed too." Stone was given three life sentences for the murders of Lin Russell and Megan, six, and the attempted murder of Josie, then nine, near their home at Chillenden, Kent, in 1996. They were tied up and beaten with a hammer in a 15-minute attack.

The bodies of Lin and Megan were found lying close to each other, covered in blood. Megan's swimming costume was found a few feet away. The family dog, Lucy, was also lying in the copse.

Lin Russell's husband, Shaun, was told of the court ruling by a family liaison officer from Kent police. A spokesperson for the force said: "We are happy with the decision and it would be inappropriate to make any further comment since our aim is to ensure that Michael Stone has a fair retrial." Lord Justice Kennedy, Mr Justice Maurice Kay and Mrs Justice Hallett are to give their reasons for the court's decision next week. Stone's retrial will not get under way before September because his counsel has prior commitments.

The judges then adjourned proceedings to consider the question of whether or not Stone - who remained in custody pending the decision - should face a new trial. Yesterday, Stone's counsel, William Clegg QC, argued that he could not have a fair trial because of the huge amount of prejudicial publicity surrounding the case. "No jury could try his case fairly and any conviction resulting would inevitably be unsafe," he said. He claimed that the case was still very much at the front of public consciousness, as illustrated by recent front-page headlines, television coverage and a book and television documentary, Josie's Journey, about the surviving sister. Mr Clegg told the court: "You have only to mention the Christian name of Josie Russell or the name Michael Stone for the ordinary man in the street to know exactly what you are talking about." Nigel Sweeney QC, for the crown, said a retrial was in the public interest. "We in the criminal courts invest juries who try cases... with good sense, good judgment and an ability within the trial to put out of their minds anything they might have heard before," he said. Stone, wearing a white sports top, showed no emotion as the judges ordered the retrial, nor as Mr Clegg indicated that he would not be applying for bail on his client's behalf. A new trial is not likely to take place until the autumn and will probably be held away from Kent, where the crimes took place. His sister, Barbara, 38, said: "We are thrilled to bits that the convictions have been quashed. At last he's got a chance to prove his innocence. Michael is happy that his conviction has been quashed too." Stone was given three life sentences for the murders of Lin Russell and Megan, six, and the attempted murder of Josie, then nine, near their home at Chillenden, Kent, in 1996. They were tied up and beaten with a hammer in a 15-minute attack. The bodies of Lin and Megan were found lying close to each other, covered in blood. Megan's swimming costume was found a few feet away. The family dog, Lucy, was also lying in the copse. Lin Russell's husband, Shaun, was told of the court ruling by a family liaison officer from Kent police. A spokesperson for the force said: "We are happy with the decision and it would be inappropriate to make any further comment since our aim is to ensure that Michael Stone has a fair retrial." Lord Justice Kennedy, Mr Justice Maurice Kay and Mrs Justice Hallett are to give their reasons for the court's decision next week. Stone's retrial will not get under way before September because his counsel has prior commitments.

webTitle: Western allies urge Rwanda to leave Congo

fields.headline: Western allies urge Rwanda to leave Congo
fields.trailText: Rwanda is under growing pressure from Britain and other key allies at the UN to pull its troops out of the Democratic Republic of Congo after a charm offensive by Congo's new president, Joseph Kabila, during a whirlwind tour of the US and Europe.
fields.body:
Rwanda is under growing pressure from Britain and other key allies at the UN to pull its troops out of the Democratic Republic of Congo after a charm offensive by Congo's new president, Joseph Kabila, during a whirlwind tour of the US and Europe.

But Rwanda continues to say that it will not withdraw its forces until guarantees are in place to ensure that its borders are secure from attack by the Hutu extremists who led the 1994 genocide of Tutsis.

Mr Kabila won over the UN and foreign governments last week with promises to implement a peace accord signed but blocked by his father, Laurent Kabila, who was assassinated three weeks ago.

The new president urged the UN security council to deploy more than 5,500 peacekeepers to Congo swiftly, and promised "dialogue and reconciliation" with opposition and rebel groups. But this week back in Kinshasa, Mr Kabila reaffirmed his father's hardline position that the prerequisite for peace is the withdrawal of hostile foreign forces from Congo. Troops from Rwanda, Uganda and Burundi occupy more than half the country.

"What Congo wants is that the aggression must be stopped, the occupation must be completely terminated," Mr Kabila said. He also said he was in no hurry to legalise political parties and declined to reveal whether he views the presidency as a job for life.

Rwanda's president, Paul Kagame, has ruled out a unilateral withdrawal while Congo continues to play host to tens of thousands of armed members of the interahamwe Hutu militia and former Rwandan army which led the 1994 genocide. The militiamen have vowed to continue their war against the Tutsis.

Mr Kagame also wants other foreign troops - principally the Zimbabwean and Angolan forces backing Mr Kabila - withdrawn at the same time as his own. And he is demanding that all Congolese parties be brought into political talks, a condition Mr Kabila has said he will meet. On Wednesday, Mr Kagame addressed the UN security council. Its members, apparently persuaded that Mr Kabila is sincere, called on Rwanda to pull out of Congo. The greatest pressure came from France, which supported the regime that organised the genocide.

But Rwanda's main allies on the security council, the US and Britain, are also applying pressure. America's acting representative to the UN, James Cunningham, criticised Rwanda for the "alarming" human rights situation in areas it occupies where hundreds of thousands of people are alleged to have been killed or died from hunger, disease and maltreatment.

"Rwanda's claims to the right of self-defence are badly undercut when so many Congolese are victimised," he said. "We do not believe that Rwanda can secure its long-term security interests via a policy of military opposition to the government of Congo."

Britain's UN representative, Jeremy Greenstock, pressed Mr Kagame to bring a halt to the Rwandan army's plunder of eastern Congo. Mr Kagame's responses were not persuasive. He brushed aside accusations of human rights abuses by his troops by saying such violations were also widespread in areas of Congo under government control. And he dismissed the charges of looting Congo's gold and diamonds as a "diversionary" issue compared to the threat from the interahamwe.

webTitle: Police dig for Brink's-Mat gold after underworld tipoff

fields.headline: Police dig for Brink's-Mat gold after underworld tipoff
fields.trailText: The enduring mystery of   what happened to millions of pounds worth of gold bullion taken in the Brink's-Mat robbery took a sudden twist yesterday when police began excavating land owned by a builders' merchant near Hastings in Kent.
fields.body:
The enduring mystery of what happened to millions of pounds worth of gold bullion taken in the Brink's-Mat robbery took a sudden twist yesterday when police began excavating land owned by a builders' merchant near Hastings in Kent.

Although the operation was shrouded in secrecy, it is understood Scotland Yard's flying squad ordered the dig when officers received credible information from underworld sources that gold bars had been buried on the site.

If bullion or cash is found, detectives believe they know who had it stashed there - Ken Noye. One of the country's most powerful criminals, Noye, 53, was jailed last year for the murder of Stephen Cameron on a sliproad of the M25 near Swanley in Kent.

Previously, Noye had been sentenced to 14 years - reduced to 13 on appeal - for his involvement in handling gold stolen from the Brink's-Mat security depot at Heathrow in 1983. Detectives investigating the robbery found 11 gold bars worth £100,000 wrapped in cloth in a drainage trench at Noye's former home in West Kingsdown, Kent.

They believe Noye was also instrumental in smelting gold before selling it on. Yesterday Detective Superintendent John Shatford was coordinating the dig beneath the concrete floor of a timber shed belonging to a firm on the Old London Road in Ore outside Hastings.

A team of officers working inside a large white tent was using drills and thermal imaging equipment. Nothing was found in the initial excavation at R Winchester builders, but sources said the dig could continue for up to three days.

A police spokeswoman refused to confirm what officers were looking for, saying only that Scotland Yard was "acting on intelligence gathered as a result of a lengthy investigation initiated last year''. No one had been arrested, she said. Det Supt Shatford, however, said that Ronald Winchester, the owner of the builders' merchants, was helping police with their inquiries.

"We don't know what, if anything, we are going to find,'' said one source. "But we wouldn't have started this unless we had pretty good information. You can never be 100% sure what will turn up until you start looking.''

The robbery, at 6.30am on November 26 1983, was Britain's biggest, securing £26m of gold. A bribed security guard let six armed men into the Brink's-Mat warehouse. They poured petrol over staff and threatened them with a lit match if they did not reveal the combination numbers of the vault.

It is thought more than £17m of the cash realised from the gold has been accounted for by police, and some of the remainder is thought to have been invested in property in Britain and Spain.

Dozens of gold bars are still unaccounted for. It was assumed most had been melted down and would never be recovered. Only two of the robbers have been convicted. Michael McAvoy and Brian Robinson are each serving 25 years.

Watching the excavation yesterday, many local people expressed dismay that the police might find gold in the ground. "If I'd known there was gold there I would have gone down with a spade in the middle of last night and tried to find it myself," said Eileen Boggins, landlady of the Hare and Hound pub, overlooking the search site.

fields.headline: Hold the mayo
fields.trailText: Mr Andrew Roth is incorrect (Obituary, January 22) in attributing my late husband's appointment in 1970 as chairman of the House of Commons catering sub-committee to an outbreak of salmonella poisoning in the House.
fields.body:
Mr Andrew Roth is incorrect (Obituary, January 22) in attributing my late husband's appointment in 1970 as chairman of the House of Commons catering sub-committee to an outbreak of salmonella poisoning in the House. My husband, Reginald Bennett, was asked to take on that post in order to make good the depletion of the wine cellar brought about under the chairmanship of the previous incumbent - Mr Robert Maxwell.

The "salmonella incident" took place in the summer of 1967 after a large government reception held at Lancaster House and hosted by the then foreign secretary, George Brown, in honour of the president of Italy. A large number of politicians and diplomats were taken ill; it was found that the mayonnaise in the canapés had been made with imported duck eggs. The House of Commons kitchens did not do the catering.
H M Bennett
London

fields.headline: Banking on the euro
fields.trailText: I thought the front page (Blair shows his hand on the euro, February 8) was a little over the top. Even the Sun was more circumspect. What else does "early in the next parliament" mean if not within two years?
fields.body:
I thought the front page (Blair shows his hand on the euro, February 8) was a little over the top. Even the Sun was more circumspect. What else does "early in the next parliament" mean if not within two years?

That said, having a little more clarity on the timetable is excellent news for British business. Anyone with an ounce of business sense will tell you it is madness to rule out joining the euro without an assessment of the economy, whether you opt for Mr Brown's formula of the "five economic tests" or not.

I cannot see how it puts the euro higher up the agenda for the general election either. The situation is unchanged. The British people will decide whether we go in or not when they vote in the referendum.
A M Oldroyd
London
amoldroyd@yahoo.co.uk

 I have just received a letter from my French bank informing me of the date when the euro replaces the franc - January 1 2002. This contrasts sadly with the pathetic level of debate in this country from all sides.

The French feel secure that their culture will not be undermined by mere currency change. Here, empire loyalists witter on about "sterling", while a "modernising" government doesn't have the guts to make the irrefutable case for change. We are in an insane limbo with half a House of Lords, half a health service and half in Europe. Can we get on with it now, please?
Kit Jackson
London
Kit.Jackson@care4free.net

 I congratulate Tony Blair on his stance toward when a referendum might be on the Britain's entry into the single currency. The announcement tells us what we are aiming for. It gives us a strategic planning horizon and gives the certainty that has been required. It is also excellent news from a business perspective. The biggest problem they face is uncertainty but now business has a timetable to work from.

The recent decision by Nissan to build the Micra at its Sunderland plant came because this country has kept the option to join the single currency, while other firms such as Corus have announced job losses because of the currency volatility they face between the pound and the euro.

It is right that the matter is settled by a referendum. Anyone who says otherwise does not understand the meaning of democracy.
Anna Yearley
Wantage, Oxfordshire
annayearley@hotmail.com

webTitle: Letter: In defence of Ariel Sharon

fields.headline: In defence of Ariel Sharon
fields.trailText: By electing Ariel Sharon, Israel has not "given up on peace" (front page, February 7). Israel's voters have sent a profound message to their own leaders - and to the Palestinian leadership and the world - that they want an end to violence, not its perpetuation.
fields.body:
By electing Ariel Sharon, Israel has not "given up on peace" (front page, February 7). Israel's voters have sent a profound message to their own leaders - and to the Palestinian leadership and the world - that they want an end to violence, not its perpetuation. Similarly, to suggest that by visiting the Western Wall, Ariel Sharon is doing an injustice to Muslims - the Guardian chose to say "twists the knife in Muslim wounds" - is an absolute disgrace.

It is completely untenable to propound the view that an Israeli leader, by visiting a uniquely Jewish holy site, is offending Muslims, unless one subscribes to the radical and rejectionist Muslim view of the Jew/Israeli as infidel.

Surely a paper with the Guardian's liberal traditions can find a way to come to terms with the democratic choice of Israelis (and more broadly with the Arab-Israeli conflict) without adopting the rejectionist Arab agenda and falling into the intellectual cul-de-sac of championing one side's truths, its pain and its sensitivities, at the expense of those of the other.
DJ Schneeweiss
Press secretary, Israeli embassy

webTitle: Slowdown in the US dents outlook for ICI

fields.headline: Slowdown in the US dents outlook for ICI
fields.trailText: ICI has finally completed its lengthy, and at times painful, transition from bulk to speciality chemicals concern, only to run into the slowdown in the United States.
fields.body:
ICI has finally completed its lengthy, and at times painful, transition from bulk to speciality chemicals concern, only to run into the slowdown in the United States.

Once the bellwether of British industry ICI is now heavily dependent on the US, which accounts for around a third of both sales and profits.

By contrast Britain now represents only 12% of sales and, at 7,000, the British workforce is only a sixth of the total worldwide.

Worries about the outlook in the US depressed the ICI share price yesterday despite a sharp rise in full-year pre-tax profits - before exceptionals and goodwill amortisation - from £376m to £450m.

Sales from continuing operations rose from £6.18bn to £6.41bn - though they were virtually unchanged in the fourth quarter. The firm's shares closed 35p lower at 491p.

ICI, which now spans a range of speciality chemicals from food to fragrances as well as paints - including an upmarket line for Ralph Lauren - acknowledged that it has been hit by the slowdown in the US, particularly at National Starch which recorded its first drop in profits for 30 years.

However, Tim Scott, finance director-designate, said yesterday: "If the phones stopped ringing in mid-December, they started ringing again in January."

Though January was not always the best indicator, the group said it was confident that it was well positioned to respond to a more difficult trading environment.

The group ended the year with net debt of some £2.8bn - about £452m up on the year - and though it declined to give a forecast for what will happen over the coming year, a combination of improved operational cash flow, a further £900m in further installments on the last round of disposals and lower dividend payments should help cut the burden.

Chief executive Brendan O'Neill said 2000 had been a defining year for ICI. "The new ICI has emerged - it is now a reality rather than a promise," he said.

fields.headline: Police 'closing in' on Damilola killers
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: A significant new witness has given detectives in the Damilola Taylor murder hunt hope that they can arrest and charge his killers, police sources said yesterday.
fields.body:
A significant new witness has given detectives in the Damilola Taylor murder hunt hope that they can arrest and charge his killers, police sources said yesterday.

The witness has described seeing 10-year-old Damilola being confronted in Blake's Road, Peckham, south London, by a group of youths.

A scuffle took place which led to Damilola falling to the ground just a few hundred yards from his home on the North Peckham estate. The youths ran off.

Officers are convinced that the witness has provided the breakthrough which they have been working for since Damilola was stabbed at 4.45pm on November 27 last year.

No other witness has provided such specific information about a confrontation in Blake's Road at around the time of the murder.

Officers, led by detective chief inspector Trevor Shepheard, intend to make one last appeal to those who saw the attack to speak voluntarily, if only to be eliminated from the investigation. "We are closing in," said one officer. "The net is tightening. This is a last days of the sale offer.

"If someone was there but was not involved, then come forward and tell us. If it was an accident, tell us. Or we will come knocking at your door."

The source added: "We are at a critical stage of the investigation in terms of making a possible arrest and charges. We want to secure all the evidence we are able to secure. We are in constant touch with the crown prosecution service.''

Significantly, the new witness remembers exchanging words with a Scotsman who was also in Blake's Road at the time of the attack.

Officers are wondering whether the man was the same Scot who rang Crimestoppers to say he had seen an incident in a nearby road involving a young boy and a group of youths. "We need to speak to this Scotsman once again," said a source. "It is vitally important we get clarity on this issue."

A third person is also known to have been in Blake's Road when Damilola was stabbed. He was wearing a green jacket, jeans and was balding.

Persuading witnesses to come forward when there are gangs in the area, including one known as the Peckham Young Boys, has been one of the major tasks of the murder squad.

"There is a constant background of intimidation that exists on the North Peckham estate,'' said a source. "It can be bullying, stealing or threats of violence."

However, in recent weeks officers feel they have begun to win the confidence of people who have provided important evidence.

Damilola was stabbed in his left leg as he walked home from an after school computer class at Peckham library.

fields.headline: Spring awakening
fields.standfirst: Gloucestershire
fields.trailText: Gloucestershire.
fields.body:
The RSPB/Today programme survey on garden birds produced a top ten species list which would not have been replicated here in the Cotswolds town of Tetbury. The morning residents on the steep stone-tiled roofs around us are jackdaws, and they are down to the bird table with speed and enthusiasm the moment kitchen scraps are put out, to the exclusion of smaller species. Capable of domestic damage too, these jackdaws.

A pair tumbled down the chimney into our neighbour's living room while she was away. Fortunately, we were going in on a daily cat-feed rota and, finding the soot and mess made by the birds, and the panic-stricken exit of the feline, my wife was able to open a window and get the birds out. A longer internment would have seen more of the place trashed by the confined pair. The species which gave us the happiest nesting experience last year was the wren. Mother wren chose the inside apex of a stone archway for a secure nesting site. She judged the day of fledging perfectly, but the seven nestlings could only flutter straight down to the cobbles 10 feet below. We were watching - four baby wrens landed on me and clung briefly, and three on my wife. All rapidly followed their mother up the garden. She will be welcome again this year, though we cannot promise to be in the cushioning position. Harbingers of spring appeared on Stinchcombe Hill today.

Morning mist cleared to winter sunshine and blue sky. Two larks were singing loudly, high against the sky, clearly proclaiming territorial rights, and a buzzard was circling in languid flight over woodland in a style reminiscent of warmer conditions.

fields.headline: Educating the system
fields.trailText: The suggestion from the House of Commons education select committee to bribe universities with £800 per head to take more students from disadvantaged backgrounds shows just how out of touch MPs are with the real problems suffered by students and their teachers in the university system.
fields.body:
The suggestion from the House of Commons education select committee to bribe universities with £800 per head to take more students from disadvantaged backgrounds shows just how out of touch MPs are with the real problems suffered by students and their teachers in the university system.

This government abolished student grants and instituted fees in the most cack-handed way imaginable, causing real hardship among many students, as the MPs know full well from the evidence put before them. At the same time Mr Blunkett and Mr Brown have done almost nothing to reverse the continued decline in the unit of resource the universities get for teaching each student: it has effectively halved in the past 30 years.

The latest politically correct dodge is to coerce universities, in the name of equality of opportunity, to provide so called access courses, despite the fact that some of the students recruited are, as a result of our similarly underfunded and demoralised school system, woefully short of the necessary skills, knowledge and attitudes needed to make a success of higher education.

University teachers are supposed to do the remedial teaching, a task for which they are not fitted and have no inclination, so the access students drop out early. What a waste of time and money.

Until we have a properly funded higher education system with a realistic, equable loans scheme for providing living costs for the students and an increase in the resources given for teaching and research, (as the ignored Bett and Cubie reports suggested) the once most admired system of higher education in the world will continue to be a source of shame, not pride. Prof Michael J Rennie
University of Dundee

 We should surely welcome Tessa Blackstone's largesse in attempting to get universities to recruit more disadvantaged students. I wonder if such incentives could be back-dated to reward those institutions who have been far-sighted enough to act on this, already. About nine years should do it ...
Prof Nigel Wood
De Montfort University, Leicester
npwood@dmu.ac.uk

 Many graduates will be horrified by the news that Warwick University intends to make purchase of a laptop computer a condition of entry from the autumn of 2003 onwards (Students angry at computer 'elitism', February 8).

This is a fundamental and far-reaching change to the operation of the British university system which effectively introduces a top-up fee for study at Warwick. By citing the disputed figure of 70% PC ownership among undergraduates to support its plans, the university is attempting to solve one perceived inequity by imposing a far greater one.

A Warwick graduates' action group is being formed to campaign for greater equity of access to higher education in light of the current proposal. The introduction of tuition fees endangered this principle but Warwick's plans threaten its last remnants.

Concerted action is required from Warwick students, staff and graduates in order to defeat this worrying proposal, which would set a dangerous precedent for all British universities.
Steve Thomas
Coventry
laptopstop@talk21.com

webTitle: Letters: Turbulence over priests in politics

fields.headline: Turbulence over priests
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Wheatcroft is not the only one alarmed at the prospect of an army of clerics in the House of Commons (Turbulent priests, February 8). If recent experiences in relation to section 28 and the age of consent are anything to go by, it would be very bad news for the gay community.
fields.body:
Geoffrey Wheatcroft is not the only one alarmed at the prospect of an army of clerics in the House of Commons (Turbulent priests, February 8). If recent experiences in relation to section 28 and the age of consent are anything to go by, it would be very bad news for the gay community.

The kind of religionists who would seek political power at present are almost all standing on a platform of anti-gay propaganda. The regressive influence such people have had in the Lords is evidence enough that a pseudo-synodical House of Commons is a very bad idea.
George Broadhead
Gay and Lesbian Humanist Association, Kenilworth, Warwickshire

 Oh dear, you really can't resist it can you - the knee jerk reaction to anything to do with the church? A fairly common-sense bit of legislative tidying up and you summon up fears of demonic clergy "flooding" the Commons (a good tabloid word that - "give them an inch and the flood gates will open"). And worse than that, they'll all be bigoted fascists - look what happened in Slovakia!

The reality will probably be a tiny handful of Anglican vicars (probably Liberal Democrats!) lost in a sea (or should that be a "flood"?) of lawyers. But let's not allow reality to get in the way of lazy thinking, stereotyping and cliches. And let's hope for some intelligent coverage of things religious.
Revd Michael Peet
London
michael@mpeet.fsnet.co.uk

webTitle: Restoration of south London's Jurassic Park

fields.headline: Restoration of south London's Jurassic Park
fields.trailText: Denizens of the world's first dinosaur park, created 150 years ago in south London, are to have their dignity restored.
fields.body:
Denizens of the world's first dinosaur park, created 150 years ago in south London, are to have their dignity restored.

The lifesize representations, made of painted concrete, were built by Benjamin Hawkins between 1852 and 1854 for display on a lake in the Crystal Palace park.

The term "dinosaur" had been coined 12 years previously, and visitors proved as susceptible to dinomania as today.

Although Hawkins based his models on the best fossil evidence available, it became clear within a few years that they were inaccurate. They have been quietly decaying in the run-down park ever since.

Yesterday the local authority, the London borough of Bromley, announced it would restore much of the park. Its palaeontological adviser, Peter Doyle of the University of Greenwich, said the imperfect dinosaurs were representative of a certain period in science.

"What I would like to do is celebrate Victorian ingenuity, while acknowledging the background of the known scientific facts of the time."

Details are wrong on some of the 29 models. A horn on the head of a iguanadon should, it is now known, be on the animal's thumb. Other representations are speculative, such as the toad-like labyrinthidons. All Hawkins had to go on was a set of teeth and a footprint.

"As science advances, old ideas are discarded," said Prof Doyle. "Once you build something in concrete the size of a house you can't change it."

The park was opened five years before Charles Darwin published Origin of the Species. A similar display for Central Park in New York was cancelled when authorities balked at the implied challenge to the book of Genesis.

webTitle: G2: Pass notes on Nigel Dempster

fields.headline: No: 1816
fields.standfirst: Nigel Dempster
fields.trailText: Nigel Dempster
fields.body:
Daaahling. Sorry?

Sweeeetie. Que?

Haven't seen you for ages. Kiss kiss. You've been going to those society parties again, haven't you? Maybe. I've warned you about those. They're not thrown for the likes of us.

I know, but I do so badly want to mingle with the lords and ladies of this fine land, brush shoulders with the celebrities and learn more about the intimate lives of the rich, famous and notorious. Perhaps you'd be better off working for the Daily Mail.

Well, I do have to admit a bit of a penchant for Nigel Dempster. Nigel Who?

You're just being cruel. Anybody who's anybody has heard of the Dumpster, aka the Greatest Living Englishman. He's the undisputed king of gossip columnists, a doyen of the tabloid right, chief informant on a celebrity-studded world, a walking guide to who's who ... You journalists are so self-obsessed.

I know, darling. But isn't it wonderful? Not if you're a London bollard.

Now you've lost me. It transpires that at 5.35pm on Saturday, the diarist's Honda collided with a central reservation and overturned. Dempster managed to free himself and was taken to hospital with minor hand injuries. He was later arrested for drink driving.

How deliciously scandalous. Even more so when you learn that it happened only a few days after he celebrated the end of a teetotal January...

Never! I shall have to tell someone. Where's Lady Victoria Hervey when you need her? This isn't the first time he has been arrested for drink-driving. He was convicted in 1998.

Most likely to say: "I'm an institution."

Most likely to be told: "You should be in an institution."

fields.headline: Omissions on emission
fields.trailText: You suggest (Analysis, February 7) that we will not reduce greenhouse gas emissions by as much as we say because our climate change programme wrongly assumes that overall output from nuclear electricity generating plants will continue at or above current levels. Not so.
fields.body:
You suggest (Analysis, February 7) that we will not reduce greenhouse gas emissions by as much as we say because our climate change programme wrongly assumes that overall output from nuclear electricity generating plants will continue at or above current levels.

Not so. Our projections include a 15% reduction in output from nuclear energy by 2010. Even if (as you imply) the Wylfa and Oldbury nuclear power stations closed before 2010, that would only add 0.6% to our total C02 emissions - compared to estimated cuts of 19%.

I can confirm that the UK's climate change programme will reduce the UK's greenhouse gas emissions by up to 23% below 1990 levels in 2010. This is considerably beyond our legally binding Kyoto target of a 12.5% cut. Larry Whitty
Under secretary of state, Dept of the Environment

webTitle: Letter: No money for Mr Vaz

fields.headline: No money for Mr Vaz
fields.trailText: The confidentiality of the inquiry by the parliamentary commissioner for standards into a number of allegations of impropriety against my client Keith Vaz MP, all of which he denies, still prevents him from publicly refuting them.
fields.body:
The confidentiality of the inquiry by the parliamentary commissioner for standards into a number of allegations of impropriety against my client Keith Vaz MP, all of which he denies, still prevents him from publicly refuting them.

However, an error by Patrick Wintour in his description of one of these allegations (Media hounding Vaz says Cook, February 5) needs to be corrected. It is not true that Mr Sarosh Zaiwalla has ever claimed that he at any time made any payment in cash to Mr Vaz.

This error has led to the claim by David Hencke (February 7) that Mr Zaiwalla has "backed down" over this allegation in giving oral evidence to the select committee on February 6. In fairness to Mr Zaiwalla, it should be made clear that he has been consistent throughout the inquiry in stating that he has never made any cash payment to Mr Vaz or any other payment to him personally or for his personal benefit. Mr Vaz, of course, has confirmed that he has never received any such payment.
Geoffrey Bindman
Bindman & Partners Solicitors, London

fields.headline: Rocket science
fields.standfirst: Want to sell more pizza? Try piling on a few unusual toppings. Walnuts, say, or a handful   of rocket. Well it worked for Pizza Express, reports Esther Addley - even if the purists are horrified. But Matthew Fort is unimpressed by the top-heavy combos
fields.trailText: Want to sell more pizza? Try piling on a few unusual toppings. Walnuts, say, or a handful of rocket. Well it worked for Pizza Express, reports Esther Addley - even if the purists are horrified. But Matthew Fort is unimpressed by the top-heavy combos.
fields.body:
So, what do you fancy eating for dinner tonight? Can't quite make up your mind between Italian and Chinese? Worry not, help is at hand. Just pop into Sainsbury's on your way home from work, where for £3.29 you can pick up a pizza topped with Peking crispy duck. Or at Asda, a "pizza professional" will rustle up a char sui pork pizza. Or one topped with cajun chicken. Or if you want to stay European, a pizza with frankfurters and mozzarella.

For those seeking a symbol of 21st-century globalisation in edible form, nothing comes close to humble pizza, a circle of dough topped with - well, whatever you please. From its lowly origins as the staple diet of the south Italian poor, the pizza has come to represent the very essence of cross-cultural selectivism. Start in Europe, add a sprinkle of Cajun or a splash of India, and garnish with a little taste of China. Stick it under the grill and hey presto, almost literally a global melting pot.

Never mind the burger or the vindaloo, nothing, it seems, can satisfy our hunger for pizza. British supermarkets sold a record 200m pizzas in 1999, worth £503m. Another £1bn was spent on takeaway pizza. We may grow out of fish and chips or tire of chicken korma, but the pizza market is continuing to grow at 8% year on year.

The high street restaurant chain Pizza Express is the latest to benefit from Britain's love affair with the pizza. Earlier this week it published figures showing a 10% increase in sales at its 256 restaurants in the UK. Those looking for the company's secret need only compare the current menu with that of 18 months ago. The wine list has doubled (the prices are also rather more substantial), but the significant change is a more subtle one.

Out goes the marinara (anchovies, garlic, tomato, olives, no cheese), to be replaced with some slightly more exotic culinary coinages. Alongside staples such as the margherita and the quattro formaggi now sit the pizza alle noci, an intriguing mix of spinach, walnut halves, garlic, gorgonzola and tomato (see right), and the curiously named Soho pizza, a standard mozzarella and tomato and garlic combo which comes topped with parmesan and a sizeable handful of rocket.

Nothing too controversial, but just that little bit more adventurous. And these more adventurous toppings are big-sellers. "There's no doubt at all that our good results have been due to the change in the menu," says the company's chief executive, Ian Eldridge. The company is not yet at the stage of offering pizza vindaloo but, he says, never say never.

The pizza's greatest asset in dealing with this multicultural onslaught is its sheer versatility. Pizza manufacturers, it seems, can tweak their basic design as much as they please and the customers still keep coming back for more.

There is now a generation of pizza lovers that has come to believe that deep pan is the real McCoy, and the Italians don't do it right because their pizzas are too thin and don't come with enough cheese. The stuffed crust pizza, an innovation of the past couple of years in which those bits of base that aren't topped with goodies are filled with them, is beginning to catch on in a similar way. Last year Pizza Hut took this trend to its logical conclusion and introduced the Edge, a pizza so loaded with toppings that it effectively has no crust.

The mere thought, needless to say, is enough to bring pizza purists out in a cold sweat. Giorgio Locatelli, the ebullient proprietor of the upmarket Italian restaurants Zafferano, Spiga and La Spighetta in London, finds the very thought of stuffed crust, deep pan or - God forbid - pineapple pizzas appalling.

"I take my hat off to some of the big pizza chains, because they are great companies making a lot of money, but the quality to a pizza purist is terrible. It's as if they are trying to achieve the flatness of McDonald's - standardising it, so they can sell it all over the world. I don't know any Italian person who likes deep pan pizza. You're getting 350g of cheese in a big 12-inch pizza, how are you possibly going to digest that?"

While he doesn't want to sound like a snob, says Locatelli, heaping ever more toppings on pizzas and making them ever more doughy merely serves to diminish the pizza's status as a delicious, healthy, simple meal. "Those who know pizza don't even eat it with mozzarella on it. Personally I just like it with a touch of garlic because I like the taste of the dough. You can appreciate the great flavour if you don't drown it with cheese. The difference between making pizza properly and mass producing it is the difference between chargrilling a piece of meat or boiling it. We make pizzas which are very light, which often have just a tomato with perhaps artichoke and garlic, no mozzarella, and then you put a little chopped rocket or something on top once it has been cooked."

Locatelli's 12-year-old-son recently returned from a supermarket trip and suggested that he put chicken vindaloo pizza on the menu. And his response? "I beat him up. I ended his life." He is joking - just.

Those terrified at the prospect of supermarket shelves stocking nothing but pizza sprinkled with pad thai need not fear, however. We Brits may be more adventurous than we were but, true to form, not that adventurous. Of "mega" pizzas sold in Asda last year, a full fifth were ham and pineapple. For the time being at least, it seems, most culinary adventurers are prepared to travel no further than that well-known home of Italian cuisine, Hawaii.

Matthew Fort's verdict: 'I wondered if my pizza had been shrunk in the wash'

'What do the dishes in blue mean?" I asked the waiter. "They're the new dishes," he said. "I've been working here a year, and they've always been on, but that's what I've been told to say, so I say it." These very same dishes in blue, we have been told, are responsible for a 10% rise in the profits of Pizza Express.

How could one resist? So it was a tonno e fagioli - tuna and beans - and a pizze alle noci for me.

Tonno e fagioli has been a stand-by for Italian restaurants in this country practically since the Romans. It is a classic dish - just cannellini beans, canned tuna, olive oil, lemon juice, and a little chopped red onion and black pepper.

The Pizza Express version got the beans and red onion right - just. There weren't really enough of them, but then there was so much else going on - diced peppers, olives (of a kind), balsamic vinegar. There were even a few shards of tuna and some little balls of baked pizza dough.

When the pizza arrived, I couldn't help wondering if Pizza Express's leap in profits had as much to do with the downsizing of the pizzas (coincidental with a stiffish hike in the prices?), as it did to its wonderful way with new toppings. Mine seemed to have shrunk in the wash. Mind you, by the time I had, well, not finished eating because I couldn't, I rather wished that it had shrunk away altogether.

I chose my pizza alle noci, complete with gorgonzola, tomato puree, spinach, garlic and walnuts, partly to find out whether anything that sounded so disgusting could actually be so disgusting. It was perhaps merciful that the tomato puree had no discernible flavour at all. Do people really want to eat such stuff? Well, clearly they do, and it isn't hard to see why. Pizza Express is familiar. It represents safe eating, the Angus Steak House of our vegetarian days. Naturally, it has followed the inevitable law of chain restaurants: the more money spent on kitting out the restaurants, the worse the food becomes. Design is the distraction. You get an eating experience instead of food. In a soulless kind of way, it's not a bad place to eat. It fits nicely into that space before or after a film or the theatre.

And it is so cheap as to absent itself from criticism. Or is it? I paid £11.60 for some tonno e fagioli, pizza and a glass of water. Add on a tip of 12.5%, which I did because I liked my truthful waiter, and you get a bill of £13.05 - quite a lot for foul food.

From its lowly origins as the staple diet of the south Italian poor, the pizza has come to represent the very essence of cross-cultural selectivism. Start in Europe, add a sprinkle of Cajun or a splash of India, and garnish with a little taste of China. Stick it under the grill and hey presto, almost literally a global melting pot. webTitle: Notebook: Rate cut may head off recession

fields.headline: MPC takes out an insurance policy
fields.standfirst: Notebook: Rate cut may head off recession
fields.trailText: Notebook: Rate cut may head off recession
fields.body:
For some in the City, the Bank of England's decision to cut interest rates yesterday was a high risk, even a reckless, move.

The economy looks pretty strong, the housing market is robust, pay settlements are nudging upwards, so cheaper money will simply lead to excess demand and higher inflation. Britain, quite simply, is not the United States.

But think back to the autumn of 1999. At that point, inflation in the UK was below the government's 2.5% target yet the Bank's monetary policy committee did not hang about. It believed that the strength of the economy would eventually lead to upward pressure on prices so it took pre-emptive action, not once but four times.

As a result, those who were quick to praise the Bank for being forward looking then should apply the same logic to yesterday's quarter-point reduction in rates. With the US economy looking weaker by the day, all the risks for the UK are on the downside.

Underlying inflation stands at 2% and is heading towards 1.5% over the next few months, so the Bank need have no fear that its easing of monetary policy puts the government's 2.5% inflation target in jeopardy.

Indeed, the real threat to the global economy is deflation not inflation, as Japan knows only too well. Since it was given operational control over interest rates in May 1997, the Bank has tended not to indulge in one-off moves. There was a progressive tightening of policy in 1997 and early 1998 followed by a steady easing in the aftermath of the Russian debt crisis in the summer of 1998.

Yesterday's decision may buck the trend, being merely an insurance policy against a US-induced recession. But the chances are that rates will be closer to 5% than 6% by the end of the year. And rightly so.

Gloves are off

The surgical gloves have come off at Toft Hall, the quaintly named head office of SSL International. The condoms-to-catheters health care business is based in the nouveau riche enclave of Knutsford, Cheshire, which is somehow appropriate for a company which is new to the billion-pound league.

It seems that directors want someone to take the blame for November's profits warning. Chief executive Iain Cater and chairman Stuart Wallis are the leading contenders, both commanding loyalty and dislike in equal measure.

Critics of Cater maintain that he pushed through two mergers too quickly - first, linking Seton to Scholl and then adding Durex condoms maker London International. Having grown the company from £30m to £1.7bn, he was unable to keep a grip on its distant subsidiaries.

His sympathisers point out that this is his first slip-up in 10 years, and that he had the right to expect advice and support from his more experienced non-executive colleagues. Wallis had previously run the health care business Fisons, and if anyone knows about stocking issues - the cause of SSL's difficulties - it is him. He contributed to the damage caused in November by dashing out of an analysts' meeting to catch a plane, and by giving the general impression that he was only peripherally involved.

Boardroom tensions have been simmering at SSL for two months, which cannot be healthy for a business going through a critical recovery period. It is time for shareholders to decide whether they want to ditch a young management team for its first serious slip-up, or throw out the one experienced City name on the board.

Shell suits

Everything has always been done with due decorum at Shell Tower, so yesterday no one was trying to steal the limelight from Sir Mark Moody-Stuart, now in his twilight months as chairman of the Anglo-Dutch oil firm. But there was a noticeable trial run for Phil Watts, his successor, who takes the reins in June.

Mr Watts fielded many of the questions and was ready to take more once Sir Mark had retired at the end of a results presentation to mark the group's $13.1bn (£9bn) record annual profits, up 85% on last time.

Preliminary results stories do not come much punchier than this, so Mr Watts was probably right to revel in the good times while they are here. However, even in a downturn he looks unlikely to wilt.

The chairman-designate is a blunt no-nonsense Midlander in contrast with the urbane and cultured Sir Mark. Mr Watts has been with Shell since the 1960s and has put much of the fire into the company's highly successful restructuring.

Asked whether we could expect to see any change of direction in the company under his chairmanship, he replied "no". Boring!, cried the audience. If being successful is boring then "I like boring things," came the reply. So be it.

fields.headline: Co-op reveals action plan
fields.standfirst: Refashioning a £9m movement: Naming and shaming, tougher targets and hardnosed moves into new markets in 60-point plan
fields.trailText: Refashioning a £9m movement: Naming and shaming, tougher targets and hardnosed moves into new markets in 60-point plan.
fields.body:
A 60-point action plan to revitalise the £9bn Co-op movement was unveiled yesterday at the end of an eleven month investigation. The study, which was set up with the backing of the Prime Minister, is likely to see the reintroduction of the "divi" payout to Co-op members.

It also suggests the introduction of tough new business targets which are likely to mean some Co-op businesses being sold off or shut down.

The Co-operative Commission's 100-page report comes after decades of decline in the Co-op movement. It said the greatest weakness was the old fashioned image of the retail stores, whose share of the grocery market has dwindled from more than 25% to just 5%.

In the last five years the retail societies' trading profits have plunged from £160m to less than £90m.

But the Co-operative Commission, chaired by TUC general secretary John Monks, believes the Co-op movement can be reinvigorated. In its report it says the Co-op brand can be exploited and that customers would welcome a modern, socially responsible alternative to other businesses. Mr Monk said the Co-op movement could "tap into the public's disillusionment with corporate greed and lack of ethical standards."

Tony Blair told Co-op leaders: "It is important to the development of a strong social economy that the Co-operative movement continues to prosper in the new century."

The twelve-strong commission's 60 recommendations are designed to "reconnect and define" the Co-op's social goals, "utilise the Co-op's advantage and ensure commercial success".

To ensure commercial success the commission hopes to set a minimum acceptable return on capital of 10%. The big supermarkets make twice that, but the Co-ops currently make only about 3%.

It also wants external monitoring of targets and to develop new national branding. It said the societies must also move into new sectors and develop cross selling.

The move into new sectors - which the commision suggested could include long term care for the elderly and childcare - would be masterminded by a "hard-nosed" new ventures working group.

The commission said the societies must also put their chief executives and financial controllers onto their boards and bring in non-executive directors to fill skills gaps. Boards are currently made up of elected members.

It also wants the Co-op bank and CIS insurance group to integrate their business strategies. "They should urgently create a single business strategy to maximise the customer base both organisations have", said Commission secretary Alan Donnelly.

Full merger of the two businesses had been considered and rejected. To "reconnect" with the community the commission said a minimum dividend level of 10% should be distributed to the Co-op's two million individual members and the wider community.

Mr Donnelly said it was "the return of the divvie", and should not be in the form of a loyalty card. He urged the movement to expand credit unions and said a social investment task force and a Co-op Foundation should be established "to sponsor best practice" in Co-ops.

The Commission has concluded that businesses which continue to underperform should be named and shamed. "We are not proposing to keep failing businesses alive", said Mr Donnelly. "Where societies do not meet targets, the spotlight will shine on them very closely." Underpeforming societies could have non-executives appointed to them and ultimately the Co-op brand could be withdrawn.

It also wants government action to protect the societies against carpetbaggers, like the attack on the CWS orchestrated by financier Andrew Regan in 1997. Yesterday Graham Melmoth of the Co-op Group, which has a turnover of £8bn, pledged his support to the commission.

The commission's recommendations will be put to the Co-operative Congress at its annual meeting in May.

How pioneering spirit paid dividends

The roots of the Co-operative movement were in the north and its power base remains there. The first Co-op shop was set up in 1844 by 28 Rochdale workers to sell high quality food at reasonable prices to working class families and return profits to customers as a dividend.

The Rochdale Pioneers had come up with a winning formula. Within 20 years there were 300 Co-ops, mostly in Lancashire and Yorkshire; by the turn of the century there were 1,400.

In 1872 the Co-Operative Wholesale Society was formed - to service member societies by buying in bulk and enabling hundreds of Co-ops nationwide to take advantage of their collective buying power.

The CWS opened factories to provide goods, developed support services like banking and insurance and moved into a range of other services - such as travel and funerals.

By the 1960s the movement was in decline as grocery stores lost business to burgeoning supermarkets. Many Co-ops merged to form larger regional societies and the Co-operative Retail Society gobbled up struggling rivals. T

oday, the Co-op is the world's largest co-operative movement, with more staff and a larger turnover than companies like Marks & Spencer, ICI and British Airways.

Last year - after an audacious attempt by Monaco-based financier Andrew Regan to buy out the CWS with a £1.5bn bid - CWS and CRS merged.

The Co-op Group was formed and Prime Minister Tony Blair backed the setting up of the Co-operative Commission to consider the movement's future.

The 47 retail Co-ops employ 105,000 workers and manage 4,643 shops, including 44 superstores, while the Co-op Group employs 50,000 staff and has 1,126 food shops. The Co-op Bank employs 4,000 staff.

webTitle: Merant shares hit as deal fails

fields.headline: Merant shares hit as deal fails
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Merant, the e-business software firm that has seen its share price shattered by three profits warnings over the past year, delivered more bad news yesterday for investors when it said that talks regarding a possible takeover of the company had been abandoned.
fields.body:
Merant, the e-business software firm that has seen its share price shattered by three profits warnings over the past year, delivered more bad news yesterday for investors when it said that talks regarding a possible takeover of the company had been abandoned.

Shares in Merant dived 14p to 103p, leaving them firmly below the level at which they first started trading two years ago and well below the highs touched a year ago.

Merant first announced that it was in talks that could lead to it being taken over in December, but had always emphasised that the talks were tentative at best. However, shareholders are likely to have been disappointed that a deal has not materialised, given that the board announced as long ago as August that it was considering ways of boosting its sagging share price.

"The board of Merant is intent on delivering value to shareholders and continues to review a broad range of strategic alternatives," it said in a statement. Management has been rumoured to be looking at a possible buyout.

Third-quarter results for the period to January 31 are expected to show revenues of approximately £53.6m. Last month Merant tried to diversify its product range by paying £18m for Web Content Management, a unit of IBM which lost $7.6m last year.

Merant offers a broad range of e-business software to large, mainly US-based, corporations.
