webTitle: Seumas Milne on the West's response to Ariel Sharon

fields.headline: The man of blood
fields.standfirst:
We call such men war criminals when their names are Milosevic or Pinochet. But not when it's Sharon

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
Special report: Labour's ethical foreign policy
fields.trailText: We call such men war criminals when their names are Milosevic or Pinochet. But not when it's Sharon.
fields.body:
Governments and their leaders can no longer hide from global justice, we have been repeatedly assured. They cannot shelter behind national jurisdictions and state sovereignty. Those responsible for human rights abuses, ethnic cleansing, atrocities and, most of all, war crimes, must and will be pursued regardless of national boundaries in an inter-dependent world.

That was the theme of Nato's "humanitarian war" against Yugoslavia - enthusiastically championed by Tony Blair - and of the hunting down of Serbian and Croatian warlords, the plans for an international war crimes court and the millions of dollars handed out by the US congress for the prosecution of Iraqi leaders and their families.

It was also the message of the citizen-led attempt to prosecute the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet and the rupture of political relations between Austria and the rest of the European Union in response to the rise to power of Jörg Haider's far right Freedom party in Austria. But the partisans of this brave new "doctrine of international community" have been strangely subdued since the election of the extreme rightwing general Ariel Sharon as Israel's prime minister. It has, it transpires, been business as usual with the man held personally responsible for the largest massacre of civilians in the history of the Arab-Israeli conflict.

The British prime minister had a reportedly cordial chat with Sharon on Wednesday, while Robin Cook looked forward to "building on common ground" and "moving the peace process forward" with a politician whose swaggering provocation in Jerusalem last year triggered the current Palestinian uprising and whose suggestion for dealing with demonstrators was to "cut off their testicles". President Bush meanwhile promised Sharon that US support for Israel was "rock solid".

Of course, governments deal with all sorts of leaders with ugly records. But Sharon is more than that. By any reasonable reckoning, he is a war criminal. This is a man of blood, whose history of terror and violation of the rules of war stretches back to the early 50s, when his unit slaughtered Palestinian villagers, through his brutal onslaught on the refugees of Gaza in the 70s, to his central role in Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon in which up to 20,000 people died.

Around 2,000 of them were butchered in 36 hours in the Palestinian refugee camps of Sabra and Shatila by Lebanese Phalangists effectively under Sharon's control. Sharon had repeatedly insisted that the camps were full of terrorists. In reality, the victims were overwhelmingly unarmed civilians, the PLO's fighters having been evacuated with an American-brokered promise of protection for their families.

Israel's own Kahan commission found Sharon "personally" but "indirectly" responsible for the massacre, though whether an independent court would be so generous is open to question.

Now Sharon's return to power will put the good faith of supporters of an international justice system to the test. Their critics maintain that the new supranational doctrine of intervention and extra-territorial legality is a fraud, designed to give a spurious human rights legitimacy to big power bullying of weaker states that threaten their authority or interests. War crimes or human rights violations committed by the major powers, or by western allies in particular, they argue, will always be treated according to different standards and go unpunished.

The prospects are certainly not encouraging in the case of Israel, which has long been allowed by its western sponsors to violate a string of UN security council resolutions, while other states in the region are subjected to lethal regimes of sanctions and bombing attacks for their transgressions.

Sharon's most horrific crimes are more recent than Pinochet's and his responsibility for the Sabra and Shatila killings is better documented than, say, that of the indicted former Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic for the comparable Srebrenica massacre. It will be objected that Sharon has been chosen in a democratic election and that pursuing him for 18-year-old crimes will do nothing to advance the chances of a peace settlement.

Such a settlement will become more likely once the majority of Israelis realise that Sharon's hardline policies of repression will not deliver the security they crave, while sanctions seem more suitable for a state whose citizens have a say in policy, rather than for dictatorships where they have none.

Of course, no western government is likely to lift a finger against Sharon, though human rights and pro-Palestinian groups are already gearing up to attempt a Pinochet-style legal action if he ventures abroad. There is little prospect even of some mark of disapproval, such as a Haider-style diplomatic protest or the suspension of arms sales called for by a group of Labour MPs on Wednesday. These might at least send Israeli voters the message that there are limits to external material support.

During the Kosovo war, Tony Blair announced that his foreign intervention policy was based on a "subtle blend" of self-interest and moral purpose. Given the reaction to Sharon's election, this seems to boil down to moral purpose with enemies, but self-interest when it comes to friends.

webTitle: The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle

fields.headline: The Adventures of Rocky and Bullwinkle
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Tries too hard to replicate the wackiness of cartoon in live action form. Very wearing.
fields.body: A quirky, jerky live-action-plus-animation-FX comedy that is going to be hard work if you are not familar, as generations of Americans evidently are, with the US cartoon adventures of Rocky the squirrel and Bullwinkle the moose. The movie version is produced by Robert De Niro's Tribeca company with De Niro himself playing the villainous Fearless Leader, squandering the capital of his reputation by sending up the "You talking to me?" routine from Taxi Driver. Like the recent movie of Inspector Gadget, this tries too hard to replicate the wackiness of cartoon in live action form, resulting in what can only be described as entertainment for those with eroded attention spans. Very wearing.

fields.headline: Benjamin Smoke
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The jury is presumably still out on the question of his musical importance, but in this movie Benjamin is witty, engaging and utterly lacking in self-pity.
fields.body:
A documentary that was a labour of love for directors Jem Cohen and Peter Sillen about Robert Dickerson, alias Benjamin, a cult singer-songwriter-drag-queen from Cabbagetown, Georgia, known chiefly to cognoscenti such as Patti Smith and Michael Stipe. Benjamin's melancholy fate has been, two years after his death from Aids, to reach a wide audience only posthumously, with this movie. From the interviews that Cohen has got, Benjamin emerges as a likable, bohemian figure. The jury is presumably still out on the question of his musical importance, but in this movie Benjamin is witty, engaging and utterly lacking in self-pity, and his cosmopolitan charm is remarkable, marooned as it is in the dilapidated wastelands of the deep south.

fields.headline: Remember the Titans
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: This is a Walt Disney film produced by Jerry Bruckheimer, so no one could possibly expect complexity or subtlety.
fields.body: Here is an earnest, bombastic, feelgood movie in which the issue of racial harmony is treated as roughly being equal in importance to the holy game of football, about which in American cinema there must be no agnosticism of any kind. This is a Walt Disney film produced by Jerry Bruckheimer, so no one could possibly expect complexity or subtlety. Denzel Washington is the tough, mean, yet visionary coach of a high school team in 1971 in Virginia, masterminding their first season as a (notionally) integrated unit, ordering them to get along - for the good of the team. Many are the worthy, dull, liberal platitudes, but the film is partly redeemed by Washington's dignity and presence.

fields.headline: Almost Famous
fields.standfirst: It's got the music - but what's happened to the sex and drugs in Cameron Crowe's 1970s rock tribute, asks Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: When a blast of real Jimi Hendrix comes on the soundtrack, it's like a slug of Jack Daniel's after drinking diluted Sunny Delight.
fields.body:
Garlanded with Golden Globes, Bafta nominations and Oscar rumours, this is the most over-rated cinema event of the year: a bafflingly heavy-handed coming-of-age nostalgia-fest about the early 1970s rock scene, apparently based on director Cameron Crowe's own teenage adventures in rock journalism. It systematically pulls the teeth from rock music, detaching from it all sense of danger, excitement and hedonism, making it instead a soundtrack for Crowe's heart-warming, mind-numbing morality tale about family values.

Patrick Fugit plays William, a cute 15-year-old who flukes his way into going on the road with an up-and-coming rock band called Stillwater, and writing about it for Rolling Stone. He's given big-brotherish support and advice from journalist Lester Bangs (Philip Seymour Hoffman) but his querulous, protective mom Frances McDormand is having kittens about the whole business.

Spinal Tap set the bar very, very high for the level of humour and affectionate connoisseurship required for something like this and, in fact, Almost Famous often looks like Spinal Tap minus the gags and indeed the insight. (A scene in which the manager shows the band the new T-shirt design is practically a replica of Tap's notorious Smell the Glove album-cover argument.)

When Patrick tries to blag his way backstage, earnestly announcing himself as a "journalist", he gets a homily from Stillwater's lead guitarist Russell, played by Billy Crudup in the hairy, sloppy early-1970s mode he deployed for playing runner Steve Prefontaine in Without Limits. "We play for the fans, not the critics," he says. But Patrick shows Russell he knows all about the music, so they let him in. It is a basically a cumbersome, solemn version of Wayne and Garth throwing themselves at the feet of Alice Cooper and chanting: "We are not worthy." And Wayne's World seems oddly more sincere, and more knowledgeable, than Cameron Crowe's world. Here, and throughout, the vital element of wit is missing. But lots of other things are missing too.

Sex, for example. We all know about the crazed egotists of rock: the wildmen and Aleister Crowley enthusiasts with their retinues of jailbait groupies - the legions of wealthy men for whom feminism was still just a rumour. Almost Famous primly distinguishes between the exploited women and a higher class of girl called a "band aid" - more like a sweetly pretty and largely platonic muse on the tour bus - personified by the kooky yet gorgeous Penny Lane, played by the fantastically irritating Kate Hudson, who is perpetually laughing with transcendentally blonde flower-child wisdom. (Wouldn't Liv Tyler have been more piquant casting?) A group of older band-aids skittishly deflower innocent cherubic Patrick: a very cute reversal of the usual male- female roles in "deflowering" situations on the road.

So, please, who on earth does Crowe think he's kidding? Maybe the coy "band aid" stuff was what some rock star or rock chick told him when he was a naive teenager; maybe they believed it and maybe he believed them - at the time. But now?

Then there are drugs. There's no nasty jacking up - but Russell has an "acid trip": perhaps the safest, cleanest, most U-certificate Yellow Submarine acid trip in history. It causes him to be a bit feisty at a teenagers' party, jumping off the roof into a swimming pool, fully clothed. No Brian Jones-style dénouement , and afterwards he's as right as rain. The only overdose situation comes deliberately, when poor vulnerable and unhappy Penny Lane gets into a near-thing - with quaaludes, famously the pharmaceutical of choice for the Carpenter siblings.

Finally, of course, there's rock'n'roll itself, and Crowe's biggest crime is to make this sound so comfy and dull. The big problem is that we have to sit through a lot of Stillwater's imaginary numbers: and very vapid they are too. When a blast of real Jimi Hendrix comes on the soundtrack, it's like a slug of Jack Daniel's after drinking diluted Sunny Delight.

Inevitably, Patrick finally has to go home to mom, and there's a soupy "home's best" moral implied. Well, it's supposed to be a love letter to the period, and Crowe has made no bones about using a rose-tinted lens. But did he have to be so wilfully naive? And what's the point of sentimentally excising the dark side of rock when it's precisely the filth and sleaze that many of his target audience will be perversely sentimental about?

If this solemn and disconcertingly reactionary film gets Academy awards it will be very depressing, though perhaps a prize is due for Philip Seymour Hoffman: droll, raddled, winningly concerned for his young protege. He gets the film's one genuine laugh, dancing to Iggy Pop and doing a very wacky windmill movement with his arms. In the movie, Bangs is always warning that the dullards and the idiots would ruin rock. But the film itself is the warning.

fields.headline: Faithless
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Beautifully composed and passionately performed to a high level of art and technique. This is an unanswerably powerful film - a film for intelligent grown-ups.
fields.body:
Faithless is the kind of high arthouse movie that has not been in vogue for many a long year - a movie which appears to come from before the era of irony and dumbing down, a movie indifferent to demotic influences, and drawing intelligently on the aesthetics of music and the stage. Beautifully composed and passionately performed to a high level of art and technique, it is directed by Liv Ullmann from a script by Ingmar Bergman, which in turn is taken from aspects of the master's own life - in which Ullmann has played her own legendary part. And indeed the inter-relationship of art and life, fiction and fact, is at the fulcrum of this fascinating ensemble piece about the minuet of the deceiver and the deceived, among the cultured and elegant European classes, living lives which are outwardly furnished with serene ascetic taste, but inwardly writhing in extravagant agony.

We begin with a writer living on an island, named, candidly enough, Bergman (played by Bergman veteran Erland Josephson), his face incised with age and anguish. In one corner of the room, there is a film projector, and a desk where the screen should be. The story he is incubating and its dramatis personae take shape before us, and then we enter the life of the marionettes. Marianne, played by the outstanding Lena Endre, is married to Markus (Thomas Hanzon) but embarks on an affair in Paris with David, played by Krister Henriksson. Anguish and jealousy ensue, and the chief sufferer is Marianne's infant daughter, who is subjected to unbearable cruelty.

It is the kind of film in which the leading lady can say lines like: "Markus said sex with me was better than conducting the Rite of Spring," without the smirk of bathos that would come in another sort of movie. Even preposterously comic scenes, such as David's rehearsal of his calamitous avant-garde "anti-play", are coloured by the perfect sobriety which Ullmann and Bergman bring to this material.

With absolute faith in its own seriousness and that of its audience, Faithless addresses the life of the mind, and the erotic life, with equal conviction - and searches the wound of existence unflinchingly. This is an unanswerably powerful film - a film for intelligent grown-ups.

fields.headline: Dude, Where's My Car?
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: The big set-pieces are ripped off from the Farrellys and Abbott and Costello, and yet there are some decent gags.
fields.body:
The title is, in its insouciant way, inspired. Like Honey, I Shrunk the Kids it tells you the plot, the tone, the genre . . . everything. Written by Philip Stark and co-starring Ashton Kutcher - both from the very bright Fox sitcom That 70s Show - this is the tale of two stoner dudes played by Kutcher and Seann William Scott who wake up after a bitchin' party to find that their car is . . . kind of like gone? And they have to like find it? Because otherwise their girlfriends will be really like pissed at them? Our heroes then retrace their steps and the resulting misadventures involve, as good fortune would have it, encounters with babes in bikinis.

It's very broad and nowhere near the quality of teen hits like Clueless or Ten Things I Hate About You, but I have to admit it: I giggled a number of times. The big set-pieces are ripped off from the Farrellys and Abbott and Costello, and yet there are some decent gags. In the end, however, the relentless crassness pushes it just the wrong side of charmless and eventually you kind of wish the dudes would find their car, and kind of, like, totally, y'know, like drive off in it?

fields.headline: Don
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: I found Don a little opaque, but its severity and seriousness are impressive, as is Jalili's powerful social concern with poverty.
fields.body:
My first experience of the Iranian director Abolfazl Jalili was his segment of the portmanteau-movie Tales From Kish, shown at Cannes two years ago, co-directed by Jalili, Mohsen Makhmalbaf and Naser Taghvai - cinematic short stories of wonderful Lewis Carroll charm and surreal whimsy. Tales From Kish is well overdue for UK distribution, but pending that, here is Jalili's full-length feature, Don, from 1998.

Don is about the plight of the orphaned and dispossessed children of modern Iran - the stateless offspring of the 1980-88 war's traumatised generation - resorting to all sorts of scams and subterfuge to get the identity papers they need to work: epitomised by one boy, the son of a helpless drug addict. This uses non-professionals and employs neo-realist devices familiar from Kiarostami. Its focus on children is also distinctive: it dramatises the adult issues of a younger Iran questioning its identity. I have to say I found Don a little opaque, but its severity and seriousness are impressive, as is Jalili's powerful social concern with poverty.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: X-Men | Gone in 60 Seconds | My Dog Skip
fields.trailText: X-Men | Gone in 60 Seconds | My Dog Skip
fields.body:
X-Men
Rental Fox Pathé Cert 12 ***

Your response to X-Men will probably depend on whether your childhood comic reading came from DC Comics (Batman and Superman) or, like me, DC Thomson (Dennis the Menace and Little Plum). X-Men comes from DC's rival Marvel, whose best-known screen transfer to date was Howard the Duck. They have better luck this time with Bryan "Usual Suspects" Singer's good-looking and impeccably PC superheroes film. But the film has a problem packing in so many superheroes with ludicrous Gladiators-style names and, like chess pieces, different special functions. One plot strand has a senator planning a mutant registration scheme, whose historical precedent is made clear with the film's gritty start in a 1945 concentration camp. With Patrick Stewart and Ian McKellen as prime monsters (good and bad), this is a very Old Vic kind of superhero showdown. It has some striking scenes and ideas but doesn't amount to a lot and leaves many questions to the inevitable sequels (like why "X-Men" when some of them, like Halle Berry in a Rick Wakeman fright wig, are women, and what put Stewart in the wheelchair?). A DVD follows on March 12.

Gone in 60 Seconds
Rental and DVD rental Buena Vista Cert 15 ***

Much-maligned, maybe, but this is a Bruckheimer production with all that that implies: it's paced with no speed bumps, rubber is burned, explosions explode, it's hard, fast and slickly efficient like the cars our hero Nicolas Cage is nicking to save his brother's life from snarling Christopher Eccleston. Having a Brit as the villain is typical of the lack of originality, casting Angelina Jolie as a long-retired car thief is typical of its contempt for logic. But I'd rather watch Cage ripping off cars than doing that moping, concerned look he had throughout City of Angels (it recurs here in a brotherly lurve subtext) and - with Enemy of the State as one big exception - this is better than a lot of other Bruckheimers on offer in the showroom.

My Dog Skip
Rental Warner Cert U ***

Frankie Muniz is the shy, bullied, nine-year-old in Yazoo, Mississippi in 1942. Then he gets a dog. This is nostalgic and sentimental by definition but, being without a nine-year-old to hand, I think I would have loved it at that age. It's closer to Stand By Me than Beethoven and very well acted, not least by Muniz, Kevin Bacon, as his dad, and star terrier Moose, taking some time off from playing Frasier's Eddie. But rent carefully - this could produce more determined infant pooch dreams than 102 Dalmatians.

webTitle: Leeds fail in Sydney with their own Olympic bid

fields.headline: Leeds fail in Sydney with their own Olympic bid
fields.trailText: Leeds United have had a £2m bid to buy a 51% stake in Sydney Olympic rejected by the Australian National Soccer League club.
fields.body:
Leeds United have had a £2m bid to buy a 51% stake in Sydney Olympic rejected by the Australian National Soccer League club.

Olympic, currently second in the league, were one of five Australian clubs approached by the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale as his club attempt to forge links there. While they have not ruled out a 50-50 alliance with the Yorkshire club, Olympic's owners do not want to give up their majority stake.

Ridsdale, who had been working with Mark Viduka's agent Bernie Mandic on the deal, hopes to develop youth academies in Australia and sign promising youngsters to join their compatriots Harry Kewell and Viduka at Elland Road, generating merchandising opportunities in return.

Hull City's administrators are confident tomorrow's home game with Leyton Orient will go on at Boothferry Park after talks with the stadium's owner David Lloyd, who on Tuesday had the ground closed.

webTitle: Kohl pays fine to avoid trial

fields.headline: Kohl pays fine to avoid trial
fields.standfirst: Special report: the German corruption scandal
fields.trailText: Helmut Kohl, Germany's longest-serving chancellor and the architect of its reunification, last night agreed to pay a £100,000 fine rather than stand trial for accepting illegal party donations.  His decision looked certain to hasten the end of a scandal that once threatened to shake Germany's democracy to its foundations.
fields.body:
Helmut Kohl, Germany's longest-serving chancellor and the architect of its reunification, last night agreed to pay a £100,000 fine rather than stand trial for accepting illegal party donations. His decision looked certain to hasten the end of a scandal that once threatened to shake Germany's democracy to its foundations.

Justice ministry officials in Dsseldorf had earlier given their blessing to a deal negotiated between Mr Kohl's lawyers and prosecutors who have been investigating him for the past 13 months.

Under the terms of the agreement, which has yet to be approved by a court in the former federal capital of Bonn, the prosecutors would shelve their inquiry in return for payment of the fine. According to a statement from his lawyers, Mr Kohl said last October he would agree to the fine "to avoid a lengthy legal process that would be a great burden to him and his family".

The fine is a stiff one, but the former chancellor has considerable financial resources. Last year he contributed DM700,000 to pay separate fines imposed on his party. The chancellor had earlier admitted breaking the law on party funding, but refused to provide crucial information to investigators.

Yesterday's deal was the latest of several indications that Mr Kohl has reached an understanding with the governing Social Democrats to end more than a year of scandal and tension.

Members of his own party, the Christian Democrat Union (CDU), yesterday claimed that the affair had been blown out of proportion. Prosecutors in Bonn have been considering whether to bring charges against Mr Kohl since January last year, after he admitted hiding the source of campaign donations while chancellor from 1982 to 1998. Following his confession, it emerged that millions of pounds had been secretly accepted by his party in the 25 years that he was its leader.

Under the terms of a law introduced by Mr Kohl's government, substantial donors in Germany must be identified to prevent parties swapping favours for cash if elected. However, Mr Kohl has refused to disclose the identity of the CDU's benefactors, saying that he had given them his word of honour not to do so.

Professor Hans Herbert of the School for Administrative Studies in Speyer said: "Kohl's concealment of the names of his donors is a continuing violation of the party [funding] law and even of the constitution. I cannot understand the decision of the Bonn prosecution service."

The affair began after it emerged that CDU officials had accepted a case stuffed with notes from a businessman. Karl-Heinz Schreiber was the intermediary in an arms deal that had been approved by Mr Kohl's government. A parliamentary inquiry was set up but last month its Social Democrat chairman said it had uncovered no evidence. Mr Kohl has refused to answer many of the inquiry's questions on the grounds that the answers could have an impact on the criminal investigation.

Almost every indication suggests the affair is passing into history with the active co-operation of Gerhard Schrder's centre-left government. Earlier this week, it ignored pleas from the parliamentary inquiry and deported to France one of the few men who could shed light on claims that the CDU accepted a huge kickback from the French oil company Elf Aquitaine.

webTitle: Airport official ensures scandal takes off

fields.headline: Airport official ensures scandal takes off
fields.standfirst: A Brazilian's passport raises questions that have rocked the European game
fields.trailText: Whether the customs officer at Warsaw airport was tipped off or just sensed something dodgy, it was he who started it all, just before his lunch break. Peering at a passport, he asked a question: "Where does Dos Santos play?"
fields.byline: Rory Carroll in Rome and Vivek Chaudhary
fields.body:
Whether the customs officer at Warsaw airport was tipped off or just sensed something dodgy, it was he who started it all, just before his lunch break. Peering at a passport, he asked a question: "Where does Dos Santos play?"

A nervous ripple passed through the Udinese squad. Silva dos Santos Warley is Brazilian but he played in Italy. A team-mate piped up: "in attack".

The officer smiled but did not return the document. He typed into his computer and the fuse was lit. A Uefa tie against Polonia Warszawa had earned itself a footnote in the annals of football scandals. It was 12.40pm on September 13.

Warley's passport was Portuguese, signed by a Lisbon civil guard called M Ferreira. It did not take long to discover it was fake. There was no M Ferreira.

Yesterday the consequences continued fizzing through Italy's Serie A, scorching eight clubs and 24 players in a widening investigation that could destroy careers and put people in jail for four years. Elsewhere across Europe, in Spain and France, the passport scandal has also been sending shock waves through the football world, calling into question the entire integrity of the game.

The Spanish football federation has ordered all first and second division clubs who have players born outside the EU to prove they have genuine dual nationality by 6pm today. Copies of their passports must be accompanied by a solicitor's letter confirming that the passport is genuine. Players will be asked to submit documents such as a grandparent's birth certificate to show they have family who originated in Europe.

In France two clubs have already been hit by points deductions after becoming caught up in the scandal. St Etienne, one of the country's most famous clubs, was docked six points after the Ukrainian goalkeeper Maxim Levitsky and Brazilian striker Alex were found to be using fake passports.

The national champions Monaco were docked two points, subsequently withdrawn on appeal, by the French football federation for lack of vigilance over spurious papers used by the Chilean international Pablo Contreras to enter the country.

The involvement of such leading names from French football highlighted the endemic nature of the passport problem. Indeed, given the pressures of modern-day football and the desperation of bigger clubs to succeed, it is no surprise that they are the ones who have become most embroiled in the saga.

Italy, for example, has the most lucrative league in Europe and is considered a major collaborator in the European-wide racket to get round league limits on foreign players. Italian clubs are allowed up to five non-EU players on their books and can field up to three at any one time. Rumours of bogus documents and ancestry claims have circulated for months. Implicated along with Udinese are Milan, Bari, Internazionale, Lazio, Roma, Parma and Napoli. Other clubs are expected to be named next week.

The league is in uproar. Star players are scrambling to leave the country, managers are screaming libel and fans are panicking over possible disqualifications.

The Italian football federation's prosecutor this week recommended disciplinary action against two Udinese officials and four of its players. Warley, Valentin do Carmo Neto Alberto and Jorginho, all Brazilian, had Portuguese passports signed by M Ferreira. Alejandro da Silva, a Paraguayan, was said to have a stolen passport.

With the help of the club officials they conspired to avoid restrictions on non-European Union players, claimed the prosecutor. Jorginho, Warley and Da Silva have left Italy; Udinese issued a statement denying wrongdoing and attacking critics for undermining their stock-market launch.

Pierpaolo Marino, the club's director-general, was incandescent. "This is summary justice. I have never had anything to do with passports, I have never had to deal with prosecutors, I have never been interrogated by anyone." The Italian media have excoriated the ruling body for dragging its feet compared to its English, French and Spanish counterparts.

The biggest fish so far is Inter's Uruguayan midfielder Alvaro Recoba. Fresh from signing a five-year package that would make him one of history's highest-paid footballers, he was indicted last week and could be jailed for four years.

Police allegedly found a "very mediocre counterfeit" Italian passport in his Milan home, obtained with false claims of Italian ancestry, said Gazzetta dello Sport. Recoba left Uruguay's Nacional to join Inter in 1997 with a Uruguayan passport and was called South American by Inter fan sites. The club's large stable of non-EU players restricted his appearances but in September 1999 he gained an Italian passport.

Recoba, nicknamed El Chino for his oriental features, reportedly told prosecutors he thought the document was legitimate as it was obtained with the help of Inter's director, Gabriele Oriali, who has also been indicted. The club said it had nothing to do with the investigation and had "total confidence in the good faith of the player".

Lazio, already reeling from fans' violence and racism, risks becoming the highest profile casualty. Its Argentine midfielder, Juan Sebastian Veron, is due in court on February 16, charged with inventing an Italian grandmother.

He was an architect of last year's Italian title triumph and his case, implicating the club president Sergio Cragnotti, has triggered demands to strip Lazio of their title.

webTitle: Madeleine Bunting on Sex and the City

fields.headline: Loadsasex and shopping: a woman's lot
fields.standfirst:
Sex and the City is a huge success but its feminism is distinctly lite

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Sex and the City is a huge success but its feminism is distinctly lite.
fields.body:
Depending on your point of view, Sex and the City is either about the abject failure of feminism or a witty commentary on the predicament of single, thirtysomething women. Carrie, Miranda, Samantha and Charlotte shag and shop their way around New York. Now, with a weekly double bill, it seems viewers can't get enough.

The extraordinary success of the show - it is clocking up audiences not far short of those for the long-running hit ER - has everyone scratching their heads. What does this television phenomenon say about where women are at? And how did a show targeted at a niche audience become such a hit that even the defeated Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, could joke this week that he was planning to catch up on all the episodes of Sex and the City that he'd missed?

The most important ingredient is loadsasex. This is the show which sent shockwaves through the prim US television world as the most sexually explicit programme ever. But don't be confused, the nudity is discreet, sex scenes rare and shots are coy (postcoital women always have sheets pulled over their breasts). The emphasis is not on the action, but on talking about it and here, it really does get radical. The four discuss every kind of sex - masturbation, dildos, telephone sex and blow jobs - comparing experiences, offering advice and encouragement. Nothing is out of bounds, sex is an adventure playground which doesn't necessarily have much to do with love.

This kind of treatment probably has a lot to do with the gay scriptwriters playing on male fantasies of female availability and voracious appetite. But the sex stuff works because it turns on its head the age-old female sexual victimhood. The whole rationale of Sex and the City is that these women want pleasure, know how to get it and are determined to do so. And the kick is in the assumption that the women are always great in bed, the men more variable. Patriarchy's Great Stud Myth is toppled as these women analyse and judge men's performance; they spare no quarter, ruthlessly trampling over men's sexual insecurities by comparing and contrasting their lovers. It's brash bravura - and highly entertaining.

The second ingredient is to wrap up the sex in an idealised world. This is pure escapism - the sort which has intelligent women glued to Hello and OK! magazines, a voyeuristic appetite to glimpse the perfect lives of other people. It's part of the way many women often measure up their lives: once, they would have twitched the net curtains, now they read about Tom and Nicole's marriage breakdown or follow the shenanigans of Carrie and Big.

In this perfect world, there is little evidence of work, and even less of stress and exhaustion. The women invariably look stunning in a huge range of dressy clothes, have perfect figures and high-maintenance hair. Keeping up those kinds of appearances (all those saunas and exercise classes) should be a near full-time task. The large wardrobes are complemented by stylish apartments in stylish neighbourhoods and eating in stylish restaurants. There is a leisurely ease in their lives, and what's airbrushed out is that element of squalor, filth, and irritation (no cabs and traffic gridlock) which is an inescapable part of most city-living. New York is transformed from the city with more rats than human beings to a glamorous metropolis of beautiful people.

In this perfect urban world, the women have a perfect female camaraderie. Their friendship has replaced families and men as the most durable, unconditional relationship: it's really a manifesto for lesbian separatism. What's omitted is the competitiveness and rivalry which, more or less submerged, runs through a lot of female friendship; for example, how come these sexually voracious women never go after each other's men? But there's enough truth in it to give a glimpse of the wonderfully refreshing intimacies of single, childless, female-only company - scurrilously scathing of male pretension and hysterically funny.

What this all adds up to is feminism lite - which is about as much feminism as the mainstream wants right now. Carrie may use her oven as a storage cupboard and Miranda has no use for a rolling pin, but apart from shedding domestic chores, the lives of these women still revolve entirely around men. They end up reinforcing the double standards against which they rail so wittily.

fields.bodyText: Depending on your point of view, Sex and the City is either about the abject failure of feminism or a witty commentary on the predicament of single, thirtysomething women. But don't be confused, the nudity is discreet, sex scenes rare and shots are coy (postcoital women always have sheets pulled over their breasts). The emphasis is not on the action, but on talking about it and here, it really does get radical. The four discuss every kind of sex - masturbation, dildos, telephone sex and blow jobs - comparing experiences, offering advice and encouragement. Nothing is out of bounds, sex is an adventure playground which doesn't necessarily have much to do with love. This kind of treatment probably has a lot to do with the gay scriptwriters playing on male fantasies of female availability and voracious appetite. But the sex stuff works because it turns on its head the age-old female sexual victimhood. This is pure escapism - the sort which has intelligent women glued to Hello and OK! magazines, a voyeuristic appetite to glimpse the perfect lives of other people. It's part of the way many women often measure up their lives: once, they would have twitched the net curtains, now they read about Tom and Nicole's marriage breakdown or follow the shenanigans of Carrie and Big. The women invariably look stunning in a huge range of dressy clothes, have perfect figures and high-maintenance hair. Keeping up those kinds of appearances (all those saunas and exercise classes) should be a near full-time task. The large wardrobes are complemented by stylish apartments in stylish neighbourhoods and eating in stylish restaurants. There is a leisurely ease in their lives, and what's airbrushed out is that element of squalor, filth, and irritation (no cabs and traffic gridlock) which is an inescapable part of most city-living. In the end, the only weapon these women have is their humour. fields.headline: Edwards wraps it up early as slick Spireites soar ever higher
fields.trailText: Two goals in the first fifteen minutes ended the Cheltenham challenge, as Chesterfield go sixteen points clear.
fields.body:
Chesterfield welcomed the first ever visit of Sky's cameras to Saltergate last night by extending their lead at the top of the Third Division to 16 points.

That is a cushion not even Manchester United can match and the manner in which they pulled further away from the second-placed Brighton would surely have met with approval at Old Trafford.

The Spireites effectively killed the game with two goals in the first 15 minutes and then went into cruise-control for the rest of the match a la United. But unlike United's pursuers, those chasing Chesterfield have games in hand: Brighton could all but demolish the seemingly impossible deficit to one point by winning the five games they have outstanding.

But there is nothing to beat points on the board and Nicky Law's team were so slick in seeing off Cheltenham, a club with play-off ambitions themselves, that any worries at Saltergate are more likely to be as a result of the wrong sort of headlines on the City pages.

The home side's only anxious moments came early on when Town forced two corners in the first five minutes. In fact the visitors won more than their share of corners but it did them little good once Chesterfield realised they were vulnerable to the through-ball.

There was more than a hint of offside when Town's back four was breached by Jamie Ingledow's pass in the tenth minute. Luke Beckett galloped on to it but the chance seemed lost when Cheltenham goalkeeper Steve Book forced the striker wide.

Beckett's low cross back in lacked power but an embarrassing air shot from Chris Banks left David Reeves with a simple side-foot in for his 13th goal of the season.

Marcus Ebdon was the architect of Chesterfield's second five minutes later, his through-pass finding Reeves. This time Book parried the shot but the rebound landed conveniently for Rob Edwards to pass the ball into the unguarded goal.

Thereafter Chesterfield moved back into third gear while Cheltenham huffed and puffed and continued to dominate the corner count. But Town will need rather more than supremacy at set pieces to reduce the 31-point gap that separates the two teams this morning - as indeed will all the other clubs in the division.

webTitle: Sheringham says Sugar's lack of spending made him leave Spurs

fields.headline: Sheringham says Sugar's lack of spending made him leave Spurs
fields.trailText: Teddy Sheringham told the high court yesterday that he left Tottenham in 1997 because the then chairman Sir Alan Sugar would not spend money on top players.
fields.body:
Teddy Sheringham told the high court yesterday that he left Tottenham in 1997 because the then chairman Sir Alan Sugar would not spend money on top players.

The England striker was giving evidence for the Daily Mail which is defending a libel action by Sugar over a claim that he was "miserly" in his stewardship of Spurs.

Associated Newspapers and the sports journalist Jeff Powell deny that the December 1999 article was libellous and plead fair comment.

Sheringham, who moved from Spurs to Manchester United for £3.5m in June 1997, said that when he mentioned the possibility of buying the midfielder Paul Ince, Sugar said he would not pay up to £7m for a 29-year-old and then pay him between £25,000- £30,000 a week.

"My reaction was one of thinking 'Well that's what the top clubs are paying and that's what it takes to keep top players at your club'. All I'd heard over the five years at Tottenham was that he [Sugar] would get it right. I was very disappointed with the situation and things never changed. I wanted the top players to come to Tottenham rather than me going somewhere else to play with them."

Earlier, the 53-year-old Sugar had given evidence that Sheringham's statement that Spurs were not ambitious enough was the sort of "excuse" that footballers often gave when they left a club. He said the real reason Sheringham asked for a transfer was that Spurs would not give him a five-year contract.

Sugar said that after Sheringham left, the club paid £6m for Les Ferdinand. They had also spent £1m a year on their youth academy and £25m on the redevelopment of White Hart Lane. Sugar, who, when the case opened yesterday had left the court in tears, broke down again as he described his reaction to the article. "I just felt total frustration that someone can write something like this which is so far from the truth." The hearing was adjourned until today.

Joe Kinnear yesterday became Luton's fourth manager since the end of last season when the club's new director of football announced that Lil Fuccillo would be standing down to leave him in full control of first-team affairs.

"I'm the manager, full stop," said Kinnear, who has signed a 3º-year contract. "I'm in charge of anything to do with football. Lil's role at the moment is helping me out, as everybody else is at the club. Lil will hopefully be helping out as far as the decisions go. As far as my knowledge is concerned Lil's reaction was OK." Fuccillo, though, only discovered that he had been displaced after seeing a report on television yesterday.

It is Kinnear's first managerial appointment since a heart attack forced him out of Wimbledon in 1999. He had been director of football at Oxford United, the only club below Luton in the Second Division, for four months but left them 10 days ago.

Fuccillo, a Luton player for eight years until 1983, rejoined the club as chief scout on September 29. Twenty days later he became assistant manager to Ricky Hill and four weeks after that took over as first-team coach after Hill's sacking. Hill had only replaced Lennie Lawrence last July.

webTitle: Shambles as Vieira banned for only one match

fields.headline: Shambles as Vieira banned for only one match
fields.trailText: The Football Association's hardline disciplinary code was reduced to a shambles yesterday when Patrick Vieira escaped with a one-match ban for kicking Leeds' Olivier Dacourt in the throat.
fields.body:
The Football Association's hardline disciplinary code was reduced to a shambles yesterday when Patrick Vieira escaped with a one-match ban for kicking Leeds' Olivier Dacourt in the throat.

Having been found guilty of violent conduct by an FA disciplinary commission, the Arsenal midfielder should have received at least a three-game suspension under the guidelines drawn up by the FA's chief executive Adam Crozier before the start of the season.

Instead the Frenchman will miss only Arsenal's home match with Ipswich tomorrow and pay a £10,000 fine. He was cleared of a second misconduct charge, of allegedly butting Eirik Bakke in the same game at Elland Road in November.

Vieira left Soho Square without commenting but looked satisfied. Crozier and the FA's chairman Geoff Thompson are thought to be less pleased with the three-man commission's failure to apply the mandatory penalty and are expected to make their feelings clear within the FA as they they attempt to get the disciplinary procedure back on track.

The tough guidelines form a major part of Crozier's work and he has seen them repeatedly undermined. This week Leicester's Matt Elliott and Southampton's Hassan Kachloul had violent conduct charges reduced to improper conduct and were given a £5,000 fine and a one-match ban respectively.

The problems Crozier faces may stem from political infighting at Soho Square. The disciplinary commissions are generally made up of councillors from the counties, many of whom feel marginalised by the new regime.

The counties' power was hit by restructuring overseen by Crozier which saw the disbandment of the 92-member council.

The Vieira case was the latest example of a commission failing to uphold fully the recommendations of the video panel set up by Crozier this season to examine incidents missed by referees.

Only in punishing Stan Collymore for stamping on Paul Gascoigne has a panel met the guidelines' stipulation that violent conduct is worthy of a three-game ban, as agreed with the League Managers' Association, players' union (PFA), Premier League and Football League.

Yesterday's panel noted Vieira's improved disciplinary record; he has been booked only once since his early-season five-game ban. Yet the guidelines clearly state that in cases recommended by the video panel penalties should be at least equivalent to those which would have been handed out by the referee.

fields.headline: Newcastle plan deal down under
fields.trailText: In the wake of Manchester United's deal with the New York Yankees, Newcastle United have re-opened negotiations to buy the Australian club Carlton.
fields.body:
In the wake of Manchester United's deal with the New York Yankees, Newcastle United have re-opened negotiations to buy the Australian club Carlton.

The United chairman Freddie Shepherd visited the Melbourne club before Christmas and, while talks stalled, he confirmed yesterday: "We are talking to them again. We have not been sitting back and have things in the pipeline all over the world. Hopefully we can pull off some deals which will be of massive benefit for Newcastle."

The Geordies hope to tour Singapore and Japan at the end of the season in a bid to tap into the Far Eastern market, while they are discussing a possible link-up with the American businessman Lamar Hunt, owner of the MLS side Columbus Crew and the Kansas Chiefs baseball team.

"Lamar Hunt is one of the biggest sports entrepreneurs in the States and we are looking at ways in which we can help eachother," added Shepherd, who met Hunt at United's pre-season friendly with Columbus Crew in Ohio last July.

Newcastle's transfer-listed centre-half Alain Goma, currently nursing a broken hand, has been recalled to the French squad for the friendly against Germany on 27 February.

webTitle: Exit Bates, blaming Hoey and Pontius Pilates

fields.headline: Exit Bates, blaming Hoey and Pontius Pilates
fields.trailText: Ken Bates yesterday demonstrated his own peculiar brand of diplomacy and accountability by resigning from the Wembley stadium project and blaming everybody but himself for the way it has been handled.
fields.body:
Ken Bates yesterday demonstrated his own peculiar brand of diplomacy and accountability by resigning from the Wembley stadium project and blaming everybody but himself for the way it has been handled.

In an astonishing diatribe Bates claimed in a letter to the Football Association chief executive Adam Crozier that he was resigning because he did not "trust or respect" a number of people working on the project.

Bates, who was criticised for his handling of the Wembley project, described Sir David Hill-Wood, vice-chairman of Wembley National Stadium Limited, as "my Brutus".

The Chelsea chairman referred to the sports minister Kate Hoey and "her lackeys", claiming that they were working against him along with officials from the FA.

Bates also claimed that the peformance of Chase Manhattan bank, which is attempting to raise finance for the project, was abject and criticised Sir Rodney Walker, who was appointed as his replacement as WNSL chairman in December, for failing to meet him.

Bates wrote: "It is quite disgraceful that not one single person on either [FA or WNSL] board stood up publicly to defend the project. Even Jesus Christ only had one Pontius Pilate; I had a whole team of them."

Bates also alleged that "leaks and spin doctoring appear to have become a way of life within the FA" and that was the reason why he released his letter to the press.

The brunt of Bates' attack was reserved for Hoey and other officials within the FA who he claims orchestrated a campaign to remove him from the £660m project.

Bates wrote that he was the victim of a "sustained press campaign to undermine the project itself and my own credibility". He added: "We know a considerable part of it came from Kate Hoey and her lackeys. But it is also clear that a lot came from within the Football Association itself."

The Wembley project ran into serious difficulties during Bates' leadership. There have been problems raising finance from City institutions and privately many of those involved in the construction of a new stadium have claimed that Bates alienated bankers and others involved in the venture.

Walker was appointed after pressure from Hoey and FA officials who claimed that the project would have completely failed unless Bates was replaced. There were criticisms over the cost and the fact that the new stadium would have an expensive hotel and office space.

The Chelsea chairman was virtually ostracised from involvement in the project following his removal as chairman and few within the FA or WNSL were surprised at his resignation yesterday although there was shock at the nature of his outburst.

Hoey would not respond to the criticism yesterday. She said: "I have no intention of responding to Mr Bates' personal attacks except to wish him well in his other business interests. "I am sure that the whole Wembley board will now unite to make a success of this important project."

Bates wrote in his letter that after being appointed chairman of WNSL in 1997 he did his best to make the project succeed and got involved in the first place only because "the FA had got itself into a mess with low-level staff conducting negotiations for the new Wembley stadium". Bates added: "I acquired Wembley for the FA and made a substantial operating profit . . . despite having inherited a lacklustre, leaderless management."

The FA yesterday declined to respond in detail to Bates's letter. An FA statement said: "The Football Association received Ken Bates' letter of resignation from the board of WNSL with disappointment. We would like to thank him for his hard work over the past four years. "While today's letter contains some inaccuracies, they in no way detract from the contribution he has made.

"As stated last week, both the Wembley and FA boards are united and unanimous in agreeing the way forward. The new Wembley will be built and we will have a stadium to be proud of."

webTitle: Leader: on the cut in interest rates

fields.headline: Ruling out recession
fields.standfirst:
The Bank has taken the sensible course

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The Bank of England was absolutely right to lower interest rates by 0.25% to 5.75%, yesterday, a move that will lower mortgage interest charges across the board and reduce the cost of borrowing to industry.
fields.body:
The Bank of England was absolutely right to lower interest rates by 0.25% to 5.75%, yesterday, a move that will lower mortgage interest charges across the board and reduce the cost of borrowing to industry. Even though Britain is not - yet - displaying the symptoms of a sharp, US-style economic slowdown, there is no point in taking risks. The prospect of recession in the biggest economy in the world is bound to have some impact on the rest of it and it is prudent for Europe, including the UK, to take proactive steps to stimulate its own economy just in case.

Yesterday's drop in rates was timely in other respects. Coming so soon after Tony Blair's promise to decide about the euro referendum in the first two years of the next parliament, it may help to keep the pound at the lower level needed for entry while also helping to meet another of Gordon Brown's five criteria for entry, economic convergence.

Bank base rates for prime customers in the UK are now only about 1.2% higher than in Europe. Longer term interest rates have already converged. Inflation is not a problem for the foreseeable future, since the underlying rate (2.0%) is already well under the target of 2.5% and could be even further below it later this year if inflation carries on falling as is likely. Sensibly, the Bank's monetary policy committee decided to drop rates now rather than next month when it might have been interpreted as an endorsement of Gordon Brown's coming budget.

fields.headline: Part-timers win backdated pensions fight
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of part-time workers yesterday won pension rights dating back to 1976, in a House of Lords ruling which will cost public and private sector employers billions of pounds. But many who could have claimed the rights will lose out because they failed to lodge claims for back-dated pensions within six months of leaving employment.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of part-time workers yesterday won pension rights dating back to 1976, in a House of Lords ruling which will cost public and private sector employers billions of pounds. But many who could have claimed the rights will lose out because they failed to lodge claims for back-dated pensions within six months of leaving employment.

The victory marks the end of a long legal battle by six unions, backed by the TUC, to win part-timers the same rights to an occupational pension as full-time workers.

The TUC estimates that around 40,000 workers will be entitled to back-dated rights under the ruling, while a further 20,000 will be barred by the time limit. Estimates of the possible cost to employers range from £10bn to £17bn.

Digby Jones, director-general of the Confederation of British Industry, said: "It would be hard to put an exact figure on the cost but it will clearly be substantial and could affect investment and growth.

"As well as the cost, many businesses will be worried that this could be an administrative nightmare because in many cases the records will simply no longer exist."

Employers hardest hit by the ruling include banks, the NHS, and local education authorities, which all employ large numbers of part-time workers.

Unions won a ruling from the European court of justice in 1994 that excluding part-timers from pension schemes breached European law on equal pay.

Employers were forced to admit part-timers to schemes, but they argued that rights should be backdated only two years, in line with UK equal pay rules. The unions argued that employers should have to pay contributions back to 1976, the date European law first required equality in pensions.

The law lords yesterday upheld the union's argument on backdating, but decided against them on the time limits for lodging claims. The unions had sought a six-year limit, but the law lords ruled that only those who had filed claims within six months of leaving their jobs could qualify. The TUC's general secretary, John Monks, said: "This is good news for thousands of retired workers, mainly women, who will now be able to receive the pension they have been denied. Justice has been won for the women who until today faced a very bleak retirement.

"Now they can look forward to old age, safe in the knowledge that they will be more financially secure. But the TUC is very disappointed that the Lords failed to listen to the union case for extending the current cut-off for making pension claims.

"Many women who logged pension claims against their employers more than six months after leaving work will now get nothing."

The law lords ruled claims could be made up to six months after the end of a "stable employment relationship", which could include a succession of regular short-term contracts. Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said the interpretation of this rule might still prevent some teachers getting a fair pension.

"Instead of fighting against these employees' claims, the government should now let all those teachers into the pension scheme and give them appropriate pension entitlement for those years."

The banking union UniFI said it was confident that 95% of its claims, covering 6,000 women, against 57 employers, would now be met. Cases will go on to employment tribunals for decisions on entitlement, probably in groups. Former nurses, for example, would go in one batch and teachers in another. Lawyers said it could take years before all claims were determined.

fields.headline: Eminem
fields.standfirst: *** Manchester Arena
fields.trailText: Eminem's reputation as world's number one bad boy rapper precedes him. Amid scenes reminiscent of the Sex Pistols, his records have been banned by student unions. Prior to this opening night of his much- publicised UK visit, Manchester council and police forces placed restrictions on the show. Meanwhile, outside the venue, gay rights groups are up in arms about the singer's lyrical use of violent imagery and supposed homophobia. In front of police lines, people distribute leaflets claiming "Eminem has gone too far".
fields.body:
Eminem's reputation as world's number one bad boy rapper precedes him. Amid scenes reminiscent of the Sex Pistols, his records have been banned by student unions. Prior to this opening night of his much- publicised UK visit, Manchester council and police forces placed restrictions on the show. Meanwhile, outside the venue, gay rights groups are up in arms about the singer's lyrical use of violent imagery and supposed homophobia. In front of police lines, people distribute leaflets claiming "Eminem has gone too far".

Sympathies aside, casual bystanders could be forgiven for wondering why a pop star could provoke such fury. Over the next few weeks, Anthony Hopkins will stalk our screens as Hannibal the Cannibal. Nobody expects the actor to really eat human limbs for supper, but in pop there is an identification of the singer with the song. Eminem's music is filled with murderous, misogynous characters such as Slim Shady, but there is nothing to suggest this is any more real than Hammer Horror, or, Sir Cliff's satanic Devil Women. Eminem (real name Marshall Mathers) hails from a dysfunctional Detroit background and has a troubled personal life, but is primarily a fantasist. He is pop*s own Stephen King, producing art that's repellent but compelling. His use of words like "bitch" and "faggot" is unfortunate, but in US hip-hop these are put-downs, with less of the inflammatory ramifications they have here.

Sixteen thousand fans gave the thumbs up to a show rooted in cinematic horror. Eminem - as Slim - recreates the Texas Chainsaw Massacre (in accordance with officialdom, the saw is not plugged in) and appears in an electric chair. Much of the rest is a very standard rap show. The contentious lyrics are often inaudible. On record Eminem comes across as a genuinely anti-social nihilist, but live is a good old-fashioned crowd pleaser. Of course, few escape his cartoon rage - from his mum to the thousands of "bitches" in the audience who cheer his homicidal threats. It certainly helps that the bad boy is very cute. At one point, he gets the entire audience to shout that they're "drug addicts". Really? Noticeably, he draws the line at racism. As a white rapper who has fought hard for the respect of the rap community, his instincts for self-preservation over-rides that for shock.

And on record, Eminem is a master of complex psychological games. His detractors have not noticed that his glorious hit Stan explores unrequited male to male adoration, but here the song's eerie gravitas is undermined by raps of "England". Of the vaunted homophobia, one of Eminem's rappers wields a rubber phallus but it's more pantomime than sinister. A more dicey moment arrives when Eminem ("against my attorney's advice" - really?) mentions the weapons charges facing him in the US, but it becomes just a way of introducing his tune Criminal. Eminem is playing some dangerous games, but the bottom line is showbiz.

 Eminem plays the Docklands Arena, London E14 (020-7538 1212), tonight and tomorrow.

fields.headline: Write on
fields.standfirst: If you want to get ahead get a dictionary, says Judi James, or your bad spelling will leave you on the bottom rung of the career ladder
fields.trailText: Firm favourites: If you want to get ahead get a dictionary, says Judi James, or your bad spelling will leave you on the bottom rung of the career ladder.
fields.body:
Ever wondered why that next rung up the career ladder always seems to evade you? Have you applied for internal promotion time and time again, only to see the job you covet offered to someone with all the charisma and intellect of a sweaty sock?

Well, according to recruitment consultants Office Angels, it could be more than your breath fresheners that are letting you down. Their latest survey among employers throws up the fact that 77% of them rate literacy and attention to detail a big influence on promotional prospects. Sloppy spelling and poor grammar from staff left 20% of managers fuming, while 53% said they viewed the guilty employee as lazy and unprofessional - 35% of them wouldn't even read any further if they spotted a number of literacy errors, so you can forget that chance of a new job if you began your letter of application: "Dear Sur"

You would think grammar and spelling perfection would be easy with the help of modern technology but your spellcheck does not differentiate between the wrong choice of words, and it does not tell you where to place the apostrophes, either. Many programmes happily spew out American spellings and most will only correct use of capitals at certain, obvious spots.

Employees complain that they see mistakes in over half of all work given to them. This also means that half the work they see is correct, which amazes me more, although it has to be said that most bosses cannot spell themselves, and so may well be missing a whole raft of extra errors.

I recently attended a seminar by a top business manager who is - incidentally - an ex-teacher. There is nothing I love more than seeing ex-teachers show off a lack of basic knowledge. This woman obviously had problems with the flipchart. "It's strange the way these felt-tip pens always seem to make you spell wrong, isn't it?" she giggled as she blundered her way through massively complex words like: "assertive" and "management" without the aid of a dictionary.

So how can you learn to correct your own mistakes? Your PC will do as much as it can but you will need a paper dictionary lying nearby to double-check any words that could still be spelt wrongly. And do not be too embarrassed to ask for help if you need a second opinion with your grammar. Scan through your own work several times and read it out loud as well, if you still think there may be a problem. Hearing the words you have written may point up any hidden flaws in the layout. If you are still stumped over something, ask a colleague for his/her advice.

Emails are the biggest source of spelling mistakes, as most of us rely on speed of communication over quality of content and will quite cheerfully send it off without spell-checking first. Always correct your E-mails as thoroughly as you would a business letter. A few seconds spent considering content and spelling will do a lot to enhance your image in the company.

Miss-spelt names probably cause the greatest amount of corporate grief. Petty though it might be, we all like to see our names spelt correctly on any written communication. One manager in a leading consultancy company recently confided in me that they lose more clients through small detail errors that they do from large mistakes involving vast amounts of dosh. Evidentially it can be quite ok to recommend the wrong investment or over-charge on an account by mistake, but absolutely unforgivable to spell the client company's name wrong on the envelope or letterhead.

fields.headline: Flood of claims expected
fields.trailText: Insurers are bracing themselves for a fresh deluge of claims as more flooding hits the UK and there are growing fears that insurance premiums will rise steeply.
fields.body:
Insurers are bracing themselves for a fresh deluge of claims as more flooding hits the UK and there are growing fears that insurance premiums will rise steeply.

Those who have already had to claim once already are likely to face a hefty increase for cover. Some may find that flooding is now excluded on the new policy.

If this is the case, BIBA, the British Insurance Brokers Association, says using a broker is often better than agreeing to pay more for cover. The household market remains competitive and a broker can often find a cheaper deal.

Norwich Union, the UK's largest general insurer, says it may refuse cover to some homeowners who have been flooded before, but said this will only be as a last resort.

Flood claims have increased 15-fold over the past 40 years, and many believe this has been caused by climate change. Royal & SunAlliance announced last month its claims bill for the last three months of last year was £200 million and with more floods predicted, the worst is not over.

The army is now being drafted in to tackle the crisis in some regions, which is expected to worsen over the next few days. There are 83 flood warnings and nine severe flood warnings currently in place.

A spokesman for The Environment Agency said: "The situation in the south of England remains serious with river levels responding quickly to the heavy rain, causing widespread surface water flooding."

In the Kent town of Herne Bay, a number of homes became uninhabitable because of several feet of water at ground floor level. Many roads across Sussex are now impassable, with Lewes and Uckfield again being among the worst hit.

Last November, there was several million pounds worth of damage caused in these two towns alone by flooding. Insurers are now issuing their own warnings to try and minimise damage. Chubb, which specialises in insuring high value homes is asking policyholders not to leave items of value on the ground floor if they are in a high risk area.

BIBA has also issued the following guidance for homeowners:

&#149: Move as much as possible upstairs once a flood alert is announced
&#149 Remember that buildings may become unsafe, with doors and windows swollen
&#149 Turn off electricity and gas at the mains. Drinking water may become contaminated so wait to hear from utility companies before consuming.
&#149 Pull furniture away from walls and oil all hinges and locks to prevent them corrosion
&#149 Once the clean-up gets under way, leave windows, doors and built-in cupboards open and keep rooms heated
&#149 Drying out a building can take months so don't be in a hurry to redecorate;
&#149 Treat walls with an anti-mould solution before decorating
&#149 Keep all receipts for temporary emergency repairs if you plan to claim
&#149 Watch out for signs of 'heave' caused when the ground expands because of flooding. This can lead to serious structural problems and a surveyor should be employed if it is suspected.

Longer term the insurance industry says it wants to work closely with the government and town planners to ensure no more homes are built on flood plains. But, this poses tough challenges, as at the same time, the government has said three million more homes will be built by 2016, and new sites are in short supply.

The Association of British Insurers (ABI) has said any homes at risk of repeated flooding could become uninsurable. It estimates that 4% of Britain's housing stock, or 1.3 million homes with a combined value of £35 billion, are built on flood plains. Some insurers have been rapped for slow claims handling because of the volume of work. Axa was singled out, but says most of its policyholders were happy with the service they received.

Other insurers are emphasising they are pulling out all the stops to sort out problems. A spokeswoman for Cornhill Direct said: "In one week alone staff handled three times the number of household claims they would normally expect to receive in a month and still the claims are coming in." She added many staff had volunteered to work extra hours, stay late and work weekends.

Claims team leader, Jan Coward said: "Staff have dealt with all kinds of claims ranging from tiles off roofs to the much more serious cases of flooding and complete destruction of property."

fields.headline: Barclays launches new savings account
fields.trailText: Barclays Bank, which has just announced a big hike in its profits, has launched a new savings account that can pay a rate of interest of 5%, which while is better than some of its high street rivals, is less competitive than many others in the market.
fields.body:
Barclays Bank, which has just announced a big hike in its profits, has launched a new savings account that can pay a rate of interest of 5%, which while is better than some of its high street rivals, is less competitive than many others in the market.

This is an example of the High Street banks continuing to offer savings products that offer lower rates than those from smaller, rival banks and mutual building societies.

Egg, for example, pays 6.3 per cent for Internet savings, while Intelligent Finance (IF) from the Halifax pays 6 per cent, as does building society Norwich & Peterborough.

The new Barclays account will be available to customers from this month at all branches. Customers need to pay in a minimum of £25 into the account by standing order.

All customers need to do to open a Barclays Regular Savings Account is set up a monthly standing order for a minimum of at least £25.

The account offers savers a variable flat rate of 2.50 per cent and provided that customers make no more than one withdrawal in 12 months, the customer will receive an additional bonus of 2.50 per cent. David Craggs, director of savings at Barclays said: "Over the next 12 months we expect over 100,000 customers will open a regular savings account."

The new savings account will be available online and via the telephone later on in the year.

Despite the fact that it can be beaten elsewhere, the new Barclays account is vastly better than the offering from Lloyds TSB, that claims to give "attractive tiered rates of interest", that range from a miserly 1.05% on balances of £1 and 1.5 % for above £200.

fields.headline: UK 'breaking rules' on paid holidays
fields.trailText: Workers on short-term contracts in the UK could win the statutory right to four weeks' paid holiday every year after an announcement from the European court of justice in Luxembourg yesterday.
fields.body:
Workers on short-term contracts in the UK could win the statutory right to four weeks' paid holiday every year after an announcement from the European court of justice in Luxembourg yesterday.

In a controversial but non-binding opinion that could later become a full legal judgment, the court ruled that UK legislation on the matter was flawed and did not comply with the European Union's working time directive.

In Britain people need to work for a minimum of 13 weeks before they can begin to accrue any rights to paid leave, but the court's advocate general declared yesterday that this was unlawful and said paid annual holiday should be a right.

The opinion delighted the broadcasting and entertainment union, Bectu, which had taken the Department of Trade and Industry to court over the limited rights accorded to its 30,000 members.

Stephen Cavalier of the law firm Thompsons, which is representing Bectu, said: "By giving freelance workers and those on short-term contracts fewer rights than their full-time colleagues or those on long-term contracts, the government turned them into a second class of employee and gave employers the green light to exploit the use of these kinds of contracts in order to avoid their obligations."

The DTI said it would wait for confirmation, while the Confederation of British Industry said the decision would hit industries that employed workers seasonally, such as the hotel and catering sectors. "We are concerned that the directive is being goldplated and we are not the only country to have these concerns."
